Title: The argon cluster beam installed in the ADONE storage ring

Abstract: The argon cluster beam, with a maximum thickness of 1.5 × 1014 atoms/cm2, installed at Frascation the ADONE storage ring, is described. The cluster beam works at room temperature and is used as radiator to produce an intense tagged photon beam with energy up to 1.2 GeV. The argon bea, properties were measured using electrons stored in ADONE; the results are in good agreement with the expected values. The apparatus can produce cluster beams of higher thickness and work with different gases. It is suitable for internal target experiments with the 1.5 GeV stored electrons. © 1990.

Authors: Mollhoff T., Sukehiro S., Van Aken H., Flameng W.
Title: Long-term preservation of baboon hearts. Effects of hypothermic ischemic and cardioplegic arrest on high-energy phosphate content
Affiliations: Katholieke Universiteit, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Minderbroeders Straat 17, 3000 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Mollhoff, T., Katholieke Universiteit, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Minderbroeders Straat 17, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Sukehiro, S., Katholieke Universiteit, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Minderbroeders Straat 17, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Van Aken, H., Katholieke Universiteit, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Minderbroeders Straat 17, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Flameng, W., Katholieke Universiteit, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Minderbroeders Straat 17, 3000 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Baboon hearts were preserved ex vivo after hypothermic ischemic or cardioplegic arrest and were stored cold (0.5°C) for 24 hours. Ischemic arrest was induced on cardiopulmonary bypass after general cooling to 25°C. Cardioplegic arrest was induced using either a hyperkalemic standard cardioplegic solution National Institutes of Health ([NIH] solution) or the recently developed University of Wisconsin (UW) organ preservation solution. ATP and catabolites were assessed in serial transmural biopsies. Cardioplegia significantly delayed the breakdown of ATP during storage. After infusion of the adenosine-supplemented UW solution, myocardial content of adenosine was high as compared with that in NIH-arrested hearts (9.12 versus 0.01 μmol · g-1 dry wt). During cold storage, however, adenosine converted to inosine in spite of profound hypothermia. This renders unlikely the potential of fast resynthesis of ATP out of the supplemented nucleoside pool after reoxygenation.
Author Keywords: Cardioplegia; High-energy phosphates; Ischemia
Index Keywords: animal cell; article; cardioplegia; controlled study; energy metabolism; hypothermia; methodology; monkey; nonhuman; organ culture; priority journal; Adenosine Triphosphate; Animal; Cardioplegic Solutions; Cold; Comparative Study; Heart; Heart Arrest, Induced; Heart Transplantation; Hypothermia, Induced; Myocardium; Organ Preservation; Papio; Time Factors

Title: Chemical reactions at solid-solid interfaces induced by pulsed laser annealing
Affiliations: LISE, Institute for Studies of Interfacial Science, Facultés Universitaires N-D de la Paix, Rue de Bruxelles 61, B-5000 Namur, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Petit, E.J., LISE, Institute for Studies of Interfacial Science, Facultés Universitaires N-D de la Paix, Rue de Bruxelles 61, B-5000 Namur, Belgium; Caudano, R., LISE, Institute for Studies of Interfacial Science, Facultés Universitaires N-D de la Paix, Rue de Bruxelles 61, B-5000 Namur, Belgium
Abstract: Al thin films (thickness < 1000 Å) evaporated on the (111) face of an Sb single crystal, and Al-Sb multilayer thin films (thickness < 1000 Å) evaporated on glass and quartz substrates were irradiated in UHV by the pulsed beam of an excimer laser. The samples were characterized in-situ during the growth of the films and after the irradiations by Auger and photoelectron spectroscopies without breaking the vacuum, and later, by scanning electron microscopy. The formation of the AlSb compound is observed above the fluence threshold previously reported. Lateral transport of matter and inhomogeneous reaction are observed after irradiation of the Al films deposited on Sb crystals, leading to the formation of an inhomogeneous surface with holes and particles. A strong chemical reaction between the substrate and the films also leads to a partial oxidation of the film evaporated on quartz or glass. We observed the same behaviour under the IR laser beam from a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser. One has taken advantage of fast thermal processes of thin films induced by pulsed or scanned CW laser beams for applications like synthesis of compounds by laser alloying, oxidation of thin films, planarization, and phase changes in optical data storage media. The relevant parameters needed to predict the evolution of the film/substrate interface under strong laser irradiation using the thermal model are not only: (i) the thermal properties of the substrate, and (ii) the optical characteristics of the film-substrate system, but also (iii) the chemical stability of the interface, and (iv) the free surface energies of the substrate and of the film, at least above the melting fluence threshold or if thermal cycling is expected over large periods of time. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions--Photochemical Reactions; Intermetallics--Synthesis; Laser Pulses--Radiation Effects; Spectroscopy, Auger Electron--Applications; Spectroscopy, Photoelectron--Applications; Interfacial Photochemical Reactions; Intermetallic Compound Synthesis; Laser-Evaporated Semiconducting Films; Pulsed Laser Film Annealing; X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy; Semiconducting Films

Abstract: Very tightly-focused ion beam was obtained by 'Plasma Focus Diode' (PFD), yielding focusing diameter of ∼ 360 μm, and power density of ∼ 0.1 TW/cm2 at the beam energy of ∼ 1.5 MeV. Enhanced energy deposition was observed in the interaction with aluminium target with the enhancement ratio of ∼ 1.5. In comparison of the experimental data with 1-D hydrocode simulation, good agreement is obtained between them. © 1990 World Scientific.

Authors: Burtsev V.A., Ermolaev Y.L., Kalinln N.V.
Title: Future possible applications of different powerful pulsed generators in accelerating technology
Source title: 1990 8th International Conference on High-Power Particle Beams, BEAMS 1990
Affiliations: Efremov Scientific and Research Institute of Electrophysical Apparatus, Leningrad 189631, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Burtsev, V.A., Efremov Scientific and Research Institute of Electrophysical Apparatus, Leningrad 189631, Russian Federation; Ermolaev, Y.L., Efremov Scientific and Research Institute of Electrophysical Apparatus, Leningrad 189631, Russian Federation; Kalinln, N.V., Efremov Scientific and Research Institute of Electrophysical Apparatus, Leningrad 189631, Russian Federation
Abstract: An application package was created for numerical simulation of powerful pulsed electromagnetic energy generators of different types. These generators include those based on the capacitive energy storages in the form of Arkad'ev-Marx generators with forming lines, inductive storages with pulsed high-current multy-staged charging and switching by electroexplosive current breakers as well as magnetic cumulative generators with step-up transformers. Examples of such generators applications in the acceleration technology are considered. Conditions of their matching with high-current electron beam producing vacuum diodes were investigated numerically for obtaining maximum efficiency of energy transmission into the beam. Our calculations demonstrated the possibility of obtaining in this accelerators high-aperture electron beams having rectangular cross section and time duration of t = 1-10 microseconds, electron energies Ue = 0.5 MeV and currents of the order of tens and hundreds of kiloamps. © 1990 World Scientific.
Index Keywords: Capacitive energy storage; Current breakers; Electron energies; Energy transmission; High-aperture; High-current; High-current electron beams; Inductive storage; Magnetic cumulative generators; Maximum Efficiency; Rectangular cross-sections; Step up transformers; Time duration; Vacuum diodes; Electromagnetic waves; Electron beams

Authors: Arzhannikov A.V., Astrelin V.T., Gorbovski A.I., Koidan V.S., Lebedev S.V., Nikolaev V.S., Semyonov E.P., Smirnov A.V., Sharapov V.K., Shcheglov M.A.
Title: Design features of megavolt generators for production of microsecond E-beams with energy more than 100 kJ
Source title: 1990 8th International Conference on High-Power Particle Beams, BEAMS 1990
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Arzhannikov, A.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Astrelin, V.T., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Gorbovski, A.I., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Koidan, V.S., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Lebedev, S.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Nikolaev, V.S., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Semyonov, E.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Smirnov, A.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Sharapov, V.K., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Shcheglov, M.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: Now all these generators are in the operation: 1. The U-1 generator is being in operation since 1980 and produces REB with the following parameters: electron energy W ≃ 1.1 MeV, maximum current I ≃ 50 kA, energy content Q ≃ 140 kJ, pulse duration τ ≃ 5 - 7 μs. In the focused beam the current density is up to 6 kA/cm2 and Q ≃ 110 kJ. Over 2500 shots have been made. 2. The U-2 generator is being in operation since 1986. First it was used for the generation of the cylindrical beam with the following parameters: W ≃ 1 MeV, I ≃ 50 kA, Q ≃ 160 kJ τ ≤ 10 ≃s. In 1989 there was obtained a 5 × 140 cm ribbon beam with an energy content of about 150 kJ. The ribbon beam transport and its cross section transformation from the ribbon shape to a circulal one have been carried out at the energy 50 kJ. Over 1500 shots have been made. An increase of the energy content by adding of the additional energy storage is planning now. 3. The U-3 generator operates since 1987. There was achieved the energy content of the beam of about 180 kJ. Over 600 shots have been made. © 1990 World Scientific.
Index Keywords: Beam transport; Cylindrical beams; Design features; E-beams; Electron energies; Energy content; Focused beams; IS planning; Production of; Pulse durations; Particle beams

Title: High-voltage generators for high-power microsecond REB production
Source title: 1990 8th International Conference on High-Power Particle Beams, BEAMS 1990

Authors with affiliations: Astrelin, V.T., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation; Chikunov, V.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation; Koidan, V.S., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation; Lebedev, S.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation; Nikolaev, V.S., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation; Shcheglov, M.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation; Smirnov, A.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation; Voropaev, S.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation
Abstract: The experience of design, operation and application of the high-voltage generators for the microsecond REB production with energy content of over 100 kJ is summarized. The variants of capacity storages designed according to the LC-generator scheme and been charged by 1 MV d.c. voltage are described. © 1990 World Scientific.
Index Keywords: Energy content; High voltage generators; Particle beams

Title: Problems of modelling biophotolysis of water in molecular photocatalytic systems
Affiliations: Pisarzhevskii Institute of Physical Chemistry, Ukrainian S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Kiev, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Khmara, L.A., Pisarzhevskii Institute of Physical Chemistry, Ukrainian S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Kiev, Russian Federation
Abstract: The current state of affairs in the field of creation of molecular photocatalytic systems for the conversion and storage of solar energy modelling the process of photosynthetic decomposition of water is discussed. The structure of the organized molecular systems based on sensitized phospholipid vesicles with membrane-isolated catalysts of oxidation and reduction of water is examined. Attention is focussed on the stage of oxidation of water to molecular oxygen, i.e. modelling photosystem II. In this connexion the author considers the development of research starting with modelling of the process of oxidation of water by multi-electron photosynthetic mechanisms in homogeneous acidic and alkaline media and also work on the creation of molecularly organized systems of photo-oxidation of water using single electron catalysts. The possibilities of creating molecular photocatalytic systems are discussed uniting the reactions of oxidation and reduction of water and also the factors limiting in principle the closure of the redox cycle of systems in the visible region of the spectrum. The structure of the catalytic complex of oxidation of water in native photosynthetic membranes is considered. Special attention is paid to the manganese-protein interactions in the system of photosynthetic oxidation of water and also the linkage of manganese with the individual proteins of the complex of evolution of oxygen. Current ideas on the structure of the metallic nucleus of the natural catalyst of decomposition of water are presented. From the published data the author determines the main directions along which research is developing most vigorously and successfully. © 1992.

Title: Development of dry food for larvae of Coregonus lavaretus L. II. Liver histology
Affiliations: Zoologie II, University of Karlsruhe, Kaiserstr. 12, D-7500 Karlsruhe, Germany; Institute for Lake Research and Fisheries, Untere Seestr. 81, D-7994 Langenargen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Segner, H., Zoologie II, University of Karlsruhe, Kaiserstr. 12, D-7500 Karlsruhe, Germany; Rösch, R., Institute for Lake Research and Fisheries, Untere Seestr. 81, D-7994 Langenargen, Germany
Abstract: Metabolic effects of four dry diets or of living zooplankton underlying different growth responses of larval Coregonus lavaretus were assessed by analysing diet-induced liver structural alterations. Diets I, II and IV contained yeast, diet III was without yeast. Live food resulted in large hepatocyte nuclei, indicative of intensive cell metabolism, and in a strong development of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER), indicative of strong hepatocellular protein synthesis. Among all dietary treatments, hepatic energy stores (glycogen) were lowest in the zooplankton group. The hepatocellular features described are indicative of primarily anabolic liver metabolism in zooplankton-fed larvae. The four dry diets led to significantly smaller nuclei, indicating lower cell metabolic activity. Diets I-III, which all contained wheat flour, resulted in poor development of the RER and in significantly increased hepatic glycogen storage, whereas the carbohydrate-free diet IV was associated with lower glycogen contents and improved development of the RER. It was concluded that coregonid larvae are not able to metabolize efficiently carbohydrates absorbed from the diet. The presence (diets I, II, IV) or absence (diet III) of yeast in the dry food was of no relevance for liver function, indicating that yeast is not a crucial ingredient for successful coregonid starter diets. © 1990.

Title: Energy reserves and storage polymers in intact bacteria analyzed by metabolic calorimetry
Affiliations: Biochemistry Department, University of Minnesota, 1479 Gortner Avenue, St. Paul, MN 55108, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boe, I.N., Biochemistry Department, University of Minnesota, 1479 Gortner Avenue, St. Paul, MN 55108, United States; Lovrien, R.E., Biochemistry Department, University of Minnesota, 1479 Gortner Avenue, St. Paul, MN 55108, United States
Abstract: Bacteria grown under nitrogen limitation and excess carbon accumulate energy storage polymers such as PHB, poly β-hydroxybutyrate. On mixing 1 to 2 ml. suspensions of such cells (2-20 mg. of cells) with air but no additional carbon in a calorimeter large heats evolve until cellular internal energy reserves are consumed. Division of the overall heat by the specific heat content of monomer aerobic metabolism - estimated as (-)200 Kcal/mole PHB monomer - gives the apparent weight of energy reserve content of the cells. The calorimetric method is easier to carry out than conventional respirometric or oxygen uptake methods that require tight control of oxygen concentration baselines. In calorimetry any roughly set oxygen concentration suffices if there is an excess of oxygen sufficient to exhaust the storage materials residing in the cells. © 1990.

Authors: Scheinfein M.R., Unguris J., Kelley M.H., Pierce D.T., Celotta R.J.
Title: Scanning electron microscopy with polarization analysis (SEMPA)
Affiliations: National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Scheinfein, M.R., National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Unguris, J., National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Kelley, M.H., National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Pierce, D.T., National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Celotta, R.J., National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States
Abstract: The high spatial resolution imaging of magnetic microstructure has important ramifications for both fundamental studies of magnetism and the technology surrounding the magnetic recording industry. One technique for imaging surface magnetic microstructure on the 10-nm-length scale is scanning electron microscopy with polarization analysis (SEMPA). This technique employs a scanning electron microscope (SEM) electron optical column to form a medium energy (10-50 keV), small probe (<50 nm) of high current (>1 nA) on a ferromagnetic specimen. Secondary electrons excited in the ferromagnet by the high spatial resolution probe retain their spin-polarization orientation as they leave the sample surface. The spin polarization of the emitted secondary electrons can be related directly to the local magnetization orientation. A surface magnetization map is generated when the spin polarization of the secondary electrons is analyzed as the electron beam is rastered point-by-point across the ferromagnet's surface. In this review article we review the important instrumental components characterizing the SEMPA system. Characteristics of the electron probe forming optics, electron spin-polarization analyzers with associated transport optics, and signal processing electronics will be described. Emphasis on the fundamental design requirements will be stressed. Data acquisition, storage, and processing, as it applies specifically to SEMPA, will be reviewed. Instrumental artifacts specific to SEMPA will be outlined and techniques for their correction given. Examples of magnetic images at high spatial resolution will be shown.

Title: Modeling of electron-beam-controlled semiconductor switches
Affiliations: Department for Electrical and Computer Engineering, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA 23508, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brinkmann, R.P., Department for Electrical and Computer Engineering, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA 23508, United States
Abstract: The subject of this paper is the mathematical modeling of a recently proposed class of electron-beam-controlled high-power semiconductor switches that are able to overcome the space-charge limitation of conventional electron bombarded semiconductor devices by utilizing the secondary ionization effects of cathodoluminiscence and bremsstrahlung. Current densities of several kA/cm 2 at forward voltages some 10 V can be controlled with an electron beam of 100 keV and 1 A/cm2; holdoff voltages of more than 100 kV/cm and dark currents as small as 10 μA/cm2 are possible. The concept has several possible applications: Its fast and repetitive closing and opening under load makes it suitable for inductive energy storage applications; its linear characteristics suggests a use as a high-power modulation device.

Authors: Kung C.C., Chauchard E.A., Lee C.H., Rhee M.J., Yan L.
Title: Observation of power gain in an inductive energy pulsed power system with an optically controlled semiconductor opening switch
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742
Authors with affiliations: Kung, C.C., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742; Chauchard, E.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742; Lee, C.H., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742; Rhee, M.J., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742; Yan, L., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742
Abstract: Power gain has been observed, for the first time, in an inductive energy storage pulsed power system with an optically controlled semiconductor opening switch. A specially tailored 1.054 μm pulse from a Nd:glass laser was utilized to activate a GaAs switch of the p-i-n diode configuration, producing an output pulse with a power gain of more than 10.

Title: Synchrotron x-ray scattering studies of magnetic materials (invited) (abstract)
Affiliations: Physics Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gibbs, D., Physics Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: With the recent development of resonant techniques,1 -3 interest in x-ray magnetic scattering as a probe of magnetic and electronic structure has been steadily increasing. Significant efforts now exist at most of the x-ray storage rings around the world. These have led to proposals for dedicated beamlines at the Advanced Photon Source and at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility planned for Argonne and Grenoble, respectively. In this talk we describe recent results of polarization and resonance studies of rare-earth and actinide materials using synchrotron radiation. For incident x-ray energies far above an absoption edge, we measure the degree of linear polarization of the scattered beam and identify the orbital and spin contributions to the magnetic cross section.1 When the incident x-ray energy is tuned near the M and L absorption edges, large resonant enhancements of the magnetic cross section, and resonant harmonics, are observed.1-3 This behavior may be understood on the basis of electric multipole transitions to unoccupied magnetic states in the conduction band.2 These techniques provide new directions to x-ray magnetic scattering studies using synchrotron radiation, including possible applications to multilayer and surface magnetic structures, and to the spectroscopy of magnetic states in the rare-earth and actinide series.

Title: Occupation of quantum states determined by energy storage in superlattice quantum state transfer devices
Affiliations: U. S. Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirchoefer, S.W., U. S. Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States
Abstract: Quantum state occupation is observed in admittance measurements of two well type (bilevel) superlattice channel conduction devices known as quantum state transfer devices. A small-signal measurement is used to identify the energy storage in applied electric fields between adjacent dissimilar quantum wells. The spatially dependent nature of the miniband structure of bilevel superlattices is thereby confirmed. This energy storage is found in the same regime of device voltage bias as the previously investigated negative differential resistance, supporting the proposition of a common quantum origin between these two phenomena.

Title: A chemical interpretation of heat generated in "cold fusion"
Affiliations: 700 New Hampshire Avenue, NW, Washington, D.C., 20037, United States; 16511 Grande Vista Drive, Derwood, 20855, Maryland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rittner, E.S., 700 New Hampshire Avenue, NW, Washington, D.C., 20037, United States; Meulenberg Jr., A., 16511 Grande Vista Drive, Derwood, 20855, Maryland, United States
Abstract: It is concluded from a thermochemical analysis that the steady-state "excess heating" observed in calorimetric experiments1 is attributable to the heat of formation of liquid D2O resulting from recombination of D2 and O2 gases generated in the electrolytic cell. The recombination is catalyzed by both electrodes and the extent of the reaction increases on stirring, especially when D2 gas sparging is used for this purpose. Thermal effects of stored chemical energy, which include thermal power output exceeding electrical input in the short term and cathode meltdown from total sudden release, arise from storage of D atoms in supersaturated solid solution within the cathode volume. Their recombination to form D2 builds up high internal pressures, causing multiple fracture. Excess heat is liberated as D atoms and D2 molecules fall into deep traps created on fresh Pd surfaces, supplemented by D recombination heat. Postulation of unknown nuclear processes to account for the heat is not necessary. © 1990 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Author Keywords: chemical interpretation; Cold fusion; heat generated

Title: Some myths surrounding energy
Affiliations: Brunei University
Authors with affiliations: Beynon, J., Brunei University
Abstract: This article discusses energy as an abstract quantity and considers the effect of using inappropriate language in the teaching of energy. Illustrations of the 'storage of energy' are taken from gravitation and the combustion of coal.

Authors: Andrianov V.V., Baev V.P., Kazantsev N.A., Ostashev V.E., Parizh M.B., Sheinkman V.S.
Title: A variable inductor circuit design for inductive energy storage systems
Affiliations: Institute of High Temperatures, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences 13/19, Izhorskaja ulitsa, 127412, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Andrianov, V.V., Institute of High Temperatures, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences 13/19, Izhorskaja ulitsa, 127412, Moscow, Russian Federation; Baev, V.P., Institute of High Temperatures, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences 13/19, Izhorskaja ulitsa, 127412, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kazantsev, N.A., Institute of High Temperatures, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences 13/19, Izhorskaja ulitsa, 127412, Moscow, Russian Federation; Ostashev, V.E., Institute of High Temperatures, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences 13/19, Izhorskaja ulitsa, 127412, Moscow, Russian Federation; Parizh, M.B., Institute of High Temperatures, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences 13/19, Izhorskaja ulitsa, 127412, Moscow, Russian Federation; Sheinkman, V.S., Institute of High Temperatures, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences 13/19, Izhorskaja ulitsa, 127412, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: A circuit design for matching an inductive energy storage to a utility grid and a complex load (railgun accelerator) is discussed. A circuit design is suggested for control of the discharge current to provide effective transfer of the energy stored in the inductive storage. It is shown that this circuit design, with a variable winding inductance, provides energy transmission control and allows both a higher efficiency of energy transfer and arrangement of a quick response reserve power source to maintain high-current energy transmission. The arrangement discussed may be used to provide matching of the energy user's load current to the energy storage's initial current which is determined either by the possibility of energy accumulation in the system or by the power supply source's current.

Title: Magnetic theory of very small devices (invited)
Affiliations: IBM Research Division, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Slonczewski, J.C., IBM Research Division, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: A principal theme of this report is that the exchange-stiffness parameter replaces magnetic anisotropy as the principal core-material parameter (besides MS) governing the sensitivity of a read head when the cross-sectional dimensions of the core are less than 1 μm. A cylindrical magnetic tube within the core of a read head would provide micromagnetic advantages. Under certain conditions the unstable exchange energy stored in a magnetic vortex interacts with the stabilizing effect of self-demagnetization to amplify the stored flux by drawing fringing flux from the underlayer and shield. Reading characteristics which are valid, from the micromagnetic standpoint, down to storage-cell areas as small as (40 nm)2 are predicted. For sensitive reading, the core length must be near 100 (D/1 μm)2 μm, where D is the outer diameter of the tube.

Title: Photoluminescence and thermoluminescence properties of Ca 2PO4Cl:Eu2+
Affiliations: Phys. Lab., Utrecht Univ., Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Meijerink, A., Phys. Lab., Utrecht Univ., Netherlands; Blasse, G., Phys. Lab., Utrecht Univ., Netherlands
Abstract: In Ca2PO4Cl the Eu2+ ion occupies two different crystallographic sites. The main difference between the sites is their size. The vibronic coupling strength of the 4f7 to 4f65d transition on Eu2+ is very sensitive to this difference in size resulting in Huang-Rhys factors of S=3 and S=9 for the two sites. The observation of vibronic structure in combination with 7FJ splitting in the excitation spectrum of the Eu2+ emission makes an accurate determination of the splitting of the 4f6 configuration in the 4f65d excited state possible. This splitting is smaller than the free ion values for Eu3+, which is probably due to a reduction of the spin-orbit coupling parameter and/or to crystal-field splitting of the 7FJ terms. Upon irradiation with low energy X-rays Ca 2PO4Cl:Eu2+ acts as a storage phosphor. Analysis of the thermoluminescence suggests a centre-to-centre recombination mechanism.

Authors: Caffey D.P., Utano R.A., Allik T.H.
Title: Diode array side-pumped neodymium-doped gadolinium scandium gallium garnet rod and slab lasers
Affiliations: Center for Night Vision and Electro-Optics, Fort Belvoir, VA 22060-5677, United States; Science Applications International Corporation, 1710 Goodridge Drive, McLean, VA 22102, United States
Authors with affiliations: Caffey, D.P., Center for Night Vision and Electro-Optics, Fort Belvoir, VA 22060-5677, United States; Utano, R.A., Center for Night Vision and Electro-Optics, Fort Belvoir, VA 22060-5677, United States; Allik, T.H., Science Applications International Corporation, 1710 Goodridge Drive, McLean, VA 22102, United States
Abstract: Gadolinium scandium gallium garnet (GSGG) was studied as a high average power laser host material utilizing diode array side pumping. Maximum optical slope efficiencies of 41.5% for Nd:GSGG in the rod geometry and 32.5% for a Nd:Cr:GSGG zig-zag slab were obtained at 1.06 μm. Nd:GSGG and Nd:YAG have similar fluorescence lifetimes while Nd:GSGG has better energy storage capabilities due to its smaller stimulated-emission cross section.

Authors: James D.G., Faulder R.J., Warren G.N.
Title: Phenology of reproductive status, weight, and lipid reserves of biprorulus bibax (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae)
Affiliations: Yanco Agricultural Institute, New South Wales Agriculture and Fisheries, Yanco, NSW, Australia
Authors with affiliations: James, D.G., Yanco Agricultural Institute, New South Wales Agriculture and Fisheries, Yanco, NSW, Australia; Faulder, R.J., Yanco Agricultural Institute, New South Wales Agriculture and Fisheries, Yanco, NSW, Australia; Warren, G.N., Yanco Agricultural Institute, New South Wales Agriculture and Fisheries, Yanco, NSW, Australia
Abstract: Adult Biprorulus bibax (Breddin) in southwestern New South Wales showed substantial variation in weight and lipid reserves associated with reproductive condition. Females were reproductive from September to March but contained the greatest number of eggs during spring (September-November). Females were larger and heavier than males. Highest body weights occurred in nonreproductive individuals overwintering on oranges or mandarins. Lowest body weights occurred during summer (December-February). Nonreproductive bugs overwintering on oranges or mandarins (but not lemons)contained substantial lipid reserves (0.040-0.048 g/0.1 g). Lipid levels of summer reproductive bugs were about half those of individuals overwintering on nonlemon citrus. Overwintering survival of B. Bibax is facilitated by biochemical adjustments associated with reproductive dormancy. The accumulation and storage of energy reserves to enable survival during seasonal adversity are fundamental to the success of this citrus pest in southeastern Australia. © 1990 Entomological Society of America.
Author Keywords: Biprorulus bibax; Insecta; Phenology; Reproductive status
Index Keywords: Citrus; Hemiptera; Insecta; Pentatomidae

Title: Evaluation of the heat loss from partially buried, bermed thermal energy storage tanks
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ryerson Polytechnical Institute, Toronto Ontario M5B 2K3, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Rosen, M.A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ryerson Polytechnical Institute, Toronto Ontario M5B 2K3, Canada
Abstract: A seasonal heat storage model is developed to describe the steady-state thermal behaviour of the soil regime surrounding large, cylindrical, partially buried heat storage tanks having soil bermed against the above grade portion of the tank wall. The increase in tank heat loss rate occurring when an in-ground tank is repositioned at a higher level and bermed is determined for several berm configurations, using a numerical approach. The results are presented in both graphical and analytical forms, for a range of berm heights, soil conductivities and insulation thicknesses. The results appear to provide convenient and accurate design aids for predicting the heat loss characteristics of bermed seasonal heat storage tanks, and as well to be applicable with little error to most non-circular tanks normally encountered. The analytical aid, which is more convenient and as accurate as the graphical aid, appears to be particularly useful for activities involving numerical simulation, economic analysis, and optimization. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: berm; modelling and simulation; Thermal storage

Authors: Gulia N.V., Ochan M.Yu., Al'brekht A.V., Protsenko V.I., Serkh A.G.
Title: Design and investigation of metal-composite superflywheels with compensating lobe element
Authors with affiliations: Gulia, N.V.; Ochan, M.Yu.; Al'brekht, A.V.; Protsenko, V.I.; Serkh, A.G.
Abstract: The authors worked out a new concept of a compensating element for ensuring elastic connection of the wound rim with the hub of a superflywheel at high rotational speeds. To increase the load bearing capacity in all regimes, only tensile stresses (and not bending stresses) must arise in the compensating element (henceforth called lobe). The concept consists in the choice of the profile in the form of a flexible massive thread because it is known that in a field of centrifugal forces of inertia a flexible thread is free of bending stresses. Thus the problem reduces to the determination of the shape assumed in rotation by a flexible thread fastened at one end to the hub, and at the other end to the extended rim of the superflywheel. © 1991 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Index Keywords: Composite Materials - Applications; Energy Storage; Metals and Alloys - Applications; Stresses - Analysis; Flywheel Compensating Lobe Element; Flywheel Energy Storage; Metal-Composite Flywheels; Superflywheel Design Diagram; Flywheels

Authors: Kane Thomas J., Cheng Emily A.P., Gerstenberger David C., Wallace Richard W.
Title: Single-frequency diode-pumped lasers for free-space communication
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kane, Thomas J., Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States; Cheng, Emily A.P., Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States; Gerstenberger, David C., Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States; Wallace, Richard W., Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States
Abstract: Laser-diode pumping of monolithic ND:YAG rings can lead to output powers of hundreds of milliwatts from a single laser. We have built several lasers with diffraction-limited single-mode output of 380 mW. These lasers can be injection-locked in a chain configuration to sum their power, while maintaining diffraction-limited, single-frequency operation. We demonstrated this chaining technique with two lasers, with a total output of 340 mW, and expect that it is practical for up to about ten lasers. Thus with lasers of 380 mW, output of 3 Watts is possible. The chaining technique, if properly engineered, results in redundancy. Monolithic, diode-pumped Nd:YAG ring lasers can provide narrow-linewidth, tunable output which is adequate for use as a local oscillator in a coherent communication system. We build a commerical laser which has a linewidth of about 2 kHz, a power of 5 milliwatts, and which is tunable over a range of 30 MHz in a few microseconds. We phase-locked one of these lasers to a second, similar laser. This demonstrates that the powerful technique of heterodyne detection is possible with a diode-pumped laser used as a local oscillator. A key to the usefulness of these lasers in space communication is modulation. We have experimented with a technique for converting the cw, infrared output of these lasers into randomly pulsed, green output useful for Pulse-Position Modulation. Energy storage in an external resonant cavity permits peak green output to be much more powerful than cw infrared input. We have also begun experimentation with techniques for phase and amplitude modulating the output of these lasers. We are taking advantage of the coherence of the output in order to reduce the voltage required for conventional electro-optic modulation.
Index Keywords: Lasers, Ring; Lasers, Semiconductor--Optical Pumping; Pulse Time Modulation; Semiconductor Diodes; Free-Space Communication; Laser Diodes; Optical Communication

Authors: Matsushita Tatsuhiko, Suzuki Akio, Ohgaki Hitoshi, Aoki Takanori, Nakau Tanehiro, Okuda Masahiro
Title: Measurements of crystallization velocity and activation energy in the optical recording films with In-Sb-Te system
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Osaka Sangyo Univ, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsushita, Tatsuhiko, Osaka Sangyo Univ, Osaka, Japan; Suzuki, Akio, Osaka Sangyo Univ, Osaka, Japan; Ohgaki, Hitoshi, Osaka Sangyo Univ, Osaka, Japan; Aoki, Takanori, Osaka Sangyo Univ, Osaka, Japan; Nakau, Tanehiro, Osaka Sangyo Univ, Osaka, Japan; Okuda, Masahiro, Osaka Sangyo Univ, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Crystallization velocities and activation energies in the initial crystallization process, obtained from measurements transmissivity (reflectivity), are described for amorphous In-Sb-Te films 400 Approximately 600 A thick, which are set up in a chamber with a window guiding of the light through a long-distance focused lens. The crystallization velocity was obtained to about 100 A/s for Inx(Sb0.4Te0.6)1-x (x=0.2 Approximately 0.3) films. The activation energy was determined by Kissinger's plot to be 1.5 approximately 2.0 eV. The frequency factor was calculated by the Johnson-Mehl-Avrami equation; log10 ν0=20 approximately 30 (Hz). Static repetition cycles of about 3 × 104 were recognized in the film composition of x = 0.2 for the sample structure without upper protection layer.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Optical; Indium Antimony Tellurium Alloys - Thin Films; Recording; Activation Energy; Johnson-Mehl-Avrami Equation; Optical Recording; Optical Materials

Authors: Vanderpool M.J., Paul G.G., Miller J.F.
Title: Development of fiber-based nickel hydroxide electrodes for nickel/iron batteries
Affiliations: Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc., Joplin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vanderpool, M.J., Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc., Joplin, United States; Paul, G.G., Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc., Joplin, United States; Miller, J.F., Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc., Joplin, United States
Abstract: Nickel hydroxide electrodes based on non-woven nickel fiber mat substrates are being developed for use in high energy density nickel/iron batteries for electric vehicle applications. The objective of this effort is to reduce battery weight and cost, while increasing cell design flexibility with the advent of thicker nickel electrodes. Nickel/iron cells have been constructed with fiber-based nickel electrodes by Eagle-Picher, and their electrical performance characteristics and cycle life are being evaluated at Argonne National Laboratory.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary--Performance; Fibers, Nontextile; Storage Battery Vehicles; Cycle Life; Nickel Fiber Mat; Nickel Hydroxide Electrodes; Nickel Iron Batteries; Electrodes, Electrochemical

Title: Thermal response of phase-change energy storage units
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burke, A.F., Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: The thermal responses of two commercially available phase-change energy storage units were measured during heating and cooling cycles in an air-solar facility. One of the units utilized sodium sulfate decahydrate and the other calcium chloride hexahydrate as the phase-change material. The storage units were instrumented with thermocouples on the external surface as well as interior to the material. The temperatures were tracked during the freeze-melt cycles utilizing a DEC Rainbow PC-based data acquisition system. The thermocouple data were reduced to obtain plots of the temperatures vs. time and energy stored or withdrawn and heat transfer rate and heat transfer coefficient vs. time. The heating and cooling cycle tests took 10-20 hours to perform.
Index Keywords: Calcium Compounds; Heat Transfer; Sodium Compounds; Air-Solar Facility; Calcium Chloride Hexahydrate; Phase-Change Energy Storage Units; Sodium Sulfate Decahydrate; Thermal Response; Energy Storage

Title: Numerical study of the effect of inlet geometry on stratification in thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ghajar, A.J., Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States; Zurigat, Y.H., Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States
Abstract: A finite-difference computer code incorporating two methods of discretization for the advection terms in the flow governing conservation equations has been developed. These methods are the Weighted Upwind Difference Scheme (WUDS) and the Second Order Upwind Difference Scheme (SOUDS). Application of the code to a stratified thermal storage showed very good agreement between the experimental temperature profiles and the predicted ones when using SOUDS as opposed to WUDS. Investigation of the effect of the inlet geometry on thermal stratification in a thermal storage tank was carried out using the SOUDS method. Results show that the effect of the inlet geometry is not significant for Richardson numbers above 10. Thus a performance criterion for stratified thermal storage tanks with different inlet geometries has been established.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques - Finite Difference Method; Flow Governing Conservation Equations; Pressure-Velocity Adjustment Equations; Second Order Upwind Difference Scheme (SOUDS); Thermal Energy Storage; Weighted Upwind Difference Scheme (WUDS); Energy Storage

Title: Applying a multifunction protective relay for the cogeneration industry
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Power Division (Publication) PWR
Affiliations: Beckwith Electric Co Inc, Largo, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harlow, James H., Beckwith Electric Co Inc, Largo, United States
Abstract: Since the enactment of the National Energy Act of 1979, many private energy producers have been planning and building small generation and cogeneration facilities in order to sell power to the local utility. Previously, the generation sources that were not owned by a utility were typically very large industrial plants with generators connected to the power system at a substation through a dedicated line. However, many of the non-utility generators (called DSG for dispersed sources of generation or dispersed storage and generation) built after 1979 are connected directly to the closest utility distribution circuit. With this configuration, the parallel generator may energize a distribution line after the utility circuit breaker or line recloser has opened. One study in particular addressed the economics of small cogeneration, considering the costs of capital equipment for installations up to 800 kW capacity. One notable conclusion of that study is that once the desired level of protection is defined, the costs to protect the interconnection do not vary with generation capacity. The study reports that 'utility grade' relays affording a 'high level' of protection will represent more than 25% of the cost of the major power system capital equipment at 800 kW and nearly 50% for a 100 kW installation. The obvious question is: 'Is it possible and practical, using advanced digital electronic design, to incorporate most (or all) of the required protection functions into one package and thereby significantly reduce the expense?' This question was turned into an objective, and the resulting multifunction protective relay is explained in this paper. The paper is written from the viewpoint of the power system protection engineer and considers the method used to decide which functions to include, the reasoning behind these decisions, and the general operation of the various functions.
Index Keywords: Relay Protection--Applications; Multifunction Relays; Relay Functions; Cogeneration Plants

Authors: Sciandra A., Gouze J.L., Nival P.
Title: Modelling the reproduction of Centropages typicus (Copepoda: Calanoida) in a fluctuating food supply: Effect of adaptation
Affiliations: Station Zoologique, Université P.M.Curie, BP. 28, Villefranche-sur-mer, 06230, France; Projet EDORA, INRIA, Route des Lucioles, Sophia-Antipolis, Valbonne, 06565, France
Authors with affiliations: Sciandra, A., Station Zoologique, Université P.M.Curie, BP. 28, Villefranche-sur-mer, 06230, France; Gouze, J.L., Station Zoologique, Université P.M.Curie, BP. 28, Villefranche-sur-mer, 06230, France, Projet EDORA, INRIA, Route des Lucioles, Sophia-Antipolis, Valbonne, 06565, France; Nival, P.
Abstract: A mathematical model of the reproduction of the copepod Centropages typicus is proposed, which takes into account the physiological processes involved in the transformation of available food into eggs (ingestion, assimilation, storage, maturation) and the associated metabolic rates. The principal hypothesis is that maturation is regulated by the level of energy storage. The simulations fit adequately to the measurements of the egg-laying rate in constant as well as in varying food concentrations. It is demonstrated that the classical steady-state relationships between food and egg laying rate do not provide a good estimation of the fecundity of C. typicus when food fluctuates periodically. The model predicts that the average egg-laying rate of a population of C. typicus changes radically for periodicities of food variation <̃2 days. The average rate is insensitive to the periodicity of food variation for a period >2 days. It is suggested that the frequency of food variation is a parameter as important as quality and quantity, which must be taken into account to predict adequately the egg production of females during their lifespan. © 1990 Oxford University Press.
Index Keywords: calanoid; copepod; reproduction; Calanoida; Centropages typicus; Copepoda

Authors: Hoffmann Geoffrey W., Davenport Michael R.
Title: A network that uses the outer product rule, hidden neurons, and peaks in the energy landscape
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Dept of Phys, Univ of British, Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Hoffmann, Geoffrey W., Dept of Phys, Univ of British, Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada; Davenport, Michael R., Dept of Phys, Univ of British, Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
Abstract: The results of the development and simulation of an extended version of the discrete Hopfield neural network are summarized. The network uses hidden neurons to optimize the orthogonality of the memory space. The process is fast because it is noniterative, and the design is such that a hardware implementation would require no executive processor during memory storage or retrieval. Simulations indicate that the storage capacity of the network and the radius of attraction of each memory are significantly better for uncorrelated memories than those of the standard Hopfield model. Hidden neurons permit flexibility in the network capacity for memories of a given length and make it possible for the network to solve second-order problems.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Information Retrieval Systems; Hidden Neurons; Hopfield Model; Neural Networks

Title: Humidity control system for Winchester 5 1/4 inches rigid disk drive
Source title: Journal of engineering computing and applications
Affiliations: Imprimis Technology Inc, Oklahoma City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nwosu, Harold U., Imprimis Technology Inc, Oklahoma City, United States
Abstract: Extreme changes in humidity may be a source of failure for Winchester 5 1/4 inches rigid disk drives. High relative humidity can result in head-to-disk stiction during contact between read/write heads and magnetic recording disks. Conditions of low relative humidity may alter the surface energy of the head/disk interface resulting in excessive friction and wear. Variations in humidity will alter the behavior of lubricants on magnetic recording disks if proper control is not instituted. This article discusses the design concept and approach used by the small disk division of Imprimis Technology Inc to control relative humidity in a sealed Winchester rigid disk drive. Imprimis Technology Inc is a supplier of high performance storage devices and components to original equipment manufacturers and remarketers.
Index Keywords: Computer Peripheral Equipment--Disk Drives; Gaskets--Design; Desiccants; Humidity Control

Authors: Grundner M., Hahn P.O., Lampert I.
Title: Aging of hydrophilic Si surfaces and roughness of the Si/SIO2 interface after thermal oxidation
Affiliations: Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Burghausen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Grundner, M., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Burghausen, Germany; Hahn, P.O., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Burghausen, Germany; Lampert, I., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Burghausen, Germany
Abstract: Aging of a hydrophilic silicon surface leads to enhanced roughness of the Si/SiO2 interface after thermal oxidation. Removal of the OH groups before storage by derivatization avoids this effect. Furthermore, a simple H2O dip before thermal oxidation restores the properties of the as prepared surface. Combined measurements of surface morphology by ARLS (Angle Resolved Lightscattering) and chemical surface composition by HREELS (High Resolution Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy) lead to the conclusion that inhomogeneous condensation-hydrolization reactions of the hydrophilic surface during storage are responsible for the increase in roughness after thermal oxidation.
Index Keywords: Semiconducting Silicon - Surface Properties; Semiconductor Devices - Cleaning; Surfaces - Spectroscopic Analysis; Angle Resolved Light Scattering; Derivatization; High Resolution Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy; Hydrophilic Silicon Surface Roughness; Silicon Wafer Thermal Oxidation; Wafer Cleaning Technology; Integrated Circuits

Title: Subminiature telemetry technology
Affiliations: U.S. Air Force Armament Lab, Elgin Air Force Base, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keller, G.E., U.S. Air Force Armament Lab, Elgin Air Force Base, United States
Abstract: Current telemetry instrumentation systems are subject to space and weight limitations for use in bombs, dispensers, submunitions, projectiles and other tactical weapon systems. It is not now feasible to instrument submunitions and projectiles for weapon effectiveness data because state-of-the-art telemetry devices cannot be rapidly and cost effectively installed in unmodified munitions. Aircraft modifications for flutter/loads testing are expensive and time consuming. This program will develop a low cost telemetry chip-set consisting of integrated sensors, signal conditioning, transmitters and encryptors. 'Peel-and-Stick' telemetry devices, containing a specific chip-set with integrated sensors, a battery, and antenna in a small package, will also be developed. Subminiature Telemetry Technology (SMT) will directly impact all future tactical submunition development programs during pre-production RDT&E. This program will also support compatibility and safe separation testing done in the Air Force SEEK EAGLE program. Conventional and kinetic energy projectile programs and advanced missile programs will have long-term benefit. Telemetry and encryption designs developed in this program will advance the state-of-the-art in telemetry fabrication from hybrid to monolithic providing smaller, more shock resistant systems at a lower cost. Subminiature telemetry devices could be integrated with the weapon system during its development allowing for a non-destructive, non-contaminating test of the system. This will reduce the cost and logistics of determining weapon readiness and health status during long time periods of storage.
Index Keywords: Cryptography; Military Communications - Telemetering; Subminiature Telemetry; Telemetering Systems

Title: High efficiency, high energy optical amplifier for femtosecond pulses
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Princeton Univ, Princeton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nighan Jr., W.L., Princeton Univ, Princeton, United States; Fauchet, P.M., Princeton Univ, Princeton, United States
Abstract: We report on the design and performance of an improved copper vapor laser pumped amplifier for femtosecond optical pulses. Consideration of the large duration mismatch between pump and seed pulses, the short energy storage time of the gain dye, spatial mode matching, and polarization effects led to an amplifier design of 1.5% efficiency, which is greater than previous designs. Pulses of >10 μJ energy and approximately 65 fsec duration are generated that are focussable to less than twice the diffraction limit. The multiple pass amplifier incorporates optimized mode matching, an antireflection coated flowing dye cell, and a polarized, spatially smoothed pump beam.
Index Keywords: Laser Beams; Lasers, Dye; Light--Amplifiers; Femtosecond Pulses; Optical Amplifiers; Laser Pulses

Title: Watershed management
Source title: International Journal of Water Resources Development
Affiliations: International Water Resources Association, 76 Woodstock Close, Oxford 0X2, 8DD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Biswas, A.K., International Water Resources Association, 76 Woodstock Close, Oxford 0X2, 8DD, United Kingdom
Abstract: Water management has increasingly been realized to be an essential component of sustainable water development. While no-one argues with the desirability of proper watershed management, achieving it has not been an easy task. It requires concurrent accomplishment of many tasks, among which are strict control of land-use practices, afforestation and forest management, and implementation of appropriate soil and water conservation practices. Two main impacts of inadequate watershed management are discussed. These are increased reservoir sedimentation which reduces storage capacity which may in turn render water projects uneconomic, and changing patterns of stream flow. It is argued that watershed management should not be viewed exclusively from the narrow perspective of benefits to water projects alone. It should be considered essential for soil and water conservation and forest management, which in the long run will enhance the prospect of self-reliance of nations in terms of food, fibre and energy. © 1990 Butterworth-Heinemann Ltd
Index Keywords: forest management; policy implementation; reservoir sedimentation; soil and water conservation; stream flow; sustainability; watershed management; agriculture; article; water management; water supply

Authors: Marschke K.W., Caldeira P., Lipo T.A.
Title: Utilization of the series resonant DC link converter as a conditioning system for SMES
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Marschke, K.W., Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Caldeira, P., Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Lipo, T.A., Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: A novel superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) system utilizing a high-efficiency series resonant DC link power converter as the conditioning converter is presented. This system generates a high-frequency (20 kHz or more) resonant current in a series link, and switching is done at zero current instants, reducing switching losses to a minimal value. Through the utilization of an adequate control strategy, input power factor can be fully adjusted during the charging, storing, and discharging modes of the SMES, improving the overall system efficiency. Different semiconductor devices are employed as the switching elements of the resonant converter, and switching losses are established for each case. Experimental results from a monophase and three-phase system verified the results obtained from digital simulation.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Electric Converters, Static; Electric Losses; Electric Networks, Switching - Resonant Circuits; Superconducting Magnets; Reactive Power Control; Series Resonant DC Link Converter; Superconductive Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES); Switching Losses; Electric Energy Storage

Title: Adaptable power supply for superconductive magnetic energy storage system
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Arizona State Univ, Tempe, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Karady, George G., Arizona State Univ, Tempe, AZ, USA
Abstract: A new power supply which permits the independent regulation of the active and reactive power of a superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) system is discussed. The power supply consists of 20 units connected in parallel. Each unit contains a 24-pulse bridge converter, a thyristor-controlled regulating transformer, and a thyristor switched capacitor bank. An SMES system using the power supply is capable of improving power system stability and oscillation damping, as well as performing load leveling. The power supply can be built with commercially available components using well-proven technology.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric Converters, Static; Electric Power Factor - Correction; Electric Power Systems - Stability; Superconducting Magnets; 24-Pulse Bridge Converter; Superconductive Magnetic Energy Storage; Thyristor-Controlled Regulating Transformer; Thyristor-Switched Capacitor Bank; Electric Energy Storage

Authors: Veron L., Rouille C., Etlicher B., Dufour B., Buzzi J.-M., Boivinet R.
Title: C+ and C2+ optimized plasma opening switch for inductive storage
Affiliations: Lab du CNRS, Ecole Polytech,, Palaiseau, France
Authors with affiliations: Veron, L., Lab du CNRS, Ecole Polytech,, Palaiseau, France; Rouille, C., Lab du CNRS, Ecole Polytech,, Palaiseau, France; Etlicher, B., Lab du CNRS, Ecole Polytech,, Palaiseau, France; Dufour, B., Lab du CNRS, Ecole Polytech,, Palaiseau, France; Buzzi, J.-M., Lab du CNRS, Ecole Polytech,, Palaiseau, France; Boivinet, R., Lab du CNRS, Ecole Polytech,, Palaiseau, France
Abstract: Summary form only given. A plasma erosion opening switch (PEOS) experiment has been conducted to measure plasma density and velocity. Carbon plasma was created by a capacitor bank. Plasma density was measured either by microwave interferometry or by Faraday cup. From the charge collectors, the velocity of the plasma jet was determined. The time structure of the plasma was studied as a function of the capacitor bank charging voltage. The plasma composition was determined by time-integrated spectroscopy. Plasma extension in space was measured by time-integrated photography. The time evolution of line radiation was correlated with both interferometry and charge collectors. Three components of the plasma were determined and studied in time: H+, with velocity VH = 7 cm/μs, C+, and C2+, with velocity VC = 2 cm/μs. These velocities agree with the hypothesis of equal energy per atom, VH = VC (mH/mC)1/2, and the plasma expansion model.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Carbon; Electric Switches; Interferometry; Plasmas--Density; Faraday Cup; Plasma Erosion Opening Switches; Summary Only; Plasma Devices

Title: Channel network analysis using simultaneous solution algorithm
Source title: Hydraulic Engineering - Proceedings of the 1990 National Conference
Affiliations: Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, United States
Authors with affiliations: Choi, G.W., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, United States; Molinas, A., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, United States
Abstract: In this paper, a simultaneous solution algorithm for one dimensional unsteady flow routing through channel networks is introduced. This direct solution algorithm is based on the double sweep method. It utilizes separate recursion equations for continuity, momentum and energy equations for each of the individual components of channel networks. By doing so it converts the channel network problem into a single channel problem. The new algorithm is utilized in a linearized unsteady flow model using full dynamic flow equations. The required computer storage for the coefficient matrix of the whole system is reduced significantly from the 2N × 2N matrix to a 2N × 4 matrix. Here, N is the number of sections required for computing flow variables in the channel network. The algorithm presented in this paper provides an efficient and accurate modeling of unsteady flow events through channel networks.
Index Keywords: Computer Aided Analysis; Flow of Fluids--Unsteady Flow; Mathematical Techniques--Algorithms; Channel Networks; Dynamic Flow Equations; Network Analysis; Simultaneous Solution Algorithms; Flow of Water

Title: Broad-band impedance matching of the RLC generator and load
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Dept of Electr Eng & Comput Sci,, Univ of Illinois, Chicago, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Zha, Qiang-Zhong, Dept of Electr Eng & Comput Sci,, Univ of Illinois, Chicago, IL, USA; Chen, Wai-Kai, Dept of Electr Eng & Comput Sci,, Univ of Illinois, Chicago, IL, USA
Abstract: A simple theory is presented for the design of a broadband impedance matching network which, when operating between a given RLC generator z1(s) and an RLC load z2(s), yields a maximum Chebyshev lowpass or bandpass response. Using realizability conditions for the double frequency-dependent terminations, a theorem is presented, which states that if there exists a second-order all-pass function such that the resulting reflection coefficients are bounded-real and satisfy Youla's (1964) conditions at each zero of transmission of z1(s) and z2(s), a ladder equalizer exists. A method to realize such a ladder is described. After choosing the order of the transfer function at least equal to the total number of the energy storage elements of z1(s) and z2(s), the result can easily be extended to any all-pole lowpass response for any non-Foster positive-real impedances z1(s) and z2(s) except for the case where z1(s) and z2(s) have a common finite zero on the jω-axis.
Index Keywords: Electric Networks--Equivalent Circuits; Mathematical Techniques--Poles and Zeros; Coupling Networks; Equivalent Network; Impedance Matching; Ladder Equalizer; Power Transfer; Scattering Matrix; Electric Filters

Title: Solar Energy in the 1990s
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Abstract: This conference proceedings coatings 12 papers. Topics covered include: panel cooling and heating of buildings using solar energy; progress in dessicant cooling; dessicant contamination in dessicant cooling systems; a solar powered air-compression dehumidifier; rating solar collectors based on thermodynamic availability; thermal response of phase-change energy storage units; a mathematical model and computer simulation of radiant panel heating systems; comparison of mass and heat transfer coefficient of liquid dessicant mixtures in a packed column; solar cooling of buildings; performance and cost projections for advanced wind turbines; economics of hydrogen liquefaction; and, design and cost of near-term OTEC plants for the production of desalinated water and electric power.

Title: Computer modeling of thermal energy storage in phase change materials with direct contact heat transfer
Affiliations: Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gadalla, M.A., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, United States; Sharif, M.A.R., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, United States
Abstract: Some physical insights about the phase change behavior of clathrates which are used as energy storage medium are provided in this paper. Direct contact heat transfer mode is studied. A numerical model compatible with the latent heat release rate is used to predict the temperature distribution inside the storage tank. Control volume approach is used to obtain the finite difference expressions for the governing equation. Predicted temperature history during system operation is compared with experimental data.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer; Direct Contact Heat Transfer; Phase Change Materials; Materials

Title: Proceedings of the Symposium on Nickel Hydroxide Electrodes
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 29 papers. The first part of this symposium volume deals with fundamental studies concerning the kinetics, structure, and electrochemistry of the nickel hydroxide and new nickel electrode materials. The second part of this symposium volume deals with nickel battery electrodes; their fabrication, characterization, and operation in various battery systems. Some topics discussed by the papers are cited as examples: the nickel oxide electrode: structure and performance; the influence of foreign ions addition on the electrochemical behavior of the nickel hydroxide electrode; electrochemical studies of conductive polymeric nickel porphyrin anodes in basic media; development of a high-energy density pasted nickel electrode; accelerated method of sintered plate impregnation with nickelous hydroxide; on the mechanical properties of nickel oxide electrodes; the interaction of hydrogen with nickel electrodes; calorimetry of nickel-hydrogen cells; and nickel-zinc battery for electric vehicles applications.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary--Charging; Electrochemistry; Electrodes--Structure; Mathematical Models; Nickel Compounds--Electrodes; EIREV; Nickel Cadmium Batteries; Nickel Hydrogen Batteries; Self Discharge; Sintered Nickel Electrodes; Storage Battery Vehicles; Electrodes, Electrochemical

Title: Metastable singlet NF. Reactivity and energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Kansas State Univ, Manhattan, United States
Authors with affiliations: Du, K.Y., Kansas State Univ, Manhattan, United States; Setser, D.W., Kansas State Univ, Manhattan, United States
Abstract: A flow reactor using the 2F + HN3 reaction to generate NF(a1Δ) has been used to systematically study the reactions of NF(a1Δ) at 300K. The bimolecular self-removal rate constant for NF(a1Δ) was assigned as 5±2 × 10-12 cm3 s-1. Quenching rate constants by stable molecules span a wide range of values; those for diatomic molecules, with the notable exception of the halogens, generally are less than 1 × 10-14 cm3 s-1, but more reactive molecules, such as C2H4, NH3 and P(CH3)3, have rate constants of approximately 1 × 10-11 cm3 s-1. For those polyatomic molecules which can act as Lewis bases, a correlation exists between the magnitude of the quenching rate constant and the base strength. The rate constants for the halogens increase dramatically with molecular weight and the rate constant for I2 is (1.5±1.0) × 10-10 cm3 s-1. The rate constants for open shell atoms and molecules tend to be smaller than expected; values for NO2, NO, F, N, O and C are 0.65 × 10-14, 0.10 × 10-14, 4 × 10-13, 5 ×10-13, 6 × 10-12 and 2.7 × 10-11 cm3 s-1, respectively. In general, the NF(a1Δ) quenching rate constants are not so large as to preclude the utilization of complex schemes to extract the stored energy of NF(a1Δ).
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions; Energy Storage; Halogen Compounds; Molecules; Flow Reactors; Lasers, Chemical

Authors: Grunder M., Hahn P.O., Lampert I., Schnegg A., Jacob H.
Title: Surface composition and morphology of SI wafers after wet chemical treatments
Affiliations: Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Burghausen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Grunder, M., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Burghausen, Germany; Hahn, P.O., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Burghausen, Germany; Lampert, I., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Burghausen, Germany; Schnegg, A., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Burghausen, Germany; Jacob, H., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Burghausen, Germany
Abstract: Wafer production or processing demands the application of chemical treatments for the sake of cleaning, dissolving dielectric layers or surface conditioning. The chemical state of the silicon surface after usual treatments with HF, water, and fast oxidizing media has been studies by means of XPS (X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy) and HREELS (High Resolution Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy). Storage effects are included, too. Specifically it is shown that the hydrophobic state obtained by a HF dip is due to Si-H groups and hydrophilicity is caused by Si-OH groups. Conclusions on reaction paths are drawn.
Index Keywords: Hydrofluoric Acid - Applications; Semiconducting Silicon - Chemical Treatment; Semiconductor Devices - Chemical Treatment; Spectroscopy, Photoelectron - Applications; High Resolution Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy; Hydrophilic Treatments; Silicon Wafer Chemical Treatment; Wafer Wet Cleaning Technology; Integrated Circuits

Title: Central valley project operations
Affiliations: U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, Sacramento, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jackson, Michael, U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, Sacramento, United States
Abstract: The Federal Central Valley Project (CVP) utilizes the water supply and storage regulated by the CVP's four major northern California reservoirs, Clair Engle, Whiskeytown, Shasta, and Folsom Lakes, to meet the majority of the CVP's needs and obligations. These northern reservoirs have a combined storage capacity of 8.25 million acre-feet. This storage is primarily regulated by making releases through the 6 powerplants and 2 power tunnels that are inter-related with the operation of these northern reservoirs. Water transfers from these northern facilities to the San Joaquin Valley are accomplished by providing sufficient flows to meet the instream needs of water rights holders, fishery, water quality standards in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta Estuary, and Delta exports. Energy generated by these northern facilities is used to help meet the power needs of the CVP's export and pumping facilities south of the Delta. The major southern facilities of the CVP include the Delta Mendota Canal, San Luis Canal, and the Federal portion of San Luis Reservoir in central California. These southern facilities are operated to transfer the water south of the Delta. All of the CVP's needs and obligations are met throughout the year while the CVP operators do their best to balance the refill potentials of the major northern California storage reservoirs.
Index Keywords: Reservoirs; River Basin Projects; Water Resources--Management; Water Supply; Water--Storage; Central Valley Project; Northern California Reservoirs; Operations; Water Transfers; Water Distribution Systems

Title: International Conference on Optoelectronic Science and Engineering '90
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Abstract: The proceedings contains 276 papers. Authors: Kim A., Weiner M., Youmans R., Zeto R.
Title: Sub-nanosecond risetime high power pulse generation using photoconductive bulk GaAs devices
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, A., U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Weiner, M., U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Youmans, R., U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Zeto, R., U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States
Abstract: The interest in fast risetime, high power photoconductive devices stems from several potential applications including pulse, impulse, and high power microwave generation [1, 2]. As the voltage becomes large and the switching speed becomes extremely fast, the generation of high power electrical pulses using photoconductive devices becomes very complicated because of effects such as surface flash-over, stray inductance, stray capacitance, and abrupt impedance transitions. Two approaches were taken to produce maximum output voltage amplitude without degradation in switch risetime. A coaxial transmission line with a switch holder filled with a high dielectric strength liquid was fabricated for long pulsewidths (2 ns). For the narrow pulsewidths ( 2 ns) a quasi-radial transmission line was fabricated. By incorporating a photoconductive bulk GaAs device with opposite gridded electrodes into these specially designed energy storage elements, and illuminating the switch with a mode-locked Nd:YAG laser, electrical pulses with risetimes of several picoseconds have been realized.
Index Keywords: Garnets; Laser Pulses--Pulse Generators; Lasers, Solid State--Mode Locking; Photoconducting Devices; Photoconducting Materials; YAG Lasers; Semiconducting Gallium Arsenide

Title: Panel cooling and heating of buildings using solar energy
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Middle East Technical Univ, Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Kilkis, Birol, Middle East Technical Univ, Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: With respect to solar energy utilization in buildings, solar energy is abundant in Summer when there is no heating load, but instead cooling may be essential. On the other hand, for solar heating purposes, seasonal storage is mostly a necessity for conventional heating units. Panel heating or cooling systems which can operate with moderate fluid temperatures, and demand only moderate intensities of energy sources like solar energy, offer a favourable choice in solar energy utilization. The same panel installation can be used year round, both for heating and cooling purposes. In panel heating, direct utilization of solar collector outputs is generally possible. In this article, as well as the basic theory, design principles which were developed by the author are given in detail for both panel heating and panel cooling applications. A design study that has been carried out at Middle East Technical University for an existing solar house is presented. A single effect Lithuim-Bromide-Water solar absorption unit rated at 3.5 kW to effectively cool the two story solar house of 96.6 m2 area was found to require 42.2 m2 of flat plate collectors. For winter heating, floor heating panels, electrical water heating back-up, and additional solar collectors was found to be necessary.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Solar Energy Systems; Heating--Solar; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Flat Plate Collectors; Lithium-Bromide-Water Solar Absorption Unit; Panel Cooling; Panel Heating; Solar House; Buildings

Title: Survey of the NF(b → X) visible laser candidate
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Aerospace Corp, El Segundo, United States
Authors with affiliations: Heidner, R.F., Aerospace Corp, El Segundo, United States; Herbelin, J.M., Aerospace Corp, El Segundo, United States
Abstract: Three chemical systems have been proposed for generating a visible electronic transition laser on NF(b → X) at λ = 529 nm. Each concept involves generating NF(a1Δ) and upconverting it to NF(b1Σ) with HF(v ≥ 2), O2(a1Δ), or I, respectively. The stimulated emission cross section for NF(b → X) is small due to a small Einstein coefficient (A ≈ 50 s-1) and ro-vibronic dilution of the oscillator strength. Large inversion densities are mandated which raise problems with gas phase side reactions involving the collision of two excited state species. In addition, the combination of low gain and high energy storage density results in large intracavity fluxes for a real laser device. Work is proceeding in all these relevant areas.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions; Visible Lasers; Lasers, Chemical

Authors: Woodall H.N., McDaniel D.H., Mendel C.W., Rochau G.E., Zagar D.M., Simpson W.W., Zuchowski N.P.
Title: Long conduction time POS experiments on MITE
Affiliations: Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
