Authors with affiliations: Woodall, H.N., Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; McDaniel, D.H., Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Mendel, C.W., Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Rochau, G.E., Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Zagar, D.M., Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Simpson, W.W., Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Zuchowski, N.P., Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Summary form only given. MITE is a power flow testbed that has been modified to conduct experiments in high-power plasma opening switch (POS) technology and apply this technology to inertial confinement fusion. The goal of the experiment is to develop a POS that conducts megampere currents for 300 ns, then opens in 5-10 ns. MITE/POS is an advanced power flow experiment that uses a magnetically insulated transmission line (MITL) as the inductive energy store and as a means to shape the output pulse. This experiment demonstrates that a simplified, lower-cost facility can be built by eliminating water pulse-forming lines and water switching. The disadvantage is that a new technology, the triggered POS, must be implemented. The triggered POS is necessary for synchronization of multiple modules with a long-conduction-time POS. The MITE facility has been modified to drive a 250-nH, 16.6-Ω MITL at 0.9 MA to accommodate this power flow experiment. A MITL inductive energy storage of 101 kJ is available for POS switching to a matched load. Experiments leading to the development of the triggered POS have been conducted using segmented flashboards and magnetic-field controlled plasma sources.
Index Keywords: Electric Switches; Inertial Confinement Fusion; Magnetic Fields; Magnetic Shielding; Plasma Opening Switches; Summary Only; Plasma Devices

Authors: Walker Jr. Arthur B.C., Bailey Wayne, Chupp Edward L., Hudson Hugh S., Wu Shi Tsan
Title: Advanced Solar Observatory
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walker Jr., Arthur B.C., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Bailey, Wayne, Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Chupp, Edward L., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Hudson, Hugh S., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Wu, Shi Tsan, Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Abstract: We describe a conceptual plan for the development of a comprehensive long duration solar space observatory, the Advanced Solar Observatory (ASO). The ASO is intended to provide solar astronomers with the observational power (spectral, spatial, and temporal resolution, sensitivity, and breadth of wavelength coverage) necessary to address fundamental problems relating to the solar convection zone and activity cycle, the thermal and non-thermal processes which control the transport of energy, mass and magnetic flux in the solar atmosphere, the generation of the solar wind, and the dynamics of the inner heliosphere. The Advanced Solar Observatory concept encompasses three proposed Space Station based instrument ensembles: (i) the High Resolution Telescope Cluster which includes far ultraviolet, extreme ultraviolet and x-ray telescopes, (ii) the Pinhole/Occulter Facility which includes Fourier transform and coded aperture hard x-ray and gamma ray telescopes and occulted ultraviolet and visible light coronagraphs, and (iii) the High Energy Facility which contains neutron, gamma ray and low frequency radio spectrometers. Two other facilities, the Orbiting Solar Laboratory (OSL), which will contain high resolution visible and ultraviolet telescopes on a free-flying platform, and a package of Global Dynamics Instruments will, with the Space Station ensembles, form a comprehensive capability for solar physics. We describe the scientific program of the ASO, current instrument concepts for the Space Station based ASO instrument ensembles, and plans for their accommodation on the Space Station.
Index Keywords: Data Processing - Data Acquisition; Image Storage, Digital - Storage Devices; Satellites - Orbital Laboratories; Sun - Imaging Techniques; Telescopes - Accessories; Advanced Solar Observatory (ASO); Detector Arrays; High Resolution Telescope Cluster (HRTC); Orbiting Solar Laboratory (OSL); Ultraviolet Telescopes; X Ray Telescopes; Spacecraft

Authors: Hassan Yassin, Blanchat Thomas, Hild Robert
Title: Full-field velocity imaging technique using high-energy pulsed laser velocimetry
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hassan, Yassin, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States; Blanchat, Thomas, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States; Hild, Robert, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States
Abstract: Digital Pulsed Laser Velocimetry (DPLV) is a novel full-field, two dimensional, noninvasive, quantitative flow visualization technique. The technique described here includes the use of direct digitization of the images for flow analysis using a high resolution imaging system. The image data is stored for further analysis by a series of new image processing and analysis software developed for flow experiments. The imaging processing and analysis software developed includes a compression program for reducing storage requirements of the image data to 10%. An image finding, smoothing, and defining program has also been developed. Analysis time has been greatly reduced and the software is now running on a PC/AT compatible. This program groups pixels that could logically be defined as one image, smooths that image and calculates important parameters for the image. In the technique images via a high resolution camera (1024 × 1024), ten consecutive frames of data, separated by a time increment of 150 ms, are recorded. Each of these ten frames contains the images of particles at that one instant of time. A third computer program is developed to match the image from each of the frames into tracks of the particles through time. The program uses a statistical technique to determine the best possible path of the fluid seeds. The ability of pulsed laser velocimetry with these image processing techniques to capture simultaneous and quantitative rather than qualitative information is its most important capability.
Index Keywords: Computer Software; Image Processing; Laser Pulses; Velocimeters - Laser Applications; Flow Analysis; High Resolution Imaging; Pulsed Laser Velocimetry; Two Dimensional Flow Visualization; Flow of Fluids

Authors: Vill Arnold A., Salk Ants A.
Title: Excimer laser of extremely homogeneous UV spark preionization
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Estonian Acad of Sciences, Estonia, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Vill, Arnold A., Estonian Acad of Sciences, Estonia, Russian Federation; Salk, Ants A., Estonian Acad of Sciences, Estonia, Russian Federation
Abstract: In most commercial and laboratory excimer lasers spark discharge is used for preionization, or to be more exact a number of rows of spark gaps along electrodes. It is necessary to make allowances for heterogeneity of preionization across the field and for soiling due to erosion of electrodes of preionization and irreversible plasmochemical processes in arc channels of these sparks. In this work a method of spark preionization, which is free from the first defect - heterogeneity across the field is suggested. There has been also suggested a method of suppression of consequences of erosion and soiling - i.e. the defence of windows from dust.
Index Keywords: Anodes - Laser Applications; Electrodes - Laser Applications; Electron Tubes, Thyratron - Laser Applications; Electronic Circuits - Laser Applications; Ultraviolet Radiation; Laser Chambers; Laser Output Energy; Storage Capacitors; Ultraviolet Spark Preionization; Lasers, Excimer

Authors: Yoshikawa Kuniyoshi, Mori Seiichi, Sakagami Eiji, Ohshima Yoichi, Kaneko Yukio, Arai Norihisa
Title: Lucky-hole injection induced by band-to-band tunneling leakage in stacked gate transistors
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Toshiba Corp, Saiwaiku, Kawasaki,, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoshikawa, Kuniyoshi, Toshiba Corp, Saiwaiku, Kawasaki,, Japan; Mori, Seiichi, Toshiba Corp, Saiwaiku, Kawasaki,, Japan; Sakagami, Eiji, Toshiba Corp, Saiwaiku, Kawasaki,, Japan; Ohshima, Yoichi, Toshiba Corp, Saiwaiku, Kawasaki,, Japan; Kaneko, Yukio, Toshiba Corp, Saiwaiku, Kawasaki,, Japan; Arai, Norihisa, Toshiba Corp, Saiwaiku, Kawasaki,, Japan
Abstract: The band-to-band tunneling leakage characteristics of thin oxide MOSFETs are investigated by utilizing stacked-gate structure FETs. The behavior of threshold voltage variations under drain stress with open-circuit source is analyzed in detail. A simple lucky hole injection model is proposed to explain the behavior. Program-disturb phenomena in EPROM cells were well described by the model. The depletion layer along the channel formed by the applied drain voltage gives energy to cold holes created by band-to-band tunneling. Such lucky holes are injected easily and reach the gate electrode.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Digital--PROM; Semiconductor Materials--Charge Carriers; EPROM cells; Lucky-hole injection; Stacked gate transistors; Transistors, Field Effect

Title: Geologic map and geothermal assessment of the Mount Adams volcanic field, Cascade Range of southern Washington
Affiliations: U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hildreth, Wes, U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, United States; Fierstein, Judy, U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, United States
Abstract: More than 60 Quaternary vents make up the basalt-to-rhyodacite Mount Adams volcanic field and have erupted scoriae and lavas with a total volume of >370 km3. The Mount Adams andesite-dacite stratocone itself is a compound edifice that includes the high cone above 2300 m (20-10 ka), remnants of at least two earlier andesite-dacite cones as old as 0.5 Ma, and 7 Holocene flank vents. Four other Holocene vents and tens of vents contemporaneous with Mount Adams are peripheral to the stratocone. All of these vents, including Mount Adams, lie within a N-S eruptive zone 55 km long and 5 km wide. The age of all known Mount Adams silicic products (>100 ka) and the heterogeneous mafic compositions of the summit cone and Holocene lavas make it unlikely that the stratocone is underlain by an upper-crustal reservoir. Rather, the stratocone at the focus is built up of fractionated hybrid magmas that rise from MASH zones (melting-assimilation-storage-homogenization). The pyroclastic core of breccia and scoria at Mount Adams has undergone acid-sulfate leaching and deposition of alunite, kaolinite, silica, gypsum, sulfur, and Fe-oxides and has been a constant source of avalanches and debris flows. Most heat supplied from depth to the fumarolically altered core is dispersed by the high precipitation rate and high permeability of the rubbly lava flows so that a hydrothermal convection pattern is not maintained. Summit-restricted fumaroles are weak and diffuse.
Index Keywords: Geology - Tectonics; Geothermal Energy - Evaluation; Geothermal Fields - Exploration; Volcanoes; Flank Vents; Fumaroles; Melting Assimilation Storage Homogenization (MASH) Zones; Pyroclastic Core; Scoriae; Stratocone; Geological Surveys

Authors: Musicki Z., Hilal M.A., McIntosh G.E.
Title: Optimization of cryogenic and heat removal system of space borne magnets
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Musicki, Z., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Hilal, M.A., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; McIntosh, G.E., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Abstract: Space based superconducting magnets require a refrigerator system to maintain operating temperature at the design value. The magnets use helium gas cooled shields and multilayer insulation. Refrigerator power is determined based on the heat leak to the shields and to the magnet winding, as well as current leads and charging losses. Electric power is supplied by a power source such as a SP-100 type reactor or solar panels. Cryogenic and heat removal system masses included in the optimization are: the insulation and shields, the refrigerator, the power supply and the heat removal panel. The system is optimized to determine the optimum radiator temperature, superinsulation thickness, helium mass flow rate and helium inlet temperature to the shields.
Index Keywords: Cooling systems; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Heat transfer; Optimization; Refrigerators; Space applications; Heat removal systems; Helium gas cooled shields; Multilayer insulation; Space based superconducting magnets; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Superconducting magnets

Title: An accurate method for modeling transformer winding capacitances
Affiliations: Cow Creek Enterprises, Inc, Azalea,, OR, USA
Authors with affiliations: Collins, John A., Cow Creek Enterprises, Inc, Azalea,, OR, USA
Abstract: A simple method of modeling parasitic transformer capacitances is presented. This method allows determination of quantitative values for various transformer parasitic capacitances, allows the utilization of a transformer model for circuit analysis that takes the parasitic effects into account, provides a means of critically judging the merits of various winding configurations, and allows the designer to determine whether a given circuit configuration will increase or minimize the effect of transformer parasitic capacitance. Voltage and energy relationships are described for uniform field discrete capacitors. Terms that provide a precise way of characterizing these relationships are defined, and examples are given. Nonuniform field capacitive energy storage as found in layer-wound or toroid structures is investigated. With these relationships established, the modeling methodology is presented by a series of examples. It is shown that what appear to be small changes in circuit configuration can result in enormous changes in transformer parasitic effects.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric Networks - Equivalent Circuits; Electric Transformers - Losses; Energy Dissipation; Energy Storage; Mathematical Techniques - Vectors; Capacitive Energy Storage; Non-Uniform Field Energy Storage; Stored Energy Vectors; Transformer Parasitic Capacitances; Transformer Winding Capacitances; Electric Windings, Transformer

Authors: Andrianov V.V., Batenin V.M., Bashkirov Yu.A., Rumyantsev V.V.
Title: Superconducting magnetic energy storage for power system control
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Andrianov, V.V., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Batenin, V.M., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Bashkirov, Yu.A., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Rumyantsev, V.V., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The possibilities of using superconductor magnetic energy storages for the enhancement of reliability in the operation of power systems and power equipment are studied as well as the improvement of their performance. Some results obtained in this field of study at research institutions of the USSR are described. Information is provided on the planned building of an experimental facility comprising a 107-108 J superconductor storage and a 30 MW converter under the research program of the USSR State Committee for Science and Technology and Academy of Sciences.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Performance; Power system control; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Superconducting magnets

Title: Conceptual design of a 0.1 W magnetic refrigerator for operation between 10 K and 2 K
Affiliations: Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Moffett Field, United States
Authors with affiliations: Helvensteijn, Ben P.M., Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Moffett Field, United States; Kashani, Ali, Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Moffett Field, United States
Abstract: The design of a magnetic refrigerator for space applications is discussed. The refrigerator is to operate in the temperature range of 10 K-2 K, at a 2 K cooling power of 0.10 W. As in other magnetic refrigerators operating in this temperature range GGG has been selected as the refrigerant. Crucial to the design of the magnetic refrigerator are the heat switches at both the hot and cold ends of the GGG pill. The 2 K heat switch utilizes a narrow He II filled gap. The 10 K heat switch is based on a narrow helium gas gap. For each switch, the helium in the gap is cycled by means of activated carbon pumps. The design concentrates on reducing the switching times of the pumps and the switches as a whole. A single stage system (one magnet; one refrigerant pill) is being developed. Continuous cooling requires the fully stationary system to have at least two stages running parallel/out of phase with each other. In order to conserve energy, it is intended to recycle the magnetic energy between the magnets. To this purpose, converter networks designed for superconducting magnetic energy storage are being studied.
Index Keywords: Cryogenic liquids; Energy storage; Helium; Low temperature operations; Magnetic devices; Refrigerants; Space applications; Superconducting magnets; Switches; Converter networks; Gadolinium gallium garnet (GGG) pill; Heat switches; Magnetic refrigerator; Superconducting magnetic energy storage; Refrigerators

Title: Optimal design of cryogenic bucking cylinder for space borne toroidal magnets
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: AbdelMohsen, H.H., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Abdelsalam, M.K., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Abstract: The potential application of superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) in space necessitates the use of light weight coil supporting structure in an optimal configuration. This provokes the use of constant tension toroidal coil supported by optimal composite material structure. D shaped coil exhibits a constant tensile force to minimize the tensile structure mass. Compressive forces are to be reacted by the bucking cylinder. The present paper introduces material-, geometric-, and shape-optimal design of the bucking cylinder for space borne toroidal magnets.
Index Keywords: Composite materials; Cylinders (shapes); Design; Electric coils; Energy storage; Optimization; Space applications; Structural design; Cryogenic bucking cylinder; Optimal design; Space borne toroidal magnets; Superconducting magnets

Authors: Li Q., Li X., McIntosh G.E., Boom R.W.
Title: Minimization of total refrigeration power of liquid neon and nitrogen cooled intercepts for SMES magnets
Affiliations: Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, Q., Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China; Li, X., Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China; McIntosh, G.E., Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China; Boom, R.W., Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China
Abstract: The major advantages of liquid nitrogen and neon cooled heat intercepts over those cooled with helium gas are that nitrogen and neon boiling at constant temperatures holds the shield temperatures constant and these cryogens can be stored for long time operation without refrigeration. The major problem with helium cooling is that the shield starts to warm up immediately whenever refrigeration is interrupted because there is no reserve. The purpose of this work is to develop a procedure to minimize the total refrigerator power input requirement by locating the liquid nitrogen and neon cooled heat intercepts both on supports and in multilayer insulation. The optimization method is based on the Lagrange multipliers method and obtained results are normalized.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Cryogenic liquids; Helium; Mathematical models; Neon; Nitrogen; Optimization; Refrigeration; Heat intercepts; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) magnets; Total refrigeration power; Superconducting magnets

Authors: Ruiz J.M., Lorenzo S., Lobo I., Amigo J.
Title: Minimal UPS structure with sliding mode control and adaptive hysteresis band
Affiliations: Departamento de Tecnologia Electron, Universidad de Valladolid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Ruiz, J.M., Departamento de Tecnologia Electron, Universidad de Valladolid, Spain; Lorenzo, S., Departamento de Tecnologia Electron, Universidad de Valladolid, Spain; Lobo, I., Departamento de Tecnologia Electron, Universidad de Valladolid, Spain; Amigo, J., Departamento de Tecnologia Electron, Universidad de Valladolid, Spain
Abstract: The application of a sliding control mode based on a variable structure system (VSS) for an uninterruptable power system (UPS) is presented. The incorporation of adaptive control facilitates converter operation within a constant commutation frequency, adding an implicit harmonic control to the intrinsic voltage regulation capacity of the VSS systems. The converter is characterized by online generation and good transient performance. The validity of this technique is confirmed by computer simulation. As a consequence of the system's behavior, a minimal-UPS structure is proposed for operation in parallel with the utility grid. The resultant power converter can operate as a reactive power compensator, an energy storage system, and an active filter for the line.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Control Systems, Adaptive; Electric Converters, Static; Harmonic Generation - Spectrum Analysis; Hysteresis; Adaptive Hysteresis Band; FFT Analysis; Sliding Mode Control; Uninterruptible Power Suplies; Electric Power Supplies to Apparatus

Authors: Berganov I.R., Isayev R.I., Makhkamdzhanov B.M.
Title: Investigation of a self-contained solar power source for fiber-optic transmission systems
Source title: Telecommunications and Radio Engineering (English translation of Elektrosvyaz and Radiotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Berganov, I.R.; Isayev, R.I.; Makhkamdzhanov, B.M.
Abstract: One of the problems of introducing main line fiber optic transmission systems FOTS, is delivery of electric power to equipment at unattended regeneration points (URP). This problem arises because-trunk fiber-optic cables are manufactured without metallic cores that could be used for transmitting power to the URP. Using nuclear or thermal self-contained power sources for this purpose has not always been economically justified. Certainly, if a permanent electric power grid is available near the route, the URF equipment may be supplied from it. However, when there is no such opportunity, solar sources of electric power (SPS) merit attention; these are used in some countries for supplying the URP equipment. Development and operation of solar supplies require solution of a number of complex problems, the principal ones being creation of reliable and stable electric power supply sources; orientation of the photo-converters (PC) towards the Sun; prevention of contamination of the PC surface by various components of the air; determination of the optimal capacity of storage devices. The authors of this paper propose one solution of these problems: an experimental SPS is described, and data are given for the investigation of solar radiation in a Mid-Asian region, with statistical data for the contamination of a PC surface; these are used as a basis to determine the optimal capacity of the storage batteries.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Fiber Optics; Solar Energy; Solar Power Sources; Unattended Regeneration Points; Optical Communication

Authors: Crisenza G., Ghidini G., Manzini S., Modelli A., Tosi M.
Title: Charge loss in EPROM due to ion generation and transport in interlevel dielectric
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Agrate Brianza, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Crisenza, G., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Agrate Brianza, Italy; Ghidini, G., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Agrate Brianza, Italy; Manzini, S., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Agrate Brianza, Italy; Modelli, A., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Agrate Brianza, Italy; Tosi, M., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Agrate Brianza, Italy
Abstract: A new charge loss mechanism in EPROMs implying generation of mobile ions in the bulk of the interlevel dielectric is proposed. Mobile ions generated in the intermediate dielectric screen the negative charge stored into the floating gate. Charge release is a field-assisted thermally activated mechanism. The phosphorus content of the interlevel dielectric seems to increase the activation energy of the phenomenon. Experiments designed to directly evaluate interlevel dielectric ion generation have been performed. Finally, the impact of this new data loss effect on the scaling down of the EPROM cell has been evaluated.
Index Keywords: Dielectric Materials; Ions; EPROM; Interlevel dielectrics; Ion generation; Mobile ions; Data Storage, Digital

Title: Effects of high frequency injection and optical feedback on semiconductor laser performance
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Eastman Kodak Co, Rochester, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gage, Edward C., Eastman Kodak Co, Rochester, United States; Beckens, Scott, Eastman Kodak Co, Rochester, United States
Abstract: The dominant laser noise sources are mode hopping and mode partition noise. The former noise is particularly troublesome as it results from an alternation of the dominant laser mode, which causes output power fluctuations and irreproducible playback performance. At certain combinations of drive current, temperature, and optical feedback, this unstable behavior is observed. The second contributor, mode partition noise, is the broad-band noise associated with the transient variation in the partition of energy per mode.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Optical--Storage Devices; Noise, Spurious Signal; Mode Partition Noise; Optical Feedback; Optical Recording Heads; Lasers, Semiconductor

Title: Inductive energy insertion for SMES conductor stability testing
Affiliations: General Dynamics Space Systems Div, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gurol, H., General Dynamics Space Systems Div, San Diego, United States; Albert, G.W., General Dynamics Space Systems Div, San Diego, United States
Abstract: The objective of this paper is to discuss the experimental and modeling work performed to understand issues related to inductively transferring energy to a large cable-in conduit conductor (CICC) with an operating current of 200 kA. The goal of this energy insertion is to perform stability margin testing, one of several tests planned. A basic requirement of the test is the ability to insert about 1 Joule/cc in times ranging from 1-10 msec into the test conductor. A model was developed to estimate the distribution of induced current within the conductor. An RLC circuit was chosen using this model to ensure that the needed energy insertion could be accomplished. Tests were performed at room and cryogenic temperatures. Further validation of the approach used was provided by sub-scale conductor testing. Full-scale conductor testing is expected to be completed in Fall of 1989.
Index Keywords: Cryogenics; Electric current distribution; Electric energy storage; Induction heating; Low temperature testing; Networks (circuits); Stability; Cable in conduit conductor (CICC); Inductive energy insertion; Resistance inductance capacitance circuit; Stability margin testing; Superconducting cables

Authors: Johnson Donald E., Clements Neal D., Ruckstedter Eric
Title: Hyperconducting 5 MJ 1 MA pulse transformer
Affiliations: IAP Research, Inc, Dayton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, Donald E., IAP Research, Inc, Dayton, United States; Clements, Neal D., IAP Research, Inc, Dayton, United States; Ruckstedter, Eric, IAP Research, Inc, Dayton, United States
Abstract: Energy storage pulse transformers offer the possibility of storing energy at 10 to 50 kA and delivering power to the load at 1 MA or more. We sized a 5 MJ, 1 MA transformer with a coupling coefficient of 0.99. The transformer uses hyperconducting aluminum (high-purity aluminum in a high-strength aluminum matrix) cooled in liquid hydrogen as the primary conductor. The hyperconducting aluminum results in the smallest and lightest transformer design. In this paper we describe how we size closely-coupled (non iron-cored) transformers. We examine the effect of conductor strain, turns ratio, transformer shape, and coupling on the mass of the transformer. Finally, we size the 1 MA, 5 MJ transformer as an example of a full-scale system.
Index Keywords: Aluminum; Cooling; Couplings; Cryogenic liquids; Electric conductors; Energy storage; Hydrogen; Strain; Hyperconductivity; Pulse transformers

Title: Cryogenic equipment of liquid hydrogen powered automobiles
Affiliations: Messer Griesheim GmbH, Duesseldorf, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ewald, R., Messer Griesheim GmbH, Duesseldorf, Germany; Kesten, M., Messer Griesheim GmbH, Duesseldorf, Germany
Abstract: A possible consequence of the dramatic changes taking place within the global atmosphere because of uncontrolled consumption of fossil energy resources, is the eventual substitution of hydrocarbon fuels of our present transportation systems by pure hydrogen. Future hydrogen powered vehicles are most likely to use liquified cryogenic gas because of its superior storage efficiency compared to other hydrogen storage techniques. The paper describes the development and state of the art of mobile cryogenic storage tanks and supply systems currently realized in experimental hydrogen vehicles. Special attention is focussed on the design and performance of the liquid hydrogen vessel including the on-board installations for control and operation as well as the necessary external refueling system.
Index Keywords: Automobile engines; Automotive fuels; Cryogenic liquids; Fuel storage; Fuel systems; Hydrogen fuels; Synthetic fuels; Liquid hydrogen powered automobiles; Cryogenic equipment

Authors: Walker D.L., Kimball F.M., Kimmy E.R., Loyd R.J., Peck S.D., van den Bergh H.H.
Title: Design of a 200 kA conductor for superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES)
Affiliations: Space Systems Div, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walker, D.L., Space Systems Div, San Diego, United States; Kimball, F.M., Space Systems Div, San Diego, United States; Kimmy, E.R., Space Systems Div, San Diego, United States; Loyd, R.J., Space Systems Div, San Diego, United States; Peck, S.D., Space Systems Div, San Diego, United States; van den Bergh, H.H., Space Systems Div, San Diego, United States
Abstract: This paper reports the status of the design of a 200 kA conductor for a Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) system. The reasons for adopting the Cable-In-Conduit-Conductor concept were reported previously. A brief review of these reasons together with the conductor design requirements will precede a description of the method used to establish the detailed design of the conductor. This method utilized manufacturing development test and evaluation techniques to provide discriminators between several CICC configurations. The rationale for selecting the detailed design configuration is given together with a brief overview of conductor testing.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Superconducting magnets; Testing; Cable in conduit conductor (CICC); Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Electric conductors

Title: Sulfur sludge and its regulations: a case study at the Geysers KGRA, Lake County, California
Affiliations: Geysers Geothermal Co, Santa Rosa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crockett, Charlene L., Geysers Geothermal Co, Santa Rosa, United States
Abstract: The use of geothermal energy to produce electricity is environmentally benign in comparison to the use of fossil fuels. However, at The Geysers in Northern California, the resource contains hydrogen sulfide gas which is regulated by the local Air Pollution Control District and may not be emitted to the atmosphere without abatement. The abatement of H2S results in the production of a sulfur sludge which is sometimes hazardous. Federal and State regulations, administered by the Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Health Services respectively, regulate the treatment, storage and disposal of this sludge. The Department of Transportation regulates its transport from the site of generation to its disposal point. Regulations covering sulfur sludge and analysis of the options available for its disposal are discussed.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution - Control; Geothermal Energy - Applications; Hydrogen Sulfide - Legislation; Sewage Treatment - Sludge Disposal; Wastewater Treatment; Sulfur Sludge; Geothermal Springs

Authors: Kudo Kazuki, Yamada Ichiro, Katoh Kikuji
Title: Minimum energy positioning control in optical disk drives
Affiliations: NTT Appl Electron Lab,, Musashino-shi, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kudo, Kazuki, NTT Appl Electron Lab,, Musashino-shi, Tokyo, Japan; Yamada, Ichiro, NTT Appl Electron Lab,, Musashino-shi, Tokyo, Japan; Katoh, Kikuji, NTT Appl Electron Lab,, Musashino-shi, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: To achieve high-speed positioning in optical disk drives, optimal control and mechanical design are important. From this point of view, the construction of a practical minimum-energy positioning control system based on an optimal regulator is proposed. Calculations show that the proposed control can realize optical head positioning with almost constant positioning accuracy and power consumption per unit time for various positioning times. Experimental and calculated positioning trajectories of the optical head positioner agree well. Repetitive velocity errors are with 5 mm/s, and repetitive positioning errors are within ten tracks, indicating the effectiveness of the proposed control.
Index Keywords: Computer Peripheral Equipment--Disk Drives; Control Systems, Optimal--Applications; Data Storage, Optical--Disk; Calculated Positioning Trajectories; Minimum Energy Positioning Control; Optical Disk Drives; Optimal Regulator; Repetitive Velocity Errors; Control, Mechanical Variables

Title: Superconducting magnetic energy storage and other large-scale SDI cryogenic applications programs
Affiliations: Pentagon, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Verga, Richard L., Pentagon, Washington, United States
Abstract: The SDI Power and Power Conditioning program is sponsoring the development of a number of large-scale cryogenic and superconducting technologies. The largest of these programs is the development of Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) for terrestrial storage of energy for use in powering ground-based directed energy weapons. SMES also has application to the commercial electric utility industry, which is co-sponsoring the development of an Engineering Test Model (ETM). Other cryogenic applications under development by SDI for use in space power systems include hydrogen-cooled cryo-conductors, superconducting turbo-alternators and high temperature superconductor power leads.
Index Keywords: Cryogenics; Energy storage; Military engineering; Engineering test model (ETM); Ground based directed energy weapons; High temperature superconductor power leads; Hydrogen cooled cryoconductors; Power and Power Conditioning program; Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI); Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Superconducting turboalternators; Superconducting magnets

Authors: Cope David B., Snyder Mark D., Wiesman Richard M.
Title: Magnetic and structural design of a liquid hydrogen-cooled magnet utilizing high-purity aluminum conductors and a boron/epoxy composite as structural reinforcement
Affiliations: Foster-Miller, Inc, Waltham, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cope, David B., Foster-Miller, Inc, Waltham, United States; Snyder, Mark D., Foster-Miller, Inc, Waltham, United States; Wiesman, Richard M., Foster-Miller, Inc, Waltham, United States
Abstract: A novel design concept for a liquid hydrogen-cooled magnet with high-purity aluminum conductors is being developed. We propose a modified Brooks coil design in which the low-strength conductors are allowed to undergo limited plastic deformation. The conductors are supported by an advanced composite structure which limits the magnitude of the conductor plastic strains. The magnetic energy stored per unit mass of the device is 150 J/g. The need to limit strain-induced resistivity and minimize magnet weight led to the selection of a boron-epoxy composite as the structural reinforcement material. To investigate some of the structural mechanics of our design concepts, we utilized an axisymmetric finite element model. This model was subjected to both cooldown stresses and magnetic body forces. Initial numerical results have shown that the strain-induced resistivity can be limited to an acceptable value.
Index Keywords: Aluminum; Boron; Composite materials; Cryogenic liquids; Electric conductivity of solids; Electric conductors; Energy storage; Epoxy resins; Finite element method; Mathematical models; Reinforcement; Structural design; Brooks coil design; Magnetic energy storage; Plastic deformation; Plastic strains; Strain induced resistivity; Structural mechanics; Electromagnets

Authors: Matsuda Atsunori, Matsuno Yoshihiro, Kataoka Shigeyuki, Katayama Shinya, Tsuno Toshio, Tohge Noboru, Minami Tsutomu
Title: Pregrooving on glass disks by the sol-gel method (part 2) - effects of the addition of organic polymers on the formation of glass films in the SiO2-TiO2 system
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Nippon Sheet Glass Co, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsuda, Atsunori, Nippon Sheet Glass Co, Tsukuba, Japan; Matsuno, Yoshihiro, Nippon Sheet Glass Co, Tsukuba, Japan; Kataoka, Shigeyuki, Nippon Sheet Glass Co, Tsukuba, Japan; Katayama, Shinya, Nippon Sheet Glass Co, Tsukuba, Japan; Tsuno, Toshio, Nippon Sheet Glass Co, Tsukuba, Japan; Tohge, Noboru, Nippon Sheet Glass Co, Tsukuba, Japan; Minami, Tsutomu, Nippon Sheet Glass Co, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: The effects of the addition of polyethylene glycol (PEG) on the formation of gel-derived glass films in the SiO2-TiO2 system were studied, aimed at their application to the optical memory disks. The viscosity of the as-prepared sols increased almost linearly with increasing PEG content. The increase in viscosity of the sols during the storage was retarded with decreasing molecular weight of PEG added and with increasing amount of PEG added. The viscosity increase of the sols during the storage, however, showed a similar temperature dependence, i.e. almost the same apparent activation energy was obtained, in the sols containing different amounts of PEG. These findings indicate that PEG added to the SiO2-TiO2 sols scarcely reacts with the hydrolyzed inorganic species. The hardness of the resultant PEG-containing gel films greatly decreased with increasing PEG content. The gel films containing PEG of the smaller average molecular weight showed the higher hardness and the steeper increase in hardness with increasing the heat-treatment temperature than those containing PEG of the larger average molecular weight. For a high performance in the fine patterning process and densification of the resultant patterned films, PEG of the smaller amount and the smaller molecular weight is favorable, provided the PEG-containing gel films are initially soft enough to emboss fine patterns by pressing a stamper. Incorporated PEG in the SiO2-TiO2 gel films decomposed completely at temperatures over 300°C and had a very slight influence on chemical bondings in the resultant films.
Index Keywords: Films - Additives; Glass - Coatings; Optical Devices - Applications; Optical Properties; Glass Disks; Optical Memory Disk; Polymer Addition Effects; Pregrooving; Sol Gel Coating Technique; Data Storage, Optical

Title: 14th International LNG/LPG Conference and Exhibition - GASTECH 90
Abstract: This conference contains 33 papers. The subject matter is primarily concerned with various forms of natural gas and its production, trade, storage, marketability and energy utilization. Reliability evaluations are made for for LNG terminals and leakage monitoring systems. Membrane technology of purification and separation of gases is also studied. Plans for use of LNG and LPG in various countries is reviewed.
Index Keywords: Combustion--Measurements; Economics; Energy Resources--Costs; Structural Analysis--Thermal Effects; Tankers--Performance; EIREV; Large Scale Experiments; Leakage Monitoring System; Pressure Swing Absorption; Raw Material Supply; World Market; Natural Gas, Liquefied

Title: Proceedings of the 25th Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference - IECEC '90
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Abstract: Eighty two papers contained in this volume of the conference proceedings. The main topics are energy systems and policy impact on energy. On the topic of energy systems there are articles on thermal management, conservation, transportation, environmental issues, mechanical and thermal storage, alternative fuels etc. On the topic of policy impact on energy there are articles on energy for developing countries, greenhouse effect on energy choices and domestic policies
Index Keywords: Computers; Energy Conservation; Heat Exchangers; Heat Transfer; Mathematical Models; Direct Contact Heat Transfer; EiREV; Electrochemical Cell; Laminar Flow Heat Exchangers; Specific Fuel Consumption; Vapor Compression Air Conditioner; Energy Management

Authors: Fujii S., Tarumi H., Yuasa K.
Title: Application of cogeneration system to building equipments
Affiliations: Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujii, S., Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Tarumi, H., Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Yuasa, K., Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The secondary utilization of exhaust heat is consistent with the phase utilization of energy and it is especially effective for relatively low temperature operation such as heating, cooling, hot-water supply, etc. It is usually considered that cogeneration systems can reduce system fuel requirements because cogeneration makes simultaneous production of electric power and useful thermal energy that is normally discharged from power units such as engines and turbines. Moreover, they have many problems in commercial use such as balance of electricity and heat demands, correspondence between electricity and heat generation, large electricity fluctuation, etc. Therefore, it becomes important to evaluate the energy conservation effect on cogeneration systems. Particularly, in Japan, cogenerators have almost imperfect interconnection to the centralized electricity grid. Namely, most cogenerators are only able to purchase electric power, not to sell. In this paper, the authors discuss the energy conservation potential of commercial cogeneration systems.
Index Keywords: Electric Utilities; Energy Conservation; Heat Storage; Mathematical Models; Cogeneration Plants

Title: NASA's future space power needs and requirements
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Schnyer, A.Dan, NASA, Washington, DC, USA; Sovie, Ronald J., NASA, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The National Space Policy of 1988 established the US's long-range civil space goals, and has served to guide NASA's recent planning for future space mission operations. One of the major goals was to extend the human presence beyond earth's boundaries and to advance the scientific knowledge of the solar system. A broad spectrum of potential civil space mission opportunities and interests are currently being investigated by NASA to meet the espoused goals. Participation in many of these missions requires power systems with capabilities far beyond what exists today. In other mission examples, advanced power systems technology could enhance mission performance significantly. Power system requirements and issues that need resolution to ensure eventual mission accomplishment are addressed, in conjunction with the ongoing NASA technology development efforts and the need for even greater innovative efforts to match the ambitious solar exploration mission goals. Particular attention is given to potential lunar surface operations and technology goals, based on investigations to date. It is suggested that the nuclear reactor power systems can best meet long-life requirements as well as dramatically reduce the earth-surface-to-lunar-surface transportation costs due to the lunar day/night cycle impact on the solar system's energy storage mass requirements. The state of the art of candidate power systems and elements for the lunar application and the respective exploration technology goals for mission life requirements from 10 to 25 years are examined.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering--Energy Conversion; Electric Power Generation--Space Applications; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Space Research; Space Stations--Power Supply; Civil Space Missions; Energy Storage; Lunar Missions; Nuclear Reactor Power Systems; Solar Exploration; Space Missions; Spacecraft

Title: Siting compressed - air energy storage plants
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Electric Power Research Inst, Palo Alto, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mehta, B.R., Electric Power Research Inst, Palo Alto, United States
Abstract: Compressed - air energy storage (CAES) is a modular, environmentally acceptable and economically attractive energy storage technology. A 290 - MW, 4 hour plant has been operating in Huntorf, West Germany since 1979. Since early 1988, the first U.S. CAES 110 - MW, 26 - hour capacity plant is in construction and will be ready for commercial operations in mid - 1991. Both plants use solution-mined cavities for compressed - air storage. Many utilities are concerned about the availability and viability of sites for underground air storage. Many of these concerns can be resolved by using the extensive experience of the natural gas storage industry. This paper summarizes results of EPRI research for siting CAES plants in various geological formations. Geotechnical methods and examples are presented to help utilities evaluate air storage sites available in their service area.
Index Keywords: Compressed Air; Gas Turbine Power Plants - Energy Storage; Compressed Air Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Title: Water storage tank size requirements for residential heat pump/air-conditioner desuperheater heat recovery
Affiliations: A.O. Smith Corp, Seminole, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cook, Robert E., A.O. Smith Corp, Seminole, United States
Abstract: It is generally recognized that substantial amounts of service hot water can be generated from otherwise wasted condenser heat by proper application of a desuperheater to a residential heat pump or air conditioner. The actual heat recovered is highly dependent on water temperatures through the desuperheater, storage tank size to store the hot water recovered, piping, air conditioner/heat pump (AC/HP) capacity, and climate. This paper suggests tank size and piping strategies for such systems.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Heat Exchangers; Heat Exchangers--Efficiency; Heat Pump Systems--Heat Exchangers; Hot Water Supply Systems--Energy Conservation; Tanks--Design; Air Conditioner Desuperheaters; Condenser Heat Recovery; Heat Pump Desuperheaters; Heat Recovery Water Heaters; Water Storage Tank Design; Water Heaters

Title: Adaptive robust control scheme applied to a single-zone HVAC system
Affiliations: Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, Ye-Hwa, Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States; Lee, Kok-Meng, Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States
Abstract: This paper addresses the modeling and control of a heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) system while the system is operating under uncertainty. The uncertainty may be due to thermal storage effect, heat and moisture generation, or outside temperature and humidity change. These may be unpredictible for a generic room. The adaptive robust control proposed for this system will take the uncertainty into account. No statistical information of the uncertainty is ever needed. The uncertainty is assumed bounded but the bound is unknown.
Index Keywords: Control Systems, Adaptive--Synthesis; Control Systems--Computer Simulation; Probability--Random Processes; Adaptive HVAC System Control; Adaptive Robust Control Systems; Optimal Energy Utilization Control; Uncertain Dynamical System Control; Office Buildings

Authors: Drost Kevin, Antoniak Zen, Brown Daryl
Title: Thermal energy storage for an integrated coal gasification combined-cycle power plant
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Drost, Kevin, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA; Antoniak, Zen, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA; Brown, Daryl, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA
Abstract: An investigation is conducted of using molten nitrate salt thermal energy storage in an integrated gasification combined-cycle power plant to allow the facility to economically provide peak- and intermediate-load electric power. The results of the study show that an integrated gasification combined-cycle power plant with thermal energy storage can reduce the cost of coal-fired peak- or intermediate-load electric power by between 5% and 20% depending on the plant's operating schedule. The use of direct-contact salt heating can further improve the economic attractiveness of the concept.
Index Keywords: Coal Gasification Plants; Electric Power Generation; Combined Cycle Power Plant; Direct-Contact Salt Heating; Integrated Coal Gasification Plant; Molten Nitrate Salt Thermal Energy Storage; Peak-Load Electric Power; Thermal Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Authors: Tillmetz Werner, Dietrich Gunther, Benz Uwe
Title: Regenerative fuel cells for space and terrestrial use
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dornier GmbH, Friedrichshafen, West Germany
Authors with affiliations: Tillmetz, Werner, Dornier GmbH, Friedrichshafen, West Germany; Dietrich, Gunther, Dornier GmbH, Friedrichshafen, West Germany; Benz, Uwe, Dornier GmbH, Friedrichshafen, West Germany
Abstract: Electrolysis, fuel cell, and energy storage technologies are compared and evaluated. The use of a fuel cell and electrolyzer with an immobilized electrolyte is selected as the most promising technique. A comparison of the batteries demonstrates that a RFCS (regenerative fuel cell system) could be a serious competitor in future space activities, especially with increasing power level and energy to be stored. Also, for many terrestrial applications, highly efficient energy storage systems will be of great interest in the near future. Aspects of the terrestrial use of a RFCS are discussed.
Index Keywords: Electrolysis; Energy Storage; Electrolyzers; Regenerative Fuel Cells; Fuel Cells

Authors: Takahashi Isao, Amei Kenji, Itoh Youichi
Title: High performance and long life uninterruptible power source using a flywheel energy storage unit
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Nagaoka Univ of Technol, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, Isao, Nagaoka Univ of Technol, Japan; Amei, Kenji, Nagaoka Univ of Technol, Japan; Itoh, Youichi, Nagaoka Univ of Technol, Japan
Abstract: The development of a flywheel uninterruptible power supply incorporating electrolytic capacitorless inverters and converters, optocouplerless power device drive circuits, loss reduction of high-frequency insulated-gate bipolar transistor (IGBT) inverters, and high-response regeneration control of the induction motor is described. Results from experiments performed on a three-phase, 5-kVA uninterruptible power source show that the system provides over 15 years of life, 100% input power factor, a 1% output voltage distortion, and a 93.4% efficiency.
Index Keywords: Electric Converters; Electric Inverters; Electric Motors, Induction; Flywheels; Transistors, Bipolar; IG Bipolar Transistors; Uninterruptible Power Supplies; Electric Power Supplies to Apparatus

Authors: Fujii T., Igarashi M., Fushimi K., Hashimoto T., Hirota A., Itoh H., Jin-nai K., Hashimoto T., Kouzuma I., Sera Y., Nakayama T.
Title: Zinc/bromine battery development for electric power storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujii, T., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan; Igarashi, M., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan; Fushimi, K., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan; Hashimoto, T., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan; Hirota, A., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan; Itoh, H., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan; Jin-nai, K., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan; Hashimoto, T., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan; Kouzuma, I., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan; Sera, Y., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan; Nakayama, T., Meidensha Corp, Shinagawaku, Tokyo,, Japan
Abstract: The construction of a 1-MW-class zinc/bromine battery system for electric power storage is described. This battery is constructed of twenty-four 25-kW submodule batteries in series connection. The preshipment test method of the battery module, the maintenance and reliability of each submodule, and the design of the cooling system and cleaning apparatus for the pilot plant's exhaust are described in detail. It indicated that the life of a zinc/bromine battery is dependent upon the durability of a carbon-plastic electrode. The physical and chemical characteristics of the deteriorated electrode are analyzed.
Index Keywords: Bromine; Composite Materials; Electrodes; Energy Storage; Zinc and Alloys; Carbon-Plastic Electrodes; Cleaning Apparatus; Cooling Systems; Electric Power Storage; Zinc/Bromine Battery Systems; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Measurement of the velocity of natural convection movements in an LNG storage tank
Affiliations: Gaz de Fr, Nantes, France
Authors with affiliations: Marcel, O., Gaz de Fr, Nantes, France
Abstract: Natural convection movements resulting from energy inputs from inner walls frequently occur inside liquefied gas storage tanks. Whenever a stratification has developed within the stored LNG, these movements largely contribute to a sudden and unexpected homogenization, commonly called 'rollover', which often results in a considerable and undesirable production of gas. Currently, prediction models of the evolution within a liquefied gas storage tank do not take such movements into account. In fact, the so-called turbulent natural convection occuring inside large-size tanks has received little research attention. In order to improve our knowledge of this phenomenon and to provide the data required to validate the calculation codes, a system designed to measure convection velocity has been studied at the Onera Research Center in Toulouse. It was subsequently installed in the 500 m3 LNG storage tank at the Gaz de France Cryogenic Testing Station of Nantes.
Index Keywords: Data Processing--Data Acquisition; Heat Transfer--Convection; Cryogenic Testing Station; Storage Tanks; Natural Gas, Liquefied

Title: A solar assisted spherical capsule-type latent heat thermal energy storage/heat pump system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Yonezawa Tech High Sch, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hirose, Koichi, Yonezawa Tech High Sch, Japan; Saitoh, Takeo, Yonezawa Tech High Sch, Japan
Abstract: A unique latent heat thermal energy storage/heat pump (LHTES/HP) system using spherical capsules is proposed, and the experimental and simulated results are presented for when the system is operated as a solar energy system. It is shown that the supercooling of the phase change material (PCM), which has been one of the most serious problems in using many salt hydrates, can be resolved by the introduction of a heat pump, since the heat stored during the supercooling period can be utilized through the aid of the heat pump. The variation of the coefficient of performance (COP) of the heat pump, and the effects of the flow rate of the working fluid, the collector area, the ambient temperature, the capsule diameter, and other parameters on the thermal performance are examined via the prototype experiments and the computer simulation.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Heat Pump Systems; Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage/Heat Pump Systems; Phase Change Materials; Solar Energy Systems; Spherical Capsule; Supercooling; Solar Energy

Title: Energy dusted under the rug, or is there intelligent life on earth?
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Bay Technologies, Inc, Annapolis,, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Szego, George C., Bay Technologies, Inc, Annapolis,, MD, USA
Abstract: The author addresses the US energy and energy-connected environmental and economic crises. The 'musts' of US energy policy are outlined. Among them are 'energy plantations', salt ponds, establishing fuel consumption levels, offpeak electric energy storage via pumped hydro, thermal solar domestic water heaters, and passive solar housing.
Index Keywords: Biomass; Energy Resources; Fuels; Power Generation; Water Heaters--Solar; Energy Conservation; Energy Plantations; Passive Solar Housing; Pumped Storage Hydroelectric Power Plants; Salt Ponds; Energy Policy

Authors: Guyot-Sionnest P., Prazeres R., Ortega J.M., Bazin C., Bergher M., Billardon M., Couprie M.E., Velghe M., Petroff Y.
Title: Coherent harmonic generation with an optical klystron
Source title: XVII International Conference on Quantum Electronics. Digest of
Affiliations: Lab pour l'Utilisation du, Rayonnement Electromagnetique,, Centre Univ Paris-Sud, Orsay, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Guyot-Sionnest, P., Lab pour l'Utilisation du, Rayonnement Electromagnetique,, Centre Univ Paris-Sud, Orsay, Fr; Prazeres, R., Lab pour l'Utilisation du, Rayonnement Electromagnetique,, Centre Univ Paris-Sud, Orsay, Fr; Ortega, J.M., Lab pour l'Utilisation du, Rayonnement Electromagnetique,, Centre Univ Paris-Sud, Orsay, Fr; Bazin, C., Lab pour l'Utilisation du, Rayonnement Electromagnetique,, Centre Univ Paris-Sud, Orsay, Fr; Bergher, M., Lab pour l'Utilisation du, Rayonnement Electromagnetique,, Centre Univ Paris-Sud, Orsay, Fr; Billardon, M., Lab pour l'Utilisation du, Rayonnement Electromagnetique,, Centre Univ Paris-Sud, Orsay, Fr; Couprie, M.E., Lab pour l'Utilisation du, Rayonnement Electromagnetique,, Centre Univ Paris-Sud, Orsay, Fr; Velghe, M., Lab pour l'Utilisation du, Rayonnement Electromagnetique,, Centre Univ Paris-Sud, Orsay, Fr; Petroff, Y., Lab pour l'Utilisation du, Rayonnement Electromagnetique,, Centre Univ Paris-Sud, Orsay, Fr
Abstract: First results from the new synchrotron radiation facility SUPER-ACO are presented. This storage ring provides a stable (300-ps FWHM) e+-beam with a lower energy dispersion and higher current than ACO. The Nd:YAG laser oscillator has been modified by adding an acoustooptic mode-locker and an acoustooptic modulator with simple feedback and timing electronics to generate a stable pulse (300 ps FWHM with intracavity etalon) synchronized with the e+-packet. After amplification and frequency doubling, the system delivers 300-ps 100-mJ pulses at 532 nm with 5% stability, allowing the transfer of 150-MW peak power in the optical klystron. A significant improvement has been observed with approximately 3 × 108 photons/pulse at 173 nm, 1.5 × 106 at 106 nm, and approximately 105 at 76 nm in a 0.1-mrad angular spread. This is approximately 2 orders of magnitude better than on the ACO, and the stability of the third harmonic is also much better (20% peak to peak). These results are, however, less than theory would predict by nearly an order of magnitude. The temporal overlap of the laser and e+ pulses at high currents shows anomalous bunch lengthening that widens the cross correlation. At low current, the expected I2 dependence for a coherent process is observed, but at higher current the increased energy dispersion and bunch lengthening lead to saturation.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Synchrotron - Storage Rings; Acoustooptical Devices; Electron Tubes, Klystron; Lasers, Solid State - Mode Locking; Synchrotron Radiation; Digest of Paper; Positrons; Harmonic Generation

Authors: Capulli John, Donley Sam, Deligiannis Frank, Shen David
Title: Primary lithium cell life studies
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Capulli, John, TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA; Donley, Sam, TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA; Deligiannis, Frank, TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA; Shen, David, TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: One solution for providing a truly independent power source is to package, within the critical subsystem element, a primary battery that can remain dormant for time periods as long as the mission life, which can be 10-15 years, maximum. When primary power from the spacecraft solar array/battery system is interrupted, the backup battery system, which is connected through a diode to the power input line, would automatically support the load to avoid a power interruption to the critical load for a time period long enough to ensure that ground control could access the satellite and correct the anomaly by sending appropriate commands to the spacecraft. Critical subsystems identified for the application are telemetry and command circuits, volatile computer memory, attitude control circuits, and some critical payloads. Due to volume packaging and weight restrictions that exist on most spacecraft, coupled with the long storage periods required, lithium cell technology was selected for the backup power source. Because of the high energy density (200-400 Wh/kg), long shelf life, and load capability (approximately 0.5 A), soluble cathode primary lithium technology was chosen. The most important lithium cell properties that require detail characterization for this application are capacity loss, shelf life, and the voltage delay mechanism. These are functions of storage time and temperature. During storage, a passive film builds up on the lithium electrode. The film protects the lithium electrode from progressive capacity decay but requires time to break down when a load is applied. This phenomenon results in a depressed voltage during the period of film breakdown which can last from fractions of a second to minutes.
Index Keywords: Satellites; Spacecraft; Backup Battery Systems; Electric Batteries

Title: Plans for natural gas importation into Greece. The LNG terminal at Revythousa Island
Affiliations: Public Gas Corp of Greece (DEPA) S A, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Dragatakis, L., Public Gas Corp of Greece (DEPA) S A, Athens, Greece
Abstract: The gas industry in Greece dates back to 1857 with the installation of the city gas manufacturing plant in Athens. This facility was operated until 1984 by the Municipal Gas Company of Athens. Gas produced by naphtha catalytic reforming is presently supplied to about 8,000 customers connected to the distribution network in the central Athens area. Current plans for the expansion of use of natural gas in Greece are based on the actual and expected energy consumption, within the sectors in which gas is competitive with other energy sources, ie. industrial, commercial, central heating and domestic sectors. Natural gas will replace oil products eg. fuel oil, gas oil and LPG and also electricity in domestic use for cooking and hot water. The target is to substitute 12% of the primary energy demands of the country with natural gas.
Index Keywords: Natural Gas Pipelines--Greece; Combustion Vaporizers; Revythousa Island; Storage Tanks; Natural Gas, Liquefied

Title: Performance monitoring of an adsorption heat pump. Model development and simulation studies
Affiliations: LIMSI-CNRS
Authors with affiliations: Meunier, F., LIMSI-CNRS; Zanife, T., LIMSI-CNRS
Abstract: Performance monitoring of an adsorption heat pump has been studied in a case of hot water delivery to a slaughterhouse when heat demand is a very irregular function of time. As the heat delivered by an adsorption heat pump is discontinuous, a heat storage tank has been used. The influence of the heat transfer fluid mass flow rate in the heat pump is very important because a low mass flow rate yields a high temperature lift but a low efficiency, a high mass flow rate produces instabilities on the condenser and yields a low efficiency, and an intermediate mass flow rate yields a reasonable efficiency and a correct temperature lift. Nevertheless, after a very large peak demand, the temperature requirement is not satisfied and a 7% dissatisfaction of the needs is obtained. To get 100% satisfaction of the needs, it would probably be necessary to overdesign the heat pump and the boiler.
Index Keywords: Boiler Firing--Gas; Energy Storage--Effects; Heat Pump Systems--Performance; Heat Transfer--Computer Simulation; Adsorption Heat Pumps; Heat Pump System Simulation; Hot Water Heating Systems; Hot Water Storage; Hot Water Supply Systems

Title: Reducing energy costs and peak electrical demand through optimal control of building thermal storage
Affiliations: Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Braun, James E., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, United States
Abstract: This paper describes an investigation into the use of building thermal capacitance as a means of reducing the operating costs associated with maintaining adequate comfort conditions in buildings (termed 'dynamic building control'). The state of the building thermal storage can be controlled through variations of the zone temperatures over time within the thermal comfort region. The primary opportunities in varying zone setpoints in an optimal fashion are associated with shifting cooling loads from daytime to nighttime to (1) reduce peak electrical demands, (2) take advantage of low nighttime electrical rates, (3) offset mechanical cooling with 'free' cooling at night, and (4) enhance equipment operation at more favorable part-load conditions. The approach utilized in this study was to apply dynamic optimization techniques to computer simulations of buildings and their associated cooling systems for a range of conditions in order to determine the maximum possible savings. Results indicate that both energy costs and peak electrical use can be significantly reduced through optimal control of the intrinsic thermal storage within building structures. However, the cost savings depend upon several factors, including (1) utility rate structure , (2) part-load characteristics of the cooling plant and air-handling system, (3) weather, (4) the occupancy schedule, and (5) building thermal capacitance.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Energy Conservation; Buildings--Energy Storage; Control Systems, Optimal--Performance; Energy Storage--Control Systems; Energy Utilization--Costs; Building Thermal Energy Storage; HVAC System Operating Cost Reduction; Optimal Energy Storage Control Systems; Peak Electrical Demand Reduction; Office Buildings

Authors: Borger William U., Massie Lowell D.
Title: Space systems requirements and issues: The next decade
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Aero Propulsion & Power Lab,, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Borger, William U., Aero Propulsion & Power Lab,, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH, USA; Massie, Lowell D., Aero Propulsion & Power Lab,, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH, USA
Abstract: Some of the more important space power technology issues, requirements, and challenges are described, and the impact of new component technology on the overall performance of space power systems is assessed. Advanced component, subsystem, and system technologies which will make a difference in the future in terms of the performance, reliability, and survivability of next-generation baseload and burst-mode space power systems are emphasized. Technology disciplines related to power sources (solar, nuclear, and chemical), power conversion, energy storage, power conditioning, distribution, and control, and waste heat acquisition, transport, and rejection are addressed. For some of these technology disciplines, performance trends are developed which can be used on the basis for projecting future advanced power system performance. Performance capabilities for several different types of space power systems for both baseload and burst-mode applications are postulated based on evolving technology and point designs which incorporate projections of advanced component capabilities. The technology options for meeting higher power baseload (5-100 kW steady state) and burst mode power requirements (tens to hundreds of Megawatts/hundreds to thousands of seconds) are summarized.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Space Applications; Power Generation; Solar Cells; Space Stations--Power Supply; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Nuclear Reactors; Photovoltaic Technology; Power Conditioning; Regenerative Fuel Cells; Space Power Systems; Spacecraft Batteries; Aerospace Engineering

Authors: Takashima Koichiro, Ishimaru Fuminari, Kunimoto Asao, Kagawa Hiroshi, Matsui Kazumasa, Nomura Eiichi, Matsumaru Yuji, Kita Akira, Iijima Shigeru, Kato Takehiko, Matsuo Yasushi, Nakayama Taesuke, Sera Yousuke
Title: A plan for a 1MW/89MWh sodium-sulfur battery energy storage plant
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takashima, Koichiro, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Ishimaru, Fuminari, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Kunimoto, Asao, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Kagawa, Hiroshi, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Matsui, Kazumasa, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Nomura, Eiichi, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Matsumaru, Yuji, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Kita, Akira, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Iijima, Shigeru, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Kato, Takehiko, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Matsuo, Yasushi, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Nakayama, Taesuke, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan; Sera, Yousuke, Yuasa Battery Co, Ltd, Takatsuki,, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: A number of 300-Ah Na-S cells and 20 pieces of thermally insulating casings are being manufactured together with other necessary equipment for building a 1-MW/8-MWh battery energy storage plant in a substation of a utility company. The construction of the building in which the plant will be installed is complete, and a part of the equipment is being installed. The manufacturing of the cells will continue to the end of spring 1991, but by the end of the summer of 1990, when half of the cells will have been manufactured, one half of the plant (corresponding to a rating of 500 kW/4000 kWh) will be constructed, and testing will begin. The testing will include various performance tests which evaluate battery performance, inverter performance, and system performance as well as the compatibility with the utility network. While the test is being carried out, the remaining half of the system will be constructed to make a complete 1-MW/8-MWh Na-S battery energy storage system. The complete system will also be tested.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Sodium and Alloys; Sulfur; Sodium Sulfur Batteries; Electric Batteries

Authors: Drost M.K., Antoniak Z.I., Brown D.R.
Title: Thermal energy storage for power generation applications
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Drost, M.K., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Antoniak, Z.I., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Brown, D.R., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Abstract: Studies strongly indicate that the United States will face widespread electrical power constraints in the 1990s. In many cases, the demand for increased power will occur during peak and intermediate demand periods. While natural gas is currently plentiful and economically attractive for meeting peak and intermediate loads, the development of a coal-fired peaking option would give utilities insurance against unexpected supply shortages or cost increases. This paper discusses a conceptual evaluation of using thermal energy storage (TES) to improve the economics of coal-fired peak and intermediate load power generation.
Index Keywords: Fossil Fuel Power Plants - Energy Storage; Nitrate Salts; Thermal Energy Storage; Electric Power Generation

Title: Analytical solution of heat transfer problems in a cylindrical packed-bed energy storage system
Affiliations: Univ of Nigeria, Nsukka, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Onyejekwe, David C., Univ of Nigeria, Nsukka, Nigeria; Nwoke, Christian, Univ of Nigeria, Nsukka, Nigeria
Abstract: The paper discusses the heat transfer processes involved in a packed-bed energy storage system. Equations describing these processes are formulated. These equations are solved analytically using Laplace's transform. Sample calculations based on experimental results are employed to illustrate the use of the general solution.
Index Keywords: Cylinders; Energy Storage; Mathematical Transformations--Laplace Transforms; Packed-Bed Energy Storage; Heat Transfer

Authors: Kaun T.D., Duoba M.J., Gillie K.R., Hash M.C., Simon D.R., Vissers D.R.
Title: Development of a sealed bipolar Li-alloy/FeS2 battery for electric vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Nat Lab, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kaun, T.D., Argonne Nat Lab, IL, USA; Duoba, M.J., Argonne Nat Lab, IL, USA; Gillie, K.R., Argonne Nat Lab, IL, USA; Hash, M.C., Argonne Nat Lab, IL, USA; Simon, D.R., Argonne Nat Lab, IL, USA; Vissers, D.R., Argonne Nat Lab, IL, USA
Abstract: A bipolar Li-alloy/FeS2 battery with molten LiCl-LiBr-KBr electrolyte and MgO powder separator is being developed. Such a battery would be operated at 400-425°C and is expected to attain high performance and long cycle life (>1000 cycles). An overcharge-tolerant cell design safeguards the Li-alloy/FeS2 cells in the bipolar battery and allows charge equalization with simple trickle charging. New ceramic materials have been developed for use as the peripheral hermetic seals required for electrolyte containment in bipolar cells. A stack of four bipolar Li-alloy/FeS2 cells with these seals has been operated for over 150 cycles. The projected performance for a prototype sealed bipolar Li-alloy/FeS2 battery is 191-Wh/kg specific energy and 500-W/kg peak specific power through 80% depth of discharge. Outstanding electric-vehicle performance can be expected from such a battery.
Index Keywords: Iron Compounds; Lithium and Alloys; Seals; Storage Battery Vehicles; Electric Vehicles; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Unconventional systems for lunar base power generation and storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Waldron, R.D., Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA
Abstract: The extended duration of the lunar night and the high specific mass of Earth-imported energy storage systems (regenerative fuel cells, batteries, etc.) render PV (photovoltaic) and import storage power systems noncompetitive with nuclear power plants for lunar bases. However, power storage or generation methods which can be constructed using primarily lunar materials, used either alone or with lightweight PVs, can be attractive alternatives to nuclear power. Three generic systems which can provide favorable low-import-mass goals have been identified and studied: 1) gravitational energy generation using lunar soil; 2) thermal energy storage using basalt rock or glass; and 3) electrochemical storage using lunar-derived electrodes or fuels. The design, structural, and operational features of these methods are described.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Energy Storage; Nuclear Power Plants; Soils; Spacecraft--Lunar Missions; Electrochemical Storage; Gravitational Energy Generation; Lunar Basalt Rock; Lunar Derived Electrodes; Lunar Derived Fuels; Thermal Energy Storage; Power Generation

Title: Energy/environment potential impact of hydrogen fueled engines operating on road vehicles
Affiliations: Univ di Pisa, Pisa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Dini, D., Univ di Pisa, Pisa, Italy
Abstract: An investigation on vehicle concepts for the future is carried out, referring to the application of hydrogen fueled engines and their impact on environment. Methods to augment engine power output and to store hydrogen in the car are analyzed. Environmental problems and availability in favour of hydrogen are considered. Present high output car hydrogen operating engines, at low or high pressure injection, with liquid, metal hydride, storage, or with hydrogen 'carrier' as methylcyclohexane and ammonia, are compared in their performances, both for Otto and Diesel cycles. On the basis of a review of already experienced engines, a proposal for a hydrogen fueled car to satisfy energy, environment and economy, needs is made. It is finally discussed on results of tests of engines operating with hydrogen-enriched gasoline and diesel fuel, referring, in particular, on extensive test program carried out in cooperation with VM Motori S.p.A. for a pollution-free Diesel engine.
Index Keywords: Automobile Engines - Environmental Impact; Hydrogen Fuels - Environmental Impact; Direct Cylinder Hydrogen Injection; Future Vehicle Concepts; High Output Car Hydrogen Engines; Hydrogen-Powered Vehicles; Low Pressure Injection Engine System; Internal Combustion Engines

Title: Development of common pressure vessel nickel/hydrogen batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee,, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Zagrodnik, J., Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee,, WI, USA; Jones, K., Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee,, WI, USA
