Abstract: The individual pressure vessel (IPV) nickel/hydrogen battery, well established as an energy storage subsystem for commercial communication satellites, was adapted to terrestrial applications by developing unique design features and implementing standardized production methods that have resulted in substantial reductions in cost. One of the key design variations of the terrestrial battery is the use of a common pressure vessel (CPV). Although the potential advantages of the CPV concept have been recognized for some time, practical application was inhibited by several design issues. These included concerns of electrolyte bridging between cells, electrolyte/oxygen management, and heat dissipation. CPV battery technology for terrestrial and aerospace applications is discussed.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering; Communication Satellites--Power Supply; Electrodes--Nickel; Hydrogen; Pressure Vessels; Common Pressure Vessels; Electrolytes; Energy Storage; Individual Pressure Vessels; Nickel/Hydrogen batteries; Terrestrial Batteries; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Optimal control of ice harvesting thermal energy storage systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Paul Mueller Co, Springfield, MO,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Knebel, David E., Paul Mueller Co, Springfield, MO,, USA
Abstract: A method of optimal control for an ice harvesting chiller thermal energy storage system is defined. Optimal control of the ice harvester includes the variation of build time and defrost time as a function of saturated discharge temperature. Optimal control of the ice build/defrost cycle can save 15% of the required energy to produce the ice. Annual optimization can be used to reduce energy consumption by operating a smaller compressor for the longest period of time. The cooling equipment operates with predictive and reactive controls in order to limit instantaneous power input, thereby reducing annual energy input. Methods of cooling inventory measurement, capacity prediction, and capacity control are described.
Index Keywords: Cold Storage; Control Systems; Refrigeration; Chillers; Ice Harvesting; Optimal Control; Thermal Energy Storage Systems; Ice

Title: Nickel-titanium (NiTi) application for synthetic ligament of the knee
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Bioengineering Division (Publication) BED
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Masson, M., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: Three are currently no prosthetic knee ligament devices that have the required combination of low elastic modulus, high strength and fatigue resistance that could withstand millions of repetitive motion cycles without fiber breakage. This paper presents an alternate design that uses Nickel-titanium unique characteristics for the construction of a deformable high energy storage device. The proposed synthetic ligament is designed to satisfy the requirements imposed by the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL). The flexible 200 mm prototype is composed of a three stage arrangement of superelastic NiTi strips. Its strength, stiffness, and shape recovery properties are similar to that of the human ACL.
Index Keywords: Biomaterials; Materials With Memory; Nickel Titanium Alloys - Medical Applications; Anterior Cruciate Ligament; Shape Memory Effect; Super Elastic NT Alloy; Synthetic Ligament; Prosthetics

Title: Complex-compound low-temperature TES system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rocky Res Corp, Boulder City, NV,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rockenfeller, Uwe, Rocky Res Corp, Boulder City, NV,, USA; Kirol, Lance D., Rocky Res Corp, Boulder City, NV,, USA
Abstract: Development of a complex-compound low-temperature TES (thermal energy storage) system is described from basic chemical principles through current bench-scale system development. Important application engineering issues and an economic outlook are addressed as well. The system described uses adsorption reactions between solid metal inorganic salts and ammonia refrigerant. It is the coordinative nature of these reactions that allows for storage of ammonia refrigerant within the solid salt crystals that function as a chemical compressor during on-peak periods (substituting the mechanical compressor) and release ammonia during off-peak periods, while a mechanical vapor compression system provides the necessary reactor pressure and heat.
Index Keywords: Ammonia - Applications; Refrigerants; Adsorption Reactions; Amonia Refrigerant; Solid Metal Inorganic Salts; Solid Salt Crystals; Thermal Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Abstract: Vol. 6 of this 6 vol. conference contains 61 papers dealing mainly with the following subjects: USAF space power requirements; space power systems; isotopic fueled power systems; space power automation; power system hardware and design selection; power components; advanced space solar cells; advanced piston engines and systems; thermionic systems; space nickel-hydrogen batteries; space nickel-cadmium batteries; high voltage thermal cells; space fuel cells;space battery developments; superconducting bearings; magnetic bearings; advanced sulfur control strategies for coal; integrated environmental controls; thermal energy storage; ice technology; alternative fuels; energy policy; energy from waste and biomass; solar thermal systems; wind systems; Stirling cooler developments; Stirling solar terrestrial systems; Stirling engine generator sets; MHD underwater propulsion; underwater vehicle powerplants; advanced nuclear power reactor concepts; characterization of ion beam damaged photovoltaic devices.
