Title: Modular design expands applications of pumped storage
Affiliations: Pacific Turbine Systems Inc, San Francisco, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eastwood, John E., Pacific Turbine Systems Inc, San Francisco, United States; Olsen, David, Pacific Turbine Systems Inc, San Francisco, United States
Abstract: Pumped storage is widely recognized as the most efficient available technology for the storage of electrical energy. Escalating regulatory difficulties, together with high costs and long construction times, however, have led many utilities to abandon pumped storage as a resource option. Modular Hydroelectric Pumped Storage (MHPS) is a proprietary design approach revolving around two man-made reservoirs which standardizes major components of plant engineering and construction. Key elements of the design are outlined, new applications of pumped storage resulting from this approach are discussed, and preliminary indications of the effect of the design approach on permitting, costs and schedules are presented.
Index Keywords: Reservoirs; Structural Design--Costs; Closed System; Man-Made Reservoirs; Modular Hydroelectric Pumped Storage; Hydroelectric Power Plants

Title: New applications of superconductive magnetic energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dept of Electr Eng, Virginia, Polytech Inst & State Univ,, Blacksburg, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tam, Kwa-Sur, Dept of Electr Eng, Virginia, Polytech Inst & State Univ,, Blacksburg, VA, USA
Abstract: Three new applications of superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) technology are introduced. The first is to use SMES for the support of large-scale use of renewable energy sources such as solar photovoltaics (PV) and wind energy. The second is to use SMES in the form of a SMES/DC link to enhance economic energy interchanges between interconnected power systems. The third is to use SMES to enhance the utilization of existing power transmission facilities and to deal with the problems facing the transmission networks of the United States today. These new applications do not exclude each other or other applications of SMES. Through careful design, a SMES system installed for diurnal load leveling can also be used for one or more of these new applications to enhance various aspects of power system operation. Using one SMES system for several functions improves the economics of SMES and will make SMES a very attractive technology for the power and energy industries.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems - Interconnection; Load Leveling; Renewable Energy Sources; Superconducting Magnets

Title: Economic analysis of the energy storage technologies in the electric generation mix
Affiliations: Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Industry, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Uchiyama, Y., Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Industry, Tokyo, Japan; Nagata, Y., Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Industry, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The study aims to develop an economic analysis model to evaluate load leveling profits derived by transferring energy from on-peak to off-peak hours. A simulation model operated by a personal computer was developed to calculate the expected benefits when energy storage technologies are introduced into an electric generation mix. Compressed-air energy storage (CAES) is chosen to evaluate load-leveling profits in the model. The result shows that CAES is estimated to be installed in the early year of next century and its installed capacity would be increased in proportion as share of nuclear in the total electricity output becomes increased.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation - Applications; Electric Power Generation - Simulation; Compressed Air Energy Storage Technology; Electric Generation Mix; Electric Power Source Modelling; Energy Storage Technologies; Energy Storage

Title: Latent heat thermal energy storage and waste heat reuse in a single periodic kiln
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Israel
Authors with affiliations: Solomon, A.D., Israel
Abstract: An analytical description is given of the performance of a single brick plant kiln that reuses waste heat and that stores latent heat thermal energy. Expressions are found for the time-varying optimal distribution of waste heat and heat derived from the thermal storage system. The relevant mass flow rate is calculated for a typical kiln.
Index Keywords: Thermodynamics; Waste Heat Utilization; Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage; Mass Flow Rate; Optimal Distribution of Waste; Single Brick Plant Kiln; Single Periodic Kiln; Waste Heat Reuse; Heat Storage

Authors: Bourne Richard, Hoeschele Marc, Lindeleaf Warren, Kallett Richard
Title: Integrated thermal energy storage systems: Field test results in Sacramento, California
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Davis Energy Group, Inc, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bourne, Richard, Davis Energy Group, Inc, CA, USA; Hoeschele, Marc, Davis Energy Group, Inc, CA, USA; Lindeleaf, Warren, Davis Energy Group, Inc, CA, USA; Kallett, Richard, Davis Energy Group, Inc, CA, USA
Abstract: Integrated thermal energy storage (ITES) systems, which deliver full heat-pump space conditioning and water heating with compressor operation largely off-peak, offer electric utilities a promising option for improving competitiveness with gas heating and control of power supply and rate uncertainties. ITES system installation includes a large outdoor unit, one or more indoor fan-coil units with associated supply/return ductwork, and connecting piping. The outdoor units, available in 3.5- and 5.0-ton sizes, may be placed in either freestanding or built-in positions. A large, well-insulated space conditioning thermal storage tank comprising the lower half of the outdoor unit stores ice and chilled water in summer and hot water in winter. The ITES system controller selects from three operating modes based on programmed instructions which consider time of year, time of day, outdoor conditions, and storage conditions. Key findings from a pilot program are provided.
Index Keywords: Buildings - Climate Control; Electric Utilities; Heat Pump Systems; Reliability; Full Heat-Pump Space Conditioning; IETS Systems; Indoor Fan-Coil Units; Integrated Thermal Energy Storage Systems; Supply/Return Duct Work; Thermal Storage Tank; Energy Storage

Authors: Bado P., Coe S., Luc Tapie L., Squier J., Mourou Gerard, Harter D.J.
Title: Ultrahigh peak power generation from terawatt to petawatt
Source title: XVII International Conference on Quantum Electronics. Digest of
Affiliations: Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bado, P., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; Coe, S., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; Luc Tapie, L., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; Squier, J., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; Mourou, Gerard, Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; Harter, D.J., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. The concept of chirped pulse amplification allows efficient amplification of ultrashort pulses by superior energy-storage materials. Terawatt peak power pulses are routinely produced by tabletop systems, and large-scale lasers are harnessed to produce pulses at the petawatt level--1 kJ in 1 Hz. Recent advances in the field of ultrahigh peak power generation and their limitations are discussed.
Index Keywords: Laser Beams; Abstract Only; High Power Laser Pulses; Pulsed Lasers; Ultrahigh Power Lasers; Ultrashort Pulses; Laser Pulses

Authors: Sarangapani S., Lessner P., Forchione J., Griffith A., LaConti A.B.
Title: Proton exchange membrane electrochemical capacitors
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Giner, Inc, Waltham, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sarangapani, S., Giner, Inc, Waltham, MA, USA; Lessner, P., Giner, Inc, Waltham, MA, USA; Forchione, J., Giner, Inc, Waltham, MA, USA; Griffith, A., Giner, Inc, Waltham, MA, USA; LaConti, A.B., Giner, Inc, Waltham, MA, USA
Abstract: Electrochemical capacitors that are free of liquid electrolyte are described. These capacitors consist of electrodes of RuO2 mixed with an ionomer electrolyte which are bonded to an ionomer membrane to form a membrane and electrode assembly (MEA). Individual MEAs can be stacked in series as bipolar elements to form a multiple cell device. The discharge characteristics and energy storage properties of these devices are described. These characteristics are discussed with respect to possible modes of energy storage.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electrolytes; Membranes; Protons; Ruthenium Compounds; Proton Exchange Membranes; Electrodes, Electrochemical

Title: 1990 Annual Meeting of the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers, Technical and Symposium Papers
Abstract: This conference proceedings is the second of two volumes and contains 112 papers on the design and performance of heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) systems for building climate control. The papers discussed deal with heat exchanger design, the use of adsorption and absorption heat pumps, the performance of ozone-safe alternative refrigerants, HVAC system energy conservation, heat transfer enhancing tube heat exchanger configurations, the use of artificial intelligence in HVAC system design, building retrofit insulation performance monitoring, HVAC systems for semiconductor cleanrooms, developments in HVAC education, underfloor air conditioning systems, pressurized stairwells and other smoke control technologies, intelligent HVAC system diagnostics, laboratory and process exhaust systems, electric lighting/HVAC system interaction, digital control of water chillers and cooling towers, optimally controlled thermal energy storage in buildings, central air conditioning system design, integrated HVAC control systems, and the use of municipal solid waste as a fuel for district heating and cooling.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Energy Conservation; Artificial Intelligence--Applications; Heat Exchangers--Design; Heat Pump Systems--Design; Refrigerating Machinery--Design; Air Conditioning System Design; Building HVAC System Design; EiREV; Intelligent Building Design; Semiconductor Cleanroom HVAC Systems; Thermal Energy Storage Systems; Buildings

Title: Combined energy balance and recursive least squares method for the identification of system parameters
Affiliations: Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Zaheer-uddin, M., Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: A combined energy balance and least squares method is used to develop a simple, recursively updated model of a building. In this model, energy balance principles are first used to obtain an estimate of the two most important parameters of a building: heat loss and heat storage. These parameters are then supplied as base values to the least squares model. The effect of this strategy on the accuracy of the predictions from the combined model is investigated. The predictions are compared with the output obtained from a detailed model.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Energy Utilization; Energy Utilization--Mathematical Models; Statistical Methods--Applications; Thermodynamics--Mathematical Models; Building Energy Use Models; Energy Balance Theory; Recursive Least Squares Estimation; System Parameter Identification; Buildings

Authors: Oowa M., Nakaiwa M., Akiya T., Fukuura H., Suzuki K., Ohsuka M.
Title: Formation of CFC alternative R134a gas hydrate
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: National Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Oowa, M., National Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Nakaiwa, M., National Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Akiya, T., National Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Fukuura, H., National Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Suzuki, K., National Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Ohsuka, M., National Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: The use of R134a as an alternative refrigerant for refrigerant gas hydrate as cool storage material was studied. The pressure-temperature phase diagram was determined experimentally. From the phase diagram, the critical decomposition temperature, pressure, and the heat of formation were obtained. The formation-decomposition tests of the gas hydrate were carried out by changing the temperature of the cell with time using a temperature-controlled bath. The relationship between the degree of supercooling and aging temperature was obtained. The effects of n-butyl alcohol on the formation of the gas hydrate were also studied. When n-butyl alcohol was added, it was found that the degree of supercooling was smaller, and the formation of the gas hydrate was smoother. It was found that R134a gas hydrate seemed to be usable for cool storage material.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Mathematical Models; Physical Chemistry; Thermodynamics; CFC Alternative; Cool Storage Material; Critical Decomposition Temperature; Formation-Decomposition Tests; Pressure-Temperature Phase Diagram; R134a Gas Hydrate; Refrigerants

Authors: Hewko Lubomyr O., Weber Trudy R.
Title: Hydraulic energy storage based hybrid propulsion system for a terrestrial vehicle
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: General Motors Res Lab, Warren, MI,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hewko, Lubomyr O., General Motors Res Lab, Warren, MI,, USA; Weber, Trudy R., General Motors Res Lab, Warren, MI,, USA
Abstract: Three classes of hydraulic hybrid systems--the pure hydrostatic, the hydromechanical, and the power assist--have been modeled, analyzed, and their behavior over US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) driving and performance schedules simulated. Their fuel economy and performance potential have been established. The class of power assist systems was identified as showing the greatest potential for passenger-car application and was analyzed in greater detail. A practical vehicular powertrain based on a power-assist system was configured for a 3625-lb inertia weight class car and optimized with respect to the component/subsystem sizes. Subsequently, energy management and control strategies were developed with the objective of maximizing fuel economy without degrading performance. The findings of this study are summarized, and the main results for the power-assist propulsion system are presented. Improvement in fuel economy, predicted through simulation of the optimized hybrid system, is 77% on the EPA urban, 6% on the highway, and 44% on the 55/45 combined driving schedule, while its acceleration performance remains equal to that of the conventional baseline vehicle.
Index Keywords: Control Systems; Energy Management; Fuel Economy; Propulsion - Hydraulic Energy; Hybrid Propulsion System; Hydraulic Energy Storage; Power Assist Systems; Terrestrial Vehicle; Vehicular Powertrain; Automobiles

Authors: Maloney Thomas M., Leibecki Harold F.
Title: Modeling and optimization of a regenerative fuel cell system using the ASPEN process simulator
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sverdrup Technology Inc, Brook Park,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Maloney, Thomas M., Sverdrup Technology Inc, Brook Park,, OH, USA; Leibecki, Harold F., Sverdrup Technology Inc, Brook Park,, OH, USA
Abstract: The hydrogen-oxygen regenerative fuel cell system has been identified as a key component for energy storage in support of future lunar missions. Since the H2-O2 regenerative electrochemical conversion technology has not yet been tested in space applications, it is necessary to implement predictive techniques to develop initial feasible system designs. The ASPEN simulation software furnishes a constructive medium for analyzing and optimizing such systems. A rudimentary regenerative fuel cell system design has been examined using the ASPEN simulator, and this modular approach allows for easy addition of supplementary ancillary components and easy integration with life-support systems. The modules included in the preliminary analyses may serve as the fundamental structure for more complicated energy storage systems. The objectives, approach, and results of this simulation are discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Electrochemistry; Energy Storage; Mathematical Models; Spacecraft--Lunar Missions; ASPEN Process Simulator; Hydrogen-Oxygen Regenerative Electrochemical Conversion; Hydrogen-Oxygen Regenerative Fuel Cell Systems; Modular Construction; Software Package ASPEN; Fuel Cells

Title: Heat-transfer characteristics of a latent heat thermal energy storage unit with a finned tube
Affiliations: Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sasaguchi, Kengo, Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Abstract: In the previous report [1], a method of three-dimensional numerical calculation was proposed to obtain the performance of a finned-tube-type latent heat thermal energy storage unit, and the validity of the calculations was checked by comparing the calculated results with experimental ones. In this report, calculations have been carried out to examine the effects of various parameters appearing in the governing equations on the heat transfer in the solidification process, and the range of these parameters in which the fin effects are significant is examined.
Index Keywords: Heat Exchangers--Finned Tubes; Heat Transfer--Tubes; Fusion Temperature; Latent Heat; Solidification Processes; Heat Storage

Title: Non-flow zinc/halogen storage cell with thin film polymer composites
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dept of Mater Res, Weizmann Inst of, Sci, Rehovot, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Manassen, J., Dept of Mater Res, Weizmann Inst of, Sci, Rehovot, Israel; Cabasso, I., Dept of Mater Res, Weizmann Inst of, Sci, Rehovot, Israel
Abstract: A report is presented on zinc/halogen batteries that do not have a flowing electrolyte, but have it absorbed on activated carbon and are intermediate between a liquid- and a solid-state system. In principle the halogen, which is formed when a potential is applied, is absorbed on a high surface activated carbon (if necessary mixed with anion exchange beads) present at the cathode side, while a lower surface area activated carbon is present at the anode side, where it acts as a base for the very small zinc particles formed during charge. The zinc and halogen compartments are separated by a thin polymer composite, which typically contains 15-20 wt% of polymer and 80-85 wt% of the electrolyte. Under these conditions the polymer composite is dimensionally stable and can be prepared in advance before it is introduced into the cell. The efficiency and energy density of this kind of cell are dependent on two variables: the amount of bromine which can be absorbed and the total amount of zinc bromide available.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Polymers - Thin Films; Zinc and Alloys; Zinc-Halogen Batteries; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Encapsulated ice thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Reaction Thermal Systems, Inc, Napa,, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Laybourn, David R., Reaction Thermal Systems, Inc, Napa,, CA, USA
Abstract: One recent advancement in the area of energy storage involves the concept of encapsulated ice for cooling storage in air conditioning systems. Its benefits are the practicality of the concept and its potential to gain widespread acceptance by the building industry. The encapsulated ice concept is attractive to the building owner, the architect and general contractor, the mechanical designer, and the system operators. The following issues are discussed: (1) locating the storage vessel on the property, (2) integration into the building heat, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) system, (3) system costs compared to benefits, and (4) the risk, liability, acceptance, and general feasibility.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Buildings; Heating; Ventilation; Encapsulated Ice; HVAC Systems; Thermal Energy Storage; Ice

Title: Remotely maintained waste transfer pump
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eargle, John C., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Abstract: Westinghouse Savannah River Company (WSRC) operates the Savannah River Site (SRS) for the Department of Energy (DOE). Waste from the processing of irradiated material is stored in large shielded tanks. Treated liquid wastes are to be transferred from these tanks to the Defense Waste Processing Facility (DWPF) for incorporation in glass suitable for storage in a federal repository. Characteristics of the wastes range from water-like liquid to highly viscous wastes containing suspended solids. Pumping head requirements for various conditions ranged from 10 meters (35 feet) to 168 meters (550 feet). A specially designed, cantilever type, remotely operated and maintained pump was designed and built to transfer the wastes. To demonstrate the design, a prototype pump was built and tested thoroughly with simulated waste. Severe vibration problems were overcome by proper drive shaft selection and careful control of the space between the pump shaft and fixed running clearances (sometimes called seals). Eleven pumps are now installed and six pumps have been successfully run in water service.
Index Keywords: Maintenance - Remote Control; Radioactive Materials - Robot Applications; Radioactive Wastes - Pumps; Robots - Materials Handling Applications; Savannah River Site; Waste Transfer Pump; Pumps

Title: Cooling cost minimization using building mass for thermal storage
Affiliations: US Army Construction Engineering, Research Lab, United States
Authors with affiliations: Snyder, M.E., US Army Construction Engineering, Research Lab, United States; Newell, T.A., US Army Construction Engineering, Research Lab, United States
Abstract: A model has been developed to determine the least-cost cooling strategy for a building by using the building mass for thermal storage. The savings is achieved by subcooling the mass immediately before the peak utility rate period, thereby shifting a portion of the cooling load off-peak. The method described formulates an objective function based on the energy consumption of a simple building model. The building is subject to thermal loads from solar and ambient temperature influences. Daily energy use is broken up into three phases: coast-up, maintenance, and subcooling, which are multiplied by an appropriate energy cost to find the total daily cooling cost. The cooling cost is then optimized with respect to an appropriate independent variable. Analytical results using the characteristics of a light commercial structure have shown cooling cost savings of 18% when compared to base case simulations.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Energy Conservation; Buildings--Energy Storage; Energy Utilization--Costs; Building Cooling Cost Minimization; Building Cooling Load Reduction; Building Off-Peak Hour Precooling; Building Thermal Energy Storage; HVAC System Energy Management; Office Buildings

Title: Evaluation of a flywheel hybrid electric vehicle drive
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Ottawa,, Ont, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Flanagan, R.C., Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Ottawa,, Ont, Canada; Keating, M., Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Ottawa,, Ont, Canada
Abstract: A program is described whose objective is to develop an advanced concept electric vehicle that will utilize a flywheel/electric surge power unit. The applications model and analysis presented simulates a minivan operating on the Federal Urban Drive Schedule (FUDS) with an all-electric powertrain. With the flywheel/electric surge power unit, it is shown that both battery load leveling (constant current or power) and the FUDS cycle performance requirements could be easily met. The Powell multidimensional algorithm is used to optimize and size powertrain components. Based on the optimization results together with component size sensitivity, overall costs, and cooling requirements, the following components are selected: (1) flywheel energy storage = 500 Wh; (2) flywheel motor/alternator = 40 kW rated; (3) drive motor/alternator = 100 kW rated; and (4) battery mass = 1000 kg. With these components, the average battery power required to operate over the FUDS cycle is only 8.5 kW, and the vehicle driving range is estimated at 182 km.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Flywheels; Mathematical Models; Optimization; Applications Model; Electric Vehicles; Federal Urban Drive Schedule (FUDS); Flywheel/Electric Surge Power Unit; FUDS Cycle Performance; Vehicles

Title: Long-range optimal strategy of plutonium utilization
Affiliations: Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Industry, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamaji, K., Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Industry, Tokyo, Japan; Nagano, K., Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Industry, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The paper describes an analysis of long-range plutonium utilization strategy with a fuel cycle optimization model; FCOM. Major findings of the analysis are summarized as follows; 1) interim storage of spent fuels provides the most economical option for adjusting the plutonium supply/demand; 2) the level of reprocessing costs controls the optimal timing and scale of plutonium recycling in light water reactors; 3) conditions under which fast breeder reactors are chosen in the optimal strategy are numerically classified.
Index Keywords: Energy Management; Energy Utilization; Nuclear Reactors, Breeder - Control; Plutonium and Alloys - Applications; Fast Breeder Reactors (FBR); Fuel Cycle Optimization Model (FCOM); Nuclear Reactors, Fast

Title: Utilisation of alternative energy for preservation of fruits. Case study
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, India
Authors with affiliations: Mithani, R.D., Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, India; Mukhopadhyay, M., Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, India
Abstract: This case study analyses the viability of utilising alternative energy for heating water from an array of solar flat plate collectors vis-a-vis for generating steam from a biodigestor gas-fired boilers with a view to cold storing 25 tonnes of apples or fruits having similar properties.
Index Keywords: Biogas--Energy Utilization; Cold Storage--Design; Food Products--Preservation; Solar Energy--Economics; Alternative Energy Utilization; Apples Preservation; Case Study; Economic Evaluation; Fruit Preservation; Energy Utilization

Authors: McElroy J.F., Molter T.W., Moulthrop L.C.
Title: SPE regenerative hydrogen/oxygen fuel cells for a lunar base power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: United Technologies, Windsor Locks,, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: McElroy, J.F., United Technologies, Windsor Locks,, CT, USA; Molter, T.W., United Technologies, Windsor Locks,, CT, USA; Moulthrop, L.C., United Technologies, Windsor Locks,, CT, USA
Abstract: A description is given of hydrogen/oxygen regenerative fuel cells which could be used for a lunar base electrical power system. Also briefly described are SPE fuel cells and SPE electrolyzers. A refinement in system requirements with a major effect on the system was the change from a constant 25-kWe power plant output to a 25 kWe lunar day power requirement and a 12.5 kWe lunar night power requirement. This nearly halves the mass of the energy storage subsystem and significantly reduces volume. The use of a tracking photovoltaic array rather than a fixed array is currently being considered. This approach allows the charging of the energy storage system through essentially the entire lunar day. This reduces both the mass of the required energy storage system fluids, which are a major system mass, and the charging electrolyzers. Additionally, a power system bus voltage of 150 VDC has been selected on a preliminary basis. This, in combination with the power requirements, allows the energy storage system designer to select appropriate cell sizes for electrolyzers and fuel cells.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems; Hydrogen; Oxygen; Electrolyzers; Lunar Bases; Fuel Cells

Authors: Ferrano Frank J., Wong Kau-Fui Vincent
Title: Prediction of thermal storage loads using a neural network
Affiliations: Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ferrano, Frank J., Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, United States; Wong, Kau-Fui Vincent, Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, United States
Abstract: The objective of the present work is to develop a neural network computer program to predict the next-day cooling load and use this prediction in conjunction with a real-time expert system to simulate management of a cold thermal storage system. The next-day cooling load prediction allows the ice thermal storage system to maximize off-peak utility rates and minimize mechanical system operation. The management system is designed to be used by mechanical engineers in the field of air-conditioning control and maintenance. The computer program is written with the aid of commercially available neural network computer software. The temperature data base includes hourly ambient temperature values for a typical year in Miami, Florida. The technique used to predict the required ice production of the thermal storage system is conducted by training a neural network with the use of definition, fact, and training network files. Once the network is trained, any temperature pattern for a 24-hour period can be used to calculate the required next-day cooling load. Neural network training included unique temperature patterns for 'cold' and 'warm' weather fronts, as well as seasonally adjusted 'normal' temperature patterns. The resulting cold thermal storage prediction is then entered into a real-time expert system for the control of the overnight chiller operation and ice storage production.
Index Keywords: Computer Systems, Digital--Real Time Operation; Control Systems, Programmed; Energy Conservation; Expert Systems--Performance; Neural Networks--Applications; Cold Thermal Storage Systems; Expert Thermal Storage Management Systems; Neural Network Based Expert Systems; Real Time Expert Systems; Thermal Storage Load Prediction; Air Conditioning

Authors: Ashour Sami S., Hanna Owen T.
Title: New explicit ODE procedures for energy system digital simulation
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dept of Chem & Nucl Eng, Univ of, California, Santa Barbara, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ashour, Sami S., Dept of Chem & Nucl Eng, Univ of, California, Santa Barbara, CA, USA; Hanna, Owen T., Dept of Chem & Nucl Eng, Univ of, California, Santa Barbara, CA, USA
Abstract: In many aerospace computer simulations, the system of differential equations to be integrated numerically is of the stiff variety, where there may be widely disparate effective time constants corresponding to the different components of behavior being simulated. In such a situation, traditional, explicit methods (such as Runge-Kutta, etc.) may not always perform well, owing to the stability requirements of the stiff system. In such a case, certain specially designed implicit methods may be appropriate, but they require considerably more storage and computation and more sophisticated computer programs. To alleviate these problems, the authors have previously developed several simple explicit integration procedures with enhanced stability properties. These methods are useful for many stiff problems, but they have the disadvantage of a relatively low order of accuracy. A method which combines enhanced stability with third-order accuracy is presented. This is accomplished at the price of certain additional derivative evaluations. The new procedure is tested on some typical stiff problems, and comparisons are made to the traditional nonstiff RK2 method and to the other explicit stiff methods previously developed by the authors.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems; Mathematical Techniques - Integration; Digital Simulation; Energy Systems; Computer Simulation

Authors: Kerslake Thomas W., Ibrahim Mounir B.
Title: Two-dimensional model of a Space Station Freedom thermal energy storage canister
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kerslake, Thomas W., NASA, Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Ibrahim, Mounir B., NASA, Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: The solar dynamic power module being developed for Space Station Freedom uses a eutectic mixture of LiF-CaF2 phase-change salt contained in toroidal canisters for thermal energy storage. Results of heat transfer analyses of the phase-change salt contaminant canister are presented. A two-dimensional, axisymmetric finite-difference computer program which models the canister walls, salt, void, and heat engine working fluid coolant was developed. Analyses included effects of conduction in canister walls and solid salt, conduction and free convection in liquid salt, conduction and radiation across salt vapor filled void regions, and forced convection in the heat engine working fluid. Void shape, location, and growth or shrinkage (due to density difference between the solid and liquid salt phases) were prescribed based on engineering judgment. The salt phase change process was modeled using the enthalpy method. The influence of free-convection in the liquid salt on canister heat transfer performance is evaluated and shown to be important for interpreting the relationship between ground-based canister performance (in 1-g) and expected on-orbit performance (in micro-g). Attention is also focused on the influence of void heat transfer on canister wall temperature distributions. The large thermal resistance of void regions is shown to accentuate canister hot spots and temperature gradients.
Index Keywords: Heat Storage; Salts - Space Applications; Energy Storage Canisters; Phase-Change Salt; Salt Phase Changes; Space Station Freedom; Thermal Energy Storage; Space Stations

Title: Analysis of the transient characteristics of the water/steam cycle at a heat and power plant with fluidized bed combustion
Source title: Proceedings of the International Centre for Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Aachen Univ of Technology, Aachen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schumacher, U., Aachen Univ of Technology, Aachen, Germany; Renz, U., Aachen Univ of Technology, Aachen, Germany
Abstract: Coal-fired power stations in Europe with thermal power outputs less than 150 MW are equipped with fluidized bed combustors. For such power plants investigations have been made on furnace and on boiler support systems. For the efficient operation of such power plants an accurate knowledge of the transient operation characteristics is needed, e.g. in case of a failure of a certain component or a sudden decrease in the load. Therefore the response of the system due to such disturbances were evaluated and modelled. The mathematical simulation of the two hours of unsteady behaviour of the water/steam cycle took more than 14 hours calculation time using method 1 on the CYBER 175 computer system at the Aachen University. With method 2 which neglects the time-dependent terms of the mass and momentum equations the calculations were completed after only 300 seconds. Both methods provide good results for cases in which changes in the energy storage are predominant.
Index Keywords: Combustion--Fluidized Beds; Energy Storage--Calculations; Steam--Mathematical Models; Discretized Conservation; Stoker Boilers; Cogeneration Plants

Title: Electrical power subsystem initial sizing
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Martin Marietta Astronautics,, Denver, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Moser, R.L., Martin Marietta Astronautics,, Denver, CO, USA
Abstract: A guide to the basics of performing the initial electrical power subsystem (EPS) sizing for a spacecraft using solar cells for the energy source and batteries for energy storage is presented. The basic engineering input is described. The output is the first estimate of the number of solar cells, the solar array area, and the number of batteries required. The energy balance equation was developed, along with the equations to find the beginning of life (BOL) solar array power, from the end of life (EOL) solar array power. It is emphasized that the number of batteries must be calculated in two ways: (1) based on the watthour requirement from the batteries in the eclipse and (2) based on the peak power demanded from the battery and the peak allowed discharge current from the battery cell. A spreadsheet program to keep track of the input, perform the calculations, and document the input and output has been written.
Index Keywords: Computer Programming - Spreadsheet; Electric Power Systems; Solar Cells - Space Applications; Electric Power Subsystems; Spacecraft

Authors: Salyer Ival O., Sircar Anil K.
Title: Phase change materials for heating and cooling of residential buildings and other applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Dayton Res Inst, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Salyer, Ival O., Univ of Dayton Res Inst, OH, USA; Sircar, Anil K., Univ of Dayton Res Inst, OH, USA
Abstract: A series of commercially available normal paraffins that, in terms of cost/performance and overall merit, constitute the most attractive PCMs (phase change materials) for known solar passive and active applications have been defined and tested. These normal paraffin PCMs span the entire -50°C to +135°C temperature range and have heats of fusion and crystallization greater than 40 cal/g, exhibit no supercooling, are nontoxic, noncorrosive, nonhygroscopic, nonhydrolyzable, and are available in quantity at a cost of around $0.50/lb. The melting and freezing temperature of the PCM can be tailored and thereby precisely located in the desired temperature range by blending the nearest neighbors without significant loss in the heat of fusion and crystallization. In solar-passive applications, the total technology developed can be used in building materials including plaster, plasterboard, cement, cement blocks, etc., to provide thermal energy storage in the 25°C comfort temperature range. Several methods or processes for packaging and containerizing the PCM in building materials such as plaster, cement, bricks, etc., have been developed. Each of the containerization methods may be useful for specific types of application, and all should provide for good heat transfer. Fire-retardant formulations that in laboratory-scale tests were self-extinguishing were developed, and this was achieved with minimum loss in thermal energy storage capacity.
Index Keywords: Bridges, Concrete; Heating; Hydrocarbons; Materials - Phase Transitions; Solar Energy; Heats of Crystallization; Heats of Fusion; Paraffin PCM; Phase Change Materials for Cooling; Phase Change Materials for Heating; Buildings

Title: Innovative approaches for off-peak air conditioning of small commercial buildings
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Calmac Manufacturing Corp,, Englewood, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: MacCracken, Mark M., Calmac Manufacturing Corp,, Englewood, NJ, USA
Abstract: A description is presented of a system that will change older cooling units into much more efficient off-peak air conditioners. First, an air-cooled central chiller is installed along with ice storage tanks either on or beside the building. Second, a set of supply and return headers are placed along the roof to each of the existing rooftop units in parallel. Finally, the cooling coils are modified from direct expansion refrigerant type to a liquid brine type. This is done by removing the separate refrigerant distributor tubes and adding a larger manifold pipe. The only other components in the existing unit are the blower and controls. The rest of the pieces in the refrigerant circuit (compressor, condenser, condenser fans, etc.) are not needed. This constitutes a complete working system. The only complication that may arise is if the existing liquid coil in the units are undersized when converted to the brine system. This is overcome by adding eutectic salts to the thermal storage tanks in order to depress their freezing point from 32°F to 28°F. This lower temperature increases the log mean temperature difference at the air-handling coil, thereby increasing coil performance.
Index Keywords: Buildings - Climate Control; Electric Power Utilization; Energy Storage; Air-Cooled Central Chiller; Cooling Coils; Ice Storage Tanks; Off-Peak Air-Conditioning; Refrigerant Circuit; Rooftop Units; Air Conditioning

Authors: Johnson Bruce G., Adler Karen P., Anastas George V., Downer James R., Eisenhaure David B., Goldie James H., Hockney Richard L.
Title: Design of a torpedo inertial power storage unit (TIPSU)
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge,, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, Bruce G., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge,, MA, USA; Adler, Karen P., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge,, MA, USA; Anastas, George V., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge,, MA, USA; Downer, James R., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge,, MA, USA; Eisenhaure, David B., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge,, MA, USA; Goldie, James H., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge,, MA, USA; Hockney, Richard L., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge,, MA, USA
Abstract: A report is presented on extending flywheel energy storage technology to develop a system--a torpedo inertial power storage unit (TIPSU)--that is capable of form, fit, and function replacement of the current torpedo thermal batteries. The design phase is directed at developing subsystem models needed to accurately size the components, developing system tradeoffs between competing configurations, and developing a baseline design. The resulting design consists of an input DC to fixed-voltage, fixed-frequency AC inverter, a high-speed induction motor, a 90,000-rpm cylindrical flywheel, a brushless, permanent-magnet (PM), rotating-backiron generator, and output rectification of filtering electronics. This design can support the electrical load requirements of the cross-over battery and is reusable.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Flywheels; Naval Vessels; Thermal Effects; Current Torpedo Thermal Batteries; Cylindrical Flywheel; Fixed-Voltage, Fixed Frequency AC Inverter; High-Speed Induction Motor; Torpedo Inertial Power Storage Unit; Torpedoes

Title: Use of clathrates for 'off peak' thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Thermal Energy Storage, Inc, San, Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: McCormack, Richard A., Thermal Energy Storage, Inc, San, Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: A discussion is presented of the Snopeak cool storage system, which utilizes clathrate chemistry to store latent energy from 42°F to 47°F, thus permitting a ready interface with most currently installed chiller systems. Design considerations and system operation are given. Maintenance considerations are outlined, and energy conservation factors are described.
Index Keywords: Buildings - Climate Control; Energy Conservation; Maintenance; Refrigerants; Thermodynamics; Chiller Systems; Clathrate Chemistry; Clathrates; Energy Conservation Factors; Off-Peak Thermal Energy Storage; Snopeak Cool Storage System; Energy Storage

Authors: Tamme R., Grozinger U., Gluck A., Kanwischer H., Neitzel U.
Title: Advanced regenerator media for industrial and solar thermal applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: DLR, Institut fuer Technische, Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Tamme, R., DLR, Institut fuer Technische, Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West, Germany; Grozinger, U., DLR, Institut fuer Technische, Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West, Germany; Gluck, A., DLR, Institut fuer Technische, Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West, Germany; Kanwischer, H., DLR, Institut fuer Technische, Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West, Germany; Neitzel, U., DLR, Institut fuer Technische, Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West, Germany
Abstract: The composite salt/ceramic thermal energy storage (TES) media concept has the potential of using phase-change materials (PCM) via direct-contact heat exchange and, therefore, the potential of significant storage-capacity improvement and cost reduction. It allows for new industrial and solar thermal applications. Lab-scale materials of Na-Ba-CO3/MgO and of Na2SO4/SiO2 have been successfully developed.
Index Keywords: Composite Materials; Energy Storage; Heat Exchangers; Silica - Applications; Solar Energy; Composite Salt/Ceramic Thermal Energy Storage; Industrial Thermal Application; Phase-Change Materials; Regenerator Media; Solar Thermal Application; Heat Storage

Title: Thermal performance of a solar collector heating water on the station roof
Source title: Quarterly Report of RTRI (Railway Technical Research Institute) (Japan)
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Lab
Authors with affiliations: Sawase, Kazuhisa, Mechanical Engineering Lab
Abstract: In order to melt the snow on the large 20,000 square meter roof area of Nagaoka station on the Joetsu Shinkansen line, an aquifer thermal energy storge system is being used which keeps large amounts of solar energy collected on the station roof in summer until it is needed in the winter. Owing to the thermal performance of the aquifer, it is possible to inject a large volume of water at high temperature into the aquifer, effectively storing the thermal energy from summer to winter. However, there is such a large heat loss due to evaporation that the solar collector efficiency is very low. It is shown that a collector for obtaining solar energy by pouring water down a roof channel covered with vinyl sheets is very promising for reasons of its high collection efficiency and simple design.
Index Keywords: Aquifers--Applications; Plastics Sheets--Applications; Solar Energy--Energy Storage; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Water Heaters--Solar; Aquifer Based Heat Storage Systems; Roof Snow Melting Systems; Solar Collector Efficiency; Solar Energy Based Water Heating Systems; Vinyl Sheet Evaporation Suppressors; Railroad Plant and Structures

Authors: Zmood R.B., Pang D., Anand D.K., Kirk J.A.
Title: Improved operation of magnetic bearings for flywheel energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dept of Commun & Electr Eng, R, Melbourne Inst of Technol, Vic,, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Zmood, R.B., Dept of Commun & Electr Eng, R, Melbourne Inst of Technol, Vic,, Australia; Pang, D., Dept of Commun & Electr Eng, R, Melbourne Inst of Technol, Vic,, Australia; Anand, D.K., Dept of Commun & Electr Eng, R, Melbourne Inst of Technol, Vic,, Australia; Kirk, J.A., Dept of Commun & Electr Eng, R, Melbourne Inst of Technol, Vic,, Australia
Abstract: Analysis and operation of prototype 500-Wh flywheel at low speeds have shown that many factors affect the correct functioning of the magnetic bearings. An examination is made of a number of these, including magnetic bearing control system nonlinearities and displacement transducer positioning, and their effects upon the successful operation of the suspension system. It is observed that the bearing control system is extremely sensitive to actuator parameters such as coil inductance. As a consequence of the analysis of bearing relaxation oscillations, the bearing actuator design methodology which has previously been used, where coil parameter selection is based upon static considerations, has been revised. Displacement transducer sensors which overcome the collocation problem are discussed.
Index Keywords: Control Systems; Electric Coils; Energy Storage; Flywheels; Displacement Transducer Sensors; Bearings

Authors: Hall David K., Lollar Louis F.
Title: Development of an automated electrical power subsystem testbed for large spacecraft
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Marshall Space Flight Center,, Huntsville, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hall, David K., NASA Marshall Space Flight Center,, Huntsville, AL, USA; Lollar, Louis F., NASA Marshall Space Flight Center,, Huntsville, AL, USA
Abstract: The NASA Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC) has developed two autonomous electrical power system breadboards. The first breadboard, the autonomously managed power system (AMPS), is a two power channel system featuring energy generation and storage and 24-kW of switchable loads, all under computer control. The second breadboard, the space station module/power management and distribution (SSM/PMAD) testbed, is a two-bus 120-Vdc model of the Space Station power subsystem featuring smart switchgear and multiple knowledge-based control systems. NASA/MSFC is combining these two breadboards to form a complete autonomous source-to-load power system called the large autonomous spacecraft electrical power system (LASEPS). LASEPS is a high-power, intelligent, physical electrical power system testbed which can be used to derive and test new power system control techniques, new power switching components, and new energy storage elements in a more accurate and realistic fashion. LASEPS has the potential to be interfaced with other spacecraft subsystem breadboards in order to simulate an entire space vehicle. The two individual systems, the combined systems (hardware and software), and the current and future uses of LASEPS are described.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering--Computer Applications; Computer Architecture; Control Systems; Electric Power Systems--Testing; Space Stations--Power Supply; Large Autonomous Spacecraft Electrical Power System (LASEPS); Smart Switchgear; Spacecraft Subsystem Breadboards; Spacecraft

Title: Magnetic propulsion in free space fields
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Staldenstrasse, Untersiggenthal, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Marek, Alois, Staldenstrasse, Untersiggenthal, Switzerland
Abstract: An autonomous closed object containing several superconducting loops, an energy reservoir, and some control can be steered to fly and stay at rest in free space more or less at will, if some conditions upon the external magnetic field and upon some object parameters are fulfilled. Qualitatively similar but less favorable properties may be expected from an object containing diamagnetic foils instead of superconducting loops. Thrust is produced by varying the internal state of the object by changing either the fluxes trapped in the loops or the angular orientation of the diamagnetic foils with respect to an internal frame.
Index Keywords: Control Systems; Energy Storage; Magnetic Levitation; Magnetism - Diamagnetism; Satellites; Diamagnetic Foils; Superconducting Magnets

Title: Performance prediction of a small-scale photovoltaic refrigerator
Affiliations: Univ of Melbourne, Parkville, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Charters, William W.S., Univ of Melbourne, Parkville, Australia; Aye, Lu, Univ of Melbourne, Parkville, Australia
Abstract: A computer program has been developed to predict the long-term performance of small-scale photovoltaic refrigeration systems (SSPVRS) having storage batteries. The method is based on radiation statistics, utilizability and monthly-average hourly cooling load. Predicted results of the computer program were compared with experimental data of an existing SSPVRS. The predicted results showed an overall error less than about 15 percent.
Index Keywords: Computer Software; Refrigerators - Performance; Solar Energy; Photovoltaic Refrigeration System; Refrigeration

Authors: Griebenow Bret L., Martinson Lori M.
Title: Robotic system for remote inspection of underground storage tanks
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Griebenow, Bret L., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Martinson, Lori M., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Company, Inc. (WINCO), operates the Idaho Chemical Processing Plant (ICPP) for the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE). WINCO's mission is to process government owned spent nuclear fuel. The process involves dissolving the fuel, extracting off uranium, and calcining the waste to a solid form for storage. Prior to calcining, the liquid waste is temporarily stored at the ICPP in underground storage tanks. The tanks were put in service between 1953 and 1966 and are operating 10 to 15 years beyond their design life. Five of the tanks will be replaced by 1998. The integrity of the remaining six tanks must be verified to continue their use until they can be replaced at a later date. In order to verify the tank integrity, a complete corrosion analysis must be performed. This analysis will require a remote visual inspection of the tank surfaces.
Index Keywords: Radioactive Wastes - Storage; Robots, Industrial - Arms; Tanks - Inspection; Remote Inspection; Underground Storage Tanks; Inspection

Title: Microwave beam powered Mars airplane
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Faymon, Karl A., NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: The feasibility of an unmanned Mars airplane that receives its primary power from an RF (microwave) beam located on the Martian surface has been analyzed. An onboard rechargeable electrochemical storage system is to be used for special maneuvers, and possible range extension when the airplane is out of the line-of-sight of the microwave source antenna is included as a back-up to the microwave system. The weight of the onboard microwave beam receiving system, relative to other power systems, and the ability to recharge the onboard energy storage system in flight result in a payload capability independent of range and significant mission flexibility. Such an airplane, its onboard power system, its methods of utilization, and the transmitting station requirements to support various Martian exploration operations are presented. The status of microwave beam technology is given, in addition to the technology advances required for the microwave-beam-powered Mars airplane. The concept is thought to be feasible, but advances in microwave technology are required. It is concluded that the payload capability gives the Mars airplane significant operational flexibility and utilization.
Index Keywords: Aircraft; Antennas--Microwave; Electric Batteries; Microwaves; Propulsion--Aerospace Applications; Energy Storage Systems; Martian Explorations; Microwave Beam Powered Mars Airplane; Onboard Microwave Beam Receiving Systems; Rechargeable Electrochemical Storage Systems; Unmanned Mars Airplanes; Aerospace Vehicles

Title: Computations of capacitance matrices for ESD between 3-dimensional bodies
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh,, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Helmsen, J.J., Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh,, PA, USA; Hoburg, J.F., Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh,, PA, USA
Abstract: The computational tool described is based upon three-dimensional geometric modeling and electrostatic charge simulation, for determination of capacitance matrices between three-dimensional bodies, including the influence of a ground plane. These matrices provide a means of computing potential and electric field distributions between approaching bodies, and thus determining relative probabilities of electrostatic discharge. Also, energy storage computations before and after a discharge provide a means for estimating the relative severity of the event. The tool is used to compute capacitance matrices for a simple model of a human body with arm and finger approaching another object.
Index Keywords: Accident Prevention; Electric Measurements--Capacitance; Electrostatics; Human Engineering--Electric Field Effects; Probability; Capacitance Matrices; Electrostatic Discharges; Three-dimensional Bodies; Electric Discharges

Authors: Verga Richard L., Buden David, Nikolich Milan
Title: Five years of SDIO power development progress
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Strategic Defense Initiative, Organization, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Verga, Richard L., Strategic Defense Initiative, Organization, Washington, DC, USA; Buden, David, Strategic Defense Initiative, Organization, Washington, DC, USA; Nikolich, Milan, Strategic Defense Initiative, Organization, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The Strategic Defense Initiative Organization (SDIO) Power and Power Conditioning Program was established to develop the power technologies needed to enable the envisioned ground- and space-based sensor and weapon systems. In particular, solar power technologies have demonstrated survivability with less weight than present systems. Hardware is being produced for space nuclear power, and lightweight, multimegawatt power source technologies have been demonstrated. SUPER (survivable power module program) is scheduled to fly in FY93, thus validating survivable solar technology applicable to all satellites of military significance for the foreseeable future. The SP-100 ground reactor test is scheduled to begin in FY94 and will provide the basis for a follow-on flight phase. Once operational, SP-100 will provide the nation with the capability to perform high-power military missions heretofore impractical, and will provide a general-purpose power source for a multitude of space exploration missions. The multimegawatt and power conditioning programs will produce the requisite power sources for space-based directed energy weapons. The SMES (superconducting magnetic energy storage) program, which will begin testing of the engineering test model in 1994, will provide a means for powering ground-based lasers with significant spinoff potential to the electric utility industry.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering--Military Purposes; Military Engineering--Space Applications; Nuclear Power Plants--Space Applications; Rockets and Missiles--Power Supply; Solar Power Plants--Space Applications; Baseload Power; Burst Power; Multimegawatt Power Source Technologies; SP-100 Space Nuclear Power System; Strategic Defense Initiative Organization (SDIO); Survivable Power Module Program (SUPER); Aerospace Vehicles

Title: Eutelsat II nickel-hydrogen storage battery system design and performance summary
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Eagle-Picher Ind, Inc, Joplin, MO,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Duff, Phillip, Eagle-Picher Ind, Inc, Joplin, MO,, USA
Abstract: The Eutelsat II nickel-hydrogen battery system was designed to supply electrical energy for prelaunch, launch, transfer, and geosynchronous orbit, including solar eclipses and peak load operations. The battery system, designated the SAR-10009 battery, consists of twenty-seven hermetically sealed nickel-hydrogen cells electrically connected in series. This battery system provides two main power outputs (power bus and pyro bus) and features three thermal sensors, two system control heating elements, resistive grounding, insulated captivated mounting provisions, individual cell bypass diode circuitry for open circuit protection, redundant electrical insulation, conformal coating, and three electrical interface connectors. The author outlines the major design features of the system and the results obtained from qualification and acceptance-level testing.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Supplies to Apparatus; Hydrogen; Nickel and Alloys; Satellites--Power Supply; Sensors; Eutelsat II; Nickel-Hydrogen Cells; Nickel-Hydrogen Storage Battery System; Open Circuit protection; SAR-10009 Battery; Thermal Sensors; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Simpow - a digital power system simulator
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: SIMPOWTM, for SIMulation of POWer systems, is a digital power system simulator developed by ABB Power Systems. One reason for its development was the need to be able to implement complete models of all established and future electrical energy supply systems in a reliable and flexible digital program package. Systems for which it is intended include multi-terminal HVDC schemes, phase-controlled static var compensators, superconducting magnetic energy storage, flexible AC transmission systems (FACTS), etc. The objective was to develop a versatile and accurate tool, mainly for use within the ABB Group, to support product sales by providing a test bench for development, design and marketing.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Control Systems--Applications; Electric Power Systems--Control; Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques--Differential Equations; Digital Power System Simulator; HVDC Converter Station; HVDC Transmission System; Power System Dynamics; Power-Frequency Models; Electric Power Transmission

Title: Conventional wallboard with latent heat storage for passive solar applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Nat Lab, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kedl, R.J., Oak Ridge Nat Lab, TN, USA
Abstract: Conventional wallboard impregnated with octadecane paraffin (melting point of 73.5°F) is being developed as a building material with latent heat storage for passive solar applications. Impregnation was accomplished simply by soaking the wallboard in molten paraffin. Concentrations of paraffin in the combined product of as high as 35% by weight were achieved. In support of this concept, a computer model was developed to describe thermal transport and storage by a phase-change material (PCM) dispersed in a porous media. The computer model was confirmed by comparison with known analytical solutions in which the PCM melts at a specific melting point. However, agreement between the model and an experimentally produced thermal transient involving impregnated wallboard was good only after the model was modified to allow the paraffin to melt over a temperature range. This was accomplished by replacing the heat of fusion with a triangular heat capacity relationship that mimics the triangular melt curve found through differential scanning calorimetry. When this change was made, agreement between the model and the experimental transient was very good.
Index Keywords: Building Materials; Computers - Applications; Solar Energy; Thermodynamics; Computer Model; Conventional Wallboard; Latent Heat Storage; Octadecane Paraffin; Passive Solar Applications; Phase Change Material; Heat Storage

Title: Portable refrigeration machine
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: American Trade Holding Corp, Long, Beach, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Taylor, William P., American Trade Holding Corp, Long, Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: A compact, self-contained refrigeration machine that is entirely free from chlorofluorocarbons, hydrocarbon emissions or noise pollution is described. It is capable of supplying refrigeration and forced draft air circulation in densely packed airline cargo containers and short haul trucks. Refrigeration and power requirements are derived from a storage charge of CO which is maintained at its triplepoint in a pressure vessel. The triplepoint temperature is low enough to enable its use as either a freezer or refrigerator, and the triplepoint pressure is adequate to power an air circulation fan. A thermostatic control maintains the air temperature near 0°F, for optimum transport of frozen cargo, or 35°F for refrigerated transport.
Index Keywords: Aircraft; Containers; Energy Storage; Materials Handling; Noise Pollution; Airline Cargo Containers; Forced Draft Air Circulation; Hydrocarbon Emissions; Noise Pollution; Portable Refrigeration Machine; Short Haul Trucks; Refrigerating Machinery

Authors: Sawase Kazuhisa, Isshiki Naotsugu, Kurosaki Yasuo, Shibuya Isao
Title: Co-generation system with an aquifer thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Railway Tech Res Inst, Kokubunji,, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sawase, Kazuhisa, Railway Tech Res Inst, Kokubunji,, Tokyo, Japan; Isshiki, Naotsugu, Railway Tech Res Inst, Kokubunji,, Tokyo, Japan; Kurosaki, Yasuo, Railway Tech Res Inst, Kokubunji,, Tokyo, Japan; Shibuya, Isao, Railway Tech Res Inst, Kokubunji,, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The thermal efficiency and the life-cycle cost of a cogeneration system with an aquifer thermal energy storage as a heat source are discussed. The cogeneration system supplies heat for room heating, air conditioning, hot water, and snow melting on the station roof (20,000 m2). Excess heat generated by the cogeneration system is designed to be saved in the aquifer until winter. From the results of the simulation study, the amount of electric power to be supplied by the cogeneration system, the amount to be purchased, fuel consumption, and thermal energy stored in an aquifer to meet seasonal energy demands are obtained. The study shows that investment in the cogeneration system is lucrative.
Index Keywords: Computers - Applications; Electric Power Generation; Energy Storage - Applications; Waste Heat Utilization; Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage; Co-Generation System; Cogeneration System; Life-Cycle Cost; Seasonal Energy Demands; Thermal Efficiency; Cogeneration Plants

Authors: Yoshinaga Hisao, Kitayama Ken-ichi, Oguri Hitoshi
Title: Holographic image storage in iron-doped lithium niobate fibers
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: NTT Transmission Systems Lab, Yokosuka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoshinaga, Hisao, NTT Transmission Systems Lab, Yokosuka, Japan; Kitayama, Ken-ichi, NTT Transmission Systems Lab, Yokosuka, Japan; Oguri, Hitoshi, NTT Transmission Systems Lab, Yokosuka, Japan
Abstract: Experimental results of holographic multiple recording in iron-doped LiNbO3 (LN) fibers are reported for the first time. An alphabetical letter composed of sixteen 2×2 mm2 pixels was recorded. A fiber geometry gurantees high energy density and long effective distance as well as flexibility in assembly. All these characteristics are favorable for a recording medium.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Optical; Holography; Lithium Compounds; Optical Data Processing; Holographic Image Storage; Lithium Niobate Fiber; Optical Computing; Photorefractive Materials; Optical Materials

Title: Experience of the 1 200 MWE super phenix FBR operation
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: NERSA
Authors with affiliations: Mergui, Adrien, NERSA; Prudhon, Patrick, NERSA
Abstract: SUPER PHENIX is the most important industrial-sized fast breeder in the world. This plant, on the site of CREYS-MALVILLE in France, is built on the left bank of the Rhone some thirty miles from Lyon. After having reached full power on 9th December 1986, the plant enjoyed a first period of continuous operation. A leak detected in March 1987 on the spent fuel storage drum, led to an outage of twenty months for the necessary investigations, as well as to implement means and complementary procedures, essentially aiming at checking the quality of the realization. After approval, the plant resumed operation and periods of energy production are optimized to coordinate activities due to the replacement of the storage drum and the operation of the plant up to depletion of the 405 EFPD reserve in the core.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Power Plants - France; Start Up; Super Phenix; Nuclear Reactors, Breeder

Authors: Tomlinson John J., Heberle David D.
Title: Analysis of wallboard containing a phase change material
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Nat Lab, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tomlinson, John J., Oak Ridge Nat Lab, TN, USA; Heberle, David D., Oak Ridge Nat Lab, TN, USA
Abstract: Efforts are underway to develop a gypsum wallboard containing a hydrocarbon PCM (phase change material). With a phase change temperature in the room temperature range, the PCM wallboard adds substantially to the thermal mass of the building while serving the same architectural function as conventional wallboard. To determine the thermal and economic performance of this PCM wallboard, the transient systems simulation program (TRNSYS) was modified to accommodate walls that are covered with PCM plasterboard and to apportion the direct beam solar radiation to interior surfaces of a building. The modified code was used to simulate the performance of conventional and direct-gain passive solar residential-sized buildings with and without PCM wallboard. Space heating energy savings were determined as a function of PCM-wallboard characteristics. Thermal comfort improvements in buildings containing the PCM were qualified in terms of energy savings. A present-worth economic analysis of the energy savings is presented, and system costs and economic payback are calculated based on current costs of PCMs under study for the wallboard application.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Energy Storage; Mathematical Models; Solar Energy - Applications; Phase Change Material; Plasterboard; Software Package TRNSYS; Thermal Mass of Building; Wallboard; Buildings

Title: Mechanical and thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lennox Industries Inc, Dallas, TX,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gilles, Ted C., Lennox Industries Inc, Dallas, TX,, USA
Abstract: The author addresses the use of unique technology for cool thermal energy storage (CTES) for application with unitary air conditioning in single-family residences and small commercial facilities as a means of ameliorating the impending electric power supply shortfall in North America. A description is presented of a particular CTES. The importance of CTES to electric utilities is examined from the viewpoints of load leveling and the economic advantage. Owner/user advantages of CTES are also outlined.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Buildings - Climate Control; Electric Power Utilization; Electric Utilities; Evaporators; Ameliorating Electric Power Supply Shortfall; Cool Thermal Energy Storage; Mechanical Energy Storage; Single-Family Residences; Thermal Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Title: Experimental and theoretical analysis of heat of fusion storage for solar dynamic space power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Tech Univ of Munich, West Germany
Authors with affiliations: Weingartner, Stefan, Tech Univ of Munich, West Germany; Blumenberg, Jurgen, Tech Univ of Munich, West Germany
Abstract: An experimental and theoretical analysis of heat of fusion storage has been performed. The storage salts LiF and LiF-MgF2 were used for the experiments. Thermophysical data on these media were measured or evaluated by comparison with calculations. A simulation model that is able to predict melt and solidification time and the heat output achievable with a given cooling condition is presented. In order to achieve a suitable charge and discharge characteristic, the heat of fusion storage canisters should be installed around the working fluid tubes or heat pipes, which also should be the heat source for the storage unit during the charge cycle. Potential applications of ceramic materials are considered. Preliminary tests with LiF indicate that the problems caused by the volume contraction of the storage salt can be solved with ceramic foams. A reduction of storage system mass by 25% is expected through the use of Sircon (Si3N4-SiC) foams. It is concluded that the heat of fusion storage concept considered here is an optimal storage design for state-of-the-art solar dynamic space power systems with storage temperatures between 950 and 1150 K.
Index Keywords: Fluorine Compounds; Power Generation--Solar Energy; Salts--Melting; Solar Power Plants--Space Applications; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Heat of Fusion Storage; Heat Pipes; Lithium Fluoride; Magnesium Fluoride; Simulation Models; Solar Dynamic Space Power Systems; Energy Storage

Authors: Fay Edgar H., Cull Ronald C.
Title: Lunar orbiting microwave beam power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sverdrup Technology, Inc, Brook, Park, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Fay, Edgar H., Sverdrup Technology, Inc, Brook, Park, OH, USA; Cull, Ronald C., Sverdrup Technology, Inc, Brook, Park, OH, USA
Abstract: A microwave-beam power system using lunar orbiting solar-powered satellite(s) and surface rectenna(s) is investigated as a possible energy source for the moon's surface. The concept has the potential of achieving reduced system mass by placing the power source in orbit. This can greatly reduce and/or eliminate the 14-d energy storage requirement of a lunar surface solar system. Also, propellants required to de-orbit to the surface are greatly reduced. To determine the practicality of the concept and the most important factors, a zeroth-order feasibility analysis is performed. Three different operation scenarios employing state of the art technology and forecasts for two different sets of advanced technologies are investigated. To reduce the complexity of the problem, satellite(s) are assumed to be in circular equatorial orbits around the moon, supplying continuous power to a single equatorial base through a fixed horizontal rectenna on the surface. State of the art technology yields specific masses greater than 2500 kg/kw, well above projections for surface systems. The specific masses are on the order of 100 kg/kW using advanced technologies, which is within the range of projections for surface nuclear (20 kg/kW) and solar systems (500 kg/kW). Further studies examining optimization of the scenarios, other technologies, such as laser transmitters and nuclear sources, and operational issues, such as logistics, maintenance, and support, are being carried out to support the Space Exploration Initiative (SEI) to the moon and Mars.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Microwaves; Solar Cells; Solar Energy; Spacecraft--Lunar Missions; Aerospace Engineering--Research; Laser Transmitters; Lunar Orbiting Solar Powered Satellites; Microwave Beam Power Systems; Solar Power Systems; Surface Nuclear Power Systems; Electric Power Systems

Authors: Giese R.F., Sheahen T.P., Wolsky A.M., Sharma D.K.
Title: High-temperature superconductors: their potential role in electric utility applications and what must be done to use them
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Giese, R.F., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Sheahen, T.P., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Wolsky, A.M., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Sharma, D.K., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: A number of proposed applications of superconductivity for the electric utility sector are described, the current status of their development is summarized, and the potential impact of successful development of high-temperature superconductors (HTSCs) is discussed. Performance goals for development of HTSCs are presented and compared with the current status of development of HTSCs. Applications discussed include large-scale generators, motors, transmission lines, magnetic storage, transformers, power electronics, and fault-current limiters.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Transmission; Superconductivity; Magnetic Energy Storage; High Temperature Superconductors
