Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Inst of Gas Technol, Chicago, IL,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Blazek, C.F., Inst of Gas Technol, Chicago, IL,, USA; Jasionowski, W.J., Inst of Gas Technol, Chicago, IL,, USA; Tiller, A.J., Inst of Gas Technol, Chicago, IL,, USA; Gauthier, S.W., Inst of Gas Technol, Chicago, IL,, USA
Abstract: Experiments and numerical modeling indicate that methane storage and delivery are enhanced by low flow rates, high pressures, and designs with low adsorbent-to-cylinder mass ratios. When the adsorbent-to-cylinder mass ratio is greater than 0.3, system behavior changes from near isothermal to adiabatic. Incorporation and utilization of in-situ thermal energy storage (TES) aids heat management, maintains near-isothermal conditions, and improves overall performance. TES thermally buffers the charging and discharging of an adsorbent system at or near the phase-change temperature of the TES media, thereby enhancing storage and delivery of methane. A tabulation of test results is included.
Index Keywords: Fuels - Storage; Methane - Applications; Natural Gas - Applications; Adsorbent-To-Cylinder Mass Ratios; Charge/Discharge Characteristics; Heat Management; High-Capacity Methane Adsorption Storage Systems; In-Situ Thermal Energy Storage; Thermal Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Title: The potential for centralized renewable energy developments in India
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Energy Systems Consultant, Berkeley,, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wolfe, Michael Hesse, Energy Systems Consultant, Berkeley,, CA, USA
Abstract: The potential for centralized renewable energy developments in India is examined within the regional context of South Asia. A scenario is presented for the staged development of three renewable energy centers to be located at coastal sites in Gujarat State on the Arabian Sea. The first would consist of a pilot demonstration center of modest scale on a site at Kort Creek, just south of the India/Pakistan border on the Rann of Kutch. The second and third sites for centers of increasing scale and energy conversion capacity would be located on and near the Kathiawar Peninsula, adjacent to the Gulfs of Kutch and Cambay, respectively. Their connection to the national power grid of India is projected together with the possibility for interconnection of the centers with the western regional system of India and the national interconnected system of Pakistan. This option is suggested as an alternative to continued independent expansion of the power systems of India and Pakistan, in order to optimize the renewable resource base to the benefit of both countries. The introduction of additional coal-fired thermal plants in India and Pakistan, causing CO2 releases and contributing to global warming, would be minimized within the South Asia region. Power system interconnection would enable the exchange of electrical energy to achieve energy trade between the two countries. This would provide a rationale for accelerated development of both the Kutch and Cambay renewable energy centers, so that surplus electrical energy over Indian western regional demand could be sold to Pakistan.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Energy Utilization; Fossil Fuels; Solar Energy; Tidal Power; Centralized Renewable Developments in India; Centralized Solar-Thermal and Tidal Generation; Energy Conversion Capacity; Global Warming; Kort Creek Pilot Demonstration Center; Renewable Energy Centers; Energy Management

Title: 8-GeV synchrotron radiation facility at Nishi_Harima
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: JAERI-RIKEN SPring-8 Project Team, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kamitsubo, Hiromichi, JAERI-RIKEN SPring-8 Project Team, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Japan Atomic Energy research Institute (JAERI) and the Institute of Physical and Chemical Research (RIKEN) are going to build an 8GeV synchrotron radiation source in Harima Science Garden City of Hyougo Prefecture. The facility consists of a 8 GeV storage ring of 1436 circumference with a natural emittance of 7.2 nmrad., an injector linac of 1 GeV and a 8 GeV synchrotron. Construction starts in 1990 and the first stored beam is foreseen in 1998. At the commissioning time 10 beam lines will be available while the remaining 50 beam lines, 32 on insertion devices and 18 on bending magnets, will be constructed successively. All these beam lines will be used by external groups.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Synchrotron - Storage Rings; Magnets; Photons; X-Rays; Beam Luminosity; Synchrotron Radiation

Authors: Erlandson A.C., Jancaitis K.S., McCracken R.W., Murray J.E., Powell H.T.
Title: Performance of a multisegment Nd:glass disk amplifier
Source title: XVII International Conference on Quantum Electronics. Digest of
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Nat Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Erlandson, A.C., Lawrence Livermore Nat Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA; Jancaitis, K.S., Lawrence Livermore Nat Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA; McCracken, R.W., Lawrence Livermore Nat Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA; Murray, J.E., Lawrence Livermore Nat Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA; Powell, H.T., Lawrence Livermore Nat Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA
Abstract: A Nd:glass multisegment disk amplifier (MSA) containing four individual 29-cm square apertures arranged in a 2 × 2 array was constructed, and its performance was measured. The MSA offers reduced complexity and reduced cost in large devices by packaging more disks and lamps in a single mechanical structure and grouping beams so that they can be easily transported as a single larger beam. It represents one-fourth of the 4 × 4 MSA that the authors proposed in their Athena design for a multimegajoule laboratory microfusion facility. The MSA design is unique in that it is only a single disk long. An arbitrary number of such modules can be closely connected longitudinally to form an integrated larger amplifier. The design of the MSA module is based on extensive data from an earlier testbed single-segment disk amplifier (SSA) in which high pumping efficiency was demonstrated. The MSA was designed to reach higher energy storage densities than the SSA, at some expense in efficiency, by increasing the lamp pump area ratio to 1.03 and decreasing the disk thickness to 3.75 cm. The gain and gain uniformity of the MSA module were measured, and the effect of module-to-module coupling of flashlamp light when two or more modules are connected was investigated. A comparison indicates that the MSA is 5-10% more efficient than the SSA. Higher radiant efficiency of the central flashlamp arrays is the major factor responsible for this improvement.
Index Keywords: Glass; Light - Amplifiers; Neodymium Compounds; Digest of Paper; Multisegment Disk Amplifiers; Lasers, Solid State

Authors: Ruud Mark D., Mitchell John W., Klein Sanford A.
Title: Use of building thermal mass to offset cooling loads
Affiliations: Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ruud, Mark D., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, United States; Mitchell, John W., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, United States; Klein, Sanford A., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, United States
Abstract: The use of ice and chilled-water storage systems to reduce peak energy demands is well established. However, relatively few experimental results have been published on the use of building thermal mass to offset demand. The use of off-peak cooling to extract heat from a building structure may increase the total energy use, while at the same time reducing peak cooling loads and cooling costs. This paper describes a project sponsored by ASHRAE TC 4.6 on thermal storage in a building. The purpose of this research project was to evaluate the effect of building thermal energy storage on the peak cooling load. To study the use of building thermal mass to reduce the peak cooling load, two experiments were performed on the independent Life Insurance building located in Jacksonville, Florida. The objective of these experiments was to 'pre-cool' the building at night and during the weekend to reduce daytime cooling loads. Supply air temperature and flow rate were measured on a floor that was being pre-cooled and on a control floor operated in a normal manner. Temperature and heat flux measurements at the concrete floor surface revealed the extent of charging and discharging of the thermal mass. Diurnal heat capacity calculations were used in analyzing the experimental results. The results showed an 18% reduction in cooling energy supplied during the daytime. There was no reduction in peak demand.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Energy Conservation; Buildings--Energy Storage; Building Cooling Load Reduction; Building Nighttime Precooling; Building Thermal Energy Storage; HVAC System Energy Conservation; Office Buildings

Authors: Brandemuehl Michael J., Lepore Mark J., Kreider Jan F.
Title: Modeling and testing the interaction of conditioned air with building thermal mass
Affiliations: Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brandemuehl, Michael J., Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States; Lepore, Mark J., Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States; Kreider, Jan F., Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States
Abstract: Thermal mass in a commercial building can affect HVAC system performance and operation through its interactions with both the zone and return air. This paper specifically examines the effects of structural thermal mass in an above-ceiling unducted return air plenum on the air temperature returning to the HVAC equipment from the zone. The paper provides a brief overview of building mass dynamics and methods of analysis, describes an experimental program for quantifying the effects of thermal mass on HVAC systems, and presents a simplified model for including plenum mass effects. The results show that thermal mass effects in building zones can be significant and that the mass in the return plenum can effectively temper building air temperatures. The results also show that a simple plenum model can be used to account for thermal storage in structural elements in a conventional return air plenum. Experimental data have been used to validate the model. The model has been validated using an analytical solution to the heat transfer problem, which provides concurrent validation of the response factor and transfer function methods commonly used in building simulation programs.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Energy Utilization; Buildings--Energy Storage; Heat Transfer--Mathematical Models; Building Thermal Energy Storage; Building Thermal Mass Dynamics; HVAC System Performance Analysis; Plenum Heat Transfer Models; Office Buildings

Authors: Goswami D.Y., Jotshi C.K., Olszewski M.
Title: Analysis of thermal energy storage in cylindrical PCM capsules embedded in a metal matrix
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Florida,, Gainesville, FL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Goswami, D.Y., Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Florida,, Gainesville, FL, USA; Jotshi, C.K., Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Florida,, Gainesville, FL, USA; Olszewski, M., Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Florida,, Gainesville, FL, USA
Abstract: A computer program developed for simulating the thermal behavior of PCM's (phase change materials) embedded in a metal matrix is used to analyze a thermal storage system for space power cycle. Two cases are analyzed: single PCM (LiNO3) in matrices of copper and aluminum for several PCM cylinder diameters, and different PCMs (LiH, LiOH-LiF, and LiNO3) in a matrix of copper. Results show that an aluminum matrix is more suitable for where temperatures of less than 800K are encountered. Thermal properties of PCM materials, such as melting point, specific heat, and latent heat, are important in determining storage time cycle and matrix material.
Index Keywords: Composite Materials; Computers - Applications; Lithium Compounds; Thermodynamics; Aluminum Matrix; Cylindrical PCM Capsules; Molten Matrix; Phase Change Materials; Space Power Cycle; Thermal Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Title: Utilization of off-peak electric power to improve cycle efficiency during peak demand periods
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Nat Lab, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jody, B.J., Argonne Nat Lab, IL, USA; Daniels, E.J., Argonne Nat Lab, IL, USA
Abstract: A procedure is described that uses off-peak power to produce ice, which could be melted during peak demand periods to produce a cold heat sink for condensation of the low-pressure steam turbine exhaust at lower temperatures, thereby allowing more expansion in the turbine, more work output per pound of steam processed, and a higher efficiency. An analysis of this process shows that substantial improvement in operating efficiency and net power output during peak demand periods can be achieved. This improvement will allow balancing of the peak and the off-peak demands and reduces the need for expensive expansion of existing facilities to meet the growing needs of a community.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Models; Power Generation; Steam Turbines; Thermodynamics; Balancing of Peak Demand; Cold Heat Sink; Cycle Efficiency; Low Pressure Steam Turbine Exhaust; Off-Peak Electric Power; Peak Demand Period; Energy Storage

Title: Safety aspects on entire lifting old HWRR tank
Source title: International Atomic Energy Agency, Proceedings Series
Affiliations: Inst of Atomic Energy (IAE), Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, Yu-Lun, Inst of Atomic Energy (IAE), Beijing, China
Abstract: The replacement of Heavy Water Research Reactor (HWRR) tank is a major part of the HWRR reconstruction. The entire lifting up, transportation and burial of the reactor tank must be safely carried out in disassembling reactor complex. For this purpose some safety-related matters were analyzed. The correct evaluation of the radiation damage of the HWRR graphite reflector, in which the reactor tank is located, is a key problem for lifting the old reactor tank. The analyses on the graphite behaviour induced by irradiation, specially on the dimension change, the release of storage energy of graphite reflector as latent heat are given in this paper. The mechanical performance of the old reactor tank and the radiation protection in the technological process of replacing the reactor tank are also related here.
Index Keywords: Graphite--Radiation Effects; Nuclear Reactors--Research Reactors; Reflectors; Nuclear Reactors, Heavy Water

Title: The 4-95 Stirling engine for underwater application
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Kockums Marine AB, Malmo, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Bratt, Christer, Kockums Marine AB, Malmo, Sweden
Abstract: The conversion of the 4-95 engine to an underwater engine with a combustor that burns diesel fuel with pure oxygen is described. Measured performance and experience from an endurance test are reported. A prototype system comprising engine with generator and high-pressure oxygen combustor has been built and tested in the engine laboratory. Before the complete system was tested, separate tests were performed on critical subsystems. The high-pressure combustor was separately tested on an air-cooled combustor test rig before it was integrated on the Stirling engine. An air-independent power system based on the Stirling engine and LOX storage can be used to provide power to unmanned underwater vehicles (UUVs). For vehicles with a total displacement of more than five tons and an energy content of 600 kWh or more, the Stirling system has higher energy density than the silver-zinc battery system.
Index Keywords: Combustors; Diesel Electric Power Plants; Electric Power Plants - Underwater; Ocean Engineering; 4-95 Stirling Engines; Underwater Engines; Underwater Vehicles; Thermodynamics

Authors: Botros N., Salhab Sammour, Ragala Ram M.
Title: Microcomputer-based analysis of diagnostic ultrasound signals
Source title: Modeling and Simulation, Proceedings of the Annual Pittsburgh Conference
Affiliations: Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale, United States
Authors with affiliations: Botros, N., Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale, United States; Salhab, Sammour, Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale, United States; Ragala, Ram M., Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale, United States
Abstract: In this paper we present instrumentation and algorithm for analyzing the backscattered ultrasound signal from simulated soft tissues. The instrumentation is a 50 MHz microcomputer-based data acquisition and analysis system. The primary application of the system is to measure the backscattered ultrasound energy from human liver tissue phantom and use this measurement to differentiate between simulated normal and abnormal liver tissues. The system consists mainly of six units: a) conditioning circuit unit; b) analog-to-digital converter (ADC) unit with an ultra high speed (TRW 1029) operating at a sample rate of 50 Megasample/second with 6-bit- ECL digital output; c) latching circuit unit; d) intermediate storage unit (12 KByte); e) control and delay unit, and f) communication ports circuit unit to link the intermediate storage circuit with a microcomputer. A pattern recognition algorithm, based on measuring the normalized Euclidean distance between the reference pattern representing simulated normal liver tissue and the pattern under examination, is applied. The normalized distance is used to measure the probability of matching between the two patterns. Our results show that the system is capable of differentiating between simulated normal and abnormal liver tissues.
Index Keywords: Pattern Recognition - Algorithms; Ultrasonic Waves - Backscattering; Abnormal Liver Tissues; Ultrasound Signals; Ultrasonic Devices

Authors: El-Genk Mohamed S., Hoover Mark D.
Title: A summary overview of recent advances in space nuclear power systems technology
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Chem & Nucl Eng Dept, Univ of, New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: El-Genk, Mohamed S., Chem & Nucl Eng Dept, Univ of, New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Hoover, Mark D., Chem & Nucl Eng Dept, Univ of, New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Recent achievements and developments of the technology of space-based nuclear power and propulsion systems are summarized. Topics covered include direct thermal and electric propulsion, static energy conversion, high-temperature materials, reliability and life, power system concepts, dynamic energy conversion, energy storage, microgravity two-phase flow, radioisotope power systems, and space nuclear safety.

Authors: Abe Yoshiyuki, Takahashi Yoshio, Negishi Akira, Kanari Katsuhiko, Tanaka Kotaro, Kamimoto Masayuki
Title: Carbon/fluoride composite for advanced solar dynamic receiver
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Lab, MITI, Tsukuba,, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Abe, Yoshiyuki, Electrotechnical Lab, MITI, Tsukuba,, Japan; Takahashi, Yoshio, Electrotechnical Lab, MITI, Tsukuba,, Japan; Negishi, Akira, Electrotechnical Lab, MITI, Tsukuba,, Japan; Kanari, Katsuhiko, Electrotechnical Lab, MITI, Tsukuba,, Japan; Tanaka, Kotaro, Electrotechnical Lab, MITI, Tsukuba,, Japan; Kamimoto, Masayuki, Electrotechnical Lab, MITI, Tsukuba,, Japan
Abstract: The application of composite materials, ceramics, or carbon materials with molten salts to latent thermal energy storage in solar dynamic receivers has been investigated as a way to overcome various problems due to the physical properties of molten salts. In connection with realizing a sophisticated and advanced receiver, an attempt at developing carbon composite with molten fluorides has been made. The relevant materials production process and preliminary results of thermal analysis are described. High-temperature He-Xe experimental systems for receiver component evaluation are described. It is concluded that although a drastic improvement in the thermal performance of the receiver using the carbon/fluoride composite is likely and the materials developed enjoy a good mechanical stability, more detailed thermoanalytical evaluation on the materials must be carried out.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Composite Materials--Space Applications; Fluorine Compounds; Helium; Salts--Molten; Carbon/Fluoride Composites; Computer Simulation; Fluorides; Helium-Xenon Loops; Latent Thermal Energy Storage; Thermal Analysis; Energy Storage

Authors: Heinemeier Kristin, Schiller Gail, Benton Charles
Title: Task conditioning for the workplace. Issues and challenges
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Heinemeier, Kristin, Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Schiller, Gail, Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Benton, Charles, Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Underfloor air distribution, once associated with computer rooms, is now being used in open-plan offices. Supplying conditioned air from the floor provides the opportunity for localized conditioning with individual control, known as 'task conditioning.' This environmental control strategy can be viewed as encompassing a combination of several more conventional strategies: zoning, ventilative cooling, direct equipment ventilation, allowance for occupant-defined comfort, use of occupancy sensors, temperature stratification, increased ventilation efficiency, and thermal storage. This paper provides an overview of task conditioning in offices, describing existing system types and the most common applications. While little research has been done concerning the comfort and energy effects of these systems, this paper outlines the current state of understanding of these issues, and identifies important questions that must be addressed to complete the understanding of this unique strategy.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Design; Computer Workstations--Air Conditioning; Floors--Piping Systems; Refrigerating Machinery--Design; Air Conditioning System Engineering; Office Building HVAC Systems; Underfloor Air Conditioning Systems; Workplace Task Conditioning; Office Buildings

Title: A family of ammonia-water adjustable proportion fluid mixture cycles
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Villanova Univ, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Marston, Charles H., Villanova Univ, PA, USA
Abstract: A set of four successively more complex versions of an ammonia-water adjustable proportion fluid mixture cycle was studied. Except for a higher turbine inlet pressure in the most elaborate version, input conditions and assumed losses are the same for each cycle. The need for an intermediate variable-composition loop is shown, along with potential gains in efficiency with the more complex cycles. The intermediate fluid loop and variable composition in an adjustable proportion fluid mixture cycle enable the transfer of significant energy from the turbine exhaust to the high-pressure side. Judicious interchange between the turbine stages and the high-pressure thermal input also provides significant improvement but there appears to be very little advantage to multistream heat exchangers.
Index Keywords: Ammonia; Energy Storage; Heat Exchangers; Water; Fluid Loops; Fluid Mixture Cycles; Fluids

Title: Electric vehicle propulsion and battery technology--1975-1995
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: EG&G Idaho, Inc, Idaho Falls,, ID, USA,
Authors with affiliations: Burke, A.F., EG&G Idaho, Inc, Idaho Falls,, ID, USA,
Abstract: Significant progress in electric propulsion systems and batteries has been made in the last 15 yr, resulting in the design and building of electric and hybrid vehicles having performance and utility approaching that of conventional internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles for many mission applications. A quantitative review of the progress made in the various technology areas associated with electric vehicles is presented. The areas considered are motors (AC and DC), power electronics and microprocessor-based controllers, traction batteries, and transaxles. It is found that the size and weight of the motor and controller are greatly reduced, and their efficiency is improved to the point that the electric driveline components are no longer any deterrent to designing electric vehicles with speed and acceleration performance comparable to that of conventional ICE vehicles. Progress on traction batteries for electric vehicles has been less dramatic than for the motor and controller. Nickel-iron (NiFe), nickel-cadmium (NiCd), sodium-sulfur (NaS), and zinc-bromine (ZnBr) batteries are being tested in vehicles, but lead-acid remains the only commercially available, affordable option for electric vehicles to be produced in any quantity. A number of electric vehicles have been built and tested using the advanced electric vehicle technology developed since 1980. These vehicles have exhibited good performance, accelerating to 48 km/h in 10 s or less and attaining speeds in excess of 100 km/h. Hybrid vehicles utilizing an electric driveline and heat engine in parallel have been built and tested in both the United States and Europe. The vehicles functioned well on both electric and engine power and offer the possibility of using primarily electricity for city driving and chemical fuels for long intercity trips.
Index Keywords: Control Systems--Computer Applications; Electric Batteries, Secondary--Space Applications; Electronic Circuits, Power Supply--Space Applications; Propulsion--Electric Energy; Storage battery Vehicles--Space Applications; Electric Drivelines; Electric Propulsion Systems; Electric Vehicles; Heat Engines; Microprocessor Based Controllers; Power Electronics; Aerospace Vehicles

Authors: Lowery John E., Lanier Jr. John R., Hall Charles I., Whitt Thomas H.
Title: Ongoing nickel-hydrogen energy storage device testing at George C. Marshall Space Flight Center
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Marshall Space Flight Center,, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lowery, John E., NASA, Marshall Space Flight Center,, AL, USA; Lanier Jr., John R., NASA, Marshall Space Flight Center,, AL, USA; Hall, Charles I., NASA, Marshall Space Flight Center,, AL, USA; Whitt, Thomas H., NASA, Marshall Space Flight Center,, AL, USA
Abstract: The primary objective of the testing is to characterize Ni-H2 cells for successful integration into the electrical power system (EPS) of the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). A broad spectrum of Ni-H2 design technology is encompassed by the testing configurations; tests include cells with dates of manufacture as early as 1976. The database includes cells of varied storage times, capacity, plate design, stack design, terminal configuration, pressure vessel thickness, separator material, potassium hydroxide (KOH) concentration, and thermal control. Currently, 196 Ni-H2 cells are being tested, grouped as follows: 12 RNH-35-3, 14 RNH-30-1, 22 HST cells (1 battery, flight spare lot), 132 HST cells (6 batteries, test modules 1 and 2 (TM1 and TM2)), 12 HST cells (3 four-cell packs, TM1, TM2, flight spare module (FSM)), and 4 HST cells (engineering lot). In addition to the characterization and life testing, an extensive thermal vacuum and purge test was conducted in November 1989 and February 1990 using the HST FSM (3 batteries composed of 69 HST cells from the flight spare lot) to help verify thermal design. A report is presented of the progress, significant findings, and future objectives of the testing.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen; Nickel and Alloys; Spacecraft; Telescopes; Hubble Space Telescope; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Weaver Robert D., Tanzella Francis L.
Title: A novel switch for use in Na/S load-levelling batteries and a maintenance strategy for its use
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Electric Power Res Inst, Palo Alto,, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Weaver, Robert D., Electric Power Res Inst, Palo Alto,, CA, USA; Tanzella, Francis L., Electric Power Res Inst, Palo Alto,, CA, USA
Abstract: A switch intended for use in Na/S load-leveling battery stationary energy storage systems is being developed. The switch can be described as a remotely activated fusible link. Discussed are the needed characteristics of the control circuitry for the switch, the ratio of cells to switches, and the estimated effect on required maintenance schedules.
Index Keywords: Electric Switches; Sodium and Alloys; Sulfur; Load Leveling Batteries; Electric Batteries

Title: Superconductivity in the 1990's
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Intermagnetics Gen Corp, Acton, MA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Stekly, Z.J.J., Intermagnetics Gen Corp, Acton, MA,, USA
Abstract: The superconducting magnet itself is a combination of several technology areas--the conductors, magnetics, structures, and cryogenics. A review is presented of the state of the art in each of the technology areas as they relate to superconductors. The purpose is to illustrate applications selectively rather than to cover all applications. It is shown that achieving required magnetic fields in terms of magnitude, distribution in space, uniformity, and time stability has reached a fine art in magnetic resonance imaging and high-energy physics. Magnetic forces increase with coil size and the magnitude of the field to be achieved. Some of the structures developed for large magnetic fusion installations are complex and massive. In the magnetic energy storage application, the earth itself is used as a structural element. The limitations on fields that can be generated using superconductors are the availability of a conductor that will carry current at the required field and the ability of the windings and structure to support the magnetic forces. While structures have so far been metallic, composites are attractive for magnet structures at cryogenic temperatures. In the cryogenics area, at one extreme are such large refrigerator installations as the Tevatron at Fermilab, where 1000 superconducting magnets are supplied with liquid-helium coolants, at the other extreme are the MRI 1-m bore superconducting magnets, which have low liquid-helium consumption and are transported from location to location by truck.
Index Keywords: Magnetic Fields; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion; Superconducting Magnets; Superconducting Materials; Tevatron; Superconductivity

Title: Parametric design studies of toroidal magnetic energy storage units
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Idaho Nat Eng Lab, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Herring, J.Stephen, Idaho Nat Eng Lab, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA
Abstract: A small systems code was written to produce and evaluate self-consistent designs for toroidal superconducting energy storage units. Designs for toroidal energy storage units produced by the this code are presented. A wide range of parameters has been considered, resulting in units storing from 1 MJ to 72 GJ. Maximum fields range from 5 T to 20 T. The masses and volumes of the coils, bucking cylinder, coolant, insulation, and outer shell are calculated. For unattended use, the allowable operating time using only the boiloff of the cryogenic fluid for refrigeration is calculated. For larger units, the coils have been divided into modules suitable for normal truck or rail transport.
Index Keywords: Codes, Symbolic; Electric Coils; Magnetic Fields; Bucking Cylinders; Toroidal Fields; Superconducting Magnets

Authors: El-Marazki L.O., AbdelMohsen H.H., Hilal M.A., Abdelsalam M.K., Meding O.
Title: Cryogenic properties of boron and graphite aluminum composites
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: El-Marazki, L.O., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; AbdelMohsen, H.H., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Hilal, M.A., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Abdelsalam, M.K., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Meding, O., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Abstract: Space borne light weight superconducting magnetic energy storage systems require the use of high specific strength composites such as boron and graphite aluminum. For light weight superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) magnets it is necessary to utilize the structure's thermal capacity for magnet protection; furthermore, high thermal and electrical conductivity structures are also required. We have initiated a testing program of the two composites a room temperature as well as at low temperatures to determine their mechanical, electrical, and thermal properties.

Title: Proceedings of the 1989 Cryogenic Engineering Conference
Abstract: This Volume 35A contains 107 papers, grouped under the following headings: half century of superfluid helium; heat and mass transfer in helium II; application of He II: cooling superconducting devices; applications of He II: superfluids in space; heat transfer to liquid helium and liquid nitrogen; multi-layer insulation; applications of superconductivity: magnets and other devices; applications of superconductivity: magnet stability, coil protection; applications of superconductivity: cryogenic techniques; and refrigeration for electronics. Some examples of topics discussed by the papers are these: fifty years of superfluid helium; dynamic and transient stability of He II cooled conductors; a design and critical technology issues for on-orbit resupply of superfluid helium; evaluation of a novel enhanced boiling surface in cryogenic liquids; experimental studies of MLI systems; superconducting machinery for ship propulsion; propagatory velocity of the normal zone in a cable-in-conduit conductor; and optimal design of cryogenic bucking cylinder for space borne toroidal magnets.
Index Keywords: Electronic equipment; Energy storage; Finite element method; Heat transfer; Helium; High temperature superconductors; Nitrogen; Space applications; Superconducting magnets; EIREV; Fountain effect; Helium II; Liquid nitrogen; Superconducting Super Collider; Superconductor magnetic energy storage; Supercritical helium; Superfluidity; Tokamak; Tore Supra; Cryogenics
