Title: The ELETTRA control system
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Sincrotrone Trieste, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Mignacco, M.P., Sincrotrone Trieste, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy
Abstract: Sincrotrone Trieste has been established to design and construct a radiation source in the ultraviolet to soft X-ray region: (ELETTRA). It will have a large number of straight sections for wigglers and undulators, with a high flux of radiation from wigglers and high brilliance from undulators, in the photon energy range from 10 eV to 1-2 keV. These design goals should be achieved by a low-emittance storage ring with beam energies between 1.5 and 2 GeV. The design considerations for the ELETTRA control system are summarized with an overview of the various control-system building blocks: operator interface, networks, process computers, access to equipment, etc. This paper describes the fully distributed architecture of the system, pointing out the extensive use of standards for both hardware and software. Particular attention will be given to some communication features such as the use of X-11, NFS (network file system) and RPC (remote procedure call) in an inhomogeneous environment. © 1990.

Authors: Nakahara K., Abe I., Furukawa K., Kamikubota N.
Title: An operator-console system of the photon factory injector linac
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakahara, K., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, 305, Japan; Abe, I., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, 305, Japan; Furukawa, K., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, 305, Japan; Kamikubota, N., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, 305, Japan
Abstract: It is sometimes difficult to unify accelerator control systems constructed in different ways. This problem arose in unifying the control systems of the injector linac and the storage ring making up the Photon Factory of the National Laboratory for High Energy Physics. One easy approach is to unify only the operator consoles; the unified console is connected to both separate control systems using gateways. The operator-console system of the Photon Factory injector linac has been designed and constructed using this approach. It consists of several workstations interconnected via a local-area network, a gateway to the old linac control network and a CATV system for the real-time display of the accelerator status. In this way the linac will be controlled from the control center of the Photon Factory storage ring. © 1990.

Title: A review: limnological management and biomanipulation in the London reservoirs
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Royal Holloway and Bedford New College, Egham, TW20 OEX, Surrey, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Duncan, A., Department of Biology, Royal Holloway and Bedford New College, Egham, TW20 OEX, Surrey, United Kingdom
Abstract: Low algal biomasses and high water transparencies are a feature of the storage reservoirs that supply most of London's treated water. This is a result of knowledgeable limnological management and biomanipulation and despite the eutrophic nature of the River Thames with its high nutrients (7 gN m-3; 1 gP m-3) and particulate organic carbon (2 gC m-3). Built-in possibilities of jetting input water are managed to prevent stratification, to ensure isothermy, to mix chemicals and plankton vertically and horizontally and to manipulate the mixed-depth of the algal populations such that their potential for biomass growth is reduced by light-energy limitation. Spring algal growth is delayed and the spring peak is reduced and curtailed by the grazing impact of considerable biomasses of large-bodied daphnid populations (Daphnia magna, pulicaria & hyalina) whose development is also supported by the continuous input of high riverine algal crops. The existence of a large-bodied daphnid zooplankton in the reservoirs is associated with low levels of fish predation since the late 1960s. Variations in the intensity and nature of this vertebrate predation during the subsequent twenty years (1968-88) are illustrated by the changes that have occurred in the relationship between the phytoplankton and zooplankton biomasses of the April-May-June quarter of the year. This example of the London reservoirs serves to illustrate biomanipulation in deep water bodies by bottom-up as well as top-down effects. © 1990 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: bottom-up effects; inputs; mixing; top-down
Index Keywords: biomanipulation; reservoir; UK, England, London

Authors: Ford S.E., Figueras A.J., Haskin H.H.
Title: Influence of selective breeding, geographic origin, and disease on gametogenesis and sex ratios of oysters, Crassostrea virginica, exposed to the parasite Haplosporidium nelsoni (MSX)
Affiliations: Shellfish Research Laboratory, Cook College, New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station, Port Norris, NJ 08349, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ford, S.E., Shellfish Research Laboratory, Cook College, New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station, Port Norris, NJ 08349, United States; Figueras, A.J., Shellfish Research Laboratory, Cook College, New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station, Port Norris, NJ 08349, United States; Haskin, H.H., Shellfish Research Laboratory, Cook College, New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station, Port Norris, NJ 08349, United States
Abstract: The recent spread and intensification of Haplosporidium nelsoni (MSX) disease in oysters, Crassostrea virginica, along the Atlantic coast of the United States has heightened interest in the use of disease-resistant strains in aquaculture and increased the need for understanding all facets of how selective breeding affects oyster performance, including reproduction. Resistance does not prevent infection, but involves an ability to restrict parasite development and to tolerate infections. We examined selected and unselected oysters, from three geographical locations, all exposed to H. nelsoni infection, to determine the influence of selection, strain origin, and parasitism on gametogenesis. Gonadal development was most frequently correlated with geographic origin of oysters: northern strains (from Long Island Sound) ripened and spawned earlier than southern strains (from the James River), even after several generations of selection at a single location in Delaware Bay. Parasitism was associated with impaired gonadal development in May when gametogenesis was occurring, but not in August, when spawning was underway. Selection for disease resistance was associated with improved gametogenic development, but only in oysters with few or no patent infections. Both parasite burden and selection for resistance were correlated with gametogenesis only in strains from the two southern-most locations, the James River and Delaware Bay, and never in those from Long Island Sound. We suggest that our observations resulted from interference by H. nelsoni in energy acquisition, storage, and conversion cycles of the oyster, which, in turn, differed seasonally according to geographic origin. Gonad development appeared to be more sensitive to parasitism when gametes were in the formative stage rather than after they had matured. Thus, southern strains, which were still in the early stages of gametogenesis when they experienced typical high parasite loads in late May, showed significantly greater inhibition than northern strains, which already had well-developed gonads at the same time. In contrast to most reports that environmental stress correlates with an increased ratio of males to females, we found a three-fold increase in the proportion of females among H. nelsoni-infected oysters compared to uninfected oysters. There was no evidence of sex-associated differential infection or mortality rates and we suggest that parasitism inhibits the development of male gametes more than female gametes. © 1990.
Index Keywords: disease; gametogenesis; oyster; parasite; selective breeding; sex ratio; USA, (Northeast), Delaware Bay; USA, (Northeast), Long Island Sound; USA, Virginia, James River; Crassostrea virginica; Haplosporidium nelsoni; Ostreidae

Abstract: A novel operating technique has been developed for a differential optical switch based on a set of parallel-connected pnpn structures. The differential function at 0.2nW input power and 400fJ input energy was realized with A1GaAs/GaAs pnpn devices. Its application to an optical S-R flip-flop was also demonstrated by introducing a storage operation of pnpn structures. © 1990 SPIE.

Title: Effects of UV-exposure and thermal history on properties of a preimidized photosensitive polyimide
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: IBM General Technology Div, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ree, Moonhor, IBM General Technology Div, United States; Chen, K.-J.Rex, IBM General Technology Div, United States
Abstract: The effects of UV-exposure and thermal history on both dynamic and static mechanical properties of Probimide 412 were studied. The stress-strain behavior at room temperature was strongly dependent upon thermal history including heat-treatment temperature and thermal annealing, but apparently independent upon the variation of exposure energy at i-line. The static mechanical properties were significantly degradated through heat-treatment at higher temperature than 350°C as well as thermal ageing over the range of 350°C approximately 400°C. For all the samples treated with various exposure energies and temperatures, their dynamic mechanical moduli (storage modulus E′ and loss modulus E″) did not show any dependency to exposure energy and thermal history below the glass transition temperature. However, its glass transition behavior was very sensitive to variations of exposure energy and thermal history. From DMTA and stress-strain results, it was evident that both thermal degradation (or thermal oxidation) and thermal crosslink formation are taken place during heat-treatment above 371°C or thermal ageing over 350°C through approx. 400°C for 10 hrs because of labile methyl and carbonyl groups of both BTDA dianhydride and aromatic diamine moieties on the polymer backbone.
Index Keywords: Copolymers--Radiation Effects; Plastics--Glass Transition; Polymers--Thermal Properties; Ultraviolet Radiation--Effects; Dynamic Mechanical Properties; Preimidized Photosensitive Polyimide; Probimide 412; Polyimides

Authors: Carlsson D.J., Chmela S., Lacoste J.
Title: Stabilization of polyolefins to γ-irradiation. The role of the initial radicals
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: Natl Research Council, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Carlsson, D.J., Natl Research Council, Canada; Chmela, S., Natl Research Council, Canada; Lacoste, J., Natl Research Council, Canada
Abstract: In this study we have identified and quantified several of the key intermediates in γ-irradiated polyolefins and examined the effects of various stabilizers on the product yields. It is shown that γ-irradiation of polyolefins gives rise to peroxyl radicals which are atypical of the subsequent chain oxidation process. The extensive chain oxidation leads to a mix of tert. and sec. hydroperoxides which approximates that expected from peroxyl reactivities. This mix overwhelms the low concentrations of products from the initial radicals even in well stabilized systems. Several stabilizer systems give high resistance to degradation during irradiation and storage and operate by suppressing the oxidative chain reactions.
Index Keywords: Antioxidants; Chemical Reactions--Free Radicals; Gamma Rays--Effects; Plastics--Stabilizers; High Energy Radiations; Hydroperoxides; Oxidative Chain Reactions; Polyolefins

Title: Dual-power autos take the wheel
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siuru, Bill, Mechanical Engineering, New York, United States
Abstract: While major improvements are on the horizon to increase the energy content of batteries, it is obvious that they will never reach the levels obtained quite easily with internal combustion engines. Nevertheless, electric vehicles are virtually noiseless and pollution-free, and are very good at conserving energy. The way to satisfy the need for cleaner-burning, more-energy-efficient, and quieter vehicles that still will satisfy consumer demands for performance may be the hybrid vehicle that capitalizes on the best features of both. This paper describes several hybrid designs currently in use.

Abstract: The authors describe a power supply for a pulsed CO2 laser that provides a variable regulated output to the high-voltage storage capacitor in the periodic mode. The supply charges the storage capacitor in one pulse by discharging a batching capacitor through a pulse transformer. The output voltage is controlled and regulated in a low-voltage circuit by short-circuiting the primary winding of the pulse transformer by a switching thyristor. The storage capacitor has a value of 0.1 μF, the voltage on the capacitor is variable to 25 kV, the repetition frequency is variable to 500 Hz, and the relative amplitude spread of the high-voltage pulses is ≤1%.

Abstract: The authors describe a transformerless high-voltage supply with a capacitive storage device for a gas-discharge flash lamp with a pulse repetition frequency of up to 50 Hz. Simple controller and charging- and discharging-commutator circuits and an original firing circuit provide a pulse power of 106 W for 200 μsec and a discharge amplitude of 2.2 kV.

Abstract: A compact gas-discharge laser that provides pulsed radiation over a wide spectral range (λ = 220-750 nm) is described. Authors: Sverdrup G.M., Buxton B.E., Chuang J.C., Casuccio G.S.
Title: Determination of Optimal Storage Conditions for Particle Samples
Affiliations: Battelle Memorial Institute, 505 King Avenue, Columbus, Ohio 43201-2693, United States; R. J. Lee Group, 350 Hochberg Road, Monroeville, Pennsylvania 15146, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sverdrup, G.M., Battelle Memorial Institute, 505 King Avenue, Columbus, Ohio 43201-2693, United States; Buxton, B.E., Battelle Memorial Institute, 505 King Avenue, Columbus, Ohio 43201-2693, United States; Chuang, J.C., Battelle Memorial Institute, 505 King Avenue, Columbus, Ohio 43201-2693, United States; Casuccio, G.S., R. J. Lee Group, 350 Hochberg Road, Monroeville, Pennsylvania 15146, United States
Abstract: Results are presented from laboratory studies on how to store particle samples to preserve them for chemical, physical, and biologic testing. Surrogate samples for power plant plume fly ash were created by using electrostatic precipitator (ESP) hopper ash. Particles of diameters less than 10 μm were suspended and mixed with three poly-cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH), one nitro-PAH, salt, and sulfuric acid. The particle mixture was then collected on filters to create surrogate samples. Samples were stored for periods of 30 and 120 days at either 20 or −79 ± 1 °C as well as under a set of variable conditions of temperature, light, and humidity. Gas chromatography/mass spectrometry and scanning electron microscopy with energy dispersive analysis were used to characterize changes in organic and elemental composition, particle size distribution, and particle morphology. Preservation of organic compounds in the samples was best achieved when the samples were packaged in Teflon-wrapped glass dishes. Both storage temperature and duration of storage can influence sample stability. In many cases storage at −79 °C provided statistically significant enhancement of organic compound stability after 120 days compared to storage at 20 °C. Particle agglomeration in some samples was suggested by microscopy results. Sulfuric acid had a deleterious effect on two of the spiked PAH. Considering all factors, the most favorable storage conditions were −79 °C in the dark. Under these conditions, loss of the lightest PAH (fluorene) was minimized; the heaviest PAH (chrysene) was stable for at least 120 days. © 1990, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Hydrocarbons - Aromatic; Materials - Storage; Sampling; Particle Samples; Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons; Air Pollution; air sampling; article; methodology; particulate matter; storage

Authors: Grønberg M., Terland O., Husebye E.S., Flatmark T.
Title: The effect of prenylamine and organic nitrates on the bioenergetics of bovine catecholamine storage vesicles
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, University of Bergen, Årstadveien 19, N-5009 Bergen, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Grønberg, M., Department of Biochemistry, University of Bergen, Årstadveien 19, N-5009 Bergen, Norway; Terland, O., Department of Biochemistry, University of Bergen, Årstadveien 19, N-5009 Bergen, Norway; Husebye, E.S., Department of Biochemistry, University of Bergen, Årstadveien 19, N-5009 Bergen, Norway; Flatmark, T., Department of Biochemistry, University of Bergen, Årstadveien 19, N-5009 Bergen, Norway
Abstract: We have compared the cardioprotective agents prenylamine and glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) with respect to their effects on the bioenergetics of catecholamine storage vesicles. Chromaffin granule ghosts, which have a well preserved ability to actively transport and store catecholamines, were used as a model for adrenergic synaptic vesicles due to their functional similarity. Prenylamine, which partially and reversibly deplete the endogenous stores of noradrenaline in adrenergic nerves and ganglia, was found to inhibit the generation of the transmembrane proton electrochemical gradient driven by a H+-lATPase, mainly by acting as an uncoupler of this ATPase. The inhibition of the energy dependent dopamine uptake (and noradrenaline biosynthesis) by prenylamine could be accounted for by its effect on the bioenergetics of the storage vesicles. The organic nitrates glyceryl trinitrate and isosorbide dinitrate also partly inhibited the catecholamine uptake in parallel with their effects on the proton electrochemical gradient. It is concluded that GTN is a weak catecholamine depletor. Experiments with 3-morpholinosydnonimin-hydrochloride, a source of nitric oxide (NO), opens up the possibility that the mechanism of inhibition of the bioenergetics of chromaffin granule ghosts by GTN is mediated by NO. © 1990.

Abstract: A variable energy (20÷100) MeV) racetrack microtron (RTM) is under construction at the ENEA Accelerator Laboratories, Frascati. This machine, designed to serve as a driver for a FEL source ((20÷30) MeV) in the infrared region, has other considerably interesting applications. All the components have been constructed with the exception of the extraction magnets. Successful tests have been made on the two main magnets and on the injection gun. The RF system can supply 5 MW, 5 μs peak power to the 2998 MHz, 5 MeV linac, which has already been tested at low power. In this paper we report a comparison between the computations and measurements performed up to the present stage of the project. © 1990 Società Italiana di Fisica.

Authors: Dunn J.P., Potter D.A., Kimmerer T.W.
Title: Carbohydrate reserves, radial growth, and mechanisms of resistance of oak trees to phloem-boring insects
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, University of Kentucky, Lexington, 40546-0091, KY, United States; Department of Forestry, University of Kentucky, Lexington, 40546-0091, KY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dunn, J.P., Department of Entomology, University of Kentucky, Lexington, 40546-0091, KY, United States; Potter, D.A., Department of Entomology, University of Kentucky, Lexington, 40546-0091, KY, United States; Kimmerer, T.W., Department of Forestry, University of Kentucky, Lexington, 40546-0091, KY, United States
Abstract: The twolined chestnut borer, Agrilus bilineatus (Weber) (Coleoptera: Buprestidae), attacks oaks (Quercus spp.) that have been weakened by prior environmental or biotic stress. Our earlier work showed that trees with relatively low winter starch reserves are more likely to be attacked by A. bilineatus the following summer. We hypothesized that such trees may have less energy available for defense (Callus formation and allelo-chemical synthesis) in tissues wounded by borer larvae. However, wounding experiments showed little or no relationship between winter or summer carbohydrate reserves, callus formation, radial growth, or concentrations of tannins and phenolics in wounded or nonwounded phloem tissues. Trees with relatively low winter carbohydrate reserves were again found to be attractive to adult A. bilineatus, although not all low starch trees were attacked or successfully colonized by borers. There was a trend for carpenterworm larvae, Prinoxystus robiniae (Lepidoptera: Cossidae), a generalist bark and wood borer, to be more successful in establishing galleries on low starch trees. Carpenterworms gained significantly more weight when fed phloem from trees attractive to A. bilineatus. Oaks that attracted large numbers of A. bilineatus or that were successfully colonized by the borer produced significantly less callus than did non-attacked trees when experimentally wounded at about the time of Agrilus egg hatch. Callus formation may limit the establishment of small larvae that feed slowly in the cambial region. These results indicate that current theory regarding relationships between increased tree stress and decreased allocation of energy reserves to radial growth and defense against phloem borers may be an oversimplification. We suggest that tree growth and the defensive response of phloem tissues may be limited more by the rate of carbohydrate utilization or by changes in source-sink relationships than by storage levels. Callus formation and synthesis of allelochemicals in wounded phloem may be under the same control as cambial activation, which is mediated by plant growth regulators and can be influenced by environmental conditions. © 1990 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Agrilus bilineatus; Buprestidae; Carbon allocation; Prionoxystus robiniae; Quercus

Authors: Hosokawa Teruo, Ido Satoshi, Nakata Jyoji, Nakajima Masayuki, Yamada Kouji
Title: Superconducting compact storage ring, Super-ALIS
Authors with affiliations: Hosokawa, Teruo; Ido, Satoshi; Nakata, Jyoji; Nakajima, Masayuki; Yamada, Kouji
Abstract: Super-ALIS is a superconducting electron storage ring. It has succeeded in the first SOR generation of a superconducting compact ring storing more than 100 mA beams. The lattice is a racetrack type of two bending and six quadrupole magnets achieving beam characteristics optimum for lithography. Super-ALIS employs a low-energy-one-pulse injection scheme. Injection energy is 15MeV and the final energy is 600MeV. To store large current beams using this scheme, a linac system with suitable characteristics has been developed. A novel beam wobbling system achieves ideal SOR vertical expansion.

Authors: Hayasaka Toa, Uno Yasumiti, Shibayama Akinori, Nishimura Kazuyoshi
Title: Normal-conducting Accelerating Ring (nar)
Authors with affiliations: Hayasaka, Toa; Uno, Yasumiti; Shibayama, Akinori; Nishimura, Kazuyoshi
Abstract: This paper presents a normal-conducting storage ring using a low-energy injection scheme by which electron energy is boosted from 15MeV (injection energy) to 800MeV (final energy). The design goals are a high energy injector for Super-ALIS and a multi purpose storage ring. To combine these functions, the ring has an octagonal configuration with 8 normal-conducting bending magnets. To achieve a high beam current, newly developed injection, RF and vacuum systems have been installed. A beam transport system has also been developed to connect the linear accelerator, Super-ALIS and the ring. Synchrotron radiation has been successfully extracted from this ring and it has also been used in the study of X-ray lithography.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Beam Injection; Electron Optics; Lithography - X-Ray; Synchrotron Radiation; Beam Transport System; Low-Energy Injection Scheme; Normal-Conducting Accelerating Ring; Super-ALIS Storage Ring; Accelerators, Linear

Title: Magnetic generators of high-power nanosecond pulses (review)
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Gor'kiy Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Meshkov, A.N., Gor'kiy Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: The study and development of nanosecond generators containing thyristors or thyratrons and ferrite compression sections are surveyed. Nonlinear devices for shaping and compression of nanosecond pulses are described. Design methods and characteristics are provided for generators with pulse durations of from 3 to 100 nsec and powers of from 10 MW to 7 GW.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electron Tubes, Thyratron; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Shaping; Magnetic Fields - Mathematical Models; Thyristors; Electric Chokes; Electric Transformers; Ferrite Applications; Magnetic Pulse Generators; Nanosecond Pulses; Permalloys; Pulse Generators

Authors: Cooper R.B., Dormuth K.W., Garg Ishwar D., Sherman Garry R., Truss Kent J., Willborn Walter
Title: Applying quality assurance to R&D projects
Authors with affiliations: Cooper, R.B.; Dormuth, K.W.; Garg, Ishwar D.; Sherman, Garry R.; Truss, Kent J.; Willborn, Walter
Abstract: The importance of developing and applying quality assurance (QA) principles to research and development projects has become especially clear to nuclear waste disposal research organizations. This has led Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL) and many other research organizations and professional societies to examine quality assurance practices closely and to adapt them to fit their own management styles and research objectives. The nature of research and development is quite different from that of manufacturing. Research organizations are faced with an imperative to implement quality assurance in their programs - but not in a way that will restrict the exploratory instincts of research staff or burden them with unnecessary bureaucracy or paperwork. The approach implemented by AECL is described, including the program background, project organization, tiers of documentation, document control and storage, program elements, the program at work, a geological pilot projects, and the need for flexibility and participation.
Index Keywords: Engineering Research; Information Retrieval Systems; Nuclear Engineering--Research; Nuclear Reactors--Waste Disposal; Radioactive Wastes--Disposal; Atomic Energy of Canada Limited; Documents; Geological Pilot Projects; Records; Research and Development; Software Development; Quality Assurance

Title: Interactive hypermedia training manual for spent-fuel bundle counters
Source title: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, AECL (Report)
Affiliations: Chalk River Lab, Chalk River, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Basso, R.A., Chalk River Lab, Chalk River, Canada; Coady, J.R., Chalk River Lab, Chalk River, Canada
Abstract: Spent-fuel bundle counters, developed by the Canadian Safeguards Support Program (CSSP) for the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), provide a secure and independent means of counting the number of irradiated fuel bundles discharged into the fuel storage bays at CANDU nuclear power stations. Paper manuals have been traditionally used to familiarize IAEA inspectors with the operation, maintenance and extensive reporting capabilities of the bundle counters. To further assist inspectors, an interactive training manual has been developed on an Apple Macintosh computer using hypermedia software. The manual uses interactive animation and sound, in conjunction with the traditional text and graphics, to simulate the underlying operation and logic of the bundle counters. This paper presents the key features of the interactive manual and highlights the advantages of this new technology for training.
Index Keywords: Personnel Training--Computer Applications; Bundle Counters; Hypermedia Software; Training Manuals; Nuclear Reactors

Title: Accuracy and efficiency in the binary star reflection effect
Affiliations: Department of Astronomy, University of Florida; Department of Astronomy, 211 Space Sciences Research Building, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, R.E., Department of Astronomy, University of Florida, Department of Astronomy, 211 Space Sciences Research Building, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Abstract: A rigorous treatment of the geometric and irradiation heating problems for the binary star reflection effect is given. The geometric and surface gravity features of the theory are developed in terms of equipotential level surfaces and are sufficiently general so as to include eccentric orbits and nonsynchronous (even centrifugally limited) rotation and to treat multiple reflection. After discussions of cases which have been adequately treated already, the need for improvements, requirements for a fully adequate theory, and some historical notes, the requisite physics, mathematics, and logic are presented. Explicit introduction of a reflection ratio (R-function) allows for a simple and natural separation of the bolometric heating problem (invoking conservation of energy) from the wavelength-specific reradiation problem. That function also facilitates solution of the multiple reflection problem in a simple and flexible iterative way. The computations are organized so that a given quantity is computed only as often as necessary, emphasizing the distinction between local surface quantities and aspect-related quantities. The local geometric, bolometric, and wavelength-specific quantities are grouped for storage according to how often they need to be recomputed. The logic for repeating or not repeating computations of local quantities in differential corrections solutions of eccentric orbit light curves is rather complicated, and it is given in a table of decision control integers which apply to a program block diagram. Some tests of a computer program based on this reflection model are given in the form of graphs in which program results are compared to a special exact case, and with results from the author's earlier program. The new program gives intuitively reasonable output for all tests, and the tests give an idea of how accurate the old program is, adopting the detailed reflection computations of the new program as a standard for comparison. A table is given which shows the convergence of the multiple reflection computations to a constant distribution of surface effective temperature.
Author Keywords: Stars: eclipsing binaries

Title: Synchrotron sideband spin resonances in high-energy electron storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mane, S.R., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: The spins of electron and positron beams circulating in high-energy storage rings become spontaneously polarized by the emission of synchrotron radiation. The equilibrium degree of polarization is strongly affected by so-called "spin resonances". This paper studies a subset of such resonances called "synchrotron sideband spin resonances". It is shown that the results from several previously published formalisms are equivalent, when the same approximations are made in all of them. In addition, some new calculations are presented, in particular the effects of orbital chromaticity. Some of the results are compared with experimental data, and the agreement is reasonable. © 1990.

Title: Monte Carlo simulations of thin internal targets in intermediate energy proton storage rings. F. Hinterberger, T. Mayer-Kuckuk and D. Prasuhn, Nucl. Instr. and Meth. A275 (1989) 239-245.

Title: Unsteady mass transfer from a vertical plate in a transverse magnetic field
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University, Abbassia, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Radwan, A.E., Department of Mathematics, Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University, Abbassia, Cairo, Egypt; Elbashbeshy, E.M.A., Department of Mathematics, Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University, Abbassia, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Unsteady mass transfer from a vertical plate in a transverse magnetic field is investigated assuming that all the fluid properties are constant. The solution is dependent on two parameters, namely the Prandtl number, Pr, and the Schmidt number, Sc. An analytical solution is presented which is valid at small values of time and this solution is extended to large values of time by using a modified Crank-Nicolson scheme. © 1990 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: PACS 84.60 Direct energy conversion and energy storage

Title: Mass transfer over stretching surface with variable concentration in a transverse magnetic field
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University, Abbassia, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Radwan, A.E., Department of Mathematics, Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University, Abbassia, Cairo, Egypt; Elbashbeshy, E.M.A., Department of Mathematics, Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University, Abbassia, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Mass transfer over stretching surface with variable concentration in a transverse magnetic field is examined. The boundary layer equations are transformed to ordinary differential equations, containing the magnetic parameter Mn and the concentration parameter λ. Numerical results for different values of the Schmidt number are presented. It is observed that the local mass transfer and concentration profile are very sensitive to the change in the values of the magnetic parameter Mn and the concentration parameter λ. © 1990 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: PACS 84.60 Direct energy conversion and energy storage

Authors: Köhler H., Diederich S., Kinzel W., Opper M.
Title: Learning algorithm for a neural network with binary synapses
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik B Condensed Matter
Affiliations: Institut für Theoretische Physik, Justus-Liebig-Universität, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, Giessen, D-6300, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Köhler, H., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Justus-Liebig-Universität, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, Giessen, D-6300, Germany; Diederich, S., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Justus-Liebig-Universität, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, Giessen, D-6300, Germany; Kinzel, W., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Justus-Liebig-Universität, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, Giessen, D-6300, Germany; Opper, M., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Justus-Liebig-Universität, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, Giessen, D-6300, Germany
Abstract: A learning mechanism for neural networks with binary synapses is defined and investigated. The algorithm is based on minimizing the energy of an Ising model. A replica symmetric calculation gives a parameter range where perfect learning is possible. A simple descent algorithm is studied by numerical simulation; and storage capacities, learning times and basins of attraction are determined. © 1990 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Stockbauer R.L., Poliakoff E.D., Ajmera P., Craft B.C., Saile V.
Title: Centre for Advanced Microstructures and Devices (CAMD) at Louisiana State University
Affiliations: Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA, 70803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stockbauer, R.L., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA, 70803, United States; Poliakoff, E.D., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA, 70803, United States; Ajmera, P., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA, 70803, United States; Craft, B.C., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA, 70803, United States; Saile, V., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA, 70803, United States
Abstract: The Centre for Advanced Microstructures and Devices (CAMD) has been established by the Department of Energy at Louisiana State University for the expressed purpose of developing X-ray lithography based techniques for manufacturing microcircuits. The heart of the Center will be a synchrotron light source optimized for the soft X-ray region and will be the first commercially manufactured electron storage ring in the United States. The magnet lattice is based on a design developed by Chasman and Green and will be similar to the VUV ring at Brookhaven NSLS and will operate at 1.2 GeV with a critical wavelength of 9.5 Å. Straight sections will allow up to three insertion devices to be installed for higher energy and higher intensity radiation. In addition to the lithography effort, experimental programs are being established in physics, chemistry, and related areas. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Authors: Mcnamara J.M., Houston A.I., Krebs J.R.
Title: Why hoard? The economics of food storing in tits, Parus spp.
Affiliations: School of Mathematics, University of Bristol, Bristol BS8 1TW, United Kingdom; King's College Research Centre, King's College, Cambridge CB2 1ST, United Kingdom; Edward Grey Institute of Field Ornithology, Department of Zoology, South Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3PS, United Kingdom; NERC Unit of Behavioural Ecology, Department of Zoology, South Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3PS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mcnamara, J.M., School of Mathematics, University of Bristol, Bristol BS8 1TW, United Kingdom; Houston, A.I., King's College Research Centre, King's College, Cambridge CB2 1ST, United Kingdom, NERC Unit of Behavioural Ecology, Department of Zoology, South Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3PS, United Kingdom; Krebs, J.R., Edward Grey Institute of Field Ornithology, Department of Zoology, South Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3PS, United Kingdom
Abstract: We present two models of food storage by small birds such as tits (Parus spp): a simple, energy-maximizing model and a more complex dynamic programming model. The results show that hoarding is advantageous when (1) the metabolic costs of carrying reserves are high, (2) food supply is variable, (3) the mean rate of intake is low, and (4) overnight expenditure of energy is high. The dynamic programming model predicts daily routines of storing and retrieval as well as changes in body mass. The predicted routine (storage in the early part of the day, retrieval near dusk) has been observed in some species that store food. We predict differences in the pattern of change of body mass through the day between storers and nonstorers, but data to test this prediction are not yet available. © 1990 International Society for Behavioural Ecology.
Index Keywords: food storing; hoarding; tit; Aves; Parus

Authors: Movshevich B.Z., Kopelovich E.A., Kuznetsov Yu.A.
Title: Generator of strong periodic magnetic-field pulses
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Gor'kiy, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Movshevich, B.Z., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Gor'kiy, Russian Federation; Kopelovich, E.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Gor'kiy, Russian Federation; Kuznetsov, Yu.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Gor'kiy, Russian Federation
Abstract: The authors describe a generator of periodic magnetic-field pulses of sinusoidal and quasi-square shape with amplitudes of 56 and 40 kOe respectively and an instability of ≈0.1% for a maximum pulse repetition frequency of 20 Hz. A feature of the device is the unipolar operation of its storage capacitors, which ensures high reliability in the periodic mode. The storage capacitors are charged by a high-frequency pulse converter with capacitor energy dosage and a maximum output power of 17.6 kW. Expressions are derived for estimation of converter efficiency and the instability of the charging voltage of the storage capacitors. The generator's control circuit and its algorithm are examined.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Shaping; Magnetic Fields - Production; Solenoids; Thyristors; Counting Circuits; Digital to Analog Converters; Flip Flop Circuits; Integrated Circuits; Pulsed Magnetic Fields; Timing Charts; Pulse Generators

Authors: Arzin A.P., Tsygankov V.V., Shtein Yu.G.
Title: Pulsed solenoid for devices of relativistic microwave electronics
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Arzin, A.P., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Tsygankov, V.V., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Shtein, Yu.G., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: The authors describe and provide the results of magnetic-field measurements for a pulsed solenoid with natural cooling that is designed to produce a field with an induction of up to 3 T in a space 1 m long and 22 cm in diameter. The energy and voltage on the capacitive storage device and the current amplitude are studied experimentally as functions of the frequency of the discharge circuit.

Title: Nutritional aspects of irradiated mangoes. A review
Source title: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, AECL (Report)
Affiliations: Whiteshell Nuclear Research, Establishment, Pinawa, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Singh, Harwant, Whiteshell Nuclear Research, Establishment, Pinawa, Canada
Abstract: Mangoes, like most other fruits, constitute a small but very important part of human diet in tropical countries. Their carbohydrate content is a source of energy; however, their main importance is as a rich source of vitamins, particularly vitamins A and C. Increasing the shelf life of mangoes is desirable, since on ripening they become highly perishable and have a very short shelf life. Low-dose irradiation is considered to be a good method for extending their shelf life. This literature review examines the effect of radiation processing on the nutrients in mangoes. In general, irradiation has little effect on the main nutrients, vitamin C, carotenoids and carbohydrates. There is a significant loss of vitamin C only in a few varieties of mangoes, while in the others the vitamin C level is unaffected. The extension of shelf life also depends on the storage conditions, particularly temperature. While low-temperature storage followed by ripening at room temperature leads to high vitamin C levels, it reduces the carotenoid levels in some varieties. Thus, the storage and the ripening temperatures should be optimized for each variety to obtain the maximum benefit of irradiation. Long-term, multi-generation rat feeding studies to assess the wholesomeness of irradiated mangoes have shown no adverse effects.
Index Keywords: Health Care - Nutrition; Mangoes; Radiation Processing; Ripening Process; Shell Life Extension; Food Products

Title: Gas/electric cold-air systems
Affiliations: Meckler Associates, P.C., Herndon, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, Gershon, Meckler Associates, P.C., Herndon, United States
Abstract: A gas-driven cold air/water system without thermal storage has been developed for office buildings and shopping centers to reduce the first cost and the energy cost of cold-air systems and to provide 40°F cold-air system options that do not overdry the air. This article describes: a gas energized cold air/water HVAC system that uses a desiccant plus 50°F chilled water to produce 40°F air; results of a study comparing the cold air/water gas cooling system with a cold all-air/partial ice system and a conventional 55°F all-air VAV system in terms of peak refrigeration requirement annual energy cost and system first cost; the impact of various utility rate structures on the energy cost of the three HVAC systems compared, and cold air/water gas cooling system benefits.
Index Keywords: Air - Cooling; Energy Utilization - Costs; Refrigerators - Gas Fuel; Water Cooling Systems; Cold-Air Systems; Desiccants; Energy Cost; Gas-Driven Cold Air/Water System; Peak Refrigeration Requirement; Buildings

Title: Mass formula dependence of calculated spallation reaction product distributions
Authors with affiliations: Nishida, T.; Nakahara, Y.
Abstract: A new version of the spallation reaction simulation code NUCLEUS was developed by incorporating Uno and Yamada's mass formula. This version was used to calculate the distribution of products from the spallation of uranium nuclei by high-energy protons. The dependence of the distributions on the mass formula was examined by comparing the results with those from the original version, which is based on Cameron's mass formula and the mass table compiled by Wapstra et al. As regards the fission component of spallation products, the new version reproduces the reaction product data obtained from thin-foil experiments much better, especially on the neutron excess side.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Statistics - Monte Carlo Methods; Nuclear Energy - Fission Reactions; Nuclides - Radioactive; Physics - Nuclear; Protons - High Energy; High-Energy Fission Products; High-Energy Proton Bombardment; Nuclear Spallation Reactions; Transuranic Waste Storage Time Reduction; Transuranic Waste Transmutation; Uranium Nuclei Spallation; Radioactive Wastes

Title: Design of coal bins and feeders for maintenance
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Univ of Wollongong, Wollongong
Authors with affiliations: McLean, A.G., Univ of Wollongong, Wollongong
Abstract: Modern coal utilization plant operation demands reliable and uniform flow of bulk solids without the use of expensive and energy consuming flow promotion devices. This operation requires the bin and feeder be maintained at some future date. Often it is found that little attention has been given to maintenance requirements of these vital plant components at the design stage. This neglect, results inefficient and costly coal handling systems. To reduce the overall long term operation costs associated with coal handling and storage it is essential that maintenance requirements be considered at the plant design stage. To this end a number of essential maintenance requirements are declared which should be incorporated in future coal plant designs. These design suggestions are presented for both coarse and pulverized coal handling systems. Furthermore the attainment and maintenance of convenient and safe work conditions and practices is stressed.
Index Keywords: Bins--Design; Coal Bins Design; Coal Plant Maintenance; Feeders Design; Material Handling Equipment; Coal Handling

Authors: Rustan P.L., Verga R.L., Nikolich M., Wiley R.L., Straw D.C.
Title: SDIO pulsed power R&D requirements
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Strategic Defense Initiative Organ,, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rustan, P.L., Strategic Defense Initiative Organ,, Washington, DC, USA; Verga, R.L., Strategic Defense Initiative Organ,, Washington, DC, USA; Nikolich, M., Strategic Defense Initiative Organ,, Washington, DC, USA; Wiley, R.L., Strategic Defense Initiative Organ,, Washington, DC, USA; Straw, D.C., Strategic Defense Initiative Organ,, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The Strategic Defense Initiative Organization (SDIO) performs pulse power research and technology base development to satisfy the requirements of six major systems: neutral particle beams, space-based free electron lasers, ground-based lasers, electromagnetic launchers, laser radars, and high power microwaves. The research is focused on component development, with mass, volume, and efficiency being the key technology drivers. Order-of-magnitude improvements are required in order to meet the requirements. These development efforts overall include the power conditioning devices and components that are needed to match the electrical characteristics of the power source with those required by the load. Technology areas include energy storage, switching, and power conversion. The authors detail the specific component requirements and two space experiments integrating developmental components: the space power experiment aboard rocket (SPEAR) and the beam power experiment aboard rocket (BEAR).
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic Launchers; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Signal; Lasers, Free Electron; Rockets and Missiles; Power Conditioning; Pulse Generators

Authors: Lindmayer Joseph, Goldsmith Paul, Gross Kirk
Title: Electron trapping optical technology. Memory's next generation?
Affiliations: Optex Corp
Authors with affiliations: Lindmayer, Joseph, Optex Corp; Goldsmith, Paul, Optex Corp; Gross, Kirk, Optex Corp
Abstract: No one data storage technology fulfills all the needs of the marketplace. This situation, has given way to research on other technologies that do offer the potential to satisfy all the demands of the marketplace. One of the most promising of these technologies is electron trapping optical memory or ETOM. Ideal erasable optical memories for computing systems should be very fast and have very high capacity in relatively small form factors to be compatible with advancing processing requirements. ETOM addresses a means to achieve such memories. An ETOM disk is coated with II-VI phosphor material; rare-earth dopants are added to create various trapping levels. When the material is illuminated with a blue laser, electrons are accelerated to a higher energy state where they remain trapped at levels determined by the dopant materials. The absorption of an infrared photon gives an electron enough energy to elevate it out of the trap, allowing it to return to the ground state and release the stored energy in the form of visible light.
Index Keywords: Optoelectronic Devices; Electron Trapping Optical Memory; Optical Memory Systems; Data Storage, Optical

Authors: Roush R.A., Mazzola M.S., Schoenbach K.H., Lakdawala V.K.
Title: Optical quenching of lock-on currents in GaAs:Si:Cu switches
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Old Dominion Univ, Norfolk, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Roush, R.A., Old Dominion Univ, Norfolk, VA, USA; Mazzola, M.S., Old Dominion Univ, Norfolk, VA, USA; Schoenbach, K.H., Old Dominion Univ, Norfolk, VA, USA; Lakdawala, V.K., Old Dominion Univ, Norfolk, VA, USA
Abstract: Infrared quenching of lock-on currents has been demonstrated in a photoconductive GaAs:Si:Cu switch. After quenching of the persistent photocurrent, the current recovers in about 25 ns to a constant value. The persistent photo and dark currents are considered to be due to double injection of carriers through the ohmic contacts of the photoconductive switch. It is noted that optical quenching of lock-on current offers the possibility of using GaAs:Si:Cu switches in high-rep-rate inductive energy storage systems.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Semiconducting Gallium Arsenide; Inductive Energy Storage; IR Quenching; Lock-On Currents; Optical Quenching; Electric Switches, Semiconductor

Title: Thermal energy storage in concrete and mud for crop storage
Source title: AMA, Agricultural Mechanization in Asia, Africa and Latin America
Affiliations: ENSIAAC, Ngaoundere, Cameroon
Authors with affiliations: Baryeh, Edward A., ENSIAAC, Ngaoundere, Cameroon
Abstract: Insulated concrete and mud heat storage units in the form of tubes and slabs have been investigated theoretically and experimentally. Solar-heated air and air blown around a hot internal combustion engine were passed through the tubes and slabs. Fluid exit temperature of up to 90°C was recorded at the end of 5 h. The concrete temperature varied from 116°C to 80°C for the tube and 116°C to 72°C for the slab. Corresponding values for mud tube and slab were 120°C to 92°C and 120°C to 88°C, respectively. The heat stored after 5 h in the concrete tube and slab were 5.75 × 104 and 4.75 × 104 kJ, respectively, while those for the mud tube and slab were 6.20 × 104 and 5.25 × 104 kJ, respectively. The heat stored(O) with time(t) was found to be related by a formula: Q = A*e-bt, where A* and b are constants. The effectiveness of heat storage increased with increasing time and decreasing storage length.
Index Keywords: Agricultural Products - Storage; Concrete - Energy Storage; Soils - Energy Storage; Solar Radiation; Waste Heat Utilization; Mud; Thermal Energy; Agricultural Engineering

Title: Power supply considerations for pulsed solid-state radar
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electric Corp,, Baltimore, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gardenghi, R.A., Westinghouse Electric Corp,, Baltimore, MD, USA; Houlne, R.C., Westinghouse Electric Corp,, Baltimore, MD, USA
Abstract: It is pointed out that high-power, pulsed, solid-state radar transmitters require special considerations for the power supplies. Unlike their vacuum tube predecessors, the solid-state transmitter amplifier operates from a low voltage (LV) power supply. High power at low voltage implies very high peak currents. The state of art is such that these high peak currents must be provided by energy storage capacitors located in close proximity to the RF power amplifiers. The power supply, then, must serve the function of a precision capacitor recharging circuit. The power supply is an integral part of the transmitter design and its design requirements are driven by the RF output power and transmitter stability requirements. The stability of the power supply is one of the most important factors in achieving the specified performance criteria for the radar system.
Index Keywords: Amplifiers, Power Type; Capacitors--Energy Storage; Pulse Generators; Semiconductor Devices; Solid State Devices; Pulsed Radar Transmitters; Solid-State Radar; Radar Transmitters

Authors: Zhang W., Zhang S.Y., Soukas A.V., Frey W.W.
Title: A PFN and transmission line simulation method for energy discharge systems
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Brookhaven Nat Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, W., Brookhaven Nat Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Zhang, S.Y., Brookhaven Nat Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Soukas, A.V., Brookhaven Nat Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Frey, W.W., Brookhaven Nat Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: An analysis and simulation algorithm for energy discharge systems consisting of a pulse forming network and a transmission line are discussed. The network formulation is represented in the state space form, and the analysis is based on the network eigensystem. In an energy discharge network, the time response is governed by the system eigenvalues, their weights, and the initial states of the energy storage elements. Therefore, the eigensystem analysis can be applied to simulate the system time response. This method differs from the time difference equation step-iterative simulation in the following aspects: (1) the accuracy of the simulation mainly relies on the eigensystem parameter evaluation; there is no cumulative time step iteration error; (2) the simulation of the network response can be calculated from any moment of time, rather than from the initial time only; and (3) since the method also provides information on the network characteristics, a model reduction can be readily obtained. Some simulation examples are presented.
Index Keywords: Electric Discharges; Electric Networks--Transmission Line Theory; Energy Discharge Systems; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Shaping

Authors: Strickland B.E., Cooper J.R., Cathell F., Garbi M., Eckhouse S.
Title: A solid state modulator using energy recovery to deliver 20 kVA to an inductive load from a 2.5 kJ/s power source
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Strickland, B.E., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Cooper, J.R., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Cathell, F., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Garbi, M., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Eckhouse, S., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: A modulator using an energy recovery scheme has been developed which is capable of delivering 20 kW to an inductive load from a 2.5 kJ/s power supply. The modulator delivers peak current pulses of 390 A to 27 μH load at a repetition rate of 10 kHz with a current regulation of 0.1%. The modulator uses arrays of MOSFETs as the switching elements and a Maxwell capacitor charging power supply, model CCDS-2.502. The modulator can be conveniently reconfigured to vary the load current and energy/pulse delivered to the load. For applications requiring peak output currents greater than ≈400 A, the modulator efficiency will decrease. As a result, the maximum power which can be delivered to the load will be limited by the capacitor charging power supply. The efficiency of the modulator can be tailored to the specific application requirements by properly choosing the number of MOSFETs which comprise the FET arrays and paying close attention to the high-frequency characteristics of the energy storage capacitor.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Semiconductor Devices, MOSFET; Transistors, Field Effect; Capacitor Charging; Maxwell Capacitors; Solid-State Modulators; Modulators

Authors: Smith R.E.H., Clement P., Head E.J.
Title: Night metabolism of recent photosynthate by sea ice algae in the high Arctic
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Waterloo University, Waterloo, N2L 3G1, Ontario, Canada; Biological Oceanography, Bedford Institute of Oceanography, Dartmouth, B2Y 4A2, Nova Scotia, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Smith, R.E.H., Department of Biology, Waterloo University, Waterloo, N2L 3G1, Ontario, Canada; Clement, P., Biological Oceanography, Bedford Institute of Oceanography, Dartmouth, B2Y 4A2, Nova Scotia, Canada; Head, E.J., Biological Oceanography, Bedford Institute of Oceanography, Dartmouth, B2Y 4A2, Nova Scotia, Canada
Abstract: Changes in intracellular distribution of recent (labelled) photosynthate during light-dark incubations were consistent with overnight consumption of low molecular weight compounds and carbohydrate, but continued protein synthesis, in sea ice algae from Resolute Passage, Canada, during April and May, 1986. Synthesis of labelled protein at night varied with preceding light availability but was always less than 30% of the daytime rate. Comparisons of labelled photosynthate dynamics against oxygen consumption and net changes of particulate matter composition and concentration showed that soluble polysaccharide was not the only major metabolic substrate, and that much of the carbon lost overnight was not recent, labelled photosynthate. Total net lipid synthesis was greatly underestimated by labelled photosynthate allocation. However, overnight consumption of the labelled lipid was directly proportional to photon flux density in the preceding light period, suggesting a short-term energy storage function for the small labelled portion of the total lipid pool. Arctic ice algae appear to incorporate only limited amounts of recent photosynthate into their large lipid pools even over a full 24 h photoperiod. © 1990 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: alga; arctic; article; metabolism; nonhuman; photosynthesis; algae

Title: Loss of mating flight and shift in the pattern of carbohydrate storage in sexuals of ants (Hymenoptera; Formicidae)
Affiliations: Laboratoire d'Entomologie, Université Paul-Sabatier, URA CNRS 333, Toulouse, F-31062, France; Musée Zoologique, CP 448, Lausanne 17, CH-1000, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Passera, L., Laboratoire d'Entomologie, Université Paul-Sabatier, URA CNRS 333, Toulouse, F-31062, France; Keller, L., Musée Zoologique, CP 448, Lausanne 17, CH-1000, Switzerland
Abstract: In ants, energy for flying is derived from carbohydrates (glycogen and free sugars). The amount of these substrates was compared in sexuals participating or not participating in mating flights. Results show that in participating females (Lasius niger, L. flavus, Myrmica scabrinodis, Formica rufa, F. polyctena, F. lugubris), the amount of carbohydrates, especially glycogen, was higher than in non-participating females (Cataglyphis cursor, Iridomyrmex humilis). Similarly, male C. cursor and I. humilis which fly, exhibit a much higher carbohydrate content than do the non-flying females of these species. Furthermore, the quantity of carbohydrates stored was generally higher in males than in females for each species. These results are discussed with regard to the loss of the nuptial flight by some species of ants. © 1990 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Ants; Mating flight glycogen storage
Index Keywords: carbohydrate; animal cell; ant; arthropod; article; flight; mating; nonhuman

Authors: McClintock J.B., Cameron J.L., Young C.M.
Title: Biochemical and energetic composition of bathyal echinoids and an asteroid, holothuroid and crinoid from the Bahamas
Affiliations: Department of Biology, University of Alabama at Birmingham, University Station, Birmingham, 35294, Alabama, United States; Department of Larval Ecology, Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institution, 5600 Old Dixie Highway, Fort Pierce, 34946, Florida, United States
Authors with affiliations: McClintock, J.B., Department of Biology, University of Alabama at Birmingham, University Station, Birmingham, 35294, Alabama, United States; Cameron, J.L., Department of Larval Ecology, Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institution, 5600 Old Dixie Highway, Fort Pierce, 34946, Florida, United States; Young, C.M., Department of Larval Ecology, Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institution, 5600 Old Dixie Highway, Fort Pierce, 34946, Florida, United States
Abstract: The biochemical and energetic composition of body components of ten species of bathyal echinoids, and an asteroid, a holothuroid and a stalked crinoid were determined from individuals sampled from a variety of deep-water sites near the Bahamas (north Caribbean Sea) in October 1988. When compared with other studies of echinoderms, no geographic- or depth-related differences in biochemical or energetic composition were found. Body-wall tissues were composed primarily of skeletal material (mineral ash), but were comparatively high in organic material in the echinothuriid echinoids, and the asteroid and holothuroid. Gut tissues and pyloric cecae had high levels of lipid and protein, indicating their potential role in nutrient storage. Body-wall tissues were generally low in energy, but were highest in the echinoids Araeosoma belli (7.7 kJ g-1 dry wt) and Sperosoma antillense (8.0 kJ g-1 dry wt), the asteroid Ophidiaster alexandri (8.9 kJ g-1 dry wt), and the holothuroid Eostichopus regalis (13.1 kJ g-1 dry wt). Energy levels of gut and pyloric cecal tissues were two to three times higher than those of body-wall tissues. Total somatic tissue energy values varied greatly among species, ranging from 1.5 kJ in the echinoid Aspidodiadema jacobyi to 142.1 kJ in E. regalis. As the bathyal echinoderms examined in this study occur in great abundance, they represent a significant reservoir of organic and inorganic materials and energy in deep-water benthic systems. © 1990 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: animal cell; animal experiment; article; benthos; chemical analysis; echinoderm; energy resource; invertebrate; marine environment; nonhuman; species difference; Animalia; Araeosoma belli; Aspidodiadema jacobyi; Asteroidea; Crinoidea; Echinodermata; Echinoidea; Echinothuriidae; Holothuroidea; Invertebrata; Ophidiaster; Sperosoma antillense

Title: Influences of season and water depth on the clonal biology of the seagrass Thalassia testudinum
Affiliations: Department of Biology, University of South Florida, Tampa, 33620, Florida, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tomasko, D.A., Department of Biology, University of South Florida, Tampa, 33620, Florida, United States; Dawes, C.J., Department of Biology, University of South Florida, Tampa, 33620, Florida, United States
Abstract: Ramet density, leaf relative growth rates, leaf chlorophyll levels, and proximate constituent levels were determined on three dates in 1988 at three water depths for a Thalassia testudinum Banks ex Konig meadow in lower Tampa Bay, Florida, USA. Density varied seasonally in patterns unique to each depth. Leaf relative growth rates indicated a unimodal, rather than bimodal, growth pattern at this site. Leaf chlorophyll levels reflected both depth-related and seasonal influences, with levels at all depths increasing in times of high light attenuation. Based on results from leaf relative growth rates and proximate constituent levels, the degree of ramet interdependence appears to vary with sampling date and water depth. The degree of ramet interdependence appears to be maximal in times of genet expansion (June and August) and minimal in times of energy storage (November). Interdependence of ramets varies spatially as well; ramets are maximally integrated in shallow regions (on those dates when genet proliferation occurs), and minimally integrated at deep edges. Depth-related differences in ramet integration are probably due to the spatial heterogeneity of the primary resource limitation varying with water depth, and to depth-related differences in ramet population dynamics. Patterns of ramet physiological integration in T. testudinum are similar to the patterns reported for terrestrial clonal plants. © 1990 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: article; clone; growth rate; marine environment; plant; plant leaf; seasonal variation; Genetta; Halophila; Thalassia testudinum

Authors: Pei Y., Shen X., Xu J.
Title: Bench measurements of the loss impedance in parts of an electron storage ring
Affiliations: Hefei National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China; Institute of High Energy Physics, Academia Sinica, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Pei, Y., Hefei National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China; Shen, X., Hefei National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China; Xu, J., Institute of High Energy Physics, Academia Sinica, Beijing, China
Abstract: The principle for measuring the loss impedance of a storage ring, which is caused by the energy loss of the stored bunched beam in passing through discontinuous parts of the vacuum chamber of the ring, is discussed and the set up to measure the loss impedance of the HESYRL storage ring is described. The measurement results of the energy loss and loss impedance of the kicker vacuum chamber, the septum vacuum chamber and other parts to be installed on the HESYRL storage ring are given. Some of the results are consistent with those measured in DESY. The results would be useful to design and improve these parts. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Authors: Owens T.G., Carpentier R., Leblanc R.M.
Title: Detection of photosynthetic energy storage in a photosystem I reaction center preparation by photoacoustic spectroscopy
Affiliations: Section of Plant Biology, Cornell University, Ithaca, 14853-5908, NY, United States; Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, G9A 5H7, Québec, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Owens, T.G., Section of Plant Biology, Cornell University, Ithaca, 14853-5908, NY, United States; Carpentier, R., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, G9A 5H7, Québec, Canada; Leblanc, R.M., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, G9A 5H7, Québec, Canada
Abstract: Thermal emission and photochemical energy storage were examined in photosystem I reaction center/core antenna complexes (about 40 Chl a/P700) using photoacoustic spectroscopy. Satisfactory signals could only be obtained from samples bound to hydroxyapatite and all samples had a low signal-to-noise ratio compared to either PS I or PS II in thylakoid membranes. The energy storage signal was saturated at low intensity (half saturation at 1.5 W m-2) and predicted a photochemical quantum yield of >90%. Exogenous donors and acceptors had no effect on the signal amplitudes indicating that energy storage is the result of charge separation between endogenous components. Fe(CN)6-3 oxidation of P700 and dithionite-induced reduction of acceptors FA-FB inhibited energy storage. These data are compatible with the hypothesis that energy storage in PS I arises from charge separation between P700 and Fe-S centers FA-FB that is stable on the time scale of the photoacoustic modulation. High intensity background light (160 W m-2) caused an irreversible loss of energy storage and correlated with a decrease in oxidizable P700; both are probably the result of high light-induced photoinhibition. By analogy to the low fluorescence yield of PS I, the low signal-to-noise ratio in these preparations is attributed to the short lifetime of Chl singlet excited states in PS I-40 and its indirect effect on the yield of thermal emission. © 1990 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: energy conversion; P700; photosynthesis; quantum yield; thermal emission

Title: Holographic associative memories
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Hughes Research Laboratories, Malibu, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Owechko, Y., Hughes Research Laboratories, Malibu, CA, United States
Abstract: A Lyapunov or "energy" function based on Kosko's BAM modelof associative memory is derived for optical associative memories basedon thin holograms in a nonlinear cavity. The dynamic behavior is illustrated using computer simulations. © 1990 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Associative processing; Associative storage; Holograms; Light modulation; Associative memory; Dynamic behaviors; Holographic associative memory; Nonlinear cavities; Optical associative memory; Light modulators

Title: Calculated performance of ALS undulator U3.9: Operation at dual wavelengths and high harmonics
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Department of Physics Z-3800, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, N Y 11794, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jacobsen, C., Department of Physics Z-3800, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, N Y 11794, United States
Abstract: Calculations of the spectral output of Advanced Light Source undulator U3.9 are presented. Effects of electron beam emittance and energy spread are included, and undulator magnet field errors are treated approximately so usable estimates of the output of high-harmonic radiation can be made. These calculations indicate that several harmonics can be used simultaneously for obtaining soft X-rays in the λ = 23-44 Å "water window" spectral range. In addition, it is shown that there is an intermediate range of photon energies (∼1-3 keV) where high harmonic undulator radiation is significantly affected by electron beam energy spread and undulator magnet field errors, yet where U3.9 will still outperform ALS wiggler W13.6 for many applications. This intermediate zone between pure undulator and pure wiggler performance may prove useful for extending the energy range at which brightness-sensitive experiments can be done at storage rings of a given electron beam energy. © 1990.

Authors: Green M.A., Frederick Dylla H., Hartline R.E., Jacobsen R.A., Manos D.M., Ng L.B., Rhodes M.A., Robinson B., Schofield G.L., Smith C.G., Thomas K.M., Wang D.Y., Younger F.C.
Title: Commercially designed and manufactured storage ring for synchrotron radiation applications
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Brobeck Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 1235 Tenth Street, Berkeley, CA 94710-1593, United States; Princeton Scientific Consultants, Inc., P.O.
