Authors with affiliations: Green, M.A., Brobeck Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 1235 Tenth Street, Berkeley, CA 94710-1593, United States; Frederick Dylla, H., Princeton Scientific Consultants, Inc., P.O. Box 2181, Princeton, NJ 08543, United States; Hartline, R.E., Brobeck Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 1235 Tenth Street, Berkeley, CA 94710-1593, United States; Jacobsen, R.A., Balboa Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 8888 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, CA 92123, United States; Manos, D.M., Princeton Scientific Consultants, Inc., P.O. Box 2181, Princeton, NJ 08543, United States; Ng, L.B., Brobeck Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 1235 Tenth Street, Berkeley, CA 94710-1593, United States; Rhodes, M.A., Balboa Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 8888 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, CA 92123, United States; Robinson, B., Brobeck Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 1235 Tenth Street, Berkeley, CA 94710-1593, United States; Schofield, G.L., Balboa Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 8888 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, CA 92123, United States; Smith, C.G., Brobeck Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 1235 Tenth Street, Berkeley, CA 94710-1593, United States; Thomas, K.M., Brobeck Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 1235 Tenth Street, Berkeley, CA 94710-1593, United States; Wang, D.Y., Brobeck Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 1235 Tenth Street, Berkeley, CA 94710-1593, United States; Younger, F.C., Brobeck Division, Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 1235 Tenth Street, Berkeley, CA 94710-1593, United States
Abstract: Electron storage ring technology is now some twenty-odd years old and is both well-advanced and accepted. As a natural consequence, the commercial manufacture of such machines is becoming a reality. This paper describes the design of what is to be the first industrially manufactured electron storage ring in the United States. As such, the design represents an outstanding example of technology transfer from US national laboratories into the private sector. The design described in this paper, for the Center for Advanced Microstructures and Devices (CAMD) facility at Louisiana State University (LSU) [B.C. Craft et al., Nucl. Instr. and Meth. B40/41 (1989) 379; R.L. Stockbauer et al., these Proceedings, p. 505], features "low energy" injection, at 200 MeV, which is only a fraction of the 1.4-GeV peak energy. Nominal operation will be at 1.2 GeV with a beam current of 400 mA and an emittance of 2 × 10-7π m rad. The corresponding value of critical wavelength is λc = 9.5 A ̊. © 1990.

Title: Survey of compact storage rings in Japan
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: KEK, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, 1-1 Oho, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki-ken, 305, Japan; The Graduate University for Advanced Studies, 4259, Nagatsuda-cho, Midori-ku, Yokohama-shi, 227, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hirabayashi, H., KEK, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, 1-1 Oho, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki-ken, 305, Japan, The Graduate University for Advanced Studies, 4259, Nagatsuda-cho, Midori-ku, Yokohama-shi, 227, Japan
Abstract: The present status of Japanese compact electron storage rings, used as synchrotron orbital radiation (SOR) sources is surveyed. Typical compact storage rings are UV sources and soft-X-ray sources below 1 GeV. The former have been used since the middle 1970s for scientific applications, and the latter are still under development, mainly for dedicated lithography sources for the electronics industry to use in producing ultralarge scale integrated (ULSI) circuits. Other types of compact storage rings now being planned generally have energies between 1 GeV and 2 GeV, and are intended for medical uses such as angiography. In this electron energy region, there is the possibility of making a free electron laser in the range from microwaves to X-rays. The definition of compact storage rings is discussed in terms of ring size, electron beam energy and insertion devices as well as configurations of the rings and their injection schemes. © 1990.

Authors: Hansen R.W.C., Brodsky E.L., Pruett C.H., Wallace D.J., Korpela E., Filipponi A., Bissen M., Welnak J.T., Green M.A., Trzeciak W.S.
Title: Implementation of an undulator beamline on Aladdin
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hansen, R.W.C., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States; Brodsky, E.L., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States; Pruett, C.H., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States; Wallace, D.J., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States; Korpela, E., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States; Filipponi, A., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States; Bissen, M., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States; Welnak, J.T., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States; Green, M.A., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States; Trzeciak, W.S., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Synchrotron Radiation Center, 3731 Schneider Drive, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States
Abstract: The first undulator monochromator on the Aladdin storage ring has been installed and recently tested. The design and alignment of an undulator beamline presented several unique problems not normally encountered in the design of bending magnet beamlines. The primary problem is the lack of visible radiation from the undulator source when it is operated under normal conditions. In this case a temporary beamline was installed to measure the intensity of undulator light transmitted through a pinhole which could be horizontally and vertically scanned through the undulator beam. This was used to adjust the steering of the beam to be centered in the port and to do some nondispersive characterization of the undulator. This temporary line was designed to permit precision alignment of the components of the beamline according to the measured position of the full energy beam. The monochromator used on this beamline is a 6 m toroidal grating monochromator (TGM). It allows further dispersive testing of the undulator and provides dispersed undulator flux for user experiments. The beamline is identical in terms of expected reflectivity losses and grating efficiencies to two similar beamlines implemented on bending magnets. This allows direct comparison of the flux available to experimenters from undulator sources to flux from bending magnets. Initial measurements indicate that with the undulator gap set for 50 eV, at the peak of the first harmonic, the undulator beamline produces 40 times more flux than a similar beamline using a bending magnet source. © 1990.

Authors: Yokomizo H., Yanagida K., Harada S., Mashiko K., Yokoyama M., Hashimoto H., Nakayama K., Kabasawa M., Harami T., Suzuki Y.
Title: Performance of the compact 300 MeV electron ring JSR
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yokomizo, H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan; Yanagida, K., Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan; Harada, S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan; Mashiko, K., Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan; Yokoyama, M., Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan; Hashimoto, H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan; Nakayama, K., Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan; Kabasawa, M., Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan; Harami, T., Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan; Suzuki, Y., Synchrotron Radiation Research Laboratory, JAERI, Tokai, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: A compact ring, JSR, has been constructed in a short period of 15 months. The magnets, vacuum chamber and rf system are well manufactured, coming up to the design expectation. The good-field region ΔB B < 2 × 10-4 extends over ±45 mm in the dipole magnets. The base pressure has reached 3 × 10-10 Torr at the pump head. An electron beam was successfully injected from a linac at an energy of ∼ 150 MeV, and electrons were smoothly accelerated and stored in JSR at a maximum energy of 300 MeV. The lifetime of the stored electrons is ∼ 30 min, which is mainly determined by collisions with the residual gas in the vacuum chamber. JSR has proved to work correctly in the storage and acceleration of electrons within an energy range from 150 to 300 MeV. © 1990.

Authors: Sasaki S., Youngman B., Winick H.
Title: The use of a single wavelength wiggler in PEP as a circular polarized hard X-ray source
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sasaki, S., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Youngman, B., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Winick, H., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: Three single-wavelength planar wigglers have been installed in the positron-electron project (PEP) storage ring in order to obtain better luminosities for high-energy physics. Two of them are located next to the X-ray undulators and can be used as synchrotron radiation sources, providing circularly polarized hard X-rays, without any major changes of the lattice and beam lines during dedicated operation of PEP. Circularly polarized hard X-rays can be obtained by selecting radiation produced in the middle of the center pole and observing this radiation above and below the orbital plane. As in the case for a bending magnet, the "out of plane" radiation has circular polarization components of opposite handedness above and below the orbital plane. Calculations presented here show that, in this way, the brightness of 90% circularly polarized 75-keV X-rays is 1.9 × 1014 photons s-1 mm-2 mrad-2 at 0.1% bandwidth when PEP is operated at 8 GeV, 20 mA in the low emittance mode and the wiggler operates at 1.3 T. This is brightness higher than that of any other source in the world. A disadvantage to this scheme is that operation of the wiggler increases the electron beam emittance due to the nonzero dispersion at the wiggler location. The emittance increases by a factor of 1.5 for the example given above. This disadvantage could be eliminated by reducing the dispersion function to zero at the wiggler location. Possible limitations due to high power density on the crotch of PEP beamline are discussed. © 1990.

Title: Low-energy injection rings
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: MAX-lab, Box 118, S-220 00 Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Eriksson, M., MAX-lab, Box 118, S-220 00 Lund, Sweden
Abstract: Low-energy injection into small electron storage rings is discussed. The most dominating effects like intrabeam scattering, ion trapping during injection and ramping are described. Examples of different low-energy injectors and their performance are given, and some features of the fast injection method are explained. Some numerical examples from the MAX storage ring are given, as well as some methods to increase the stored and ramped current. © 1990.

Title: The ALS - A third-generation light source
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Advanced Light Source This work was supported by the Director, Office of Energy Research, Office of Basic Energy Sciences, Division of Materials Sciences, of the U.S. Department of Energy under Contract No. DE-AC03-76SF00098., Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, 1 Cyclotron Road, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, A.L., Advanced Light Source This work was supported by the Director, Office of Energy Research, Office of Basic Energy Sciences, Division of Materials Sciences, of the U.S. Department of Energy under Contract No. DE-AC03-76SF00098., Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, 1 Cyclotron Road, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA, United States; Schlachter, A.S., Advanced Light Source This work was supported by the Director, Office of Energy Research, Office of Basic Energy Sciences, Division of Materials Sciences, of the U.S. Department of Energy under Contract No. DE-AC03-76SF00098., Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, 1 Cyclotron Road, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA, United States
Abstract: The Advanced Light Source, a third-generation national synchrotron-radiation facility now under construction at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, is scheduled to begin serving qualified users across a broad spectrum of research areas in April 1993. Based on a low-emittance electron storage ring optimized to operate at 1.5 GeV, the ALS will have 11 long straight sections available for insertion devices (undulators and wigglers). Undulators will generate high-brightness soft-X-ray and ultraviolet (XUV) radiation; wigglers will extend the spectrum generated into the hard-X-ray region, but at a lower brightness. Up to 48 bending-magnet ports will also be available. Engineering design has begun on a complement of three undulators with periods of 8.0, 5.0, and 3.9 cm. Among them, the photon-energy range from 5.4 eV to 2.5 keV will be covered when the first, third, and fifth undulator harmonics are used. Also being designed is a wiggler with a critical energy of 3.1 keV. Undulator beam lines will be based on high-resolution spherical-grating monochromators. A Call for Proposals has been issued for those who wish to participate in the design, development, commissioning, and operation of the initial complement of the ALS experimental facilities (insertion devices, beam lines, and experimental stations) as members of a participating research team. The deadline for receipt of proposals was August 15, 1989. Proposals are expected to reflect the Letters of Interest received from potential participating research teams (PRTs) during the previous year. © 1990.

Title: Contrast agent choice for intravenous coronary angiography
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zeman, H.D., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Siddons, D.P., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: The screening of the general population for coronary artery disease would be practical if a method existed for visualizing the extent of occlusion after an intravenous injection of contrast agent. Measurements performed with monochromatic synchrotron radiation X-rays and an iodine-containing contrast agent at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory have shown that such an intravenous angiography procedure would be possible with an adequately intense monochromatic X-ray source. Because of the size and cost of synchrotron radiation facilities it would be desirable to make the most efficient use of the intensity available, while reducing as much as possible the radiation dose experienced by the patient. By choosing contrast agents containing elements with a higher atomic number than iodine, it is possible to both improve the image quality and reduce the patient radiation dose, while using the same synchrotron radiation source. By using Si monochromator crystals with a small mosaic spread, it is possible to increase the X-ray flux available for imaging by over an order of magnitude, without any changes in the storage ring or wiggler magnet. The most critical imaging task for intravenous coronary angiography utilizing synchrotron radiation X-rays is visualizing a coronary artery through the left ventricle or aorta which also contain contrast agent. Calculations have been made of the signal to noise ratio expected for this imaging task for various contrast agents with atomic numbers between that of iodine and bismuth. The X-ray energy spectrum of the X-17 superconduction wiggler beam line at the National Synchrotron Light Source at Brookhaven National Laboratory has been used for these calculations. Both perfect Si crystals and Si crystals with a small mosaic spread are considered as monochromators. Contrast agents containing Gd or Yb seem to have about the optimal calculated signal to noise ratio. Gd-DTPA is already approved for use as a contrast agent for magnetic resonance imaging. Experiments have already been performed with Yb-DTPA in animals, and it appears to have a lower toxicity than that of Gd-DTPA. Reported animal experiments with Gd-DOTA contrast agent show no toxicity at all. © 1990.

Authors: Stockbauer R.L., Ajmera P., Poliakoff E.D., Craft B.C., Saile V.
Title: A new synchrotron light source at Louisiana State University's Center for Advanced Microstructures and Devices
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stockbauer, R.L., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Ajmera, P., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Poliakoff, E.D., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Craft, B.C., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Saile, V., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States
Abstract: A 1.2-GeV synchrotron light source is being constructed at the Center for Advanced Microstructures and Devices (CAMD) at Louisiana State University. The expressed purpose of the center, which has been funded by a grant from the US Department of Energy, is to develop X-ray lithography techniques for manufacturing microcircuits, although basic science programs are also being established. The storage ring will be optimized for the soft-X-ray region and will be the first commercially manufactured electron storage ring in the United States. The magnetic lattice is based on a design developed by Chasman and Green and will allow up to three insertion devices to be installed for higher-energy and higher-intensity radiation. In addition to the lithography effort, experimental programs are being established in physics, chemistry, and related areas. © 1990.

Authors: Lagier H.D., Gödderz K.H., Hormes J., Klein A.
Title: Magnetooptical measurements on matrix-isolated xenon in the VUV with synchrotron radiation
Affiliations: Physkalisches Institut der Universität, Nussallee 12, 5300 Bonn, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Lagier, H.D., Physkalisches Institut der Universität, Nussallee 12, 5300 Bonn, Germany; Gödderz, K.H., Physkalisches Institut der Universität, Nussallee 12, 5300 Bonn, Germany; Hormes, J., Physkalisches Institut der Universität, Nussallee 12, 5300 Bonn, Germany; Klein, A., Physkalisches Institut der Universität, Nussallee 12, 5300 Bonn, Germany
Abstract: The absorption and MCD spectra of the atomic resonance transition of Xe diluted in Ne, Ar and Kr have been studied in the energy region between 8.0 and 10.0 eV with the BESSY storage ring as light source for synchrotron radiation. Magnetic circular dichroism (MCD) is the difference in absorption between left- and right-circularly polarized light, induced by a longitudinal magnetic field. Xe was chosen as guest because of its low interaction with the host matrix compared to other guest atoms. Various concentrations and temperatures have been used in order to study the matrix-guest interaction. Compared to the gas phase the atomic resonance transition 5p6(1S0) → 5p56s(3P1) is blue shifted in all matrices. The Xe ground state is expected to show a temperature independent MCD A term. This in general is not verified by our experiments. In fact most aspects of our data do not agree with theoretical expectations. © 1990.

Authors: Kovacs S., Speiser K., Thaw W., Heese R.
Title: Optimizing a synchrotron based X-ray lithography system for IC manufacturing
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Grumman Corporation, Electronics Systems Division, Great River, NY  11739, United States; Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY  11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kovacs, S., Grumman Corporation, Electronics Systems Division, Great River, NY  11739, United States; Speiser, K., Grumman Corporation, Electronics Systems Division, Great River, NY  11739, United States; Thaw, W., Grumman Corporation, Electronics Systems Division, Great River, NY  11739, United States; Heese, R., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY  11973, United States
Abstract: The electron storage ring is a realistic solution as a radiation source for production grade, industrial X-ray lithography system. Today several large scale plans are in motion to design and implement synchrotron storage rings of different types for this purpose in the USA and abroad. Most of the scientific and technological problems related to the physics, design and manufacturing engineering, and commissioning of these systems for microlithography have been resolved or are under extensive study. However, investigation on issues connected to application of Synchrotron Orbit Radiation (SOR) in chip production environment has been somewhat neglected. In this paper we have filled this gap pointing out direct effects of some basic synchrotron design parameters and associated subsystems (injector, X-ray beam line) on the operation and cost of lithography in production. The following factors were considered: synchrotron configuration, injection energy, beam intensity variability, number of beam lines and wafer exposure concept. A cost model has been worked out and applied to three different X-ray Lithography Source (XLS) systems. The results of these applications are compared and conclusions drawn. © 1990 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Integrated circuit design; Integrated circuits; Ion beams; Manufacture; Storage rings; Timing circuits; X ray lithography; Associated subsystems; Design and implements; Design parameters; Electron storage ring; Lithography systems; Manufacturing engineering; Radiation source; Synchrotron storage ring; X rays

Authors: Hamada K., Naito H., Kume M., Yuri M., Shimizu H.
Title: High-power GaAlAs single-element lasers with nonabsorbing mirrors
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Electronics Research Laboratory, Matsushita Electronics Corp., Takatsuki, Osaka, 569, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hamada, K., Electronics Research Laboratory, Matsushita Electronics Corp., Takatsuki, Osaka, 569, Japan; Naito, H., Electronics Research Laboratory, Matsushita Electronics Corp., Takatsuki, Osaka, 569, Japan; Kume, M., Electronics Research Laboratory, Matsushita Electronics Corp., Takatsuki, Osaka, 569, Japan; Yuri, M., Electronics Research Laboratory, Matsushita Electronics Corp., Takatsuki, Osaka, 569, Japan; Shimizu, H., Electronics Research Laboratory, Matsushita Electronics Corp., Takatsuki, Osaka, 569, Japan
Abstract: We report recent approaches for attaining high-power and high-mode-stability operation in GaAlAs single-element lasers on the basis of nonabsorbing-mirror(NAM) structure. In these approaches we have developed two types of lasers. One is a short wavelength laser with high power and the other is a built-in composite-cavity laser with high selectivity of a longitudinal mode. The NAM region is provided in the vicinity of the light emitting facets through the growth of wide band-gap materials based on an MOCVD/LPE hybrid growth method. In order to attain high stability of a fundamental spatial mode, the buried twin-ridge substrate(BTRS) structure is used. We obtained a 780-nm NAM-BTRS laser which offered the maximum output power of 200 mW under cw operation as a result of complete suppression of the catastrophic optical damage. The lifetime of this laser was longer than 1,000 hours under the output power of 100 mW at 50°C as a result of the suppression of mif-ror degradation. On the other hand, we obtained a built-in composite-cavity laser which exhibited stable longitudinal mode operation in a temperature range as wide as 50°C for output powers from 3 mW to 100 mW without mode hopping due to high selectivity of a longitudinal mode. © 2019 SPIE.

Title: Solar water heating
Affiliations: QDT Ltd, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mathur, G.D., QDT Ltd, United States
Abstract: The performance of a thermosiphon solar hot water heater system with its working fluid undergoing a phase change was modeled and investigated. A well-mixed storage tank was also modeled for energy storage. Since no loads were taken, the energy balance on the storage tank was very simple. The study revealed that good collector efficiencies can be achieved and that the system can be effectively used for hot water heating. Work is currently under way to predict the long-term performance of these systems for a family of four with typical daily water consumption rates.

Authors: Maksyutenko B.P., Balakshev Yu.F., Ignat'ev S.V., Mil'shin V.I., Minko Yu.V., Mironov A.N., Tsarev V.N.
Title: 3He spectrometer for study of the time and energy distributions of delayed neutrons

Abstract: A spectrometer for study of the spectrum dynamics of delayed fission neutrons is described. The control and acquisition system is in the form of an autonomous CAMAC position on line with an SM-3 computer. Neutron amplitude-time spectra are recorded in 512 energy and 64 time channels.

Title: Molding. Hot runners meet the challenge of molding small medical parts
Affiliations: KONA Corp, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hume, William J., KONA Corp, United States
Abstract: The cost-effectiveness of hot-runner systems has become more evident in recent years, during which increasing numbers of companies have specified hot-runner molds because of the promise of reducing cycle times, eliminating scrap material, and saving overall energy costs. The medical/health care industry, one of the fastest-growing markets for plastics, is particularly demanding and challenging for injection molders. Economical hot-runner systems that satisfy even the most difficult medical/health care applications are now available. But it is for high-cavitation, small medical-part molds that hot-runner molding has real economic value. Many applications demand zero regrind, and when runner weights equal or exceed actual part weights, runner storage and handling can be costly as well as troublesome. High-cavitation small-part molds require additional design specifications: leakproof design, individual drop control, balanced fill for dimensional control of parts, and minimum center-line to center-line distance between drops. From these criteria, Kona Corp. has developed its standard Pre-Engineered hot-runner systems specifically for high-cavitation precision molding. This paper describes this system design.
Index Keywords: Health Care - Plastics Applications; Plastics Products - Medical Applications; Cavity Spacing; Gate Control; Hot Runner Systems; Individual Bushing; Medical Parts; Thermal Shutoff Control; Plastics

Authors: Mohitpour M., Pierce C.L., Graham Peter
Title: Design basis developed for H2 pipeline
Affiliations: Novacorp Intl Consulting Inc
Authors with affiliations: Mohitpour, M., Novacorp Intl Consulting Inc; Pierce, C.L., Novacorp Intl Consulting Inc; Graham, Peter, Novacorp Intl Consulting Inc
Abstract: In lieu of uniform codes or standards for hydrogen-gas pipeline design and construction, Novacorp International Consulting Inc., Calgary, developed a design basis and used it in the design, engineering, and construction of a hydrogen-gas cross-country pipeline. The pipeline joined the Alberta Gas Ethylene Co. Ltd. hydrogen purification plant to the Cominco Fertilizers/Alberta Energy Co. Ltd. anhydrous ammonia plant. This paper outlines storage and transportation difficulties, gives properties and applications, loss estimation techniques, and describes installation and safety considerations.

Title: Case study of a central-station grid-intertie photovoltaic system with V-trough concentration
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beersheva, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Freilich, Jeff, Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beersheva, Israel; Gordon, J.M., Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beersheva, Israel
Abstract: A case study of an installed, central-station (no storage), utility-intertie photovoltaic (PV) system in Sede Boger, Israel (latitude 30.9°N), is presented. This PV system was constructed with 189 polycrystalline silicon modules mounted on inexpensive, horizontal north-south axis trackers with V-trough mirrors for low-level concentration. The power conditioning unit operates at a fixed voltage rather than at maximum power point (MPP). Although design output of this system was a nominal 12-kW peak, the measured output was significantly less, occasionally dropping to zero on clear summer days. The major task was to pinpoint the causes of this deficiency and recommend system modifications. As part of this investigation, quantitative assessments of fixed-voltage operation as well as the energetic value of V-trough concentration and one-axis tracking were performed for this system and similar systems. The sample results show that fixed-voltage operation at the best fixed voltage (BFV) can achieve 96% of the yearly energy of MPP operation. The results also show the sensitivity of the yearly energy delivery to the selection of fixed voltage and its marked asymmetry about the BFV; the influences of inverter current constraints on yearly energy delivery and the BFV; and how the separate effects of tracking and optical concentration increase yearly energy delivery.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Generation--Solar Energy; Electric Power Systems--Israel; Mirrors; Solar Cells--Performance; Solar Radiation--Concentrators; Optical Concentration; Photovoltaic Systems; Sun Tracking; V-trough Concentration; Photovoltaic Cells

Authors: Hickman J.Mark, Curtis Henry B., Landis Geoffrey A.
Title: Design considerations for lunar based photovoltaic power systems
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hickman, J.Mark, NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Curtis, Henry B., NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Landis, Geoffrey A., NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: A survey was made of factors that may affect the design of photovoltaic (PV) arrays for a lunar base. These factors, which include the lunar environment and system design criteria, are examined. A PV power system design with a triangular array geometry is discussed and compared to a nuclear reactor power system and a power system utilizing both nuclear and solar power sources. It is shown that the solar array is a small percentage of the overall PV power system mass. Energy storage for the lunar night is the main mass driver; minimizing the nighttime power usage will significantly lower mass. It is further found that a tent array configured in an east/west orientation has advantages over a fixed tilt or horizontal array due to power generation at dawn and dusk.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Energy Storage; Moon--Bases; Nuclear Power Plants--Space Applications; Solar Cells--Arrays; Combined Nuclear and Solar Power Systems; Lunar Based Photovoltaic Power Systems; Lunar Night; Photovoltaic Arrays; Tent Arrays; Triangular Array Geometry; Photovoltaic Cells

Title: Photovoltaic power for Space Station Freedom
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Baraona, Cosmo R., NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: The Space Station Freedom is described with special attention to its electric power system. The photovoltaic arrays, the battery energy storage system, and the power management and distribution system are discussed. The current design of Freedom's power system and the system requirements, trade studies, and competing factors which lead to system selections are referenced. This will be the largest power system ever flown in space. This system represents the culmination of many developments that have improved system performance, reduced cost, and improved reliability. Key developments and their evolution into the current space station solar array design are briefly described. The features of the solar cell and the array, including the development, design, test, and flight hardware production status, are given.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries - Energy Storage; Electric Power Distribution; Electric Power Systems - Space Applications; Solar Cells - Silicon; Space Stations - Power Supply; Battery Energy Storage System; Photovoltaic Arrays; Photovoltaic Power Module; Power Management; Solar Arrays; Photovoltaic Cells

Title: Design considerations for Mars photovoltaic systems
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Landis, Geoffrey A., NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Appelbaum, Joseph, NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: Considerations for operation of a photovoltaic power system on Mars are discussed with reference to Viking Lander data. The average solar insolation at Mars is 590 W/m2, which is reduced yet further by atmospheric dust. Of major concern are dust storms, which have been observed to occur on local as well as on global scales, and their effect on solar array output. While atmospheric opacity may rise to values ranging from 3 to 9, depending on storm severity, there is still an appreciable large diffuse illumination, even at high opacities, so that photovoltaic operation is still possible. If the power system is to continue to generate power even on high-optical-opacity (i.e., dusty atmosphere) days, it is important that the photovoltaic system be designed to collect diffuse irradiance as well as direct. Energy storage will be required for operation during the night. Temperature and wind provide additional considerations for array design.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Extraterrestrial Atmospheres; Planets; Solar Cells--Space Applications; Solar Power Plants--Space Applications; Atmospheric Dust; Energy Storage; Mars Photovoltaic Systems; Solar Insolation; Viking Lander; Wind Effects; Photovoltaic Cells

Authors: Bailey Sheila G., Landis Geoffrey A., Perino Maria A.
Title: Photovoltaic superiority for Space Station Freedom power in the 21st century
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, Sheila G., NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Landis, Geoffrey A., NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Perino, Maria A., NASA Lewis Res Center, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: Complete power systems capable of delivering 75 kW of continuous power in low earth orbit have been compared. Performance, liabilities, and advantages are discussed for a shielded nuclear system, a solar dynamic system, and photovoltaic systems, both current Freedom Si design and near-term GaAs/Ge with NaS storage. System components include power generation, storage (if required), heat rejection, power conversion and distribution, structural support, and shielding (if required). Performance parameters indicate the substantial advantage of the GaAs/Ge photovoltaic system, which does not require altering the support structure of the current Freedom design.

Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference

Abstract: Current solar car technology, rules and strategies for the major racing events, and plans for GM Sunrayce USA, a university competition of solar-powered cars scheduled for July, 1990, are described, along with plans by the US Department of Energy to investigate the technical requirements and economic viability of solar-assisted commuter cars.

Title: The synthesis of solar radiation data for sizing stand-alone photovoltaic systems
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chapman, Richard N., Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The author describes a model that synthesizes long-term hourly insolation data from monthly average insolation data using statistical models developed from 23.5 years of hourly data from 20 weather stations scattered across the United States. This model was developed specifically for sizing stand-alone photovoltaic systems and was therefore verified by comparing system performances resulting from the synthetic data with performances resulting from actual hourly data. Comparisons of the system performances indicate that the model is valid for system sizing regardless of array orientation, seasonal changes in the load, or the average system loss of energy. In all cases, the relative error between array sizes resulting from actual and synthetic data was less than 6%. Overall, the error was less than 2.5%. The model has one limitation in that it was designed specifically for stand-alone photovoltaic systems with energy storage and should not be applied to systems without storage. In general, it is valid for any system with two or more days of energy storage.

Title: Passive viscoelastic work of isolated rat, Rattus norvegicus, diaphragm muscle.
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, University of Guelph, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Syme, D.A., Department of Zoology, University of Guelph, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: 1. The passive elastic and viscous properties of isolated rat diaphragm muscle were studied, under various strains and strain rates similar to those in the animal, to measure their effects on the storage and release of mechanical potential energy. 2. Increasing the muscle length or amplitude of the displacement increased energy loss per stretch/shorten cycle, and increased the relative recovery of potential energy from the stretch during subsequent shortening. 3. Increasing strain rates increased energy loss per cycle and decreased the relative recovery of energy put into the stretch. 4. These effects were due to increased viscous resistance and increased elastic tension with increased length, and increased viscous resistance with increased strain rates. 5. The effects of increasing strain rate alone (1‐4 Hz) were small relative to the effects of a 10% increase in muscle length or the amplitude of the length cycle. 6. Diaphragm muscle movements involving low velocity, small amplitude displacements at long muscle lengths are most effective at conserving net passive mechanical energy, while short muscle lengths minimize gross energy loss. © 1990 The Physiological Society

Title: Deformation of As-cast LiF-22mol.%CaF2 hypereutectic salt between 500 and 1015 K
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Road, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Raj, S.V., NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Road, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Whittenberger, J.D., NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Road, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: Compression tests were conducted on as-cast LiF-22mol.%CaF2 hypereutectic salt specimens at nominal strain rates varying between 1.8 × 10-6 and 0.25 s -1 over the temperature range 500-1015 K. The true stress-strain curves showed broad maxima in all instances, with negative strain-hardening rates being observed after the peak stress σmax. The stress exponent n increased from n ≈ 5 for T ≥ 900 K to n > 19 for T ≤ 600 K, where T is the absolute temperature. The apparent activation energy QA for deformation decreased linearly with increasing stress when σmax > 25 MPa from QA ≈ 350 kJ mol-1 at σmax = 25 MPa to QA ≈ 120 kJ mol-1 at σmax = 150 MPa; however, QA ≈ 320 - 350 kJ mol-1 when αmax ≤ 25 MPa. Microstructural observations of the deformed specimens showed that the CaF2 lamellae, while intact at the lower temperatures and higher stresses, had spheroidized at the higher temperatures and lower stresses. It is concluded from an analysis of the data that the deformation behavior of the hypereutectic salt can be divided into two separate regimes, both of which are controlled by the deformation of the CaF2 phase. The deformation mechanisms operating in this phase are examined. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Calcium Compounds - Deformation; Lithium Compounds - Deformation; Strain; Stresses; Calcium Fluoride Salts; Lithium Fluoride Salts; Strain Rate; Stress Exponent; Stress-Strain Curves; Thermal Energy Storage; Salts

Title: Controlled phase separation of polymer-liquid crystal mixtures for reversible optical data storage
Affiliations: University of California at Berkeley, Department of Chemical Engineering, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States; Raychem Corporation, 300 Constitution Drive, Menlo Park, CA, 94025, United States
Authors with affiliations: McIntyre, W.D., University of California at Berkeley, Department of Chemical Engineering, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States, Raychem Corporation, 300 Constitution Drive, Menlo Park, CA, 94025, United States; Soane, D.S., University of California at Berkeley, Department of Chemical Engineering, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States
Abstract: A system for reversible optical data storage has been studied, using mixtures of polymers with liquid crystal molecules. A thin coating of a polymer—liquid crystal mixture with a laser absorbing dye would be spin coated onto a substrate and recording would be done with two types of write laser pulses. One laser pulse would be of high intensity and focused to small diameter, giving large temperature gradients and relatively fast cooling rates. The other write pulse would have lower intensity and larger diameter, resulting in smaller temperature gradients and slower cooling. A third pulse, reserved for reading, would not have sufficient intensity at the wavelength absorbed by the system to heat significantly. It would be scattered at different intensities into a photodetector depending on the cooling history of the spot being read. The feasibility of the principle was demonstrated through an experiment in which a 4-8-iim sample coating is applied to clear resistor coated glass. Energy was put into the system by a pulse generator whose power and pulse duration can be controlled. Low intensity laser light scattering patterns were observed during and after the resistive pulse to monitor the sample morphology during the experiment. A short heating pulse resulted in more intense light scattering at small angles than longer, lower power pulses. © 1990 Optical Society of America.

Authors: Malkin S., Herbert S.K., Fork D.C.
Title: Light distribution, transfer and utilization in the marine red alga Porphyra perforata from photoacoustic energy-storage measurements
Affiliations: Carnegie Institution of Washington, Department of Plant Biology, Stanford, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Malkin, S., Carnegie Institution of Washington, Department of Plant Biology, Stanford, CA, United States; Herbert, S.K., Carnegie Institution of Washington, Department of Plant Biology, Stanford, CA, United States; Fork, D.C., Carnegie Institution of Washington, Department of Plant Biology, Stanford, CA, United States
Abstract: Light energy utilization in Porphyra perforata was monitored by the photoacoustic method in different conditions of illumination. Auxiliary chlorophyll a fluorescence measurements were made to estimate the fraction of open photosystem II (PS II) reaction centers. These measurements allowed a consistent quantitation of excitation distribution and transfer from PS II to PS I under the physiological conditions used. Maximum energy storage was obtained with modulated light absorbed almost exclusively by the phycobilins (light 2). Modulated light absorbed by chlorophyll a (light I) gave much smaller energy storage (about 1 3 of the maximum), which could be enhanced to the maximum by addition of background light 2. Addition of increasing intensities of background light 1 to modulated light 2 did not initially induce any effect and then decreased the energy storage to about half of the maximum. From the above results and with simple mathematical modelling, numbers were obtained for light distribution and energy transfer parameters. From the enhancement saturation curves of the effect of background light 2 on the energy storage in modulated light 1 we conclude that in state 1 light 2 is exclusively absorbed in PS II and that there is no energy transfer to PS I from open PS II reaction centers. From the value of the energy storage for light 2 in state 1 and the degree of openness of PS II reaction centers it is possible to conclude that energy transfer to PS I occurs from closed PS II reaction centers with a probability approaching 1. In state 2 light 2 is distributed more evenly (approximately in a ratio PS II PS I of 0.55:0.45) either by energy transfer via PS II from open PS II reaction centers, or by direct interactions of the phycobilins and PS I. Comparison of the maximum fluorescence values in the two states favors the second possibility. Energy transfer from PS II units with closed reaction centers occurs again in state 2 with a probability approaching 1. Comparison of energy utilization and oxygen evolution in light 1 relative to light 2 and the inhibitory effect of DCMU, which is complete in light 2 but only partial in light 1, suggests the existence of two types of PS I units: one type is engaged in electron transfer from PS II and the other type specializes in cyclic electron flow. The above quantitative analysis allows to estimate the ratio of the two types of PS I unit to be roughly about 0.3:0.7, respectively. © 1990.
Author Keywords: (Marine alga); Energy transfer; Photoacoustics; Photosystem I; Photosystem II; Spillover

Title: Changes in digestive enzyme activities during early development of the American lobster Homarus americanus Milne Edwards
Source title: Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology
Affiliations: Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Biesiot, P.M., Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, MA, United States; Capuzzo, J.M., Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, MA, United States
Abstract: Activities of digestive protease, lipase, and amylase from the foregut and midgut gland were measured during the course of early development in the American lobster Homarus americanus Milne Edwards. Total enzyme activities were very low among embryos sampled 3 days prior to hatching. Protease and amylase activities increased slightly at the time of hatching and again during larval Stage I; lipase activity did not change. Activity of the three enzymes more than doubled among Stage II larvae and although there were slight increases in enzyme activities during Stage III, they were not significant. Protease activity peaked during Stage IV, whereas lipase and amylase activities were greatest among Stage V juveniles. Different patterns were observed when specific enzyme activities (normalized on the basis of protein) are examined. Specific activities of the three enzymes were very low in embryos just prior to hatching and increased slightly during the hatching process. During Stage I, the specific activity of protease doubled, lipase specific activity increased by a factor of 10, and that of amylase increased slightly. Activities of both protease and amylase more than doubled in Stage II larvae; in general, there were no significant differences in specific activities measured in Stages II through V. Lipase specific activity did not change significantly among Stages I through V. The increase in enzyme activities among the hatching stages correlates well with morphological changes observed in the midgut gland (hepatopancreas), specifically in regard to the presence of enzyme-producing B-cells. Changes in enzyme activities among the postmetamorphic Stages IV and V may be related to changes in body form, habitat, or patterns of energy storage and utilization. Lobster larvae normally hatch during early summer but embryonic development can be accelerated in the laboratory by maintenance at high (21°C) rather than ambient temperature. Temperature conditions during embryonic development, however, had no effect on digestive enzyme activities of larvae that were induced to hatch out of season. © 1990.
Author Keywords: Amylase; Crustacean digestive enzyme; Homarus americanus; Lipase; Lobster larva; Protease

Authors: Botman J.I.M., Mutsaers P.H.A., Hagedoorn H.L., De Voigt M.J.A.
Title: EUTERPE, a small electron storage ring for XRF
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Eindhoven University of Technology, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Botman, J.I.M., Eindhoven University of Technology, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; Mutsaers, P.H.A., Eindhoven University of Technology, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; Hagedoorn, H.L., Eindhoven University of Technology, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; De Voigt, M.J.A., Eindhoven University of Technology, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: A small-sized electron storage ring is under construction at the Eindhoven University of Technology which will cover the energy range of 15 to 400 MeV. At top energy the characteristic wavelength of the synchrotron radiation spectrum is 8.3 nm for the regular dipole magnets and 1.2 nm corresponding to 1.06 keV for a 10 T wiggler magnet. This will provide useful radiation for X-ray fluorescence (XRF) up to 3.2 keV. Alternatively, photon conversion with a high power CO2 laser beam of 0.124 eV photons will generate X-rays for XRF with energies ranging from 0.5 to 300 keV, depending on the operating energy of the storage ring. This facility will provide an important extension to the activities of the Eindhoven group on PIXE, RBS and microbeam analysis. A short description of the macnine will be given together with applications and specific examples of the XRF method. © 1990.

Title: Eutectic cool storage. Current developments
Affiliations: Transphase Systems Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ames, Douglas A., Transphase Systems Inc, United States
Abstract: Eutectic phase change materials provide a versatile cool storage medium that can be applied to a wide variety of building conditions. Like ice and chilled water storage systems, eutectics have been in use for many decades. Such phase change materials (PCMs) have been developed with various phase change points. This article reviews current developments in eutectic phase change materials.
Index Keywords: Refrigeration--Energy Storage; Cool Storage; Eutectic Cool Storage; Phase Change Materials; Thermal Storage; Energy Storage

Authors: Wildin Maurice W., Mackie E.Ian, Harrison William E.
Title: Stratified thermal storage. A new/old technology
Affiliations: Univ of New Mexico in Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wildin, Maurice W., Univ of New Mexico in Albuquerque, United States; Mackie, E.Ian, Univ of New Mexico in Albuquerque, United States; Harrison, William E., Univ of New Mexico in Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: Many engineers may not feel as familiar or comfortable with stratified thermal storage as they are with phase change storage. However, stratified thermal storage is as common as the domestic water heater tank and as reliable. This article presents an overview of this technology.
Index Keywords: Refrigeration; Stratified Storage; Thermal Storage; Energy Storage

Authors: Anan'in P.S., Bugaev S.P., Bystritskii V.M., Ivanov I.B., Karpov V.B., Krasik Ya.E., Koval'chuk B.M., Novikov A.V., Petrov A.V., Ryzhakin N.N., Tolmacheva V.G., Ch'e A.E.
Title: High-power microsecond voltage-pulse generator
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Anan'in, P.S., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Bugaev, S.P., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Bystritskii, V.M., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Ivanov, I.B., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Karpov, V.B., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Krasik, Ya.E., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Koval'chuk, B.M., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Novikov, A.V., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Petrov, A.V., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Ryzhakin, N.N., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Tolmacheva, V.G., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Ch'e, A.E., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: A microsecond voltage-pulse generator is described for research in the generation of high-power electron and ion beams in diode systems that are connected in parallel with a network with an inductive storage device and a plasma-erosion breaker. The total energy capacity of the generator is 250 kJ for a charging potential of 80 kV. The generator has a self-inductance of ≈0.7 μH, a characteristic impedance of ≈1.14 Ω, an oscillation period of ≈3.83 μsec, and a damping constant of μ105 sec-1. Results are provided for the first experiments in the generation of a high-current relativistic electron beam of microsecond duration in a magnetically isolated coaxial diode.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electron Beams; Electron Tubes, Diode; Plasma Devices - Guns; Voltage Dividers; Calorimeters; Faraday Cylinders; Microsecond Pulse Generators; Plasma-Erosion Breakers; Rogowski Loops; Voltage Pulse Generators; Pulse Generators

Authors: Beale J., Curzio E.Lara, Sternstein S.S.
Title: High temperature deformation studies on CVD silicon carbide fibers
Affiliations: Cent for Composite Materials and, Structures, United States
Authors with affiliations: Beale, J., Cent for Composite Materials and, Structures, United States; Curzio, E.Lara, Cent for Composite Materials and, Structures, United States; Sternstein, S.S., Cent for Composite Materials and, Structures, United States
Abstract: The composite structure of SiC fibers produced by chemical vapor deposition is reviewed briefly in order to illustrate the complex mechanical behavior which such fibers can exhibit. A new apparatus for studying the creep behavior of fibers is described in which virtually isothermal gage lengths can be achieved at temperatures up to 1600 C. A second apparatus for measuring complex dynamic moduli from 0.1 to 25 Hz for temperatures to 1600 C is also presented. Loss (imaginary) modulus values greater than 1 part in 2000 of the storage (real) modulus can be measured. Example data are presented for a variety of loading histories, temperatures and stress levels. A new algorithm for the correction of non isothermal mechanical data is used to compute isothermal dynamic moduli values to 1600 C. It is found that anelastic processes occur both dynamically and in creep at temperatures as low as 1100 C. Activation energies for dynamic loss mechanisms are presented.
Index Keywords: Computer Programming--Algorithms; Fibers, Nontextile--Chemical Vapor Deposition; Plastics, Reinforced--Fiber Reinforcement; Silicon Carbide--Fibers; High Temperature Reinforcing Fibers; Silicon Carbide Fibers; Transformation Toughening; Composite Materials

Title: Introduction of alternative biomass crops in Europe
Authors with affiliations: Pari, Luigi
Abstract: The future holds great potential for the development and utilization of many agricultural products not only as sources of food, but also as raw materials that may be used in the non-food industries - in place of nonrenewable resources - to produce energy. The research and development programs instituted by the European Community (EC) in recent years are evidence of its interest in the research and development of new alternative crops and industrial technologies. After in-depth studies of botany, ecology, plant genetics, the most adaptable cultivation techniques, harvesting, transport, storage, and industrial processing methodologies the species which have been selected by the EC and its research centers fall into the following categories: energy crops - sweet sorghum, Jerusalem artichoke, and short- rotation forestry; fiber crops - kenaf, hemp, and cotton; and oil and fat crops - safflower, cuphea, and jojoba.
Index Keywords: Biomass--Production; Alternative Biomass Crops; Energy Crop Production; Nonfood Agricultural Products; Renewable Energy Sources; Agricultural Products

Title: Off-peak cooling with thermal storage
Affiliations: Paul Mueller Co, United States
Authors with affiliations: Knebel, David E., Paul Mueller Co, United States
Abstract: In the building and construction industry, it is a well demonstrated fact that a new technology takes 20 years to emerge from the introductory phase to common practice. Thermal energy storage (TES) technology has not proven to be an exception. This article discusses use of thermal energy storage for off-peak cooling applications.
Index Keywords: Buildings--Cooling; Off Peak Cooling; Thermal Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Title: Cool storage status update
Affiliations: Electric Power Research Inst, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wendland, Ronald D., Electric Power Research Inst, United States
Abstract: Commercial cool storage continues to gain wider acceptance by building owners and the design community. The market has been increasing by more than 50 percent per year, but still represents a small fraction of its potential. Accelerated growth is anticipated now that most major HVAC equipment manufacturers either produce storage products, are affiliated with a storage manufacturer or have products under development. This article presents an update on cool storage technology applications and market opportunities.
Index Keywords: Refrigeration; Cool Storage; Thermal Storage; Energy Storage

Title: Siah Bishe pumped-storage project in Iran
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Affiliations: Lahmeyer Int GmbH, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Failer, E., Lahmeyer Int GmbH, Germany; Bayat, H., Lahmeyer Int GmbH, Germany
Abstract: The Siah Bishe pumped-storage project, with an installed capacity of 4 × 250 MW, will be Iran's first pumped-storage scheme. At present under construction and scheduled for commissioning in 1996, the power-plant will provide a daily peak energy of 4000 MWh, considerably improving the performance of the integrated power system of Iran. The main civil structures of this project include: two concrete-faced rockfill dams, including chute spillways and diversion/bottom outlets; the power intakes, waterways and outlets; and, an underground powerhouse and transformer cavern. The detailed design will be completed in mid-1990.
Index Keywords: Dams, Embankment--Construction; Electric Power Plant Equipment; Electric Power Plants--Iran; River Basin Projects--Iran; Rockfill Dams; Siah Bishe Pumped Storage Project in Iran; Hydroelectric Power Plants

Authors: Balashov S.I., Bol'nykh N.S., Vyskubov V.P., Metelev A.P., Chlenov A.M.
Title: Voltage-pulse shaper with plasma current interrupter
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Authors with affiliations: Balashov, S.I.; Bol'nykh, N.S.; Vyskubov, V.P.; Metelev, A.P.; Chlenov, A.M.
Abstract: The authors present the results of a study of a shaper of voltage and current pulses in a system consisting of a current-pulse generator and a vacuum inductive storage device with a plasma current interrupter with microsecond energy-input times. Currents of up to 85 kA are generated in the apparatus, and the current switched to the load reaches 80 kA. The maximum times of energy input to the storage inductor are 0.5-1.5 μsec, the maximum overvoltage on the current interrupter is ≈3.2, and the rise time of the current in the diode is ≈40 nsec.

Abstract: The authors describe a magnetic pulse modulator that employs magnetization without reversal. The pulse repetition frequency is 250 kHz in the packet mode for an amplitude of 50 kV, the power is 16 MW, and the duration is 15 nsec. The number of pulses in a packet can be varied from 1 to 30. The packet repetition frequency can be varied from single transmissions to 10 Hz.

Title: Electronic excitations in crystals with complex oxyanions
Affiliations: Synchrotron radiation laboratory, Moscow State University, Moscow, 117234, Russian Federation

Abstract: Luminescence excitation spectra of a wide variety of undoped and doped (by rare-earths or transition elements) crystals with alkali-earth cations and complex oxyanions, either octahedral (ZrO32−, CeO32−) or tetrahedral (SO42−, WO42−, PO43−), have been measured using synchrotron radiation of the "Siberia-1" storage ring in the energy range of exciting photons of several bandgaps (up to 35 eV). An attempt is made to work out a uniform approach to the treatment of luminescence excitation of such systems based on the common tendencies observed in the measured spectra. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Title: Modelling muscle power output in a swimming fish
Affiliations: Department of Biology and Preclinical Medicine, University, St Andrews, Fife, KY16 8LD, United Kingdom

Title: A soft X-ray grating monochromator for undulator radiation
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB at DESY, Notkestr. 85, 2000 Hamburg 52, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Reininger, R., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB at DESY, Notkestr. 85, 2000 Hamburg 52, Germany; Saile, V., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB at DESY, Notkestr. 85, 2000 Hamburg 52, Germany
Abstract: One of the new insertion devices to be installed in the expansion of the DORIS storage ring consists of three undulators designed to cover with the first harmonic the photon energy range between 70 and 2000 eV. The concepts for a high-resolution and high-throughput monochromator that will take full advantage of this powerful new beam line are discussed. The final design is a modified SX-700 type monochromator in which the focusing elliptical mirror is replaced by a spherical one. The aberrations due to the new mirror are minimized by elongating the exit slit arm of the conventional SX-700. The ultimate resolution expected is 0.03 eV at 152 eV and 0.6 eV at 1086 eV with a photon flux up to 5 × 1011 photons/(s-100 mA) at the sample. The spot size at the sample position is less than 0.4 × 1.0 mm2. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Accessories; Insertion Devices; Ray Tracing; Undulators; Monochromators

Authors: Fernandes P., Parodi R., Salvo C., Spataro B.
Title: The design of TE storage cavities for a rf pulse compressor system
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Genova, Italy; Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Rome, Italy

Abstract: This paper deals with the design of high-Q0 TE resonators for high-efficiency rf pulse compression. The aim of our study was the development of a storage resonator to be used for an energy doubler (similar to the one used on the Stanford linac energy doubler (SLED) to increase the beam energy of the Stanford linac to 53 GeV), but to be used for a linac having a quite long filling time of 1.2 ωs. For this reason the storage resonator must be designed for an unloaded Q0 of roughly 105. By using our OSCAR2D computer code (which computes the resonant frequency, Q0 and geometry factor for any reasonable TE or TM monopolar mode of cylindrically symmetric rf cavities) we found an optimum resonator geometry. On this geometry we get the benefit of a Q0 about 10% higher than that of an ideal cylindrical cavity together with the splitting of TE0mn-like and TM1mn-like modes which in a cylindrical cavity are coalescent. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Accessories; Energy Doubler; Pulse Compression; Resonators

Authors: Kosanke R., Bernhardt D., KÖhler K.H., Voigt B.
Title: Changes in macromolecule syntheses under special consideration of UNA and the energy providing system in imbibing embryos of different aged agrostemma githago L. Seeds
Affiliations: Wissenschaftsbereich Botanik, Sektion Biologie der Ernst-Moritz-Arndt-Universität, Grimmer Str. 88, Greifswald 2200, Germany (Democratic Republic, DDR)
Authors with affiliations: Kosanke, R., Wissenschaftsbereich Botanik, Sektion Biologie der Ernst-Moritz-Arndt-Universität, Grimmer Str. 88, Greifswald 2200, Germany (Democratic Republic, DDR); Bernhardt, D., Wissenschaftsbereich Botanik, Sektion Biologie der Ernst-Moritz-Arndt-Universität, Grimmer Str. 88, Greifswald 2200, Germany (Democratic Republic, DDR); KÖhler, K.H., Wissenschaftsbereich Botanik, Sektion Biologie der Ernst-Moritz-Arndt-Universität, Grimmer Str. 88, Greifswald 2200, Germany (Democratic Republic, DDR); Voigt, B., Wissenschaftsbereich Botanik, Sektion Biologie der Ernst-Moritz-Arndt-Universität, Grimmer Str. 88, Greifswald 2200, Germany (Democratic Republic, DDR)
Abstract: Changes in macromolecule syntheses, especially RNA synthesis, and the energy providing system were investigated in seeds of Agrostemma githago aged for different periods. In embryos of aged seeds all macromolecule syntheses start later and reach a lower level than young ones. It was found that the synthesis of rRNA in embryos of aged seeds is reduced whereas the synthesis of poly (A+) RNA in relation to the total RNA synthesis is highly increased as well as the amount of this RNA species with long poly (A) chains. The results are discussed in connection with the decreased protein synthesis and the reduced ATP content and ATP formation ability in embryos during the long time storage of seeds. © 1990 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: ageing; ATP content; ATP formation ability

Authors: Bauert F., Beitz W., Weise E., Salem N.
Title: Modeling methods for a flexible computer-aided embodiment design system
Affiliations: Institute of Machine Design, Faculty of Engineering, The Technical University of Berlin, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bauert, F., Institute of Machine Design, Faculty of Engineering, The Technical University of Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Beitz, W., Institute of Machine Design, Faculty of Engineering, The Technical University of Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Weise, E., Institute of Machine Design, Faculty of Engineering, The Technical University of Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Salem, N., Institute of Machine Design, Faculty of Engineering, The Technical University of Berlin, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: The investigation and implementation of product modeling methods are two of the most important research objectives in the field of computer-aided engineering design. Commercial product modeling systems go beyond geometric modeling systems in that they are adapted to user requirements through the addition of systems that aid in the generation of engineering models and methods. The embodiment design of a mechanical energy storage system serves as an example of future continuous and flexible computer-aided design (CAD). This example is implemented with GEKO, a user system for the layout of design elements. GEKO is coupled with a commercial geometric modeler (CATIA) and uses several programming interfaces. © 1991 Springer-Verlag New York Inc.

Title: Role of the calcaneal inclination in the energy storage capacity of the human foot-a biomechanical model
Affiliations: Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Hadassah University Hospital, PO Box 12000, Jerusalem, 91120, Israel; Cosell Centre for Physical Education, The Hebrew University of Jeruselem, Glvat Ram, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel; Jerusalem College of Technology, PO Box 16031, Jerusalem, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Simkin, A., Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Hadassah University Hospital, PO Box 12000, Jerusalem, 91120, Israel, Cosell Centre for Physical Education, The Hebrew University of Jeruselem, Glvat Ram, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel; Leichter, I., Jerusalem College of Technology, PO Box 16031, Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: The energy storage capacity of the human foot as a passive structure depends on both its geometry and elastic properties. The present study examines theoretically the relationship between the energy stored in the longitudinal arch and the inclination of the calcaneus, when a vertical load is applied. A simple two-dimensional model was used, consisting of two inclined rigid elements, hinged at the apex of the arch and connected by a horizontal tension spring at the bottom of the arch. The spring serves as the energy-storing element of the model, representing the foot plantar ligaments. The behaviour of the model was examined using both a linear and an exponential spring. It demonstrated that the stored energy depends strongly on the calcaneal inclination. For a given vertical load, the energy storage capacity is low at both large and small inclinations and rises markedly at an intermediate value. Assuming that the incidence of stress fractures during locomotion is affected by insufficient energy attenuation of the foot, this model provides an explanation for the higher prevalence of tibial and femoral stress fractures in subjects with high or low arches. © 1990 IFMBE.
Author Keywords: Calcaneal inclination; Energy storage; Foot; Longitudinal arch; Model; Stress fractures

Title: Link between emissions, fuel economy
Source title: Forum for applied research and public policy
Affiliations: Natural Resources Defense Council
Authors with affiliations: Calwell, Chris J., Natural Resources Defense Council
Abstract: The twin goals of lowering automobile emissions and improving automobile fuel economy are mutually compatible. This statement refutes the traditional contentions that improvement in fuel economy can only be achieved at the expense of higher tailpipe emission. As discussed in the paper this is based on a recent research in the performance of 1989 cars and in the promise of advanced technologies. Policy considerations with regards to emission standards and fuel economy are addressed. Among the existing and emerging technologies, the following are briefly discussed: the Gerneson II system; minicar; refinements to diesel engines; energy storage systems; continuously variable transmission; aerodynamic improvements; weight reduction, new engine designs; evaporative recovery devices.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution--Control; Automobile Engines--Exhaust Gases; Carbon Monoxide--Environmental Impact; Air Separating Membrane; Fuel Efficiency; Pollutant Emissions; Automobiles

Title: Stabilization of catenary voltage fluctuations by means of the flywheel electric energy storage system
Affiliations: Keihin Electric Express Railway Co., Ltd, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Maruyama, Nobuaki, Keihin Electric Express Railway Co., Ltd, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes a system recently developed by a private electric commuter railway in Japan for temporarily storing surplus regenerative braking power as rotation energy in a large-sized flywheel. This flywheel energy storage system is constructed as a lineside energy conservation substation and is capable of operating in two models - namely, a regenerative energy storage mode and a voltage drop compensation mode. The new system has the capability of preventing power regenerative brake failure in EMUs and is intended to provide an upgraded performance by handling greater revolution speeds while reducing various kinds of loss.
Index Keywords: Cars--Braking; Electric Lines--Voltage Regulation; Electric Motors, DC--Energy Conservation; Electric Substations--Traction; Flywheels--Applications; DC Railway Substations; Electric Multiple Units; Flywheel Energy Storage Systems; Large Flywheel Generator Motors; Regenerative Braking; Regenerative Power Storage; Electric Traction

Authors: Kemmer J., Lutz G., Prechtel U., Schuster K., Sterzik M., Strüder L., Ziemann T.
Title: Experimental confirmation of a new semiconductor detector principle
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Institut für Physik und Astrophysik, München, Germany; Meserschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm GmbH, Technische Univ. München, München, Germany; Messerschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm GmbH, München, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kemmer, J., Meserschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm GmbH, Technische Univ. München, München, Germany; Lutz, G., Max-Planck-Institut für Physik und Astrophysik, München, Germany; Prechtel, U., Messerschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm GmbH, München, Germany; Schuster, K., Max-Planck-Institut für Physik und Astrophysik, München, Germany; Sterzik, M., Max-Planck-Institut für Physik und Astrophysik, München, Germany; Strüder, L., Max-Planck-Institut für Physik und Astrophysik, München, Germany; Ziemann, T., Messerschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm GmbH, München, Germany
Abstract: A new detector-amplification principle proposed by Kemmer and Lutz in 1986 has been experimentally verified. Outstanding features of this device are the built-in amplification, the signal charge storage capability and the possibility of repeated non-destructive readout. The device was used for detection of X-rays from a 241Am and from Am and from an 55Fe source. Very low noise figures (σ=30 electrons corresponding to an energy resolution of FWHM = 250 eV at 6 keV energy) have been obtained at room temperature. Various applications of the structure either as detector or as purely electronic element are possible. One of the most intriguing is the use as a pixel detector with random access non-destructive readout. This device may be operated at very low power, as only reading (of one single pixel at a time), not storing, consumes power. Further options of the device are fast clearing, gating and variation of the pixel size during readout. The latter property can be used to drastically increase the readout speed compared to more standard two dimensional devices as e.g. CCD detectors, as one may restrict the high density readout to regions of interest determined beforehand by a coarse scan of the whole detector. An alternative use of the device is as an analog or digital memory, or as a simple transistor with drastically reduced parasitic capacitances. Possible further developments are the combination with a novel three dimensional analog storage device which may either be used as a detector with built-in storage of several charge images or as a three dimensional analog memory. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Semiconductor Devices; Pixel Devices; Semiconductor Detectors; Radiation Detectors

Authors: Fretwurst E., Herdan H., Lindström G., Pein U., Rollwagen M., Schatz H., Thomsen P., Wunstorf R.
Title: Silicon detector developments for calorimetry: Technology and radiation damage
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A

Authors with affiliations: Fretwurst, E., I. Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Hamburg, Hamburg, Germany; Herdan, H., I.
