Title: Physiological responses of the mangrove Rhizophora mangle grown in the absence and presence of NaCl
Affiliations: Botanisches Institut, Der Tierärztlichen Hochschule Hannover, Bünteweg 17d, Hannover, D-3000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: WERNER, A., Botanisches Institut, Der Tierärztlichen Hochschule Hannover, Bünteweg 17d, Hannover, D-3000, Germany; STELZER, R., Botanisches Institut, Der Tierärztlichen Hochschule Hannover, Bünteweg 17d, Hannover, D-3000, Germany
Abstract: Abstract. Propagules of the mangrove, Rhizophora mangle L., were precultivated for 9 months in a greenhouse. The young plants were transferred into unaerated nutrient solutions without and with 200 mol m 3 NaCl and subsequently their growth, their water relations and the photosynthetic properties of their leaves were studied. Growth of the salttreated plants was significantly increased, while the control plants gradually died off after finishing the experiments. The shoot water potential and the stomatal resistance of the leaves were lowered while the chlorophyll contents and the chlorophyll a/b ratio in the leaves of salt‐treated plants were increased by NaCl, the net result being an enhanced rate of CO2 assimilation. The leaves of both sets of plants showed diurnal fluctuations in malic acid concentration which were more pronounced in the leaves of salt treated plants which, additionally, were more succulent. However, the plants showed no net CO2 fixation at night, indicating that Rhizophora mangle is a CAM‐cycling plant. After 200 d of cultivation without or with NaCl, the Na+, Cl and K+ concentrations in tissues and vacuoles were measured. Energy‐dispersive X‐ray microprobe analyses on root vacuoles of control plants reveal Na+ preference, on those of salt treated plants a strong K+ preference. Vacuolar K+ concentrations are neither affected by NaCl nor do they vary across the root radius. High vacuolar Na+ and Cl concentrations are found in the hypodermis followed by a stepwise decrease towards the inner root cortex cells. Ion concentrations of the photosynthetically active leaf tissues seem to be regulated by (1) radial filtration across the root cortex: (2) ion exchange of the xlem parenchyma cells: and (3) sequestration of Na+ and Cl in the hypodermal water storage tissue of the leaves. Copyright © 1990, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: EDX‐analysis; growth; ion localization; photosynthesis; Rhizophora mangle, Rhizophoraccac: CAM‐cycling; salt regulation; ultrafiltration; water relations

Title: The supply of storage in energy futures markets
Authors with affiliations: Cho, D.W.; McDougall, G.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS AFFECTING AQUIFER THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE
Source title: JAWRA Journal of the American Water Resources Association
Authors with affiliations: Hendrickson, P.L.
Abstract: ABSTRACT: Thermal energy storage involves the capture and storage of thermal energy (either heat or chill) during one time period for use at a later period. Storage of thermal energy in aquifers on a seasonal basis is one promising application of the technology that has been implemented in several foreign countries and is currently undergoing field testing in the U.S. Potential developers of aquifer thermal energy storage projects will face a number of regulatory requirements at the federal, state, and local level of government. These can include meeting: (1) surface land and ground water use restrictions, (2) regulations relating to withdrawal of ground water, and (3) requirements for reinjecting thermally altered ground waters. Separate permits for ground water withdrawal and reinjection may be required. The permit process is likely to involve opportunities for public comment and may involve contested proceedings. Copyright © 1990, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: aquifers; permits; regulations; thermal energy storage

Authors: Chen Y.C., Wang P., Waters R.G., Lee K.K.
Title: Energy storage in quantum-well lasers
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Hunter College of the City University of New York, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY, 10021, United States; McDonnell Douglas Electronic System Company, Opto-Electronics Center, 350 Executive Boulevard, Elmsford, NY, 10523, United States; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Colorado, Colorado Springs, CO, 80933, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, Y.C., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Hunter College of the City University of New York, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY, 10021, United States; Wang, P., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Hunter College of the City University of New York, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY, 10021, United States; Waters, R.G., McDonnell Douglas Electronic System Company, Opto-Electronics Center, 350 Executive Boulevard, Elmsford, NY, 10523, United States; Lee, K.K., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Colorado, Colorado Springs, CO, 80933, United States
Abstract: A new scheme of energy storage in single-quantum-well semiconductor lasers is analyzed. This scheme involves the storage of the majority of injected carriers in the continuum states of the surrounding bulk material, in which the carrier density is diluted and the higher-order carrier-density-dependent recombination processes are much smaller. This allows the inversion level to build up to a much higher level during the pumping stage of Q switching. The possibility of using indirect-band-gap semiconductors for carrier storage is also proposed. © 1990 Optical Society of America.

Title: Development of a dynamic, mechanistic model of lamb metabolism and growth
Affiliations: Growth Physiology Group, Ruakura Agriculture Centre, Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, Hamilton, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Sainz, R.D., Growth Physiology Group, Ruakura Agriculture Centre, Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, Hamilton, New Zealand; Wolff, J.E., Growth Physiology Group, Ruakura Agriculture Centre, Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, Hamilton, New Zealand
Abstract: A dynamic, mechanistic model of lamb metabolism and growth was developed for the purpose of evaluating hypotheses regarding the mechanisms of action of growth promotants. The model relates tissue growth to DNA accretion and protein turn-over. State variables include circulating amino acids, glucose, lipids and acetate; four protein pools (carcass, viscera, other tissues and wool) and storage triacylglycerol are also included. Equations are mainly of the Michaelis-Menten form, allowing for nutrient utilization patterns to be determined by relative tissue affinities for substrates (ko.5), enzymatic capacities (Vmax) and substrate concentrations ([S]). Protein degradation rates are defined as first-order with respect to protein. The model adequately simulated growth from 20 to 40 kg empty body weight. Simulated changes in nutrient input yielded reasonable energy balance response patterns, although theoretical growth efficiencies were greater than those observed in practice. Variations in volatile fatty acid absorption patterns were accommodated well, with predicted nitrogen retention closely approximating experimental observations. The model also responded appropriately to changes in dietary protein level, with body fat varying inversely with amino acid absorption. In summary, the model was found to perform adequately for the purpose of examining mechanisms responsible for alteration of growth and body composition. © 1990, British Society of Animal Science. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: growth; lambs; mathematical models; metabolism

Authors: Holland D.L., Davenport J., East J.
Title: The fatty acid composition of the leatherback turtle dermochelys coriacea and its jellyfish prey
Source title: Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom
Affiliations: School of Ocean Sciences, Marine Science Laboratories, University College of North Wales, Menai Bridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Holland, D.L., School of Ocean Sciences, Marine Science Laboratories, University College of North Wales, Menai Bridge, United Kingdom; Davenport, J., School of Ocean Sciences, Marine Science Laboratories, University College of North Wales, Menai Bridge, United Kingdom; East, J., School of Ocean Sciences, Marine Science Laboratories, University College of North Wales, Menai Bridge, United Kingdom
Abstract: The leatherback turtle, Dermochelys coriacea (L.) studied was a male, weighing 916 kg, with a total dorsal length of 291 cm. It was beached on the Welsh coast, UK in September 1988 and is currently the largest leatherback ever recorded. Total lipid formed between 87.5 and 95.4% of the dry weight of representative samples of the blubber and 43•0% and 4.9% of the liver and pectoral muscle respectively. High levels of neutral lipid in the liver (79.0% of the total lipid) as well as the blubber (87•6–99.9% of the total lipid) suggest an important energy storage function for these tissues. Overall, with the notable exception of 22:l wll, fatty acids which are found in a putative jellyfish diet of Rhizostoma, Aurelia, Cyanea and Chrysaora are also present in the leatherback liver and muscle, blubber and other fatty tissues. Fatty acid 22:lwll is present in the jellyfish samples, but is absent or at trace levels only in the leatherback tissues (0T-0*3% of the total fatty acids). The polyunsaturated fatty acids of the w3 series 20:5w3, 22:5w3 and 22:6w3 are well represented in leatherback adipose tissues, muscle and liver as well as in the jellyfish examined. The leatherback and jellyfish lipids are therefore marine in character, but are also similar to terrestrial animal lipid in having a high proportion of fatty acids of the w6 series, principally arachidonic acid, 20:4w6. The significant levels of 20:4w6 in jellyfish total lipid (9.7-20.0% of the total fatty acids) and in the leatherback neutral lipid (1.0-10.9% of the total fatty acids) and phospholipid (0-6-15.5% of total fatty acids) fractions of all tissues sampled suggests that arachidonic acid assumes more importance in food chain relationships involving leatherbacks than in other marine food webs such as those involving fish. © 1990, Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom. All rights reserved.

Authors: Wilson M.N., Smith A.I.C., Kempson V.C., Purvis A.L., Anderson R.J., Townsend M.C., Jorden A.R., Andrews D.E., Suller V.P., Poole M.W.
Title: Update on the Compact Synchrotron X-Ray Source Helios
Affiliations: Oxford Instruments Ltd., Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom; SERC Daresbury Laboratory, Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, M.N., Oxford Instruments Ltd., Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom; Smith, A.I.C., Oxford Instruments Ltd., Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom; Kempson, V.C., Oxford Instruments Ltd., Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom; Purvis, A.L., Oxford Instruments Ltd., Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom; Anderson, R.J., Oxford Instruments Ltd., Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom; Townsend, M.C., Oxford Instruments Ltd., Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom; Jorden, A.R., Oxford Instruments Ltd., Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom; Andrews, D.E., Oxford Instruments Ltd., Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom; Suller, V.P., SERC Daresbury Laboratory, Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom; Poole, M.W., SERC Daresbury Laboratory, Oxford, OX2 ODX, United Kingdom
Abstract: Helios is a compact superconducting Synchrotron X-ray source designed specifically for lithography. It will produce a total X-ray power of 8.2 kW when the design stored beam of 200 mA is achieved. The first phase of commissioning has just been completed in less than 2 months. A stored beam of 305 mA has been accumulated at the injection energy of 200 MeV and 55 mA has been accelerated to the full energy of 700 MeV. a. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: Cryogenic; Storage ring; Superconducting magnet; Synchrotron radiation; X-ray lithography

Title: Stimulating Students' Design Creativity
Affiliations: Chemical Engineering Department, University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Scott, R., Chemical Engineering Department, University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: If appropriately selected and organized, student design projects can stimulate creativity during the formation of graduate chemical engineers. Projects completed according to the procedure described fulfil Institution of Chemical Engineers Engineering Council accreditation criteria and should be readily adaptable to other integrated and specialized engineering courses. A project for Thermochemical Energy Storage and Transmission illustrates the procedure which also meets with student and industrial approval. © 1990, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Title: Phenomena in the Range of a Few Hundreds of MeV/Nucleon
Affiliations: Dept of Physics, Univ of Lund, Sölvegatan 14, Lund, S-223 62, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Jakobsson, B., Dept of Physics, Univ of Lund, Sölvegatan 14, Lund, S-223 62, Sweden
Abstract: Recent results on fragmentation and multifragmentation in heavy ion reactions in the hundreds of MeV/nucleon energy region are discussed. Some perspectives are given on the possibilities to utilize storage rings in combination with gas-jet targets in order to achieve more selective fragmentation experiments. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Authors: Tomimasu T., Noguchi T., Sugiyama S., Yamazaki T., Mikado T., Chiwaki M., Saito T., Suzuki R., Ohgaki H., Mitsui T., Hosoda Y., Takada H., Tsutsui Y., Oka Y., Emura K., Hirata Y.
Title: Development of Five Compact Storage Rings, TERAS, NIJI-I–IV, at ETL
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka, 554, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tomimasu, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Noguchi, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Sugiyama, S., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Yamazaki, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Mikado, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Chiwaki, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Saito, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Suzuki, R., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Ohgaki, H., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Mitsui, T., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka, 554, Japan; Hosoda, Y., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka, 554, Japan; Takada, H., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka, 554, Japan; Tsutsui, Y., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka, 554, Japan; Oka, Y., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka, 554, Japan; Emura, K., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka, 554, Japan; Hirata, Y., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka, 554, Japan
Abstract: At the Electrochemical Laboratory (ETL) four compact storage rings, TERAS, NIJI-I–III, have been already constructed and a compact storage ring, NIJI-IV, with long straight sections for FEL experiments will be constructed in 1990. TERAS is an 800-MeV storage ring. It has been operated since Oct. 1981 for research on atomic, molecular and solid state physics and ULSI lithography, generation of polarized SR and gamma-rays and for a free electron laser (FEL) experiment. NIJI-I (NIJI means rainbow) is a 270-MeV compact ring and has been operated from Feb. 1986 to March 1989 for machine studies of beam storage higher than 0.5 A at low energies below 150 MeV. NIJI-II is a 600-MeV conventional type compact ring and was operated in July 1989. NIJI-III is a 620-MeV superconducting type ring. NIJI-II and NIJI-III will be used for FEL and ULSI lithography experiments. Before the superconducting magnets are installed, NIJI-III with conventional type magnets has already been constructed and operated in June 1989. The conventional type magnets of NIJI-III will be replaced by superconducting type ones, starting in the fall of 1989 one by one. NIJI-IV is a 500-MeV conventional type compact ring with straight sections longer than 5 m where an optical klystron can be installed to achieve a high gain FEL experiment. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Authors: Anders W., Bürkmann K., Egan-Krieger G.V., Hartrott M.V., Lehr H., Martin M., Müller R., Oertel D., Schmidt M., Schulz L., Weihreter E., Oertel D., Schmidt M.
Title: Superconducting Storage Ring Development at BESSY – New Results from COSY
Affiliations: Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Fraunhofer Institut für Mikrostrukturtechnik, Dillenburger Str. 53, Berlin, D-1000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Anders, W., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Bürkmann, K., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Egan-Krieger, G.V., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Hartrott, M.V., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Lehr, H., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Martin, M., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Müller, R., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Oertel, D., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany, Fraunhofer Institut für Mikrostrukturtechnik, Dillenburger Str. 53, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Schmidt, M., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Schulz, L., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Weihreter, E., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Oertel, D., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany, Fraunhofer Institut für Mikrostrukturtechnik, Dillenburger Str. 53, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Schmidt, M., Fraunhofer Institut für Mikrostrukturtechnik, Dillenburger Str. 53, Berlin, D-1000, Germany
Abstract: To extend the use of synchrotron radiation outside the field of fundamental research, superconducting compact storage rings are under development worldwide. The basic concepts of such SR sources are presented with a brief outline of the main development problems. The COSY ring at BESSY has been designed as a prototype of a compact source for x-ray lithography. After detailed studies with normal conducting magnets, commissioning with the superconducting magnets began in spring 1988. The first electron beam was stored in this machine in November the same year, a milestone in the development of superconducting compact storage rings. In the meantime the energy has been raised up to 360 MeV. The main characteristics of COSY are reported together with the latest results. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Title: 1989 Joint internationaL waste management conference
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Affiliations: The Department of Nuclear Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ahn, J., The Department of Nuclear Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Japan; Suzuki, A., The Department of Nuclear Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Reviewed is the as-titled conference, held in October 23 to 28, 1989, in Kyoto, Japan, sponsored by American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers, and Atomic Energy Society of Japan, with other co-sponsoring societies. In the Conference, all the aspects of radioactive waste management were discussed, including policies and general strategies for waste management, solidification and incineration of low-, and intermediate-level wastes (LLW and ILW), shallow-land burial disposal of LLW/ILW and its safety assessment, decommissioning, storage and transportation of spent fuels, vitrification of high-level wastes (HLW), deep geologic disposal of HLW and its safety assessment by natural analogs, and partitioning and transmutation. The significance of the Conference is found in that the informations of Japan's waste management activities, which do not always reach audience in other part of the world, were conveyed in detail in the Conference. More papers were presented for LLW/ILW than for HLW, which might reflect the fact that there are still more activities for LLW/ILW than for HLW in Japan. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: ASME; High-level waste; Intermediate-level waste; International Conference; Kyoto; Low-level waste; Spent fuels; Waste management

Title: Increasing enzyme thermostability
Affiliations: Biotechnology Center, University of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liao, H., Biotechnology Center, University of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Abstract: There are many practical advantages to conducting enzyme-catalyzed reactions at temperatures of 60°-100° C. Examples include: 1) diffusion of substrates is faster at these temperatures, thus contributing to higher reaction rates; 2) aqueous solutions have lower viscosity and therefore require less energy to mix; and S) there is less risk of microbial contamination. Thus enzymes that are able to catalyze reactions at these temperatures are highly desirable in industrial and other applied settings (6). Added advantages of thermostable enzymes are that they tend to be more stable than their thermolabile counterparts at lower temperatures, thus permitting their preparation and storage under ambient conditions, and some are more resistant to chemical denaturants and proteases. However, most enzymes from conventional sources are not thermostable; that is, they are denatured when heated. This paper will discuss and contrast three approaches to obtaining thermostable enzymes: isolation from thermophilic bacteria, enzyme engineering, and cloning and selection in thermophiles. Physical methods of enzyme stabilization, such as by immobilization or by conducting reactions in anhydrous organic solvents, are alternative approaches that are beyond the scope of this paper. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Thermal Storage Efficiency of a Cylindrical Water Tank
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. Eng., Kyusyu Univ., Fukuoka 812, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyatake, O., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Kyusyu Univ., Fukuoka 812, Japan; Fujita, K., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Kyusyu Univ., Fukuoka 812, Japan
Abstract: The internal characteristics and the thermal storage performance of a cylindrical thermal storage water tank were investigated experimentally by measuring transient liquid temperature responses for the case in which hot water was charged through a horizontal inlet tube into the upper part of a tank filled with cold water. Experimental parameters varied included the diameter of inlet tube, the hot-cold water temperature difference, the mass flow rate of liquid, and the liquid level. From the experimental results and theoretical considerations, dimensionless semi-empirical equations suitable for predicting the amount of cold water mixed into the hot water region and the thermal storage efficiency of the cylindrical water tank were deduced as a function of the Archimedes number based on inflow conditions, the Peclet number, the ratio of tank diameter to inlet tube diameter, and the ratio of liquid level to inlet tube diameter. The equation derived for thermal storage efficiency was compared with existing experimental results with reasonably good agreement. © 1990, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Empirical Equation; Energy; Internal Characteristics; Temperature Stratification; Thermal Storage Efficiency; Thermal Storage Tank
Index Keywords: Liquids; Tanks (containers); Water; Water tanks; Empirical equations; Energy; Internal characteristics; Temperature stratification; Thermal storage; Heat storage

Authors: Tone S., Masawaki T., Osamura H., Taguchi H.
Title: A Rate Analysis of Photoisomerization of Norbornadiene as a Photochemical Energy Storage Material
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. Eng., Osaka Univ., Toyonaka 560, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tone, S., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Osaka Univ., Toyonaka 560, Japan; Masawaki, T., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Osaka Univ., Toyonaka 560, Japan; Osamura, H., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Osaka Univ., Toyonaka 560, Japan; Taguchi, H., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Osaka Univ., Toyonaka 560, Japan
Abstract: A rate analysis of photoisomerization of norbornadiene to quadricyclane in solution was performed under complete absorption of light. The rate of photoisomerization reaction was independent of concentration of photosensitizer and reaction temperature. The reaction was zero order with respect to concentration of norbornadiene and first order with respect to light intensity, and was described by dCQ/dt=k′ μIa where k′ is an experimental constant that was found to be identical with quantum yield. The maximum quantum yield was obtained when the reaction was carried out using benzophenone as a photosensitizer in cyclohexane. © 1990, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy Storage; Norbornadiene; Photoisomerization; Rate Analysis
Index Keywords: Light; Photoisomerization; Photosensitizers; Quantum yield; First order; Light intensity; Norbornadiene; Photoisomerization reaction; Quadricyclanes; Rate analysis; Reaction temperature; Zero order; Energy storage

Title: Process engineering concerns in the lunar environment
Source title: AIAA Space Programs and Technologies Conference, 1990
Affiliations: NASA-Johnson Space Center, Houston, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sullivan, T.A., NASA-Johnson Space Center, Houston, TX, United States
Abstract: The paper discusses the constraints on a production process imposed by the lunar or Martian environment on the space transportation system. A proposed chemical route to produce oxygen from iron oxide bearing minerals (including ilmenite) is presented in three different configurations which vary in complexity. A design for thermal energy storage is presented that could both provide power during the lunar night and act as a blast protection barrier for the outpost. A process lo release carbon from the lunar regolith as methane is proposed, capitalizing on the greater abundance and favorable physical properties of methane relative to hydrogen to benefit the entire system. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., 1990. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Heat storage; Lunar surface analysis; Methane; Blast protection; Chemical routes; Entire system; Lunar night; Lunar regolith; Martian environment; Production process; Space Transportation System; Iron oxides

Authors: Kojima T., Obara H., Shibayama K.
Title: Investigation of impulse response for an interdigital surface-acoustic-wave transducer
Affiliations: Tamagawa University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kojima, T., Tamagawa University, Japan; Obara, H., Tamagawa University, Japan; Shibayama, K., Tamagawa University, Japan
Abstract: The improved equivalent circuit model for a SAW interdigital transducer which we proposed in a previous paper con- tains an energy storage effect in addition to usual second order effects, and appropriately expresses the metallization effect. © 1990 The Japan Society of Applied Physics.

Authors: Gräf D., Grundner M., Lüdecke D., Schulz R.
Title: Reaction of hydrofluoric acid and water with the GaAs (100) surface
Source title: Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology A: Vacuum, Surfaces and Films
Affiliations: Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Research Center, Postfach 1140, D-8263, Burghausen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gräf, D., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Research Center, Postfach 1140, D-8263, Burghausen, Germany; Grundner, M., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Research Center, Postfach 1140, D-8263, Burghausen, Germany; Lüdecke, D., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Research Center, Postfach 1140, D-8263, Burghausen, Germany; Schulz, R., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Research Center, Postfach 1140, D-8263, Burghausen, Germany
Abstract: The chemical surface state of polished GaAs (100) wafers after treatments in hydrofluoric acid and in water were investigated by means of x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and high-resolution electron energy-loss spectroscopy (HREELS). After the HF treatment, the wafer surface is As rich and partially covered with fluorine. The fluorine is bonded to Ga atoms as can be deduced out of a chemically shifted component in the XPS spectra. We cannot detect hydride groups using vibrational spectroscopy (HREELS). Fluorine on top of the wafer surface can be removed by a short water rinse. Depending on the storage time of GaAs wafers in HF the As enrichment of the surface increases. We present a model for the surface state after the HF treatment with an As overlaver on top of bulk GaAs. Consistent with our angular dependent XPS measurements, we can give values for the thickness of the As overlayer. Conditions of illumination and concentration of HF influence the reaction rate of HF on the GaAs surface. The reaction with water depends strongly on the illumination and whether the treatment in water is performed in static or dynamic conditions. Rinsing samples in running de-ionized water and dark storage in water results in an oxide removal. Light storage in water in static conditions yields a Ga-rich oxide with the growth rate depending on the illumination. The oxide growth is faster on n-type GaAs than on p-type. © 1990, American Vacuum Society. All rights reserved.

Title: A sensitive MNMOS structure for optical storage
Affiliations: Deparment of Solid State Electronics, Chalmers University of Technology, Góteborg, S-412 96, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Shivaraman, M.S., Deparment of Solid State Electronics, Chalmers University of Technology, Góteborg, S-412 96, Sweden; Engstrom, O., Deparment of Solid State Electronics, Chalmers University of Technology, Góteborg, S-412 96, Sweden
Abstract: A sensitive device structure for the storage of optical signals is presented. It is based on an indium tin oxide-silicon nitride-aluminum-silicon dioxide-silicon (MNMOS) combination. The light signal is transformed to electric charge through optical excitation of charge carriers in the two metal layers. The charge is transported in the nitride conduction and valence bands to the aluminum. The latter layer is confined between the two insulator layers, thus forming a potential well for the storage of the optically induced charges. Light exposure times down to 0.1 ms are enough to store readable data by a light power of 90 ¿W/cm2at 2.2 eV photon energy. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Optical Storage

Authors: Sugawara M., Kamada H., Fujita T.
Title: A Study of the Fin Size Ratio for Freezing of Water on an Upper Cooling Wall with Fins
Source title: Nihon Kikai Gakkai Ronbunshu, B Hen/Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers, Part B
Authors with affiliations: Sugawara, M.; Kamada, H.; Fujita, T.
Abstract: This study was carried out experimentally and analytically concerning freezing water in a closed horizontal vessel having an upper cooling wall with fins. A one-dimensional simple analysis predicts the frozen layer thickness. It was found that increasing the number of fins (i. e., decreasing the length between fins L does not always enhance the frozen layer thickness. It was consequently determined that the ratio of a netfrozen layer thickness with fins to the layer with no fins has the maximum value at an optimum size ratio of fins. The optimum size ratio of fins was presented with a correlation of L/H = {0.022(λF/λI) + 2.65}(δ/H). where H : height of fins, δ : thickness of fins. λF: thermal conductivity of fins, and λI : thermal conductivity of ice. © 1990, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cold; Energy Storage; Freezing; Heat Transfer; Refrigeration

Authors: Babusci D., Casano L., D'Angelo A., Picozza P., Schaerf C., Girolami B.
Title: Project GRAAL: the scientific case
Affiliations: Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, INFN, P.O. Box 13, Frascati (Roma), I-00044, Italy; Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Roma Tor Vergata, Roma, Italy; INFN, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy; Istituto Superiore di Sanità, INFN, Sezione Sanità, Roma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Babusci, D., Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, INFN, P.O. Box 13, Frascati (Roma), I-00044, Italy; Casano, L., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Roma Tor Vergata, Roma, Italy, INFN, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy; D'Angelo, A., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Roma Tor Vergata, Roma, Italy, INFN, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy; Picozza, P., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Roma Tor Vergata, Roma, Italy, INFN, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy; Schaerf, C., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Roma Tor Vergata, Roma, Italy, INFN, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy; Girolami, B., Istituto Superiore di Sanità, INFN, Sezione Sanità, Roma, Italy
Abstract: Backward Compton scattering of laser light against the high-energy electrons circulating in storage rings has produced tagged beams of fully polarized high-energy gamma-rays with an intensity useful for the study of photoreactions. At the ESRF this technique will produce a beam of 1.5 GeV and an intensity of 107 photons per second. We discuss the technical characteristics of such a project and the scientific goals which can be achieved in the study of the electromagnetic transitions of the hardrons and the photoproduction of isobars and strange particles in nucleons and nuclei. © 1990 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: PACS 25.20 - Photonuclear reactions and photon scattering

Title: Analysis of a commercial ice-storage system: Design principles and measured performance
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Piette, M.A., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: This paper summarizes an analysis of the measured performance of an ice-storage system in a large office building. The partial storage system was installed at a cost below a conventional cooling system when the building was initially constructed. The design analysis concluded that by reducing on-peak electric demand through shifting cooling energy use to nighttime operation, the system would save about $38 000 per year in electricity costs. During 1987, savings were roughly 10% of this estimate. Reasons for the discrepancy include the inability of the system to deliver the design cooling load, and poor operating and maintenance practices. The assessment is based upon monitoring of the cooling load, compressor electricity use, chilled-water pump electricity use, and whole-building electricity use, each measured at 15-minute intervals. A primary objective of the monitoring project was to compare electricity costs of the actual system to what they would have been with a conventional cooling system, without storage. We estimated the hourly electricity use of the base case conventional system using the measured hourly cooling load data and a part-load efficiency curve for a 1617 kWt (460 ton) centrifugal chiller. Five months of cooling load data were available (February - June). The maximum electric demand shift was 150 kWe (6.1 We/m2). The average monthly peak shift was 95 kWe. Over these five months the system COP decreased from 2.82 to 1.74, while the estimated COP for the conventional system ranged from 2.84 to 2.75. Since the analysis period, the system has undergone major retrofitting to alleviate the occasional overheating and further reduce electricity costs. © 1990.

Title: New charm results from ARGUS
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Spengler, J., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: Recent results on hadronic D0 decays and P-wave charmed mesons are discussed. The data have been collected with the ARGUS detector 1 at the e+e- storage ring DORIS II at centre-of-mass energies around 10 GeV. This presentation includes the observation of several new hadronic D0 decays, the first measurement of an isospin mass splitting in the P-wave D meson sector, a decay angular analysis attempting to decompose the D*(2420)0, and the observation of a candidate for an L = 1 Ds meson. © 1990.

Title: Tritium research and technology facilities for fusion inside the bruyeres-le-chatel research center of the French atomic energy commission
Affiliations: Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, Centre de Bruyeres-le-Chatel, DETN, B.P. n12, 91680 Bruyeres-le-Chatel, France
Authors with affiliations: Hircq, B., Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, Centre de Bruyeres-le-Chatel, DETN, B.P. n12, 91680 Bruyeres-le-Chatel, France
Abstract: Because of a large tritium experience in the Bruyeres-le-Chatel Research Center (Atomic Energy Commission-FRANCE), new activities could be undertaken in 1986 inside the European Fusion Technology Program, especially tritium studies within the frame work of the Next European Torus. After presenting the general tritium research program which concerns the Torus Exhaust Gas Processing (deuterium-tritium purification and storage) and involved materials (weldability of tritium-helium containing steels and corrosion of steels by tritiated water), major obtained results are given before describing the associated equipments. © 1990.

Title: A measurement of the weak axial couplings of the b- and c-quark
Affiliations: Physikalisches Institut der Universität Heidelberg, Philosophenweg 12, 6900 Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Elsen, E., Physikalisches Institut der Universität Heidelberg, Philosophenweg 12, 6900 Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: The forward-backward charge asymmetries of the b and c quarks are measured with the JADE detector at the e+e- storage ring PETRA at √s = 35 GeV and 44 GeV using both electrons and muons to tag the heavy quarks. At √s = 35 GeV, a simultaneous fit for the two asymmetries yields the result Ab = -9.3 ± 5.2% (stat.) and Ac = -9.6±4.0% (stat.). Combining the results of 1 parameter fits of the asymmetries at both energies gives ab = -0.72±0.34 and ac = 0.79 ± 0.40 respectively. The mixing parameter for continuum b b ̄-production is determined to be χ = 0.24 ± 0.12 if both heavy quark coupling constants are constrained to their Standard Model values. © 1990.

Title: ARGUS results on antideuteron production
Affiliations: Institut für Physik der Universität Dortmund, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Lindner, A., Institut für Physik der Universität Dortmund, Germany
Abstract: Using the ARGUS detector at the DORIS II storage ring we have studied the production of antideuterons in e+e- annihilation at centre-of-mass energies around 10 GeV. From 21 events containing d candidates we determined the inclusive cross section 1 σdirhad·dσ/dp and the production rate in direct hadronic Υ{hooked}(1S), Υ{hooked}(2S) decays, which was measured to be (6.0 ± 2.0 ± 0.6)·10-5d per event while in the continuun e+e- → qq only an upper limit of 1.7. · 10-5d per event (90% CL) could be obtained. Comparisons with a simple model and other ARGUS measurements hint at the underlaying production mechanism of antideuterons. © 1990.

Title: Double Pomeron Exchange from the ISR to the SSC
Affiliations: Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, Chilton, Didcot, OX11 0QX, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Albrow, M.G., Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, Chilton, Didcot, OX11 0QX, United Kingdom
Abstract: After a general introduction to Double Pomeron Exchange I show how the existence of the process was demonstrated at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings and discuss its value there as a spectroscopic tool in meson/glueball studies. At higher collision energies as now available at the Super Proton Synchrotron and Fermilab pp Colliders it would be very interesting to study hard processes in Double Pomeron Exchange and investigate Pomeron structure. The still higher Large Hadron Collider and Superconducting Super Collider energies extend the range of this physics dramatically, possibly into the electroweak sector. © 1990.

Title: A comparison of some methods of stochastic modelling of solar energy photovoltaic storage systems
Affiliations: School of Civil Engineering, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Doran, D.G., School of Civil Engineering, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW, Australia
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Influence of temperature on moisture sorption isotherms of nigerian hides, skins and leathers
Affiliations: National Research Institute for Chemical Technology (formerly Leather Research Institute), P.M.B. 1052, Zaria, Nigeria; Department of Chemistry, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Agbaji, A.S., National Research Institute for Chemical Technology (formerly Leather Research Institute), P.M.B. 1052, Zaria, Nigeria; Agbaji, E.B., Department of Chemistry, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria
Abstract: The moisture isotherms of untanned and tanned (chrome and vegetable) goat skins and cow hides at 20, 30 and 40°C were determined. A comparison of the isotherms at 20°C for tanned and untanned cow hides showed only slight differences at low relative humidities (r.h. < 40%). Marked differences however occurred at the higher relative humidities. These results indicate that up to a r.h. of 40%, the adsorption of water is a function of surface area alone for the untanned and tanned cow hides. Other factors are likely to influence the adsorption above this r.h. Analyses of the isotherms using the established sorption models indicate that the storage stability of the hides and skins decreased with an increase in temperature. Plots of reduced isotherms at different temperatures indicated a possibility of structural modification occurring at relative humidities above 50% at the higher temperatures, for the untanned and chrome tanned hides. The energy requirements for reducing the m.c. of the skins and hides are also presented. © 1990.

Abstract: We measured the differential jet-multiplicity distribution in e+e- annihilation with the Mark II detector. This distribution is compared with the second-order QCD prediction and s is determined to be 0.1230.0090.005 at ssSMZ (at the SLAC Linear Collider) and 0.1490.0020.007 at ss=29 GeV (at the SLAC storage ring PEP). The running of s between these two center-of-mass energies is consistent with the QCD prediction. © 1990 The American Physical Society.

Title: Application of photoacoustic spectroscopy in photosynthesis research
Affiliations: Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: N'Soukpoé-Kossi, C.N., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Leblanc, R.M., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Abstract: Photoacoustic spectroscopy is a new analytical technique which allows the detection of light-induced heat production due to non-radiative deactivation of light excitation. This paper gives an overview of the theory of photoacoustics and its application in photosynthesis research to measure energy conversion and storage, and for molecular structure and interaction studies as well as oxygen evolution in photosynthetic systems. © 1990.

Abstract: The reaction e+e-e+e-00 has been analyzed using 97 pb-1 of data taken with the Crystal Ball detector at the DESY e-e+ storage ring DORIS II at beam energies around 5.3 GeV. For the first time we have measured the cross section for 00 for 00 mvariant masses ranging from threshold to about 2 GeV. We measure an approximately flat cross section of about 10 nb for W=m00<0.8 GeV, which is below 0.6 GeV, in good agreement with a theoretical prediction based on an unitarized Born-term model. At higher invariant masses we observe formation of the f2(1270) resonance and a hint of the f0(975). We deduce the following two-photon widths: f2(1270))=3.19±0.16±0.280.29 keV and (f0(975))<0.53 keV at 90% C.L. The decay-angular distributions show the 00 system to be dominantly spin 0 for W<0.7 GeV and spin 2, helicity 2 in the f2(1270) region, with helicity 0 contributing at most 22% (90% C.L.). © 1990 The American Physical Society.

Title: Frequency based localisation of structural discrepancies
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Modal Analysis and Control Laboratory, University of Lowell, Lowell, MA 01854, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shepard, G.D., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Modal Analysis and Control Laboratory, University of Lowell, Lowell, MA 01854, United States; Milani, J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Modal Analysis and Control Laboratory, University of Lowell, Lowell, MA 01854, United States
Abstract: The intent of modal analysis is to develop a reliable model of a structure by working with the analytical and experimental modal properties of frequency, damping and mode shape. In addition to identifying these modal properties it would be desirable to determine spatially which parts of the structure are modeled poorly or well. This information could be used to improve the finite element model, or to point to faults in the structure and hence help to evaluate mechanical integrity. This paper shows how the pattern of discrepancies in the pole and the driving point zero frequencies of a structure can be linked to discrepancies in the mass or stiffness of the structural elements. Only nominal mode shapes, as opposed to mode shape discrepancies, are required. Because first-order errors in mode shape cause only second-order localisation errors, the nominal mode shapes need not be measured, but can be taken from a finite element model. The success of this procedure depends on the numerical conditioning of a modal reference matrix. Strategies to ensure adequate numerical conditioning require a formulation which avoids geometric and energy storage symmetries of the structure, and ignores structural elements which contribute negligibly small potential or kinetic energy to the excited modes. Physical insight into the numerical conditioning problem is provided by a numerical example and by the localisation of a mass discrepancy in a real structure based on laboratory tests. © 1990.

Authors: Rivera J.F., Galdeano C.A., Vargas A.
Title: Some numerical criteria to measure the validity of hydro-aggregation in hydrothermal systems
Source title: International Journal of Electrical Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Instituto de Energía Eléctrica, Universidad Nacional de San Juan, Av. Libertador San Martin, 1109 (0), 5400 San Juan, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Rivera, J.F., Instituto de Energía Eléctrica, Universidad Nacional de San Juan, Av. Libertador San Martin, 1109 (0), 5400 San Juan, Argentina; Galdeano, C.A., Instituto de Energía Eléctrica, Universidad Nacional de San Juan, Av. Libertador San Martin, 1109 (0), 5400 San Juan, Argentina; Vargas, A., Instituto de Energía Eléctrica, Universidad Nacional de San Juan, Av. Libertador San Martin, 1109 (0), 5400 San Juan, Argentina
Abstract: A methodology and algorithms for the systematic research of the effect of simplifications on the mathematical modelling for the optimal annual operation planning of hydrothermal systems are discussed. The effect of simplifications in the case of hydro-system aggregation has been particularly studied. The methodology and computational algorithms are based on a scheme of successive optimizations using the dynamic programming method combined with an 'adaptive searching' method and elaborate packed storage techniques for sparse variables. The results are presented in the form of graphs of errors caused by simplifications in the modelling to calculate optimal operation programs based on requirements related to the use of a less elaborate data base and reduced main storage and processing time. © 1990.
Author Keywords: digital model; long-term scheduling; modelling of energy systems

Authors: Al-Kayssi A.W., Al-Karaghouli A.A., Hasson A.M., Beker S.A.
Title: Influence of soil moisture content on soil temperature and heat storage under greenhouse conditions
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Centre, Jadiriyah P.O. Box 13026, Baghdad, Iraq
Authors with affiliations: Al-Kayssi, A.W., Solar Energy Research Centre, Jadiriyah P.O. Box 13026, Baghdad, Iraq; Al-Karaghouli, A.A.; Hasson, A.M.; Beker, S.A.
Abstract: The effect of increasing soil moisture content on soil temperature, soil reflectance and soil heat storage is studied in this work. The results show that an increase in moisture content decreases the soil temperature differences between day-time and night-time, which provides protection to the plant root system against sharp and sudden changes of soil temperature. It is also found that the solar energy absorption increases as the moisture content increases, which results in a higher heat storage capacity at higher moisture content. Finally, plant growth rate and yield increased due to the modification of plant climate at higher moisture content. © 1990 The British Society for Research in Agricultural Engineering.

Title: Separation of liquid from vapour upon pressure relief
Source title: Journal of Loss Prevention in the Process Industries
Affiliations: Technische Universitat Munchen, Munchen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Muschelknautz, S., Technische Universitat Munchen, Munchen, Germany; Mayinger, F., Technische Universitat Munchen, Munchen, Germany
Abstract: When a chemical reactor is depressurized, or when the pressure within a vessel filled with saturated liquid has to be decreased, both vapour and liquid generally come out of the relief valve. Chemical reactors are often operated with toxic or explosive fluids, and the discharged liquid vaporizing on the ground around the vessel may reach dangerous concentrations, causing explosions or accidents with poison gas. This paper describes work on designing systems to separate the liquid from the vapour for storage in a collecting vessel. The requirement for a separation rate of at least 80% was balanced against the need for the separated liquid flow back into the reactor during the pressure relief phase. For safety reasons, separation as well as re-storage had to be carried out without using external energy. Theoretical and experimental investigations of the pressure distribution within the tube to the relief valve and an integrated separator showed that the demand for re-storage of the separated liquid within the vessel could be satisfied under certain flow conditions. Therefore, the separator had to be integrated in the pipe at a certain height above the vessel, so that the hydrostatic pressure of the separated liquid was sufficient to lead it back through another pipe against the internal pressure of the vessel. First, several separators were tested with air-water mixtures, and a twist separator and a reversing separator were developed. Experimental results with air-water mixtures and refrigerant R12 upon pressure relief showed separation rates of 90–100% with low pressure loss within the whole working range. As an alternative to separation outside the vessel, a rotary separator fixed to the vessel outlet opening was developed. A centrifugal field is produced by the separator rotor and the heavier liquid is separated from the vapour, so that only drops of size 100 μm flow with the vapour towards the central standpipe. The vapour flowing out in this way leaves the separator via four tangentially arranged nozzles under critical flow conditions. The vapour flow momentum powers the separator rotor. The arrangement was developed and tested experimentally under pressure relief conditions using the refrigerant R12. Separation rates of 69–95% were achieved at rotation speeds up to 2000 rpm. © 1990, All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: loss prevention; pressure system design; relief devices

Authors: Klaassens J.B., van Wesenbeeck M.P.N., Lauw H.K.
Title: Source-sided power flow control of a single-phase AC-to-DC series-resonant power supply
Affiliations: Delft University of Technology, P.O. Box 5031, Delft, Netherlands; Oregon State University, Corvallis, 97 222, Oregon, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klaassens, J.B., Delft University of Technology, P.O. Box 5031, Delft, Netherlands; van Wesenbeeck, M.P.N., Delft University of Technology, P.O. Box 5031, Delft, Netherlands; Lauw, H.K., Oregon State University, Corvallis, 97 222, Oregon, United States
Abstract: The objective of an AC-to-DC converter is to control the output waveform. The energy emanated from the source is adapted by passive filters, which is often a compromise between volume and effective use. A classical rectifierfilter network presents a major disadvantage: a power factor less than one which is caused by distortion of the source current. The resolution of the high-frequency input current of the series-resonant converter introduces the possibility of controlling the waveform of the source current accurately. In combination with the accurate positioning of the high-frequency current pulses, it is possible to influence the exchange of power with the source by the introduced method of active filtering. A power factor equal to one would lead to an optimal operation. The method introduced can select any value for the power factor, even for distorted voltage waveforms. However the zero-crossing of the AC source voltage introduces the necessity of storing energy. Bulky low-frequency storage elements increase the specific volume and weight of the converter while the exchange of energy with storage elements decreases the overall efficiency. The energy stored in the resonant circuit is fundamentally too low to solve this problem. The stored energy in the output capacitor, necessary to decrease the high-frequency ripple voltage, is available for these purposes. To meet the optimal conditions for the power factor at the source, a bipolar flow of energy is required. The theory of single-phase AC-to-DC series-resonant power conversion with controllable reactive power is explained. The results of simulation and experiment will establish the extensive possibilities of the proposed systems. © 1990 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Physics of ball lightning
Affiliations: Institute of High Temperatures, Academy of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Smirnov, B.M., Institute of High Temperatures, Academy of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Abstract: The present state of the ball-lightning problem is analyzed. Observational data on ball lightning are reviewed and analyzed. Analogs of ball lightning in terms of properties are discussed. Basic characteristics of ball lightning are identified. They include a rigid framework, a chemical method of internal energy storage, and a spotty emission structure. The spottiness results from the existence of a large number of small hot zones which are responsible for the emission. Problems to be resolved are pointed out. Some models which might be of assistance here are described. © 1990 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Depolarization current of a novolac p‐fluorophenol‐formaldehyde resin
Affiliations: Laboratory for Solid State Chemistry, Ruder Boškovic Institute, POB 1016, Zagreb, 41001; Chemical Research Centre, Zagreb, 41000
Authors with affiliations: Topić, M., Laboratory for Solid State Chemistry, Ruder Boškovic Institute, POB 1016, Zagreb, 41001; Katović, Z., Chemical Research Centre, Zagreb, 41000
Abstract: A Novolac p‐fluorophenol‐formaldehyde (NFF) resin was prepared by condensation of p‐fluorophenol with formaldehyde. DSC showed the glass transition effect or coinciding endothermal peak depending upon the thermal history of samples. It is supposed that the peaks are caused by breaking of the intermolecular bondings in the resin during the glass transition. The bondings are formed in the resin during the storage at room temperature. Thermally stimulated depolarization current (TSDC) measurements were carried out in the temperature range of 290 to 350 K, with the samples having an average number molecular weight M̄n of 375 and 434. TSDC curves mainly showed the dipolar relaxation α peaks. The influence of poling temperatures, the influence of M̄n, the activation energy Ea, and the physical ageing of the samples were investigated. Physical ageing was determined as the reciprocal polarizability Rp vs. time of ageing. Samples. with higher M̄n showed a higher glass transition temperature, a lower Ea, and a higher increase in Rp than the sample with lower M̄n. The increase in M̄n increased the rigidness of NFF samples. The effects are attributed to the strong hydrogen bonding. The comparison with analogous results in novolac phenol‐formaldehyde resin without fluorine is given. © 1990 Hüthig & Wepf Verlag, Basel

Ishizuka, T., Saitama University, Urawa 338, Japan; Ohta, K., Saitama University, Urawa 338, Japan
Abstract: We present the charged-particle multiplicity distributions for e+e- annihilation at center-of-mass energies from 50 to 61.4 GeV. The results are based on a data sample corresponding to a total integrated luminosity of 30 pb-1 obtained with the AMY detector at the KEK storage ring TRISTAN. The charged-particle multiplicity distributions deviate significantly from the modified Poisson and pair Poisson distributions, but follow Koba-Nielsen-Olesen scaling and are well reproduced by the LUND parton-shower model. © 1990 The American Physical Society.

Title: Climate, population viability, and the zoogeography of temperate fishes
Source title: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society
Affiliations: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources, Research Section, Fisheries Branch, Post Office Box 5000, Maple, ON, L6A 1S9, Canada; Center for Limnology, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shuter, A.J., Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources, Research Section, Fisheries Branch, Post Office Box 5000, Maple, ON, L6A 1S9, Canada; Post, J.R., Center for Limnology, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706, United States
Abstract: The feeding activity of warm- and coolwater fishes can be severely restricted during the long period of cold temperatures characteristic of winter in temperate zone lakes and rivers. The effect of such restriction is greater for smaller fish. Weight-specific basal metabolism increases as size decreases; however, there is no corresponding increase in energy storage capacity. Thus, smaller fish tend to be less tolerant of starvation conditions because they exhaust their energy stores sooner. Such size dependence of starvation endurance has often been observed in laboratory experiments. In wild populations commonly subject to winter starvation, population viability hinges on the ability of young of year to complete a minimum amount of growth during their first year of life. From south to north, this ability is increasingly restricted as the growing season shortens and the starvation period lengthens. We show that this constraint is sufficient to explain the present locations of the northern distributional limit for yellow perch Perca flavescens in central and western North America, the northern distributional limit for Eurasian perch P. fluviatilis in Eurasia, and the northern distributional limit for smallmouth bass Micropterus dolomieui in central North America. We also forecast how shifts in North American climate may relax this constraint and permit both yellow perch and smallmouth bass to thrive well to the north of their present distributions. © 1990 by the American fisheries society.

Authors: Cahill P.A., Anderson R.A., Riley M.E.
Title: Antiproton storage materials: Response of neon, argon, and benzene to a negative particle
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cahill, P.A., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Anderson, R.A., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Riley, M.E., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States
Abstract: The energies of systems composed of a point negative charge (e.g., antiproton, p, or negative muon, -) and an atom or small molecule (He,Ne,Ar,C6H6) have been calculated using large-basis-set, correlated ab initio electronic-structure methods. By invoking the Born-Oppenheimer approximation, these energies are used to generate potential surfaces for the interaction of a negative particle with an atom or small molecule. The results indicate that the particle-induced polarizations are significant even at 10-bohr separations in neon. Unusual behavior of the dipole moments of both argon and neon was calculated to occur as a function of separation. The molecular-orbital approach used here may also be useful in analyzing recent ionization behavior in low-energy pinert-gas scattering experiments. Furthermore, the calculated large degree of polarization further constrains the design of materials for long-term normal matter storage of antiprotons for advanced energy sources. © 1990 The American Physical Society.

Yellin, S.J., University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106; Yost, G.P., University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720; Zapalac, G., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94309; Zeitlin, C., University of California, Davis, CA 95616
Abstract: We present a measurement of the total cross section for hadrons, with one photon quasireal and the other a spacelike photon of mass squared -Q2. Results are presented as a function of Q2 and the center-of-mass energy W, with the Q2 range extending from 0.2 to 60 GeV2, and W in the range from 2 to 10 GeV. The data were taken with the TPC/Two-Gamma facility at the SLAC e+e- storage ring PEP, which was operated at a beam energy of 14.5 GeV. The cross section exhibits a gentle falloff with increasing W. Its Q2 dependence is shown to be well described by an incoherent sum of vector-meson and pointlike scattering over most of the observed W range. Agreement at high Q2 is improved if a minimum-pT cutoff (motivated by QCD) is imposed on the pointlike contribution. © 1990 The American Physical Society.

Title: Thermal hologram fixing in pure and doped KNbO3 crystals
Source title: Journal of the Optical Society of America B: Optical Physics
Affiliations: Institute of Quantum Electronics, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, ETH Hönggerberg, Zürich, CH-8093, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Montemezzani, G., Institute of Quantum Electronics, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, ETH Hönggerberg, Zürich, CH-8093, Switzerland; Günter, P., Institute of Quantum Electronics, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, ETH Hönggerberg, Zürich, CH-8093, Switzerland
Abstract: We demonstrate holographic fixing by means of a thermal cycling procedure in pure and doped photorefractive KNbO3 crystals. At elevated temperatures (70-100°C) the photoinduced grating is compensated for by a secondary grating that is formed by charge carriers whose thermal activation energy is -1.0 eV The secondary carriers are stable at room temperature and form the fixed grating after cooling the crystal. They are believed to be represented by ions or ion vacancies. By using our fixing mechanisms the holographic storage time in KNbO3 can be increased by a factor of 106. © 1990 Optical Society of America.

Title: Photoacoustic study of the photochemical energy conversion in Epilobium plants grown under very low light conditions
Affiliations: Université Libre de Bruxelles, Laboratoire de Physiologie végétale (CP 169), 28 avenue P. Heger, B-1050 Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Havaux, M., Université Libre de Bruxelles, Laboratoire de Physiologie végétale (CP 169), 28 avenue P. Heger, B-1050 Brussels, Belgium
Abstract: Epilobium ciliatum plants were grown under extreme shade conditions (ca 20 μmol m-2 sec-1). The photosynthetic characteristics of these low-light-grown (LL) leaves were measured using the photoacoustic technique and were compared to those of control (HL) leaves grown at a higher (5x) photon flux density (100 μmol m-2 sec-1). Adaptation to very low light was not associated with a significant change in the maximal efficiency of photochemical energy storage (value extrapolated to the zero photon density) which was around 16% in both types of leaves. The most salient characteristic of LL leaves was the very rapid saturation of the photochemistry with increasing light irradiance. This latter effect was particularly pronounced when photochemical energy storage was measured at modulation frequencies of between 450 and 600 Hz, suggesting that the rate-limiting step responsible for the rapid light-saturation of the photosynthetic electron flux in LL leaves had a time constant decay of about 3000 sec-1. The high-frequency data were confirmed by photoacoustic measurements of oxygen evolution at low modulation frequencies, which indicated that the reduction of the relative quantum yield of oxygen evolution Φ with increasing photon flux densities was considerably faster in shade-adapted adapted leaves than in control leaves. When compared to HL leaves, LL leaves had a lower Φ except, however, at very low photon flux densities (below about 10-15 μmol m-2 sec-1), where Φ drastically decreased in control Epilobium leaves ("low light state") but not in LL leaves. The preservation of a high oxygen yield at low photon flux densities could partially explain the ability of Epilobium ciliatum to grow under extreme shade conditions. © 1989.

Authors: Kikuchi H., Watanabe T., Honda T., Kanzawa A.
Title: Effect of Phase Change Material(PCM) m.p. Distribution on Latent Heat Storage
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. Eng., Tokyo Inst. of Tech., Tokyo 152, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kikuchi, H., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Tokyo Inst. of Tech., Tokyo 152, Japan; Watanabe, T., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Tokyo Inst. of Tech., Tokyo 152, Japan; Honda, T., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Tokyo Inst. of Tech., Tokyo 152, Japan; Kanzawa, A., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Tokyo Inst. of Tech., Tokyo 152, Japan
Abstract: Charge and discharge heat transfer rates were investigated by using a latent heat storage reservoir with sloped distribution of m.p. The heat storage reservoir consisted of 45 vertical cylindrical capsules. The heat transfer fluid was air and paraffin wax within the capsules was the phase change material (PCM). Melting and solidification time of the PCM were measured for three kinds of m.p. distributions. The charge and discharge heat transfer rates were estimated from the melting and solidification time respectively. Numerical results agreed with the experimental results. For the PCM with constant m.p. the charge and discharge heat transfer rates decreased downstream from the air inlet of the reservoir. The charge and discharge heat transfer rates increased by sloping m.p. distribution. The analytical investigation showed that m.p. distribution with too large or too small slope was not suitable. © 1990, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Heat Transfer; Latent Heat; PCM; Thermal Energy Storage
Index Keywords: Air; Heat storage; Latent heat; Melting; Phase change materials; Pulse code modulation; Solidification; Storage (materials); Thermal energy; Analytical investigations; Charge and discharge; Heat transfer rate; Melting and solidification; Numerical results; Storage reservoirs; Heat transfer

Abstract: The first successful laser cooling of ions at relativistic energies was observed at the Heidelberg TSR storage ring. A Li+7-ion beam of 13.3 MeV was oberlapped with resonant copropagating and counterpropagating laser beams. The metastable ions were cooled from 260 K to a longitudinal temperature of below 3 K and decelerated by several keV. The longitudinal velocity distribution was determined by a fluorescence method. After laser cooling a strongly enhanced narrow peak appeared in the Schottky noise spectrum in addition to the uncooled ion distribution. © 1990 The American Physical Society.

Title: A review of accelerators beyond 2000
Affiliations: CERN, CH-1211 Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, E.J.N., CERN, CH-1211 Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The development of the synchrotron, and later the storage ring, was based upon the electrical technology of the turn of this century aided by the microwave radar techniques of World War II. This method of acceleration seems to have reached its limit. Even superconductivity is not likely lead to devices which will satisfy physics needs into the 21st century. Unless a new principle for accelerating elementary particles is discovered soon, there is little hope high energy physics will continue to reach out to higher energies. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Title: Minimization of energy losses in fixed speed cyclic duty induction motor drives
Source title: 1st International Conference on Applications of Industrial Electronics Systems, AIES 1990 - Proceedings
Affiliations: STS International, P.O. Box 301, Getzville, NY  14068, United States
Authors with affiliations: Safiuddin, M., STS International, P.O. Box 301, Getzville, NY  14068, United States
Abstract: The concept of power factor control, for energy conservation, by reducing the voltage applied to an unloaded or lightly loaded induction motor was first introduced in late seventies by Frank J. Sola of NASA. Since then a number of Products employing phase controlled thyristors for the control of applied voltage with closed-loop power factor regulation have been marketed under various brand names by a number of manufacturers. Further refinements in load and power factor sensing as well as control circuit hardware have been either claimed through patents by Sola and others or reported in the technical literature. Analytical studies of three phase induction motors operating from phase controlled thyristors in the stator circuits have also been well documented. Study of all of these references raises some very interesting questions such as: Do the power factor controllers really improve the system power factor as product manufacturers lead one to believe? Is it really necessary to regulate power factor to minimize no load losses by voltage control? Analysis and experimental data indicate that while the operating power factor of the motor does improve by voltage reduction by phasecontrolled thyristors in the stator circuit, the overall system power factor at the input to the controller does not change. Analytical explanation of this phenomena using circle diagrams and phasor relationships as well as experimental results are presented in this paper. A new controller design based on this research and development effort is introduced. © 1990 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Controllers; Digital storage; Electric drives; Electric power factor; Energy dissipation; Induction motors; Industrial electronics; Manufacture; NASA; Power control; Stators; Thyristors; Analytical studies; Induction motor drive; Power factor control; Power factor regulations; Product manufacturers; Research and development; Technical literature; Three phase induction motor; Electric machine control

Authors: Ueda S., Matsumoto M., Kobari T., Ikeguchi T., Kobayashi M., Hori Y.
Title: Photodesorption from stainless steel, aluminum alloy and oxygen free copper test chambers
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Research Laboratory, Hitachi Ltd, Kandastu-machi, Tsuchiura-shi, Ibaraki, 300, Japan; Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ueda, S., Mechanical Engineering Research Laboratory, Hitachi Ltd, Kandastu-machi, Tsuchiura-shi, Ibaraki, 300, Japan; Matsumoto, M., Mechanical Engineering Research Laboratory, Hitachi Ltd, Kandastu-machi, Tsuchiura-shi, Ibaraki, 300, Japan; Kobari, T., Mechanical Engineering Research Laboratory, Hitachi Ltd, Kandastu-machi, Tsuchiura-shi, Ibaraki, 300, Japan; Ikeguchi, T., Mechanical Engineering Research Laboratory, Hitachi Ltd, Kandastu-machi, Tsuchiura-shi, Ibaraki, 300, Japan; Kobayashi, M., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Hori, Y., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: Photodesorption yields due to synchrotron radiation (SR) from type 316 stainless steel, type A6063 aluminum alloy and high purity oxygen free copper (ASTM Class-1 OFC) test chambers were measured. SR with critical energy of 4 KeV from the 2.5 GeV storage ring of the Photon Factory at KEK was used. The photon beam size is 0.385 mrad in both vertical and horizontal directions. Seven test chambers which have the same shape were tested. The yields of OFC finished with machining is reduced to 9 × 10-6 molecules photon-1 (N2 equivalent) which is the lowest value throughout the experiments. Stainless steel treated with electrolytic polishing and 48h prebaking at 450°C shows the second lowest yield. The yield of aluminum alloy is somewhat higher than the others. The yields for other gas species were also measured. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Gases--Desorption; Metals and Alloys--Degassing; Photons--Effects; Synchrotron Radiation--Effects; Electron Storage Rings; Photodesorption Yields; Photon-Stimulated Desorption; Storage Ring Metal Outgassing; Accelerators

Authors: Rabus H., Arvanitis D., Domke M., Puschmann A., Wenzel L., Kaindl G., Baberschke K., Comelli G.
Title: The Vibrational Fine Structure of Chemisorbed C2H4 Molecules in the (1s-1, π*) State
Affiliations: Institut für Experimentalphysik, Freie Universität, Berlin, Germany; Sincrotrone Trieste, Padriciano 99, Trieste, I-34012, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Rabus, H., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Freie Universität, Berlin, Germany; Arvanitis, D., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Freie Universität, Berlin, Germany; Domke, M., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Freie Universität, Berlin, Germany; Puschmann, A., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Freie Universität, Berlin, Germany; Wenzel, L., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Freie Universität, Berlin, Germany; Kaindl, G., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Freie Universität, Berlin, Germany; Baberschke, K., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Freie Universität, Berlin, Germany; Comelli, G., Sincrotrone Trieste, Padriciano 99, Trieste, I-34012, Italy
Abstract: The fine structure of C2H4 molecules in the (1s-1, π*) state is resolved using a plane grating ellipsoidal mirror grazing incidence monochromator at the storage ring BESSY. Two vibrational series can be identified, assigned to C-C and C-H vibrations. The natural line width of the (1s-1, π*) state was found to be 160 meV for condensed C2H4 multilayers. For submonolayers of C2H4 molecules on Ag(100) and Cu(100) this value was found to increase to 280 and 700 meV respectively. A shift to lower energies of the ground state transition is observed for the adsorbed molecules with respect to the multilayer case. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Authors: Koshizuka S., Oka Y., Kondo S.
Title: Boundary-Fitted Coordinate Method for Incompressible Flow Using Riemann Geometry
Source title: Nippon Genshiryoku Gakkaishi/Journal of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan
Affiliations: Nucl. Eng. Res. Lab., Fac. of Eng., Univ. of Tokyo, Japan; Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Fac. of Eng., Univ. of Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Koshizuka, S., Nucl. Eng. Res. Lab., Fac. of Eng., Univ. of Tokyo, Japan; Oka, Y., Nucl. Eng. Res. Lab., Fac. of Eng., Univ. of Tokyo, Japan; Kondo, S., Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Fac. of Eng., Univ. of Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Boundary-fitted coordinate (BFC) method is useful for a complex geometry compared with the usual finite difference method (FDM), in which only rectangular grid can be used. Though many BFC methods have been proposed for incompressible flow, which often appears in nuclear power plants, the researches have not yet been converged at present. An algorithm in marker- and-cell (MAC) method has been widely used in the usual FDM. In this study, therefore, we develop the MAC method to a BFC method. The governing equations are written by use of Riemann geometry, and new additional terms emerging in the equations are discussed. Contra-variant physical components are employed as variables and compared with contravariant nonphysical components. We investigate the influence of the boundary-fitted grids in contrast to the rectangular grids using a natural convection problem in a cavity possessing a slant wall and curved backward-facing step flow. Computational storage and time for the BFC method are also investigated. © 1990, Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: backward-facing step; boundary-fitted coordinate method; cavity; contravariant physical component; incompressible flow; natural convection problem; Riemann geometry

Authors: Babusci D., Casano L., D'Angelo A., Picozza P., Schaerf C., Girolami B.
