Title: Single-tube integrated collector storage systems with transparent insulation and involute reflector
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Oltmannsstraße 22, 7800 Freiburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schmidt, C., Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Oltmannsstraße 22, 7800 Freiburg, Germany; Goetzberger, A., Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Oltmannsstraße 22, 7800 Freiburg, Germany
Abstract: Integrated collector storage (ICS) systems, consisting of a pressure-resistant single tube absorber in front of an involute reflector and covered by highly transparent insulation material, have been developed. Compared to the earlier multiple-tube design the system performance has been improved. For an absorber area of 4.2 m2 in Freiburg (W. Germany) and a hot water demand of 160 liters/day, the annual solar fraction of the system is 65% with an annual efficiency of 32% (required hot water temperature is 45°C). There is no risk of freezing. Detailed computer simulations for the ICS and the back-up heating system have been made and show the influence of various parameters on the system performance. Compared to conventional solar domestic hot water systems the performance of the ICS systems is almost as good as that of systems with vacuum tube collectors but ICS systems require much less complicated technology. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Data Processing - Data Acquisition; Meteorology - Weather Forecasting; Solar Energy - Energy Storage; Integrated Collector Storage Systems; Involute Reflector; Single Tube Absorber; Solar Radiation

Authors: Lanyin S., Fangjie L., Deyou B.
Title: An advanced TiFe series hydrogen storage material with high hydrogen capacity and easily activated properties
Affiliations: General Research Institute for Non-Ferrous Metals, 2 Xinjiekouwai Dajie, Beijing, 100088, China
Authors with affiliations: Lanyin, S., General Research Institute for Non-Ferrous Metals, 2 Xinjiekouwai Dajie, Beijing, 100088, China; Fangjie, L., General Research Institute for Non-Ferrous Metals, 2 Xinjiekouwai Dajie, Beijing, 100088, China; Deyou, B., General Research Institute for Non-Ferrous Metals, 2 Xinjiekouwai Dajie, Beijing, 100088, China
Abstract: After carefully adjusting the composition of the TiFe Series hydrogen storage material, a quaternary substituted TiFe alloy was discovered and produced, with the composition of Ti1 + XFe1 - Y MnYMmZ (X = 0.01-0.09, Y = 0.1-0.2, Z = 0.002-0.028). The new alloy shows some special properties: it is very easily activated at room temperature without any heat treatment in 0.3-0.7 h; high hydrogen desorption capacity 2.05-2.15 wt%, and low hydrogen charge pressure only 2-2.5 MPa. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Hydrides - Energy Storage; Hydrogen Fuels; Titanium Iron Alloys - Physical Properties; Hydrogen Desorption Capacity; Incubation Time; Intermetallic Compounds; Hydrogen

Title: Energetically consistent bond graph models in electromechanical energy conversion
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Karnopp, D., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: Linear and rotary motors using permanent magnet field excitation can often be modeled using power-conservative gyrator elements based on the Lorentz force law and Faraday's voltage law. A common extension of such models using modulated gyrators is shown to be inconsistent with storage field models based on a stored energy state function. Although the modulated gyrator models have intuitive appeal and are useful in certain restricted circumstances, the storage field models are preferable energetically. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Electric Machinery - Exciters; Electromagnetic Field Theory; Bond Graphs; Coil Transducers; Electromagnetic Actuators; Energy Transduction; Gyrator Elements; Electromechanical Devices

Title: Economics of a solar‐assisted heating/cooling system for an aquatic centre in a tropical environment
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Miami, PO Box 248294, Coral Gables, Florida, 33124, United States
Authors with affiliations: Alkhamis, A.I., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Miami, PO Box 248294, Coral Gables, Florida, 33124, United States; Sherif, S.A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Miami, PO Box 248294, Coral Gables, Florida, 33124, United States
Abstract: The paper reports on a feasibility study of a solar‐powered heating/cooling system for a swimming pool/space combination in a tropical environment. The system employs an absorption chiller and a cooling tower to meet the locker‐room load. The heating is accomplished by employing hot water generated by heat exchange with the solar collector working fluid. Two thermal storage tanks are employed for the collector and domestic use. The absorption chiller utilizes hot water to regenerate the LiBr solution. The proposed system will enable the swimming season to be extended from 16 weeks to 52 weeks. The economic analysis is performed based on the life‐cycle‐cost method. The effects of discount rate, fuel prices, and the fuel inflation rate are discussed. The analysis shows, with the present level of fuel prices, that the solarassisted system is not economical enough over a life cycle of 10 years. The study presents different scenarios for which the solar‐assisted system is, however, economical. Copyright © 1990 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd
Author Keywords: Solar energy; Solar‐assisted cooling; Solar‐assisted heating
Index Keywords: Economics; Lithium Compounds; Solar Energy - Applications; Solar Radiation - Collectors; Life Cycle Costs; Lithium Bromide; Solar Heating; Swimming Pools

Authors: Bonizzoni G., Conte A., Gatto G., Gervasini G., Ghezzi F., Rigamonti M.
Title: Tritium storage plant based on a combination of St707 and St737 getter alloy beds for high field fusion machines
Affiliations: Istituto di Fisica del Plasma, Associazione CNR, ENEA, Via Bassini 15, 20133 Milano, Italy; Dipartimento di Fisica, Universita' degli Studi di Milano, Italy; Consorzio IGNITOR, Via Cuneo 21, 10100 Torino, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bonizzoni, G., Istituto di Fisica del Plasma, Associazione CNR, ENEA, Via Bassini 15, 20133 Milano, Italy; Conte, A., Istituto di Fisica del Plasma, Associazione CNR, ENEA, Via Bassini 15, 20133 Milano, Italy, Dipartimento di Fisica, Universita' degli Studi di Milano, Italy; Gatto, G., Istituto di Fisica del Plasma, Associazione CNR, ENEA, Via Bassini 15, 20133 Milano, Italy, Consorzio IGNITOR, Via Cuneo 21, 10100 Torino, Italy; Gervasini, G., Istituto di Fisica del Plasma, Associazione CNR, ENEA, Via Bassini 15, 20133 Milano, Italy; Ghezzi, F., Istituto di Fisica del Plasma, Associazione CNR, ENEA, Via Bassini 15, 20133 Milano, Italy; Rigamonti, M., Consorzio IGNITOR, Via Cuneo 21, 10100 Torino, Italy
Abstract: Thermonuclear fusion machines (which will be operated with D-T mixtures) should provide the tritium storage and supply systems with safety conditions. In order to prevent possible accidents, with a large release of tritium, it must be trapped in solid and reversible solution forms by absorption beds. Moreover, residual gaseous form tritium in the pipelines, and permeation through the primary containment system, must be minimized. For storage, transfer, injection and recovery, a suitable system can be designed which uses metallic getter beds. Reversible solid solutions by tritium sorption are formed with low residual partial pressure, and re-emission by heating at low temperatures, which results in the reduction of permeation. This work shows the possibility of the use of a combination of two ZrVFe getter beds with different alloy compositions as an alternative to the usual uranium beds. In particular, the characterization of the new St737 getter alloy is carried out. Advantages of the combination of the new getter with the well-known St707 getter alloy are presented. presented. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Energy--Thermonuclear Reactions; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion; Tritium--Storage; Vacuum Technology--Getters; Getter Alloy Beds; Permeation Reduction; Primary Containment System; Reversible Solid Solution; Tokamak Devices

Title: Space Power Systems Requirements and Issues: The Next Decade
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: Aerospace Power Division, Aero Propulsion and Power Laboratory, Wright Research and Development Center, Wright-Patterson AFB, Ohio 45433-6563, United States
Authors with affiliations: Massie, L.D., Aerospace Power Division, Aero Propulsion and Power Laboratory, Wright Research and Development Center, Wright-Patterson AFB, Ohio 45433-6563, United States
Abstract: This paper describes some of the more important space power technology issues, requirements and challenges as we enter the decade of the 1990's and provides an assessment of the impact of new component technology on the overall performance of space power systems. The paper emphasizes advanced component, subsystem and system technologies which will “make a difference” for the future in terms of the performance, reliability and survivability of next generation baseload and burst mode space power systems. The paper primarily addresses technology disciplines related to power sources (solar/nuclear and chemical), power conversion, energy storage, power conditioning/ distribution and control and waste heat acquisition, transport and rejection. For some of these technology disciplines, performance trends are developed which can be used as the basis for projecting future advanced power system performance. Performance capabilities for several different types of space power system for both baseload and burst mode applications are postulated based on evolving technology and point designs which incorporate projections of advanced component capabilities. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Electric Energy Storage; Electric Power Systems; Fuel Cells; Spacecraft - Power Supply; Multimegawatt Power Generation; Photovoltaic Technology; Regenerative Fuel Cells; Space Power Systems; Spacecraft Batteries; Solar Power Plants

Title: A new hybrid hydrogen/gasoline driven motor-car with a CO2 trap
Affiliations: Paul Scherrer Institute, CH-5232 Villingen PSI, Switzerland On leave for this work from the Paul Scherrer Institute and delegated to the Institute für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme of the University of Stuttgart, F.R.G.
Authors with affiliations: Seifritz, W., Paul Scherrer Institute, CH-5232 Villingen PSI, Switzerland On leave for this work from the Paul Scherrer Institute and delegated to the Institute für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme of the University of Stuttgart, F.R.G.
Abstract: A new hybrid hydrogen/gasoline-driven motor-car is proposed which is equipped with a CO2-trap and which exhibits an energy absorption ability in its storage systems (with respect to their masses) much larger than that of the best hydrogen car. The principal new idea is to use a MgH2-storage facility whose metallic atoms not only carry hydrogen atoms but, if it is decharged, also the carbon dioxide from the burned gasoline. Thus, the quality of the exhaust gases is the same as for a pure hydrogen fuelled car. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Automobile Engines - Exhaust Gases; Energy Storage; Gasoline - Research; Hydrogen Fuels - Research; Alternative Fuels; Carbon Dioxide Traps; Hybrid Motor-Cars; Manganese Hydrid torage; OTTO-Engines; Automotive Fuels

Title: Colloidal semiconductors as photocatalysts for solar energy conversion
Affiliations: Notre Dame Radiation Laboratory, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kamat, P.V., Notre Dame Radiation Laboratory, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States; Dimitrijević, N.M., Notre Dame Radiation Laboratory, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States
Abstract: Considerable attention has been drawn in recent years to develop ultrafine semiconductor particles which exhibit excellent photocatalytic properties. Size quantization effects, nonlinear optical properties and enhanced photoredox properties make quantized colloidal semiconductors potentially useful in the design of photoelectrochemical systems. Photochemical and photophysical processes that directly influence the photocatalytic properties of the semiconductor colloids and the factors that limit the charge transfer at the semiconductor/electrolyte interface are discussed here. Applications of semiconductor particulate systems in the conversion and storage of solar energy are also described. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Semiconductor Materials - Photovoltaic Effects; Solar Energy; Solar Radiation; Photocatalysts; Photoelectrochemical Systems; Photoelectrochemical Cells

Title: Freshwater floating-collector-type solar pond
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, 69978, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Sokolov, M., Faculty of Engineering, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, 69978, Israel; Arbel, A., Faculty of Engineering, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, 69978, Israel
Abstract: A new type of solar pond is introduced in an effort to provide an inexpensive, renewable heat source, mainly for space-heating purposes. The suggested freshwater solar pond is covered with floating collectors made of insulation boards and thin plastic sheets, and requires very little, if any, constructional work. Forced flow in the collector layer of the pond provides the reduction of the mean collector and pond temperatures and ensures high efficiency. The collectors also provide the necessary thermal and evaporation insulation so that freshwater may be used and the cumbersome and delicate task of salt-gradient maintenance is eliminated. Both simulation and experimental results are reported. A one-dimensional quasi-steady-state simple model is the basis for the simulation. The presented experimental data validate the simulations. Longterm performance characteristics as well as possible modes of seasonal storage utilization of such solar ponds are discussed. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer - Mathematical Models; Heating; Solar Energy; Freshwater Solar Pond; Solar Radiation

Authors: Gretz J., Baselt J.P., Ullmann O., Wendt H.
Title: The 100 MW euro-Quebec hydro-hydrogen pilot project
Affiliations: Joint Research Centre, 21020 Ispra, Varese, Italy; DECHEMA, Frankfurt, Germany; Ludwig-Bölkow-Stiftung, Ottobrunn, Germany; Technische Hochschule, Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gretz, J., Joint Research Centre, 21020 Ispra, Varese, Italy; Baselt, J.P., DECHEMA, Frankfurt, Germany; Ullmann, O., Ludwig-Bölkow-Stiftung, Ottobrunn, Germany; Wendt, H., Technische Hochschule, Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The concept of a hydrogen-based, clean, renewable energy system, conceived by the Joint Research Centre-Ispra of the Commission of the European Communities, is currently investigated by European industries and the JRC-Ispra. The scope of the investigation is to establish the main characteristics of system and components and to give a first indication of costs. The 100 pilot project is to demonstrate the provision of clean and renewable primary energy in the form of Canadian hydropower converted via electrolysis into hydrogen and shipped to Europe, where it is stored and used in different ways: electricity/heat cogeneration, vehicle and aviation propulsion and hydrogen enrichment of natural gas for use in industry and households. Three transport/storage modes are investigated: methylcyclohexane as energy carrier shipped in normal oil product carriers, ammonia shipped in special tankers and liquid hydrogen shipped in special LH2 ships and aeroplanes. First evaluations indicate costs of the electrolytic hydrogen, produced with hydropower at 2 Can, cents kWh-1, stored in a European port of 69 Dpfg Nm-3 for the methylcyclohexane mode, 57 Dpfg Nm-3 for the ammonia mode, 30 Dpfg Nm-3 for the LH2 mode by ship transportation and 77/68 Dpfg Nm-3 by air transportation. These averaged equivalent costs of 20 Dpfg kWh-1 (th) of clean, renewable and stored energy suggest competitivity within the not too distant future. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Electrolysis; Hydroelectric Power Plants; Hydrogen Fuels; Hydro Hydrogen Power Plant; Primary Energy; Vectorization; Hydrogen

Authors: Mitani Yasunori, Tsuji Kiichiro, Murakami Yoshishige, Hayashi Shigeaki, Tanaka Yuuko
Title: Stabilization of hydroelectric power system with long distance power transmission by using Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES)
Source title: Electrical Engineering in Japan (English translation of Denki Gakkai Ronbunshi)
Affiliations: Osaka Univ
Authors with affiliations: Mitani, Yasunori, Osaka Univ; Tsuji, Kiichiro, Osaka Univ; Murakami, Yoshishige, Osaka Univ; Hayashi, Shigeaki, Osaka Univ; Tanaka, Yuuko, Osaka Univ
Abstract: This paper analyzes a hydroelectric power system which collects electric power from many medium and small generators located along rivers. Finally, it transmits a large amount of electricity over a long distance to an area of customers. Thus, this system also implicitly possesses a problem of stability related to power swings which are described in the foregoing. This paper assumes a model system of hydroelectric power systems. The authors analyzed the instability phenomenon of the power swing and examined a stability control using a superconductor magnetic energy storage system (SMES).
Index Keywords: Electric power transmission; Superconducting Magnets - Applications; Long Distance Power Transmission; Power Swing Analysis; Stability Control System; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES); Hydroelectric power plants

Title: Performance simulation of the heat accumulator of the Abu Dhabi Solar Desalination Plant
Affiliations: Water and Electricity Department, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: El-Nashar, A.M., Water and Electricity Department, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates; Qamhiyeh, A.A., Water and Electricity Department, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The Solar Desalination Plant in Abu Dhabi has been in operation since September 1984 and has been running continuously since then. The plant has a capacity of 120 m3/d and uses seawater as the feed to a multieffect-stack (MES) distillation unit. The thermal energy requirement of this distiller is provided by a bank of evacuated-tube, flat-plate collectors having a total collector area of 1862 m2. The plant consists also of a heat-accumulator system which allows the solar energy collected during the day to be utilized at nighttime, thus allowing the plant to run continuously 24 hours per day. The heat accumulator is of the thermally stratified type and uses distilled water as the heat-storage medium. The temperature distribution inside this heat accumulator affects significantly the performance of the MES evaporator and its water production. To be able to predict accurately how this temperature distribution varies throughout the day remains a matter of importance to the designer of such solar desalination plant. Our main aim in this paper is to develop a one-dimensional, unsteady-state heat-transfer computer model and compare the results of this model with the actual temperature measurements taken at the solar plant. The model was developed in such a way as to take into consideration the different modes of operation of the heat accumulator, namely, charging, discharging, combined charging/discharging, and free cooling. A comparison between the calculated and measured temperature distributions indicates that the accuracy of the model is reasonably good. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Computers--Applications; Desalination; Solar Energy--Applications; Temperature Measurement; Flat-Plate Collectors; Heat Accumulator; Multieffect Stack; Performance Simulation; Solar Desalination Plant; Thermal Energy; Heat Transfer

Title: Anomalous valence and structural changes in intermetallic Ybx (FeCo)1-x films
Affiliations: Siemens AG, ZFE ME TPH 11, PO Box 3220, D-8520 Erlangen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Weller, D., Siemens AG, ZFE ME TPH 11, PO Box 3220, D-8520 Erlangen, Germany; Reim, W., Siemens AG, ZFE ME TPH 11, PO Box 3220, D-8520 Erlangen, Germany
Abstract: The 4f valence of Yb in ion beam sputtered Ybx(FeCo)1-x films (0 ≤ x ≤ 1) has been in situ examined using X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS). Structural and magnetic data of 200 nm thick films have been obtained ex situ with X-ray diffraction and Kerr hysteresis measurements, respectively. The interesting phenomenon of a 4f valence transition is observed on going from metallic Yb to intermetallic YbFeCo alloys and is clearly related to the crystallographic structure. Magnetic properties of the films show that the valence transition is a ground state property rather than a final state coupling effect in the photoemission process. No such phenomena could be observed in FeCo intermetallic alloys with Sm, Eu or Tm thus demonstrating the exceptional behavior of Yb. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Optical--Materials; Films--Spectroscopic Analysis; Intermetallics--Spectroscopic Analysis; Spectroscopy, X-ray; Sputtering; Binding Energies; Intermetallic Alloys; Kerr Hysteresis; X-ray Photoemission Spectroscopy (XPS); Ytterbium Compounds

Title: Thermal decay of an initially hot isothermal water body with application to thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Cape Coast, Cape Coast, Ghana; Department of Mathematics, Rivers State University of Science & Technology, Port Harcourt, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Adjepong, S.K., Department of Physics, University of Cape Coast, Cape Coast, Ghana; Bestman, A.R., Department of Mathematics, Rivers State University of Science & Technology, Port Harcourt, Nigeria
Abstract: The thermal decay of an initially hot isothermal water body contained in a tank was studied. Analytical solutions (including a group‐theoretic solution) were obtained for the one‐dimensional heat conduction equation with heat loss from the sides of the tank. The convective heat transfer coefficient was assumed not to be constant over the surface of the tank but to vary with space and time. A very good agreement was obtained between the group‐theoretic solution and a numerical solution using the Crank‐Nicholson finite difference scheme. The analytical results are discussed in terms of the underlying physical mechanisms. Copyright © 1990 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd
Author Keywords: Conduction; Decay; Energy; Isothermal; Nonconvective; Nonstratified; One‐dimensional; Profile; Storage; Water body
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Transfer - Liquids; Mathematical Techniques - Finite Difference Method; Water - Heat Transfer; Hot Water; Thermal Decay; Thermal Energy Storage; Solar Energy

Title: Mechanisms of disruption of the energy storage in magnetotail-like systems
Affiliations: Akademie der Wissenschaften der DDR, Zentralinsitut für Astrophysik, Potsdam-Babelsberg, 1591, G.D.R.; Space Research Institute, the Academy of Sciences, the U.S.S.R., Moscow, 117810, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Büchner, J., Akademie der Wissenschaften der DDR, Zentralinsitut für Astrophysik, Potsdam-Babelsberg, 1591, G.D.R.; Zelenyi, L.M., Space Research Institute, the Academy of Sciences, the U.S.S.R., Moscow, 117810, Russian Federation
Abstract: The solar wind interaction with magnetized celestial bodies creates metastable Earth - like magnetotails which store considerable amounts of energy. Observations indicate that this energy partially may be released, sometimes in correlation with changes in the solar wind and sometimes with a time - delay up to one hour. In this paper we will argue how both scenarios may be physically understood in terms of a reconnection instability of the magnetotail plasma, even without collisions or noise, due to Landau - damping, exclusively. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Solar Radiation; Magnetic Energy Conversion; Magnetotail Energy Storage; Magnetotail Plasma; Solar Wind Interaction; Astrophysics

Authors: Tam K.-S., Kumar P., Foreman M.
Title: Using SMES to support large-scale PV power generation
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tam, K.-S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States; Kumar, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States; Foreman, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Abstract: Due to environmental concerns and advance in solar technology, the potential for large-scale electric power generation by photovoltaics (PV) is promising. However, when the PV power generation level is high, the fluctuations and uncertainty of PV power would make the planning, operation, and control of a power system more difficult. This paper proposes and demonstrates that a superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) system can be used to overcome these difficulties and support large-scale use of PV power generation. Two system configurations for a PV/SMES hybrid system were described in this paper. In both cases, the SMES charging/discharging power is changed in response to PV fluctuations so that the combined PV/SMES power is smooth and controllable. With SMES support, large-scale use of PV power generation can be used in a power system without causing adverse effects. A coordinated PV/SMES scheme that is applicable for various weather conditions is presented in this paper. The combined PV/SMES power is dispatchable and is shown to have advantages over PV or SMES alone. PV arrays can be installed on the surface of the land occupied by an underground SMES system. With SMES support, all of the PV power can be utilized and no oversizing is needed. These benefits improve the economics of PV power generation. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Control Systems; Photovoltaic Cells; Photovoltaic Effects; Solar Energy--Applications; Daily Load Curve; Energy Storage Schemes; Large-Scale PV Power Generation; PV Generation Systems; PV/SMES Hybrid System; SMES; Power Generation

Title: Bond graph models for electrochemical energy storage : electrical, chemical and thermal effects
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Karnopp, D., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: Bond graph models for chemical kinetics are extended to electrochemical systems. Although many electrochemical systems can be considered to function in a constant temperature environment, high-power energy storage systems, such as electric vehicle batteries, undergo drastic changes in temperature in operation. Therefore the bond graph models are also extended to couple with thermal models driven by energy dissipation of a chemical or electrical nature. Electrochemical-thermal bond graph models are readily coupled to standard bond graph models for electrical and mechanical components of an overall system such as an electric vehicle. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary - Thermal Effects; Energy Storage - Mathematical Models; Storage Battery Vehicles - Performance; Bond Graph Models; Daniell Cells; Dissipation; Electrochemistry

Title: Second World Congress on Heating, Ventilating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning CLIMA 2000
Abstract: This issue contains 16 papers presented at the congress. The main topics discussed are: buildings and the building envelope; inside and outside environment; solar energy and heat storage; heat and mass transfer in HVAC components; HVAC and R systems; control and maintenance.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Energy resources; Flow of fluids; Heat transfer; Ventilation; Combined Environment; EIREV; Heat Storage; HVAC; Solar Energy; Buildings

Authors: Ecevit A., Chaikh Wais M.A.M., Al-Shariah A.M.
Title: A comparative evaluation of the performances of three built-in-storage-type solar water heaters
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Ecevit, A., Department of Physics, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey; Chaikh Wais, M.A.M., Department of Physics, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey; Al-Shariah, A.M., Department of Physics, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: Three built-in-storage-type solar water heaters of equal volume were tested under identical conditions for performance evaluation. One of these water heaters was rectangular and the other two were triangular. One of the triangular water heaters had a baffle plate and the other did not. The triangular water heater with baffle plate was found to be not superior to the rectangular one in efficiency during the heating period. However, it was more efficient during the cooling period. The triangular water heater without the baffle plate was found to be the most efficient one during both the heating and the cooling periods. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer; Solar Energy; Temperature Distribution; Temperature Profiles; Water Heaters

Title: Evaluation of reversible hydration reactions for use in thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tufts University, Medford, MA 02155, United States
Authors with affiliations: Selvidge, M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tufts University, Medford, MA 02155, United States; Miaoulis, I.N., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tufts University, Medford, MA 02155, United States
Abstract: Materials which can undergo reversible direct hydration and dehydration were investigated experimentally to determine the feasibility for use in thermal energy storage systems. The materials studied evolve heat during the hydration stage in the form of heat of adsorption or heat of solution. Heat is in turn required to dehydrate the materials. The study determined which materials can be repeatedly cycled without deteriorating their chemical structure. Initial experiments indicated that LiBr and a group of zeolites exhibited the highest thermal energy storage density (kJ/kg). These materials were further investigated to determine their thermal energy storage densities for different dehydration temperatures and times. Additional experiments were conducted to determine the optimum water/material hydration ratio, the water desorption, and the water diffusivity behavior. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Data Processing - Data Reduction and Analysis; Zeolites - Testing; Thermal Energy Storage; Water Diffusivity; Water/Material Hydration Ratio; Energy Storage

Title: Partial reduction of CO2-emissions of automobiles using metallic carbides as fuel
Affiliations: Paul Scherrer Institute, CH-5232 Villingen PSI, Switzerland On leave for this work from the Paul Scherrer Institute and delegated to the Institute für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme of the University of Stuttgart, F.R.G.
Authors with affiliations: Seifritz, W., Paul Scherrer Institute, CH-5232 Villingen PSI, Switzerland On leave for this work from the Paul Scherrer Institute and delegated to the Institute für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme of the University of Stuttgart, F.R.G.
Abstract: In order to avoid the installation of a large capacity of electricity producing power stations for the maintenance of hydrogen or hydrid-fuelled automobiles and battery powered automobiles, it is proposed to use carbides as the fuel. Instead of electricity, coal is then the main primary energy input. It is shown that the CO2-emission rates can be reduced substantially, in comparison with gasoline-fuelled automobiles, if the whole system is embedded in a general CO2-disposal strategy envisaged for a climate-neutral energy system for the future. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Automobile Engines - Exhaust Gases; Coal - Applications; Metallic Compounds - Energy Storage; Alternative Fuels; Carbon Dioxide Emissions; Metallic Carbides; OTTO-Engines; Automotive Fuels

Title: Laboratory experiments on behalf of the TNO-DGV test facility for aquifer thermal energy storage at Delft, The Netherlands
Source title: Proceedings & Information - Committee for Hydrological Research TNO
Authors with affiliations: Griffioen, J.
Abstract: For the heat storage cycle, no thermodynamic equlibrium with end-member carbonates was found after a reaction time of 44 hours at 90°C. Fast precipitation occurs as long as Fe remains in solution. Prolonged precipitation of Ca, eventually with Mg, appears inhibited by o-PO4 and organic acids. Desorption of K, NH4 and Fe upon temperature increase of the system, occurs initially. This buffering mechanism against precipitation of carbonate is not sufficient, because of the small CEC of the sediment in combination with the high hardness of the injected groundwater. Weathering of silicates leads to the release of Na, Ca and Mg. K and Si appear to be incorporated in secondary minerals. Reinjection of heated groundwater in a cold column does only induce desorption of Fe and Mn. -from Author
Index Keywords: aquifer thermal energy; hydrogeochemical process; precipitation; thermal energy storage; Delft; Netherlands

Authors: Meney K.A., Pate J.S., Dixon K.W.
Title: Phenology of growth and resource deployment in Alexgeorgea nitens (Nees) Johnson and Briggs (Restionaceae), a clonal species from South-western Western Australia
Affiliations: Kings Park and Botanic Garden, West Perth, WA, 6005, Australia; Department of Botany, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, WA, 6009, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Meney, K.A., Kings Park and Botanic Garden, West Perth, WA, 6005, Australia; Pate, J.S., Department of Botany, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, WA, 6009, Australia; Dixon, K.W., Kings Park and Botanic Garden, West Perth, WA, 6005, Australia
Abstract: Seasonal patterns are described for growth and partitioning of dry matter and selected nutrients between different age classes and types of plant organs of ramets of non-reproductive, presumed female clones of Alexgeorgea nitens in native sandplain habitat at Eneabba, south-western Western Australia. New rhizome extension and associated production of new culms and nodal roots are initiated following onset of rain in autumn. Rate of growth of these parts remains slow through winter, peaks in spring and early summer and then becomes much reduced in the hot, dry summer. The bulk (87%) of the season’s dry matter increment of new ramet parts is estimated to be derived from current photosynthesis, the remaining 13% by mobilisation of dry matter from older parts of the ramet, especially from 1- and 2-yearold culms. Growth of new organs is severely reduced by removal or shading of culms at the beginning of the season. Older culms and rhizomes carry substantial starch reserves, but mobilisation of this reserve accounts for 2% at most of the dry matter gain of new organs of intact ramets, 19% of that of shaded and 65% of detopped ramets. A substantial fraction of the starch pool of a rhizome segment normally remains until its senescence, possibly as a long-term energy reserve, utilisable after destruction of above-ground parts by fire or grazing. Concentrations of N, P, K, Ca and Mg in organ dry matter of A. nitens are generally very low in comparison with species other than those Cyperaceae or Restionaceae from similar habitats. There is no evidence of preferential storage in below-ground parts, and efficiencies of emptying of nutrient reserves from senescing ramet parts are not high. Mobilisation from older source organs of ramets of intact, unstressed clones is estimated to provide 14% of the new organ’s seasonal gain of P, 16% of Mg, 21% of Ca, 22% of N and 58% of K. Annual factorial increases of a ramet in the studied nutrient elements range from 1.3 (for K) to 2.4 (for P), indicating flexibility in exploiting sources of different nutrients as their respective availabilities change from season to season. © 1990, CSIRO. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: clonal plant; growth; phenology; Australia, Western Australia, Eneabba; Alexgeorgea nitens; Restionaceae

Title: Biogeochemical aspects of aquifer thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings & Information - Committee for Hydrological Research TNO
Authors with affiliations: Brons, H.J.; Zehnder, A.J.B.
Abstract: For the prediction of biogeochemical reactions an electron free energy diagram is presented involving microbially mediated redox reactions with organic carbon. In this respect the most important processes detrimental to aquifer thermal energy storage are iron precipitation and anaerobic metal corrosion by sulphate reducing bacteria. The factors that control the solution chemistry and the redox cycle of iron in aquifers are outlined. The generally accepted mechanism by which sulphate-reducers initiate ferrous metal corrosion is described and a remedial in situ treatment technique is proposed. -from Authors
Index Keywords: anaerobic corrosion; aquifer themal energy; biogeochemical reaction; iron precipitation; metal corrosion; microbial mediation; redox reaction; sulphate reducing bacteria; thermal energy storage

Title: The relation between aquifer thermal energy storage and hydrochemistry: an overview
Source title: Proceedings & Information - Committee for Hydrological Research TNO
Authors with affiliations: Dufour, F.C.
Abstract: The underground storage of energy in the Netherlands is focused on storage of thermal energy in aquifers. This applies for heat storage as well as for cold storage. In view of the fact that the hydrochemistry of the groundwater is more influenced by large temperature fluctuations than by small temperature fluctuations, the hydrochemical consequences are more dominant in the case of heat storage (ΔT=50-80°C) than in the case of cold storage (ΔT=5-10°C). Consequently, these proceedings are mainly dealing with heat storage in relation to hydrochemistry. -from Author
Index Keywords: aquifer thermal energy; groundwater chemistry; heat storage; hydrochemistry; thermal energy storage; Netherlands

Title: A joint project on the water use of a mallee community in late summer
Source title: The mallee lands. Proc. national mallee conference, Adelaide, 1989
Authors with affiliations: Walker, C.D.
Abstract: Evapotranspiration in a mallee community proceeded at rates of less than 0.8 mm d-1 in late summer. Evidence was gathered by a wide range of techniques. The value of modelling from meteorological data to estimate plant productivity is discussed. It seems likely that models would be improved by including plant responses such as cavitation and storage. Airborne measurements appear to be a valuable technique to study regional scales of energy fluxes. -Authors
Index Keywords: cavitation; energy fux; evapotranspiration; mallee scrub; plant; plant yield; water storage; water use efficiency

Title: Research on hydrochemistry and water treatment for heat storage in aquifers: state of the art
Source title: Proceedings & Information - Committee for Hydrological Research TNO
Authors with affiliations: Snijders, A.L.
Abstract: A coupled geochemical-transport model has been developed and basic research was conducted to the hydrochemical and microbial processes in the aquifer as a result of aquifer thermal energy storage. Furthermore, conventional water treatment methods to prevent precipitation were evaluated with respect to effectiveness and environmental effects. Eight techniques with little or no adverse environmental effects are identified for further testing. Some of these treatment methods are based on new concepts. -from Author
Index Keywords: aquifer thermal energy; hydrogeochemical process; precipitation; thermal energy storage; water treatment method

Title: Aquifer thermal energy storage: the importance of geochemical reactions
Source title: Proceedings & Information - Committee for Hydrological Research TNO
Authors with affiliations: Jenne, E.A.
Abstract: Precipitates result from oversaturation of the water with solid phases because of changing temperature, changing partial pressures of oxygen and/or carbon dioxide, and/or displacement of Ca from cation exchange sites. Precipitates are generally composed of CaCO3 (s) or Fe and Mn oxyhydroxides. As storage temperatures in excess of 100°C are used, the likelihood increases that silicate scale will form during heat extraction. The infiltration of surface water through river and lake sediments commonly results in an increase in dissolved Fe and Mn because first oxygen then Mn(IV) and Fe(III) oxides serve as the electron acceptors for the products of microbial respiration. Thus, near-surface aquifers often contain significant levels of dissolved Fe and Mn that precipitate when exposed to oxygen. -from Author
Index Keywords: aquifer thermal energy; geochemical reaction; iron; manganese; precipitate; silicate scale; thermal energy storage

Title: Technical and economic aspects of solar space heating in Turkey
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Taşdemiroǧlu, E., Mechanical Engineering Department, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey; Awad, M., Mechanical Engineering Department, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: A computer analysis of solar heating has been performed for Turkey. Results are presented for two prototype buildings using either fuel-oil or coal under different heating loads in three climatic regions (Antalya, Ankara and Kars). Cumulative cost flows are compared for the life-cycle present value technique. Optimum design magnitudes are determined for maximum life-cycle savings. The payback period for capital invested in a solar system, internal rate of return, and total savings are found for the optimum conditions. Variations of system performance are estimated. The effects of collector slope, proportionate storage tank volume, heat-exchanger parameters, and the design load on system performance are studied. Finally the economics of solar heating in Turkey are discussed and recommendations made for increased utilization of solar energy. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Energy Utilization - Economics; Heating - Solar; Collector Slope; Energy Demand Normalization; Prototype Buildings; Storage Unit; Unit Energy Cost; Energy Resources

Authors: Jentsch W., Hennig U., Wünsche J., Wittenburg H., Souffrant W.B.
Title: Methodological studies on the formation of CO2 and volatile fatty acids in porcine ileo-chyme and faeces.
Affiliations: Department of Animal Nutrition Oskar Kellner, Research Centre for Animal Production, Dummerstorf-Rostock., Germany
Authors with affiliations: Jentsch, W., Department of Animal Nutrition Oskar Kellner, Research Centre for Animal Production, Dummerstorf-Rostock., Germany; Hennig, U., Department of Animal Nutrition Oskar Kellner, Research Centre for Animal Production, Dummerstorf-Rostock., Germany; Wünsche, J., Department of Animal Nutrition Oskar Kellner, Research Centre for Animal Production, Dummerstorf-Rostock., Germany; Wittenburg, H., Department of Animal Nutrition Oskar Kellner, Research Centre for Animal Production, Dummerstorf-Rostock., Germany; Souffrant, W.B., Department of Animal Nutrition Oskar Kellner, Research Centre for Animal Production, Dummerstorf-Rostock., Germany
Abstract: As part of digestibility and energy metabolism studies in intact and ileorectostomized growing pigs model experiments were carried out on sampling techniques and the influence of storage conditions on CO2 and volatile fatty acid production in chyme. Results on the formation of CO2 and VFA in chyme and faeces are given. They indicate that chyme from the small intestine can be subjected to bacterial and enzymatic changes outside the animals and therefore must be stored in a cool place. In the chyme of IRA animals with closed colon descendens (end-to-end anastomosis) significantly reduced VFA contents were found in comparison to animals with open colon descendens (end-to-side anastomosis).
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide; volatile fatty acid; anastomosis; animal; article; bacterium; chemistry; digestion; energy metabolism; enzymology; feces; fermentation; ileum; metabolism; microbiology; preservation; rectum; stomach juice; swine; Anastomosis, Surgical; Animals; Bacteria; Carbon Dioxide; Digestion; Energy Metabolism; Fatty Acids, Volatile; Feces; Fermentation; Gastrointestinal Contents; Ileum; Preservation, Biological; Rectum; Swine

Title: An investigation of a latent heat storage porous bed and condensing flow through it
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vafai, K., Department of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States; Sözen, M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States
Abstract: In this work the transient analysis of the behavior of a packed bed of encapsulated phase change material (PCM) and the condensing flow through it is presented. The rigorous model used assumes no local thermal equilibrium between the bed particles and the working fluid, and incorporates the inertia effects in the momentum transport by the use of the Ergun-Forchheimer equation. Condensation in the working fluid is investigated. Thermal charging of the packed bed is analyzed and compared for a sensible heat storage material as well as for different latent heat storage materials (PCMs). © 1990 by ASME.
Author Keywords: Packed and fluidized beds; Phase-change phenomena; Thermal energy storage
Index Keywords: Flow of Fluids--Heat Transfer; Porous Materials--Heat Transfer; Vapors--Condensation; Ergun-Forchhmer Equation; Latent Heat Storage Materials; Latent Heat Storage Porous Bed; Phase Change Material (PCM); Heat Transfer

Title: Variable-Period Magnetostatic Undulator Designs Based on Iron-Free Current Configurations
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States; Center for X-Ray Optics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tatchyn, R., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States, Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States, Center for X-Ray Optics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Cremer, T., Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States
Abstract: The recent availability of high-energy storage rings (≥5 GeV) with long straight sections (≥20 m) for generating synchrotron radiation (SR) has provided a suitable context for initiating the development of weak-field insertion devices with relatively long periods. This, in turn, has led to the introduction of static-field undulators with variable periods, which are superior in many respects to conventional fixed-period undulators. In prior work, a segmented-wire electrostatic undulator with a widely variable period and the ability to produce arbitrarily polarized soft X-rays on the Stanford Positron Electron Project (PEP) has been introduced. In this paper, we develop the design of a magnetostatic analog of this device and derive the equations describing its performance. Based on this exercise, it is shown that other types of variable-period magnetostatic structures with significantly stronger fields could be implemented, and a specific design for a variable-period dipole configuration with the potential for generating moderate fields on medium-energy (2–4 GeV) storage rings is proposed. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Magnetostatics; Magnetostatic Undulators; Undulators; Magnetic Devices

Authors: Wilmet F., Ribet M., Bernier P., Girault Y., Elegant L.
Title: 13C NMR investigation of the solid-plastic phase transition in polyols and their mixtures
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Expérimentale, Université de NICE-SOPHIA ANTIPOLIS, Parc Valrose, 06034 NICE cedex, France; Groupe de Dynamique des Phases Condensées, Université des Sciences et Techniques du Languedoc, Place E. Bataillon, 34060 MONTPELLIER, France; Laboratoire de Chimie Physique Organique, Université de NICE-SOPHIA ANTIPOLIS, Parc Valrose, 06034 NICE cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Wilmet, F., Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Expérimentale, Université de NICE-SOPHIA ANTIPOLIS, Parc Valrose, 06034 NICE cedex, France; Ribet, M., Groupe de Dynamique des Phases Condensées, Université des Sciences et Techniques du Languedoc, Place E. Bataillon, 34060 MONTPELLIER, France; Bernier, P., Groupe de Dynamique des Phases Condensées, Université des Sciences et Techniques du Languedoc, Place E. Bataillon, 34060 MONTPELLIER, France; Girault, Y., Laboratoire de Chimie Physique Organique, Université de NICE-SOPHIA ANTIPOLIS, Parc Valrose, 06034 NICE cedex, France; Elegant, L., Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Expérimentale, Université de NICE-SOPHIA ANTIPOLIS, Parc Valrose, 06034 NICE cedex, France
Abstract: 2,2-dimethyl 1,3-propanediol (NPG) and 2-hydroxymethyl 2-methyl 1,3-propanediol (PG), polyols presenting reversible solid-plastic transition with interesting thermodynamic properties at relatively low temperature, are used for energy storage. By making homogeneous mixtures of these compounds, one expects to adjust the transtition temperature. The solid-plastic transition of these polyols and their mixtures in various proportions, determined by calorimetric measurements, are studied by 13C high resolution NMR. The spectra of the binary mixtures are the sum of the spectra of the components but their behaviour at the transition suggests that the transition mechanism of the mixtures is the same as those in the pure components. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Crystals--Phase Transitions; Molecular Crystals; Nuclear Magnetic Resonance; Solids--Physical Properties; Polyols; Solid-Plastic Phase Transitions; Plastics

Title: Optimization of thermal mass in commercial building applications
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Fleming Group, East Syracuse, NY, 13057, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, M.J., Fleming Group, East Syracuse, NY, 13057, United States
Abstract: Based on results from a one-year intensive monitoring project of a Northern New York commercial building with energy-conserving design features, a thermal storage project was undertaken to optimize the design of a thermal mass storage system for a moderately sized commercial building and transfer the technology to the commercial building sector. A generic commercial building design of 27, 000 square feet (2508 m2) was selected for the optimization project. Several different types of thermal mass designs were considered as potentially practical for a commercial building. These included a “sandmass” design such as the mass incorporated in the previously monitored commercial building mentioned above, a foundation slab of sufficient thickness to serve as a significant building thermal mass, and the use of poured cement in interior wall and floor construction. Five different office building thermal designs were selected which represented various thermal storage features and two different building insulation levels (R10 and R20). Energy performance of the five thermal designs was modeled in building energy simulations using DOE 2.1C (Department of Energy 2.1C) energy simulation code. Results of the simulotions showed a reduction in peak heating and cooling loads would be experienced by the HVAC equipment. The reduction in peak heating and cooling loads was anticipated because thermal mass within a building serves to average peak heating and cooling loads due to the capacity of the thermal mass to store and release heat from all building heat sources over a period of time. Peak heating loads varied from 1972 kBtuh (578 kW) for the R-10 light construction base case to a minimum of 980 kBtuh (287 kW) for the R-20 heavy construction sandmass storage case. Peak cooling loads dropped from 772 kBtuh (226 kW) for the R-20 light construction case to 588 kBtuh (172 kW) for the R-20 heavy construction sandmass storage case. Results of the simulations also showed annual energy savings for the high thermal mass designs. Energy savings varied from 20 percent [16.0 kBtu/ft2 (50 kWh/m2)] for the R-10 high thermal mass design in comparison to its base case to 18 percent [12.2 kBtu/ft2 (39 kWh/m2)] for the R-20 high thermal mass design in comparison to its base case. The annual energy savings are due to the ability of the thermal mass to absorb heat from all sources of heat generation (lights, occupancy, solar, and auxiliary) during occupied periods and release the heat during unoccupied periods. An optimized thermal design was developed based on results from the DOE 2.1C simulations. The initial cost for the optimized thermal storage design is lower than the initial costs for light construction office buildings, since the lower initial cost of the down-sized HVAC system for the optimized thermal storage design more than offsets the increased cost of wall and floor systems incorporated in the optimized design. Annual energy savings are realized from the high thermal mass system in both cooling and heating modes due to the interaction of building HVAC systems operation in the simulated 27000 ft2 (2508 m2) office building. Annual operating savings of $3781 to $4465 per year are estimated based on simulation results. © 1990 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning - Calculations; Energy Conservation; Energy Storage - Costs; Heating Season; Peak Cooling Demand; System Sizing; Thermal Mass; Buildings

Authors: Fankhauser H.R., Aneros K., Edris A.-A., Torseng S.
Title: Advanced Simulation Techniques for the Analysis of Power System Dynamics
Affiliations: ABB Power Systems, Vasteras, Sweden

Abstract: The uncertainty about the future development of electric power supply systems has increased during the recent years all over the world. The power utilities are forced to interconnect their grids and to operate the existing production and transmission facilities closer to their limits. This calls for studies in which the access to realistic models of all established and future electrical equipment such as multiterminal HVDC systems, phasewise-controlled Static Var Controllers (SVCs), Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) Flexible AC Transmission Systems (FACTS), etc., is very essential. The available choice of numerical methods and the proper handling of events are equally well crucial for the accuracy and reliability of the analysis. SIMPOW™ is an acronym for simulation of power systems and the trademark of a digital power system simulator that complies with the requirements above. © 1990, IEEE.

Title: Solar energy at various depths below a water surface
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, United Arab Emirates University, PO Box 17551, Al-Ain, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Jamal, M.A., Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, United Arab Emirates University, PO Box 17551, Al-Ain, United Arab Emirates; Muaddi, J.A., Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, United Arab Emirates University, PO Box 17551, Al-Ain, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The total solar energy at various depths in water has been calculated by adopting two sets of data, namely the extinction coefficient of water in the spectral range of 300–2500 nm, and the solar spectrum at sea level in the same spectral range. With the aid of a computer program designed for this purpose, the solar spectrum at various depths has been reconstructed and the total solar energy has been measured by calculating the area under the spectral distribution curves. A mathematical expression for the integrated solar energy as a function of depth in water has been derived. Copyright © 1990 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd

Title: Load management: impacts on the reliability and production costs of interconnected systems
Source title: International Journal of Electrical Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Engineering University, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Authors with affiliations: Ahsan, Q., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Engineering University, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Abstract: With the increasing recognition that load management could be beneficial to a utility, the planner has an added alternative in generation expansion planning in deciding whether to construct a new plant, to purchase power from a neighbouring utility or to implement a load management scheme. This paper evaluates the impacts of load management strategies on the reliability as well as on the production costs of two interconnected systems. Investigation has been made to find the equivalence, in terms of reliability improvement and production cost benefit, between the tie-line capacity and the percentage reduction of the peak demand. In the simulation, the correlation between the loads of two inteconnected systems is considered. The segmentation method is utilized in the numerical simulation. © 1990.

Authors: Aravas N., Kim K.-S., Leckie F.A.
Title: On the calculations of the stored energy of cold work
Source title: Journal of Engineering Materials and Technology, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mechanics, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, 19104, United States; Division of Engineering, Brown University, Providence, RI, 02912, United States; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, 93106, United States
Authors with affiliations: Aravas, N., Department of Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mechanics, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, 19104, United States; Kim, K.-S., Division of Engineering, Brown University, Providence, RI, 02912, United States; Leckie, F.A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, 93106, United States
Abstract: When a metal deforms plastically, most of the mechanical energy expended in the deformation process is converted into heat and the remainder is stored in the material. A method for the calculation of the stored energy from an experimentally determined load-displacement curve of an elastic-plastic structure is presented. The method is applied to the problem of simple tension of a polycrystalline metal and a simple technique for the calculation of the stored energy from the uniaxial stress-strain curve is presented. © 1990 by ASME.

Title: Pseudoelastic Behavior in a Polycrystalline Cu-Al-Ni Shape Memory Alloy in Comparison with the Modified Taylor Model
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Tohoku University, Sendai, 980, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ono, N., Faculty of Engineering, Tohoku University, Sendai, 980, Japan
Abstract: In a polycrystalline Cu-13.9 mass% Al-3.8% Ni-0.03% B shape memory alloy, the pseudoelastic loop and electric resistance during straining and unloading above Ms were observed. The results were discussed in comparison with the predictions made from the modified Taylor model and observations in single crystals in the literature, which suggest that either γ′1- or β′1-martensite could be stress-induced. The observed yield stress was close to the predictions made assuming these martensites, but definitely smaller than either of them, the difference being larger as temperature increased. This disagreement is primarily attributed to the simultaneous formation of the two types of martensites, which is facilitated by the effect of intergranular constraint. The difference of the observed value for the SIM formation rate to the prediction, on the other hand, was far larger than that for the yield stress, so that the work done by the applied stress was significantly larger than the energy consumed for the formation of SIM. Although various uncertainties are involved in this comparison, this apparent energy unbalance is considered to be real, being likely to be caused by energy storage in the form of elastic energy. © 1990, The Japan Institute of Metals. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: copper-aluminum-nickel; poly crystal plasticity; pseudoelasticity; shape memory alloy; stress-induced martensitic transformation; Taylor model

Title: A Multifunction Protective Relay for the Cogeneration Industry
Affiliations: Beckwith Electric Company, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harlow, J.H., Beckwith Electric Company, United States
Abstract: Since the enactment of the National Energy Act of 1979, many private energy producers have been planning and building small generation and cogeneration facilities in order to sell power to the local utility. Previously, the generation sources that were not owned by a utility were typically very large industrial plants with generators connected to the power system at a substation through a dedicated line. Many of the non-utility generators (called DSG for dispersed sources of generation or dispersed storage and generation) built after 1979 are connected directly to the closest utility distribution circuit. With this configuration, the parallel generator may energize a distribution line after the utility circuit breaker or line recloser has opened. In some cases, the DSG can support the load and operate as an isolated system. Aware of the problems associated with connecting generators in this manner, electric utilities across the U.S. developed specifications and standards to allow safe and reliable interconnections. © 1990, IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Factor - Calculations; Electric Relays - Design; Mathematical Transformations - Fourier Transforms; Signal Filtering and Prediction; Signal Processing - Digital Techniques; Discrete Fourier Transform; Multifunction Protective Relay; RMS Value Estimation; Cogeneration Plants

Title: Structures for superconductive magnetic energy storage
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Authors with affiliations: Varghese, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States; Tam, K.-S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Abstract: The cost of superconductor material is a significant portion of the total cost of an SMES (Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage) system. The mass of superconductor required to store a given amount of energy is a function of the magnet structure. Five magnetic structures applicable for SMES are examined in this paper from the viewpoint of their energy storage capacities along with the peak field magnitudes. Two force-balanced structures are analyzed and compared. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Economics; Energy Storage Capacity; Superconducting Magnets

Title: Electron Cooling of High-Z Ion Beams Parallel to a Guide Magnetic Field
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, Group X-l, MS E531, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; GSI Darmstadt, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Goldman, S.R., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Group X-l, MS E531, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Hofmann, I., GSI Darmstadt, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The cooling of high-Z ion beams through collisions with electrons whose temperature parallel to a guide magnetic field is considerably lower than their perpendicular temperature is considered. For initial electron temperatures, magnetic fields, and charged particle densities—as, for instance, are apparently attainable in the experimental storage ring (ESR) at GSI Darmstadt—electrons tend to be trapped in the vicinity of their nearest ion neighbor. This results in an energy exchange with the ions that is qualitatively different from conventional models, where electron cooling is described in terms of small angle collisions or within the linearized dielectric response theory. Such models are justified for situations where the potential energy of interaction is small compared to the relevant kinetic energy; e.g., for light ions. For the case of high-Z ions, however, it is the trapping process itself that drives the cooling. Using a variety of parameterizations of the electron shielding of the ions, it is found that the resulting steady-state ion temperature parallel to the magnetic field is less than a factor of ten higher than the original parallel electron temperature. The e-folding times of approach to the equilibrium temperature have been found to be of the order of a few milliseconds for Z in the range of 20 and above. This result is encouraging with respect to the production of ultra-cold beams or even a crystalline heavy-ion state. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Charged Particles; Electrons; Magnetic Fields; Electron Temperature; Ultracold Beams; Ion Beams

Authors: Kiehne T.M., Wilson D.E., Matthews R.D.
Title: Numerical solution technique for transient, two-dimensional combustion with multi-step kinetics
Source title: Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering
Affiliations: Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, United States; University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kiehne, T.M., Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, United States; Wilson, D.E., University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Matthews, R.D., University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Abstract: For numerical combustion problems, computational time and storage requirements scale approximately with the square of the number of chemical species. Therefore, the most difficult cases that can be solved using elementary chemical kinetics have been one-dimensional transient and two-dimensional steady formulations. This limitation and the established shortcomings of global reactions have encouraged recent development of simplified but accurate multi-step kinetics schemes. The present investigation uses one of these simplified reaction mechanisms to determine if solution of a multi-dimensional, transient, reacting flow problem is possible without resort to overly simplified, global kinetics. A laminar, two-dimensional, transient, viscous flow model has been developed which incorporates a chemical kinetics mechanism for propane consisting of four reversible reactions and only seven species. The model is used to investigate the initiation and propagation of a flame subjected to heat transfer, wall motion and shear flow. The mathematical model simulates the physical and chemical processes occurring near the centerline of a thin-gap formed by two cold, solid surfaces as one surface moves first toward and then away from the other. The governing conservation equations for mass, momentum, energy and chemical species are simplified using the thin-gap approximation. The problem is transformed to eliminate the continuity equation by using a compressible stream function formulation. The resulting mixed order system of nonlinear, boundary value problems is solved by a semi-discrete numerical procedure which employs a finite element collocation method and adaptive grid technique. Both non-reacting and reacting cases are solved to demonstrate the effect of the shear flow and cold surfaces on the flow field and on the developing laminar flame. The results reveal a complex flow with numerous substructures caused by the interaction of the developing flame with cold fluid trapped in the boundary layer adjacent to the stationary wall. The reacting flow results represent the first calculation of a laminar, reacting flow in a moving wall geometry using nonequilibrium, multi-step chemistry while simultaneously resolving the momentum and thermal boundary layers. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions--Reaction Kinetics; Flame Research; Fuels--Combustion; Mathematical Models; Propane--Combustion; Reversible Reactions; Thermal Boundary Layers; Two-Dimensional Combustion; Combustion

Authors: Liu Z.F., Hashimoto K., Fujishima A.
Title: Photoelectrochemical information storage using an azobenzene derivative
Affiliations: Department of Synthetic Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, University of Tokyo, Hongo, Tokyo 113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Liu, Z.F., Department of Synthetic Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, University of Tokyo, Hongo, Tokyo 113, Japan; Hashimoto, K., Department of Synthetic Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, University of Tokyo, Hongo, Tokyo 113, Japan; Fujishima, A., Department of Synthetic Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, University of Tokyo, Hongo, Tokyo 113, Japan
Abstract: HIGH-DENSITY information storage is becoming an increasingly important technological objective. The 'heat-mode' storage techniques (in which only the thermal energy of laser light is used in the recording process and hence information usually stored as a physical change of the storage media) that are used in current optical memories are limited by the diffraction properties of light1, and the alternative 'photon-mode' (in which information is stored as a photon-induced chemical change of the storage media) has attracted attention recently for high-density storage. The most promising candidates for realizing this mode seem to be photochro-ism and photochemical hole burning; but these have some intrinsic drawbacks1,2. Here we present a novel 'photon-mode' technique that uses the photoelectrochemical properties of a Langmuir-Blodgett film of an azobenzene derivative. The system can be interconverted photochemically or electrochemically between three chemical states, and this three-state system is shown to provide a potential storage process that allows for ultra-high storage density, multi-function memory and non-destructive information readout. © 1990 Nature Publishing Group.
Index Keywords: Aromatic Compounds--Films; Aromatic Compounds--Photochemical Reactions; Chemical Reactions--Isomerization; Chemical Reactions--Redox; Films--Langmuir-Blodgett; Azobenzene Derivatives; Electrochemical Redox Reactions; High-Density Information Storage; Photochemical cis-trans Isomerization; Photoelectrochemical Data Storage; Photon-Mode Data Storage Techniques; Data Storage, Optical

Authors: Tobushi H., Ohashi Y., Kawaguchi M.
Title: Strain Energy for Cyclic Pseudoelasticity on Ti-Ni Alloy (Characteristics of Energy Storage and High Damping)
Source title: Journal of the Society of Materials Science, Japan
Affiliations: Aichi Institute of Technology, Yachigusa, Yagusa-cho, Toyota, Japan; Suzuka Fuji Xerox Co. Ltd., Ifuna-cho, Suzuka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tobushi, H., Aichi Institute of Technology, Yachigusa, Yagusa-cho, Toyota, Japan; Ohashi, Y., Aichi Institute of Technology, Yachigusa, Yagusa-cho, Toyota, Japan; Kawaguchi, M., Suzuka Fuji Xerox Co. Ltd., Ifuna-cho, Suzuka, Japan
Abstract: The stress-strain curve of Ti-Ni alloy on pseudoelasticity forms a hysteresis loop, and there appear large amounts of recoverable strain energy and dissipated strain energy. The experiments on a wire under cyclic uniaxial tension were carried out and the influences of test temperature, maximum strain and shape memory processing temperature on the cyclic behaviors of these strain energies were investigated. The results obtained are summarized as follows. (1) The recoverable strain energy was large as the test temperature became high, and decreased with the number of cycles. (2) The dissipated strain energy depended little on the test temperature for small maximum strain, but decreased significantly in the early cycles at low test temperatures if the maximum strain was larger than the range of stress-induced martensitic transformation. (3) Among the attenuation rates of various strain energies under cyclic deformation, the attenuation rate of dissipated strain energy was largest. The variation of attenuation rate of every strain energy was significant in the early cycles, but became almost constant after the 20th cycle. This means that the training before the actual use is effective for the cyclic stability of each strain energy. (4) The rate of strain energy storage increased with the number of cycles, but the rate of strain energy dissipation decreased. (5) Both recoverable strain energy and dissipated strain energy were large as the maximum strain became large in the early cycles. If the maximum strain was in the range of stress-induced martensitic transformation, each strain energy for the 100th cycle became almost a constant value. (6) The recoverable strain energy was small as the shape memory processing temperature became high. The dissipated strain energy was large as the shape memory processing temperature became high in the early cycles, but became largest at 673K of shape memory processing temperature for the 100th cycle. © 1990, The Society of Materials Science, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cyclic characteristics; Dissipated strain energy; Pseudoelasticity; Recoverable strain energy; TiNi shape memory alloy
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Mathematical Models; Materials with Memory--Energy Storage; Metals Testing--Tensile Tests; Titanium and Alloys--Hysteresis; Cyclic Pseudoelasticity; Dissipated Strain Energy; Recoverable Strain Energy; Titanium Nickel Alloys

Title: The Role of Wall Coercivity and Energy on the Read-Out Stability of GdTb-Fe Based Magneto-optical Disks
Affiliations: Philips Research Laboratory Hamburg, 2000, Hamburg, 54, FRG, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Klahn, S., Philips Research Laboratory Hamburg, 2000, Hamburg, 54, FRG, Germany; Raasch, D., Philips Research Laboratory Hamburg, 2000, Hamburg, 54, FRG, Germany
Abstract: The read-out stability of thermomagnetically written domains in GdTb-Fe disks has been measured by recording experiments as a function of read laser power and the applied magnetic field. The domain stability increases significantly and the field dependence becomes much flatter with increasing Tb content. At low Tb content compensation temperatures below room temperature result in a strong reduction of domain stability at higher applied magnetic fields. The results of a bubble-like model using the measured magnetic and thermal properties of the disks explain and predict the recording data with high precision. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Magnetic - Disk; Laser Beams; Magnetic Materials - Bubbles; Magnetooptical Disks; Data Storage, Optical

Title: Interaction Factors of a Multi-Layered Magnetic Thin Film System
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mian, G., Department of Electrical Engineering, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130, United States; Indeck, R.S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130, United States
Abstract: Magnetostatic interaction factors of coupled magnetic thin films have been proposed to assist the analysis of the electric and magnetic properties of such systems. Three dimensional mathematical expressions of these factors have been developed. The interaction energy of the system in each film can be determined numerically using these factors. As a result, the magnetoresistive character of the system can be obtained numerically. The interaction factor decreases rapidly as the distance is increased, with the rate of decrease being faster for thinner films. The numerical solution of the output character of a coupled thin film read head agrees with previous experimental findings. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Magnetic - Film; Magnetic Heads; Magnetization; Magnetostatics; Coupled Thin Films; Multilayered Films; Magnetic Materials

Authors: Emons H.‐H., Jahn K., Flammersheim H.‐J., Mäder E., Dorschner H.
Title: Properties of high density polyethylene and its behaviour under ‘Galisol’ heat storage conditions
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Freiberg, 9200, Germany; Friedrich-Schiller-University Jena, Department of Chemistry, Lessingstraße 10, Jena, 6900, Germany; Academy of Sciences of GDR, Institute of Polymer Technology Dresden, Dresden, PSF411, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Emons, H.‐H., Department of Chemistry, Freiberg, 9200, Germany; Jahn, K., Department of Chemistry, Freiberg, 9200, Germany; Flammersheim, H.‐J., Friedrich-Schiller-University Jena, Department of Chemistry, Lessingstraße 10, Jena, 6900, Germany; Mäder, E., Academy of Sciences of GDR, Institute of Polymer Technology Dresden, Dresden, PSF411, Germany; Dorschner, H., Academy of Sciences of GDR, Institute of Polymer Technology Dresden, Dresden, PSF411, Germany
Abstract: High density polyethylene (HDPE), crosslinked by electron beams in air, is presented as a latent heat storage material for energy storage applications at a temperature level of about 120°C. The study includes thermal investigations before and after the irradiation, investigations of the form stability, gel content determinations and microscopic investigations of HDPE. An electron energy of 0.4 MeV and a radiation dosage of 200 kGy were found to be the optimum conditions for the irradiation of the investigated HDPE in air. The pellets obtained were form‐stable owing to the formation of a thin crosslinked surface layer (about 0.5 mm thickness). In spite of the presence of oxygen during irradiation, the melting enthalpy of the initial state was retained almost quantitatively. Apart from that, a quasicomplete irradiation of the pellets in volume in air, with a higher electron energy, is also possible. In this case about 95% of the initial melting enthalpy is obtained, providing a maximum gel content of 50%. Moreover, the paper offers a possibility of overcoming the low heat transfer power of HDPE by applying it in form of modified pellets in a ‘Galisol’ model storage unit with water as the heat transfer liquid. Owing to the large heat transfer area connected to boiling and condensation of water, excellent values of heat transfer power of 100–114 W/kg HDPE (ΔT=16 K) are obtained. These are comparable to those of salt hydrates, provided there is sufficient form stability. The significant influence of somewhat lower form stability on the heat output is shown. Copyright © 1990 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd
Author Keywords: Electron beam crosslinking; High density polyethylene; Latent heat storage
