Title: Anomalous Hall Effect Measurements of Domain Writing and Erasure in Magneto-Optic Thin-Films
Affiliations: IBM T.J. Watson Research Laboratory, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Webb, B.C., IBM T.J. Watson Research Laboratory, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States
Abstract: The thermomagnetic writing and erasure of sub-micron domains has been observed in a magneto-optic thin film, using the anomalous Hall effect (AHE) voltage generated within the medium itself. A TbFeCo film has been photolithographically patterned to form a cross-shaped Hall geometry a few microns across. The AHE voltage, proportional to a weighted average of the transition metal magnetization within the cross, is affected by a laser pulse in two ways. First, the laser heats the film, reducing the magnitude of the magnetization. Secondly, the sign of the A HE voltage changes as the magnetization reverses within the written domain. Time resolution is currently 100 ns, better than 10 ns resolution should be achievable. The technique has been used to make quantitative measurements of domain size and temperature profile during laser induced writing as a function of laser pulse energy and external field. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Optical; Hall Effect - Measurements; Laser Pulses; Magnetooptical Devices - Thin Films; Domain Writing; Thermomagnetic Writing; Data Storage, Magnetic

Authors: Arai K.I., Kang H.W., Ishiyama K.
Title: Magnetic Properties of Co and Co-Fe Electrodeposited Alumite Films
Affiliations: Research Institute of Electrical Communication, Tohoku University, 2-1-1 Katahlra Aoba-ku, Sendai 980, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Arai, K.I., Research Institute of Electrical Communication, Tohoku University, 2-1-1 Katahlra Aoba-ku, Sendai 980, Japan; Kang, H.W., Research Institute of Electrical Communication, Tohoku University, 2-1-1 Katahlra Aoba-ku, Sendai 980, Japan; Ishiyama, K., Research Institute of Electrical Communication, Tohoku University, 2-1-1 Katahlra Aoba-ku, Sendai 980, Japan
Abstract: Co and Co-Fe were elcctrodeposited in pores of anodic oxidized alumite films. The coercive force and the magnetic anisotropy energy of these films are examined. The magnetic anisotropy energy and the perpendicular coercive force of Co electrodeposited alumite films can be controlled widely by changing the pH and the temperature of the Co solutions without changing the particle diameter. The electrodeposited Co-Fe particles are confirmed to be single phase Co-Fe alloys by X-ray diffractions. The saturation magnetization as well as the coercive force can be controlled by changing the composition of the alloy. Magnetic alumite films having high saturation magnetization and high coercive force were obtained. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Magnetic - Film; Electrodeposition; Magnetization; Alumite Films; Perpendicular Recording; Magnetic Materials

Title: Economic impact of integrating photovoltaics with conventional electric utility operation
Affiliations: Energy Systems Research Laboratory, Electrical Engineering Department, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rahman, S., Energy Systems Research Laboratory, Electrical Engineering Department, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine the parameters which impact the value of photovoltaics (PV) to the electric utility. We have, therefore, chosen the high, medium and low load days in winter (January) and summer (July). The daily peak load has varied from 5838 MW to 9712 MW. These six days are studied for reference (no PV), high, medium, low and intermittent PV output cases. Results from these 30 case studies are summarized in this paper. In order to study the impact of operating photovoltaic (PV) systems on the electric utility production cost (fuel and variable O&M) we have chosen the load profile of a southeastern utility and the PV output data from solar test facilities in Virginia and North Carolina. In order to incorporate the short term variations we have used 10-minute resolution data for both load and PV output. Fifty generating units are made available to serve the load. These include nuclear, coal, combustion turbine, hydroelectric and pumped storage power plants. These units are scheduled in such a way that the impact of PV output can be seen primarily on the combustion turbine and thermal steam units. This is done to maximize the savings due to the PV energy. The performance analysis shows that, while the total production (fuel and variable O&M) cost savings are higher for high solar days, the increase is not proportional to the amount of PV energy output. This observation reflects very clearly on the per unit PV energy value. It is seen that the high solar day never produced the highest per unit PV energy value. In fact the highest per unit PV energy values for both winter and summer days are found to be for the low solar days. This is because during those days the PV energy outputs come closest to displacing their full equivalent amount of combustion turbine (CT) generation. As CT generation is the most expensive, this scenario gives the highest per unit PV energy value. In our study we have seen the best per unit PV energy value for the low PV output on a medium load day in winter. © 1990 IEEE
Author Keywords: Dispatchable generation; Economic dispatch; Energy value; Photovoltaics; Production cost; Ramp rates; Unit commitment
Index Keywords: Electric Utilities--Fuel Economy; Solar Cells; Daily Peak Load; Solar Days; Summer Days; Photovoltaic Cells

Title: Application of superconductive magnetic energy storage in an asynchronous link between power systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tam, K.-S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States; Kumar, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Abstract: This paper introduces the concept that SMES can be incorporated into a back-to-back DC link. With a SMES/DC link, a SMES system can be shared between several neighboring power systems. This would result in better economics for SMES usage for each participating power system. In addition to SMES operation, SMES/DC link also enables asynchronous connection and interchange of power between the interconnected systems. This paper demonstrates that SMES/DC link can be operated such that significant economic benefits can be obtained over pure power interchange or SMES operation alone. The basic principle of a SMES/DC link, which is applicable to interconnecting any number of neighboring power systems with a single SMES unit, and various interconnected system operation modes are presented. A battery/DC link is discussed in this paper and is compared with the SMES/DC link. © 1990 IEEE
Author Keywords: Battery; Control; Economic Operation; Interconnected Systems; Load Leveling; Multiterminal DC
Index Keywords: Electric Power Transmission, DC; Superconducting Magnets--Energy Storage; Asynchronous Link; Back-to-Back DC Link; Battery-DC Link; Power Interchange; Superconductive Magnetic Energy Storage; Electric Power Systems

Title: Impact of superconductive magnetic energy storage on electric power transmission
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tam, K.-S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States; Kumar, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Abstract: This paper demonstrates that a superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) system can provide a significant positive impact on electric power transmission. Through the use of SMES, transmission line loadings during heavy load hours can be reduced. Transmission losses as well as the fuel cost for these losses over a 24-hour period can also be decreased. A new SMES scheme, the SMES/dc link, is introduced in this paper for energy storage and control of power flow. The operation of this scheme and the benefits it provides are presented in this paper. © 1990 IEEE
Author Keywords: FUEL COSTS; LINE LOADINGS; LOSSES; MULTITERMINAL DC LINK; POWER FLOW CONTROL

Authors: Pohm A.V., Comstock C.S., Jiang Z.P., Ranmuthu K.T.M., Ranmuthu I.W.

Authors with affiliations: Pohm, A.V., Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering Department, Engineering Research Institute, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States; Comstock, C.S., Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering Department, Engineering Research Institute, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States; Jiang, Z.P., Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering Department, Engineering Research Institute, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States; Ranmuthu, K.T.M., Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering Department, Engineering Research Institute, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States; Ranmuthu, I.W., Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering Department, Engineering Research Institute, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States
Abstract: The energy and wall width of paired Neel walls were analytically examined. The walls studied are those which are perpendicular to the easy axes in double layer M-R elements. Specifically, the material examined consisted of two 150 A thick magnetic layers spearated by 50 A. The anisotropy constant was assumed to be 20 Oe, the exchange constant 1.25 X 10–6 ergs/cm and the saturation magnetization 983 G/47r. Wall energies ranged from 0.03 ergs/cm2 to 1.8 ergs/ cm2as the total angle of rotation across the wall varied from 60° to 270°. Wall width ranged from 2.0 µm to 0.5 µm. © 1990 IEEE

Title: Sputtered Pt/Co Multilayers for Magneto-Optical Recording
Affiliations: E.I. du Pont de Nemours &Co.(Inc), Central Research Dept, P.O. Box 80356, Wilmington, DE, 19880–0356, United States; Philips Research Laboratories, P.O. Box 80.000, 5600JA, Eindhoven, Netherlands

Abstract: By sputtering Pt/Co multilayers with either Kr or Xe instead of Ar, we achieved a large magnetic coercivity ~1000 Oe, suitable for magneto-optical recording. Sputtering with a larger mass gas reduced both the flux and the energy of back reflected gas neutrals, which can mix Pt and Co layers and compromise magnetic properties. We also made multilayer-related Pt-Co alloys with perpendicular magnetic anisotropy and coercivities of 1-3.5 kOe by sputtering them at high Ar pressures (20–50 mTorr). © 1990 IEEE

Title: Measurement of Domain Wall Energy and Simulation of Overwrite Process on TbFeCo Films
Affiliations: Central Research Lab., Hitachi Ltd., Kokubunji, Tokyo 185, Japan; University of Paris-Orsay, Applied Physics, France
Authors with affiliations: Hosoe, Y., Central Research Lab., Hitachi Ltd., Kokubunji, Tokyo 185, Japan; Suzuki, Y., Central Research Lab., Hitachi Ltd., Kokubunji, Tokyo 185, Japan; Pfeffer, N., Central Research Lab., Hitachi Ltd., Kokubunji, Tokyo 185, Japan, University of Paris-Orsay, Applied Physics, France; Okamine, S., Central Research Lab., Hitachi Ltd., Kokubunji, Tokyo 185, Japan; Ohte, N., Central Research Lab., Hitachi Ltd., Kokubunji, Tokyo 185, Japan; Suzuki, R., Central Research Lab., Hitachi Ltd., Kokubunji, Tokyo 185, Japan
Abstract: In order to analyze the direct thermo-magnetic overwrite process, the domain wall energy, saturation induction and coercivity for TbFeCo films were measured at high temperatures at which the recorded domains are formed. The domain wall energy was determined from an observation of stripe domains after AC-demagnetization at elevated temperatures. Using the obtained parameters, a simulation was performed on an overwrite process with a fixed bias magnetic field for 100nm- and 200nm-thick films. The simulation indicates that significant shrinkage of a pre-recorded domain occurs for the 200nm-thick film, which is consistent with previous observations. © 1990 IEEE

Authors: Bharadwaj S.K., Sodha M.S., Kumar A.
Title: Techno‐economic optimization of a hybrid collector‐cum‐storage system
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Sciences, TIET, Patiala, India; DAU, Indore, Madhya Pradesh, India; Solar Energy Centre, B-4 (9th Floor), CGO Complex,  Lodi Road, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Bharadwaj, S.K., Centre of Energy Sciences, TIET, Patiala, India; Sodha, M.S., DAU, Indore, Madhya Pradesh, India; Kumar, A., Solar Energy Centre, B-4 (9th Floor), CGO Complex,  Lodi Road, New Delhi, India
Abstract: A mathematical model is presented for studying the techno‐economic performance of a hybrid solar air heating system. The configuration of the system consists of a collector‐cum‐storage system for solar heating of air, an adjuster unit for bringing down the higher air temperature to the desired limit by mixing fresh air in it, and an auxiliary energy source to provide the deficient amount of heat to the air to attain the desired temperature whenever required. In order to evaluate the performance of the system, numerical calculations have been made corresponding to the climatic data of Delhi and the cost parameters prevalent in the Indian market. Numerical results show that the cost of the useful energy obtained for optimized values of collector area and water‐depth is much less than the cost of electrical heating. Title: Barkhausen Noise in Thin-Film Recording Heads
Affiliations: IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, CA 95120, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klaassen, K.B., IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, CA 95120, United States; van Peppen, J.C.L., IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, CA 95120, United States
Abstract: Barkhausen noise in thin-film heads was studied by exciting the heads with an external magnetic field and with a head coil generated field. Observed pulses show an exponential growth and decay, resulting in a second order wall energy versus displacement model. Analytical expressions are given for the observed pulse shapes. Most pulses are essentially associated with unstable regions around attractive interaction sites where a wall in equilibrium cannot exist. A method is presented which locates the position of a wall jump in P1or P2. It can also discriminate jumps occurring close to the pole faces from those farther up the yoke. © 1990 IEEE

Authors: Nishimori K., Tanaka K., Sato K.
Title: Surface Contamination on Sputter Carbon Coated Disks Measured by Using Low Energy Photoelectron Spectroscopy in an Ambient Atmosphere
Affiliations: Dept.of Mech. Eng., Nagaoka Univ.of Technology, 1603-l, Kamitomioka Nagaoka, Niigata 940–21, Japan; Analysis Center, Nagaoka Univ. of Technology, 1603-1, Kamitomioka Nagaoka, Niigata 940–21, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nishimori, K., Dept.of Mech. Eng., Nagaoka Univ.of Technology, 1603-l, Kamitomioka Nagaoka, Niigata 940–21, Japan; Tanaka, K., Dept.of Mech. Eng., Nagaoka Univ.of Technology, 1603-l, Kamitomioka Nagaoka, Niigata 940–21, Japan; Sato, K., Analysis Center, Nagaoka Univ. of Technology, 1603-1, Kamitomioka Nagaoka, Niigata 940–21, Japan
Abstract: We attempted to evaluate the surface contaminant on sputtered carbon films on rigid thin-film disk with LEPS (Low Energy Photoelectron Spectroscopy) and XPS (X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy), and examined the influence of the surface contamination on the wettability of fluorocarbon lubricant on sputtered carbon films. LEPS was as sensitive as XPS for detecting the surface contaminant. LEPS had an advantage of operating in an ambient atmosphere, while XPS was useful for the identification of chemical species of the contaminant. The XPS analysis revealed that the main contaminant was due to water in air. It was found by XPS that the wettability of the fluorocarbon lubricant decreased with an increase in the exposure time of the sputtered carbon film to air before lubrication or with an increase in the surface contaminant on the sputtered carbon film. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Carbon - Thin Films; Lubricants; Spectroscopic Analysis; Spectroscopy, Photoelectron; Sputtering; Carbon Coated Disks; Sputtered Carbon Films; Data Storage, Magnetic

Title: Micromagnetics of Closed-Edge Laminations
Affiliations: IBM Research Division, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Slonczewski, J.C., IBM Research Division, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: According to previous work, lamination of the film core in a recording head eliminates noisy closure domains - but introduces potentially noisy curling- edge walls. In quest of a possible means of avoiding the edge walls, we minimize the energy of an infinite strip composed of two laminations connected along their edges. Under the conditions that the spacer thickness is ≥ 0.2 x (magnetic-sublayer thickness) and that the energy is less than that of the closure-domain state, we predict: 1) Fully stray-field-free flux closure with no walls occurs if the sum of anisotropy and exchange - stiffness energies within the magnetic connections is negative. 2) If this energy sum is positive, then a part of the flux leaks through the spacer, forming edge walls whose angle is < 90°. Polarization switching of these walls contributes to hysteresis. 3) If a pair of would-be edge walls are so thick as to impinge on each other then the actual ground state is one of saturation along the hard axis. An advantage of closed edges is the need for thicker and therefore fewer sublayers. A disadvantage of thicker sublayers is greater eddy currents. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Magnetic; Magnetic Heads; Micromagnetics; Recording Heads; Magnetic Materials

Authors: Motomura Y., Tatsumi T., Urai H., Aoyama M.
Title: Soft Magnetic Properties and Heat Stability for Fe/NiFe Superlattices
Affiliations: Functional Devices Res. Labs., NEC Corporation, Kawasaki, Kanagawa 213, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Motomura, Y., Functional Devices Res. Labs., NEC Corporation, Kawasaki, Kanagawa 213, Japan; Tatsumi, T., Functional Devices Res. Labs., NEC Corporation, Kawasaki, Kanagawa 213, Japan; Urai, H., Functional Devices Res. Labs., NEC Corporation, Kawasaki, Kanagawa 213, Japan; Aoyama, M., Functional Devices Res. Labs., NEC Corporation, Kawasaki, Kanagawa 213, Japan
Abstract: Soft magnetic properties and heat stability for Fe/NiFe (81wt.% Ni and 19wt.% Fe) superlattice films have been investigated. X-ray diffraction data show that the films have a textured bcc Fe (110)/fcc NiFe (111) stacking. Saturation magnetic flux density (Bs) is the average of bulk Fe and NiFe values. Coercive field (Hc) value and relative permeability (μ) depend on the thicknesses of both Fe and NiFe layers. Saturation magnetostriction constant (μs) behavior is explained as the average of λs values for Fe, NiFe and Fe-NiFe interdiffusion layers. In Fe/NiFe films with 8~16nm superlattice modulation wave length and around 50% Fe layer thickness ratio, large 15 kGauss Bs value, 3000 μ values and very small λs values less than 5×10-7 were achieved. The soft magnetic properties and the superlattice periodicity are stable at up to 200°C annealing temperature. Effective interdiffusivity (DË„) values are 1.9×10-24 ~1.5×10-21m2sec-1 in the 200 ~400°C temperature range, and are found to have an Arrhenius temperature dependence. Activation energy for the interdiffusion is estimated to be 0.84 eV. Extrapolating the DË„ value to lower temperature, Fe/NiFe films appear rather stable at an operating temperature for hard disk drives. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Magnetic - Hard Disk; Magnetostriction; Superlattices - Metallic; Hard Disk Drives; Magnetic Materials

Rep., Germany
Abstract: The optical reflectivity between 0.03 and 12.0 eV and the magneto-optical polar Kerr effect between 0.6 and 4.8 eV have been measured on a polycrystalline sample of UFel0Si2. A maximum Kerr rotation of -0.55° at 0.75 eV, a value comparable to the maximum Kerr rotation of pure Fe, was observed. © 1990 IEEE

Authors: Tagavi K., Chow L.C., Solaiappan O.
Title: Void formation in unidirectional solidification
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, 40506, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tagavi, K., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, 40506, United States; Chow, L.C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, 40506, United States; Solaiappan, O., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, 40506, United States
Abstract: Visual and photographic observations of unidirectional solidification of liquids that shrink by about 10%% is reported. The liquid is contained in a constant-volume (sealed) cylindrical cell. To estimate the effect of gravity, cooling is provided from above or below. For degassed liquids, when solidified from below, it is observed that the shrinkage is accommodated at the top (like a cavity). However, when solidified from above, the shrinkage is accommodated by formation of voids and worms filled with vapor. The effect of dissolved gases is also investigated. It is observed that dissolved gases tend to distribute the voids for both solidification from below and above. Hence, dissolved gases may be used to control the location of shrinkage voids. Some discussions and predictions are made regarding the location of voids formed under zero gravity. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: Heating--Solar; Solar Energy--Energy Storage; Phase Change Materials; Thermal Energy Storage; Voids Control; Satellites

Abstract: Nonsoluble parts of conducting poly(3-alkylthiophene) become soluble into organic solvents upon irradiation of light of photon energy larger than the band gap. Title: The Reversed Word Field Switching Threshold for M-R Memory Elements
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering Department, Engineering Research Institute, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States

Abstract: The threshold properties of M-R memory cells were examined for rotational switching when a reverse word field is applied. The threshold for reverse switching is larger than that for normal switching because of the energy associated with wall formation. The wall energy is sufficient to restore the element to its original state when the word field is removed. If demagnetization corrections are included, the current analytical model adequately accounts for normal and reverse switching. The model does not adequately describe the “return” switching threshold. © 1990 IEEE

Title: Application of a spherical thermal conductivity cell to solid n-eicosane paraffin
Source title: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Bucknell University, Lewisburg, PA 17837, United States; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stryker, P.C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Bucknell University, Lewisburg, PA 17837, United States; Sparrow, E.M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Abstract: A precisely fabricated, spherical thermal conductivity cell is used to achieve stady, one-dimensional, loss-free radial heat conduction across an annular test specimen. The investigated test specimens are solid, 99% pure n-eicosane paraffin, which are cast in place by using the conductivity cell as a mold. The conductivity is determined as a function of the mean temperature of the specimen, and its sensitivity to a number of parameters is investigated. These include the presence or absence of vacuum during casting, the rate of solidification during casting, the thermal contact between the conductivity cell walls and the test specimen, the temperature difference across the specimen, the experimental site, and the aging of the apparatus and the paraffin. In supplementary experiments, the density of the solid paraffin and its melting temperature are determined. For specimens cast without vacuum, the thermal conductivity is virtually independent of the specimen temperature and of the solidification rate. However, for speciments cast under vacuum, the conductivity is found to be sensitive to the solidification rate, as is the density, and this dependence is attributed to the presence of entrapped gas bubbles. Comparison with the literature shows prior conductivity values for solid n-eicosane to be low, thereby explaining reported deviations between experimental and numerical results for solidification phase change. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer - Transport Properties; Paraffin Waxes - Thermal Conductivity; Solar Energy - Energy Storage; Fusible Materials; Phase Change Materials; Solidification Behavior; Heat Storage

Authors: Fedyunin Y., Friedlaender F.J., Nyenhuis J.A.
Title: Investigation of the Magnetization Process of Domain Walls in an Iron-Garnet Film by Direct Optical Observation of Vertical Bloch Lines
Affiliations: Moscow State University, Moscow, Russian Federation; Purdue University, School of Electrical Engineering, West Lafayette, Indiana 47907, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fedyunin, Y., Moscow State University, Moscow, Russian Federation; Friedlaender, F.J., Purdue University, School of Electrical Engineering, West Lafayette, Indiana 47907, United States; Nyenhuis, J.A., Purdue University, School of Electrical Engineering, West Lafayette, Indiana 47907, United States
Abstract: Vertical Bloch lines (VBL) were observed in a (YLuBi)3(FeGa)5O12magnetic garnet film from the light diffracted from the stripe domains. Experiments on the motion of the Bloch lines in response to magnetic fields perpendicular to and in the plane of the film were performed. For a bias field pulse perpendicular to the film there was a non-linear relationship between pulse amplitude and VBL displacement. The minimum static in-plane field for VBL displacement (VBL coercivity) was 1.3 ± 0.4 Oe. Winding VBL pairs disappeared at an in-plane field of 3.5 Oe and unwinding pairs were annihilated at lower values of in-plane field. In a new type of experiment, the amplitude of VBL displacement in response to a low frequency ac in-plane field was measured. This experiment can be used to quantify the energy of the VBL in the vicinity of the pinning sites which were found to occur regularly along the domain wall. A considerable variation in the strength and spacing of the pinning sites was found in the film studied here. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Garnets - Thin Films; Magnetic Materials - Domains; Magnetization; Iron-Garnet Films; Vertical Bloch Lines; Data Storage, Magnetic

Title: Loss of power supply probability of stand-alone wind electric conversion systems: A closed form solution approach
Affiliations: Engineering Energy Laboratory, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abouzahr, I., Engineering Energy Laboratory, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, United States; Ramakumar, R., Engineering Energy Laboratory, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, United States
Abstract: A closed form solution approach to the evaluation of the loss of power supply probability of standalone wind-electric conversion systems with energy storage is presented. A numerical example is included to illustrate the usefulness of the expressions developed. In particular, the results of this paper will enable the investigation of the relationship between the amount of energy storage and the loss of power supply probability under various operating conditions. These relationships can be employed in the design of stand-alone wind energy conversion systems to optimize certain objective functions such as total capital cost. © 1990 IEEE

Authors: Card J.C., Valentin G., Storck A.
Title: The Activated Carbon Electrode: A New, Experimentally-Verified Mathematical Model for the Potential Distribution
Affiliations: Laboratoire des Sciences du Genie Chimique, CNRS-ENS1C, 1 rue Grandville, B.P. 451, 54001 Nancy Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Card, J.C., Laboratoire des Sciences du Genie Chimique, CNRS-ENS1C, 1 rue Grandville, B.P. 451, 54001 Nancy Cedex, France; Valentin, G., Laboratoire des Sciences du Genie Chimique, CNRS-ENS1C, 1 rue Grandville, B.P. 451, 54001 Nancy Cedex, France; Storck, A., Laboratoire des Sciences du Genie Chimique, CNRS-ENS1C, 1 rue Grandville, B.P. 451, 54001 Nancy Cedex, France
Abstract: Activated carbon (AC) is an increasingly important electrode material for such applications as electrosorption, electrosynthesis, and electrical energy storage. An accurate description of the potential distribution within the electrode is essential to understanding the overall process behavior in all of these applications. Simple models developed for electrodes composed of solid materials do not accurately predict the potential behavior of AC packed bed electrodes. A new model is presented which more realistically takes into account the complex physical structure of AC beds. An intraparticle microporosity as well as the classical interparticle macroporosity are treated. Equations describing the potential distributions in both of these porous phases are solved with finite difference techniques. The model is experimentally verified over a range of operating parameters including electrolyte conductivity, potential step direction and initial value, and activated carbon type. Very good agreement is found between the model predictions and the experimental results. copyright. © 1990, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Carbon--Activated; Electrodes--Carbon; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Difference Method; Packed Bed Electrodes; Potential Distributions; Electrodes, Electrochemical

Title: Developing hypermedia systems: Avoiding hyperchaos
Affiliations: Department of Health Informatics, University of Tennessee, Memphis, TN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hahn, J.S., Department of Health Informatics, University of Tennessee, Memphis, TN, United States
Abstract: Hypermedia systems allow storage of huge collections of information from a wide variety of sources and afford immediate and random access to the collections. While providing unprecedented possibilities for storing and disseminating information, hypermedia systems have the potential to confuse the developer and the user alike with a multitude of intricacies. When hypermedia are being used in the teaching/learning process, they can cause cognitive overload and disorientation, if not designed properly. One way to resolve these problems is to develop system and content flowcharts. Although developing system and content flowcharts seems to be time-consuming work, it saves time and energy over the long run. Furthermore, it promotes efficiency. © 1990 Quest Publishing Co.

Title: Energy from nuclear power
Authors with affiliations: Hafele, W.
Abstract: Nuclear power should play a pivotal and expanded role in supplying world energy, the author says. Risks must be minimized by designing a new generation of safe reactors and agreeing to establish an international regulatory body to oversee security and the storage of waste.Nuclear power has been hailed as the solution to the world's energy problems and condemned as the most dangerous and unfitting way to produce energy. Today, in the aftermath of the Chernobyl and Three Mile Island accidents, public opposition has strengthened. Reactor construction has come to a halt in many countries. Atomic energy's vast potential can be harnessed only if issues of safety, waste, and nuclear-weapon proliferation are addressed by a globally administered institution.

Authors: Yen J.-Y., Hallamasek K., Horowitz R.
Title: Track-following controller design for a compound disk drive actuator
Source title: Journal of Dynamic Systems, Measurement and Control, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan; Mechanical Engineering Department, University of California, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yen, J.-Y., Mechanical Engineering Department, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan; Hallamasek, K., Mechanical Engineering Department, University of California, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States; Horowitz, R., Mechanical Engineering Department, University of California, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States
Abstract: The use of compound actuators in both magnetic and optical disk files has become a means of achieving increased servo actuator bandwidths. A compound actuator, comprised of a fine actuator mounted “piggyback” on a coarse actuator, positions the read/write transducers above a radial track. This paper describes a design methodology for a discrete-time feedback control system for a compound actuator in which the dynamic interaction between the actuator stages is directly considered.The performance of the servosystem, including the range and bandwith limitations of each actuator, is specified in terms of the desired frequency response of the closedloop transfer functions from the reference track position to the tracking error and to the relative position between the coarse and the fine actuator. Parameter uncertainties and structural resonances are quantified using singular value techniques to form a robustness criterion which sets limits on the attainable tracking performance.Compensator design techniques using linear-quadratic Gaussian optimal control combined with loop transfer recovery are described. The state feedback portion of the compensator is calculated using an automatic procedure, while the state estimator is calculated by solving an associated Kalman filtering problem with colored fictitious noise. The noise is colored to shape the frequency spectrum of the input energy to each actuator, the relative motion between the stages, and the position of the transducer. © 1990 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Actuators; Data Storage, Magnetic - Disk; Compound Disk Drive Actuator; Linear Quadratic Gaussian Optimal Control; Loop Transfer Recovery; Loop Transfer Recovery (LQG/LTR) Technique; Track-Following Controller Design; Control Systems

Title: Gravity-assisted melting in a horizontal cylinder heated by external forced convection

Abstract: The results of an experimental study of melting of a free solid in a cylinder heated by external forced convection have been presented. The ranges for the average wall Stefan number and Archimedes number have been varied between 0.026 to 0.053 and 8.76×106 to 3.34×108 respectively. Multiple runs have been made for most of these cases using different values of Reynolds number and free stream temperature to obtain the desired average wall Stefan number. Though the melt rate is almost identical to that for the isothermally heated capsule in about half the tests, it is strongly affected by the dynamics of the melting process in other cases, where two different melt patterns are observed. © 1990.

Source title: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, The University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, Alabama, 35486, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schreiber, W.C., Mechanical Engineering Department, The University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, Alabama, 35486, United States
Abstract: The numerical simulation of conduction heat transfer in arbitrarily‐shaped regions is relevant to many engineering applications including the casting of plastics and metals, cold region problems and latent heat storage. This class of problem offers its particular challenges. The accurate computational simulation of conduction with thermally‐dependent properties requires a solution technique with good conservation properties. The boundary‐fitted co‐ordinates of an arbitrary solution domain typically yield grids which are non‐orthogonal and which, consequently, make energy conservation difficult to model. In the current article, a technique is described to simulate accurately the conduction heat transfer in materials of thermally‐dependent properties in irregular domains. The method combines boundary‐fitted co‐ordinates with the finite volume method, FVM, to produce a numerical technique which will accurately solve this non‐linear conduction problem using a grid which may be highly skewed. This capability is achieved through a unique treatment of the cross‐derivative terms that arise when the heat conduction equation is transformed to a non‐orthogonal grid. The cross‐derivative terms represent the non‐normal components of the heat fluxes into the skewed control volume. The tangent components of the heat fluxes are interpreted in a special way to produce finite difference expressions which accurately model the cross‐derivative partial. The numerical procedure is validated by comparing it against a purely analytical mathematical method. Although the numerical results have been obtained using a highly skewed grid, they exhibit close agreement with the analytically‐derived solution. Copyright © 1990 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd
Index Keywords: Temperature Distribution - Mathematical Models; Finite Volume Method; Heat Transfer

Title: Advancement of fuel cell systems and spin-off battery technology
Source title: Berichte der Bunsengesellschaft/Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics
Authors with affiliations: Kordesch, K.
Abstract: The possibly large influence of fuel cell technology on several energy conversion and environmental aspects of the future is discussed. Solar energy and other renewable energy sources must have electrochemical storage facilities. Nuclear power can be used efficiently to electrolize water. The replacement of combustion engines in vehicles by fuel cell systems operating on hydrogen is the only way of reducing the increase of CO2 in the atmosphere if the greenhouse effect is becoming a threat. The fuel cell projects related to the manned space vehicles can provide many important spin-off's for accumulator designs and battery technology.
Index Keywords: Electrochemistry; Energy conversion; Greenhouse effect; Solar energy; Accumulator Design; Fuel Cell Systems; Renewable Energy Source; Spin-Off Battery Technology; Fuel cells

Authors: Ledjeff K., Ahn J., Zylka D., Heinzel A.
Title: Ion exchange membranes as electrolyte for electrochemical energy conversion
Source title: Berichte der Bunsengesellschaft/Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics
Authors with affiliations: Ledjeff, K.; Ahn, J.; Zylka, D.; Heinzel, A.
Abstract: For solar energy systems long term energy storage with a high efficiency is required. Hydrogen is a suitable energy carrier, its generation by water electrolysis, the conversion into heat by (catalytic) combustion and into electrical energy by fuel cells is the present state of the art. Electrolyzer and fuel cell with a solid polymer electrolyte show several advantages compared to cells with liquid electrolyte. In compact modules high energy densities and high efficiencies are realized without a costly and complicated peripheral gas and electrolyte management system. The current work is concerned with the construction of a pressure electrolyzer, a hydrogen/oxygen fuel cell and the development of a 'reversible' system which works as electrolyzer and fuel cell as well. The modification of the fuel cell for the use of methanol as a fuel is a promising goal. Methanol is an attractive fuel for a back up system in the case of exhausted hydrogen reverse. The electrochemical reactions of hydrogen, oxygen and methanol at membrane/electrode composites are investigated.
Index Keywords: Energy Conversion--Electrochemistry; Membranes--Ion exchange membranes; Solar Energy--Applications; Electrochemical Characterization; Electrochemical Energy Conversion; FC Operation; Regenerative Energy Systems; Reversible System; Fuel cells

Authors: Takada H., Tsutsui Y., Tomimasu T.
Title: Influence of Synchrobetatron Resonance on Low-Energy Injection Beam with a Compact Storage Ring
Affiliations: Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Osaka, 554, Japan; Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takada, H., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Osaka, 554, Japan; Tsutsui, Y., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Osaka, 554, Japan; Tomimasu, T., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd., Osaka, 554, Japan, Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: The effects of synchrobetatron resonance on a low-energy beam were studied using a compact storage ring. The beam profile and lifetime were measured on and off the resonance line. Although the first and second resonances were dangerous, the beam lifetime became long on the third and fourth resonances due to the vertical beam size enlargement. Through DC ion clearing, it was also found that the betatron tune shift and spread, which are caused by trapped ions, were reduced with a decrease in beam energy, contrary to expectations. These results indicate that the operating point for injection is not particularly limited in narrow regions. Moreover, the possibility of high current beam storage at low energy is suggested by making full use of the third and fourth resonances. © 1990 IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: Beam lifetime; Betatron tune shift; Compact storage ring; Ion trapping; Low-energy injection; Synchrobetatron resonance; Synchrotron tune
Index Keywords: Ion Beams; Resonators, Cavity; Beam Lifetime; Compact Storage Rings; Synchrobetatron Resonance; Accelerators, Betatron

Authors: Beutler D.E., Beezhold W., Browning J.S., Fleetwood D.M., Counts N.E., Knott D.P., Freshman C.L., Conners M.P.
Title: Comparison of Photocurrent Enhancement and Upset Enhancement in CMOS Devices in a Medium-Energy X-Ray Environment
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Technical Support Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; L & M Technologies Incorporated, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States
Authors with affiliations: Beutler, D.E., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Beezhold, W., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Browning, J.S., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Fleetwood, D.M., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Counts, N.E., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Knott, D.P., Technical Support Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Freshman, C.L., L & M Technologies Incorporated, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Conners, M.P., L & M Technologies Incorporated, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States
Abstract: Radiation-induced upset levels in SA3001 static random access memories (SRAM’s) and SA3246 clock integrated circuits (IC’s) have been measured in a medium-energy flash X-ray environment (average photon energy ~100 keV) where dose-enhancing effects are very important. By comparing device responses using a non-dose-enhancing ceramic package lid and a dose-enhancing Kovar/gold lid, dose-enhancement factors for photocurrent and upset were generated. The observed “upset enhancement” factors of 3.0 ± 0.5 (SRAM) and 2.2 ± 0.2 (clock IC) are in excellent agreement with measurements of photocurrent enhancement factors (2.5 ± 0.5) in diodes processed with the same diffusions as the complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) IC’s irradiated in a steady-state X-ray environment. These results indicate that upset is dominated by the radiation-induced transient supply current in these IC’s, and that steady-state diode photocurrent measurements are a good predictor of both photocurrent and upset enhancement for IC’s made with this technology. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Semiconductor--Radiation Effects; Photoconductivity; X-Rays; CMOS Devices Upset Enhancement; Medium-Energy X-Ray Environment; Photocurrent Enhancement; Static RAM Devices; Integrated Circuits, CMOS

Authors: Fujiwara M., Sano T., Suzuki K., Watanabe S.
Title: Thermal analysis and fundamental tests on a heat pipe receiver for a solar dynamic space power system
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Takasago R and D Center, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., Takasago, 676, Japan; Space Systems Project Department, Kobe Shipyard and Machinery Works, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., Kobe, 652, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujiwara, M., Takasago R and D Center, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., Takasago, 676, Japan; Sano, T., Takasago R and D Center, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., Takasago, 676, Japan; Suzuki, K., Space Systems Project Department, Kobe Shipyard and Machinery Works, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., Kobe, 652, Japan; Watanabe, S., Space Systems Project Department, Kobe Shipyard and Machinery Works, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., Kobe, 652, Japan
Abstract: Studies and fundamental tests were conducted on the heat pipe receiver. The advantages of this receiver are not only the improvement of reliability by the temperature uniformity, but the effective use of phase change thermal storage materials. The latter makes the receiver lighter and smaller. A performance analysis of the heat pipe receiver containing the thermal storage material was conducted using a computer program. Potassium was used as the working fluid of the heat pipe receiver. Results are compared with conventional receivers. The thermal storage ability of the phase change material (LiF-CaF2) was examined, and the influence of the volume change of the thermal storage material during its phase changes was also examined separately by an elementary test in a thermal storage tube. A prototype of the heat pipe receiver element was fabricated, and its performance was studied by simulating the insolation cycle with an electric heater. © 1990 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Heat Pipes--Testing; Solar Energy--Energy Storage; Heat Pipe Receiver; Phase Changes; Thermal Storage Material; Solar Power Plants

Authors: Kadi L., Bourges B., Adnot J.
Title: The input-output model for solar water heaters: Model errors and long-term performance estimate
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Centre D’Energetique de l’Ecole des Mines de Paris, Paris, 75272, France
Authors with affiliations: Kadi, L., Centre D’Energetique de l’Ecole des Mines de Paris, Paris, 75272, France; Bourges, B., Centre D’Energetique de l’Ecole des Mines de Paris, Paris, 75272, France; Adnot, J., Centre D’Energetique de l’Ecole des Mines de Paris, Paris, 75272, France
Abstract: Based on the experimentally observed linear relationship between the daily collected energy and the daily insolation, the development of a test method for the performance rating of solar water heaters is studied using both an analytical modeling of the daily performance and detailed simulation. This analysis has shown the existence of a general linear correlation between daily performance and external conditions (daily irradiation, ambient temperature, main’s water temperature, and storage initial temperature). Two approaches appeared possible for the long-term performance estimate and, for its simplicity, the statistical one was chosen for the definition of the European test method for solar water heaters, also known as the input-output test method. © 1990 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Models; Statistical Methods--Regression Analysis; European Test Method; Input-Output Model; Long-Term Performance; Model Errors; Water Heaters

Title: Heat Transfer Enhancement in a Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage Unit Using a Tube with Radial Fins
Source title: Nihon Kikai Gakkai Ronbunshu, B Hen/Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers, Part B
Authors with affiliations: Sasaguchi, K.
Abstract: Many investigations on the utilization of finned tubes have been performed to enhance heat transfer in a latent heat thermal energy storage(LHTES) systems. Detailed information on the heat transfer for the solidification process in the LHTES having tubes with longitudinal fins has been obtained experimentally and theoretically. For LHTES systems having tubes with radial fins, however, no thoretical studies to obtain the overall heat-exchanger performance appear to have been reported since usual numerical methods (e.g. a finite difference method) cannot be easily applied to the problem. In the present study. the overall performance of a LHTES system having tubes with radial fins has been obtained using a new method which the author proposed recently, and the performance has been compared with those of LHTES systems having a tube with longitudinal fins and having an unfinned tube. © 1990, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Finned Tube; Latent Heat Storage; Performance; Phase Change; Solidification
Index Keywords: Mathematical Techniques - Finite Difference Method; Tubes - Energy Storage; Heat Transfer Enhancement; Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage Unit; Radial Fins; Heat transfer

Title: High power, sealed, lead-acid battery for electric vehicles
Affiliations: Univ of Idaho, , ID, United States
Authors with affiliations: Edwards, D.B., Univ of Idaho, , ID, United States; Carter, B., Univ of Idaho, , ID, United States
Abstract: A novel, lead-acid battery has been designed specifically for an electric van application. The design consists of horizontally oriented, dual lugged plates in a sealed configuration. Thin plates are used in the design to obtain improved energy performance. High specific power is achieved with dual lugs and a grid aspect ratio that shortens conductor paths. Axial pressure applied to the face of the cell stack allows the thin plates to be used in a deep cycle application. Fifteen cells representing the design concept were fabricated by a battery manufacturer. Twelve of these cells were cycled. The cells attained approximately 600 cycles (80 percent depth of discharge, DOD, at the 2 hour rate) and had not failed before the tests were stopped.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary--Performance; Electric Van Batteries; Electric Vehicle Cell Design; Lead-Acid Battery; Propulsion Battery; Storage Battery Vehicles

Authors: Chang T.G., Valeriote E.M., Gardner C.L.
Title: A study of the low-temperature charge acceptance of 500 A h photovoltaic batteries: Laboratory and field tests
Affiliations: Cominco Ltd., Product Technology Centre, Miasissauga, Ontario, L5K 1B4, Canada; Department of National Defence, Research and Development Branch, Ottawa, Ontario, K1A 0Z4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Chang, T.G., Cominco Ltd., Product Technology Centre, Miasissauga, Ontario, L5K 1B4, Canada; Valeriote, E.M., Cominco Ltd., Product Technology Centre, Miasissauga, Ontario, L5K 1B4, Canada; Gardner, C.L., Department of National Defence, Research and Development Branch, Ottawa, Ontario, K1A 0Z4, Canada
Abstract: Lead/acid cells have been evaluated in both the laboratory and the field as energy-storage media for remote photovoltaic (PV)/battery systems at a low temperature (−40 °C). Although the cells could not be fully recharged, they could be cycled between two partially charged states with a very high charging efficiency and, thus, are suitable for the application. Currents, cell and battery voltages, and positive- and negative-plate potentials have been recorded and are discussed. It is determined that the capacity is positive-plate limited. Experimental data also suggested that some compound other than PbO2 is produced on the positive plates charged at −40 °C. This oxidation product is reduced during discharge, and may also be reduced at the negative plate during charging of the cell. © 1990, Elsevier Sequoia S.A.. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Photovoltaic Cells--Performance; Active Mass; Low Temperature Ambient; Power Sources; Electric batteries, Secondary

Authors: Kanbara T., Nishimura K., Yamamoto T., Tokuda K.
Title: Electric double-layer capacitors using porous and electrically conducting clay-carbon composites as electrodes
Affiliations: Research Laboratory of Resources Utilization, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 4259 Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama, 227, Japan; Department of Electronic Chemistry, Graduate School at Nagatsuta, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 4259 Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama, 227, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kanbara, T., Research Laboratory of Resources Utilization, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 4259 Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama, 227, Japan; Nishimura, K., Research Laboratory of Resources Utilization, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 4259 Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama, 227, Japan; Yamamoto, T., Research Laboratory of Resources Utilization, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 4259 Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama, 227, Japan; Tokuda, K., Department of Electronic Chemistry, Graduate School at Nagatsuta, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 4259 Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama, 227, Japan
Abstract: Porous and electrically conducting clay-carbon composites, which are prepared by firing mixtures of clay minerals and porous carbon powder, show large electrostatic capacitance (10 – 14 F cm−3; the value assigned to the surface area of the composite is about 6 – 7 µF cm−2) in aqueous and organic solutions. The composites have been used as polarizable electrodes of double-layer capacitors and characterization of the capacitors has been carried out. A capacitor using the composites as both the positive and negative electrodes gives a capacitance of 3.4 F (per cm3 of capacitor) at about 20 wt.% of carbon content in the composite. Electrolytic salts and solvents influence the internal electrical resistance of the cell, but scarcely affect the capacitance at room temperature. These results indicate that ions can move smoothly into micropores of the clay-carbon composites due to the wettability of the clay minerals to both the aqueous and the organic solutions employed in the present work. © 1990, Elsevier Sequoia S.A.. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Clay-Carbon Composites; Cyclic Voltammetry; Maintenance Free Power Sources; Electric batteries, Secondary

Title: Analysis of energy and momentum transport for fluid flow through a porous bed
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vafai, K., Department of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States; Sozen, M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States
Abstract: This paper presents an analysis for the forced convective flow of a gas through a packed bed of spherical solid particles, and the associated heat transport processes. Ergun's correlation was used as the vapor phase momentum equation in order to account for the inertia effects as well as the viscous effects. No local thermal equilibrium was assumed between the solid and the vapor phases. A thorough discussion of the thermal interactions between the solid and vapor phases and their effects on the fluid flow as well as the pressure and density fields is presented. The analysis shows that the local thermal equilibrium condition was very sensitive to the particle Reynolds number (Rep) and the Darcy number (Da) while thermophysical properties did not have a very significant effect on this condition. On the other hand, two-dimensional behavior of certain variables was found to be very sensitive to thermophysical parameters but insensitive to Rep and Da. © 1990 by ASME.
Author Keywords: Packed and fluidized beds; Thermal energy storage; Transient and unsteady heat transfer
Index Keywords: Equations of State; Heat Transfer; Porous Materials--Flow Problems; Beam Warming Type Implicit Method; Porous Bed Momentum Transport; Vapor Phase State Equation; Flow of Fluids

Title: Ice formation and heat transfer with water flow around isothermally cooled cylinders arranged in a line
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineeering, Shinshu University, Nagano, 380, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hirata, T., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineeering, Shinshu University, Nagano, 380, Japan; Matsui, H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineeering, Shinshu University, Nagano, 380, Japan
Abstract: The ice formation phenomenon and heat transfer around isothermally cooled cylinders that are lined up in the direction of flow in a crossflow of cold water were examined experimentally. Under the conditions of low Reynolds numbers and low cooling temperatures, the cylinders became linked by an ice layer. The amount of ice formed around the cylinders was much more than that for a single cylinder. A correlation equation was proposed for the amount of linked ice around the cooled cylinders. It was found that the local heat transfer coefficients on the linked ice surface showed an alternating decrease and increase in the flow direction. The mean value of the local Nusselt number showed the same characteristic as that on aflat plate in a turbulent flow. A dimensionless parameter that represents how efficiently the cylinders can work as a thermal energy storage system was introduced. © 1990 by ASME.
Author Keywords: Forced convection; Phase-change phenomena; Thermal energy storage
Index Keywords: Flow of Water--Heat Transfer; Heat Transfer--Cylinders; Cylinder Ice Growth; Ice Storage Efficiency; Isothermally Cooled Cylinders; Local Nusselt Number; Cylinders

Authors: Akio S., Yoshio U., Seiji O., Kazuyuki M., Atsushi T.
Title: Fundamental research on the supercooling phenomenon on heat transfer surfaces-investigation of an effect of characteristics of surface and cooling rate on a freezing temperature of supercooled water
Source title: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 Ookayama, Meguro, Tokyo, 152, Japan; Toshiba Co., Chiyoda, Tokyo, 100, Japan; Research Center, Mitsubishi Kasei Co., Yokohama, 227, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Akio, S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 Ookayama, Meguro, Tokyo, 152, Japan; Yoshio, U., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 Ookayama, Meguro, Tokyo, 152, Japan; Seiji, O., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 Ookayama, Meguro, Tokyo, 152, Japan; Kazuyuki, M., Toshiba Co., Chiyoda, Tokyo, 100, Japan; Atsushi, T., Research Center, Mitsubishi Kasei Co., Yokohama, 227, Japan
Abstract: In relation to the problem of supercooling for ice storage devices, a basic investigation is carried out by performing a number of experiments and a statistical analysis. In the experiments, the freezing temperature of supercooled water on a heat transfer surface is measured. It is observed that the characteristics of the surface and the cooling condition affect the freezing temperature. The probability of the initial appearance of ice within a unit surface area in a unit time interval is introduced as a function of the degree of supercooling and the surface property. Finally, a method to predict the most probable freezing temperature of supercooled water for a given cooling condition and surface property is proposed. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Cold Storage; Energy Storage; Ice; Refrigeration; Water--Cooling; Cold Energy Storage; Freezing Temperature; Ice Forming; Phase Change Materials; Supercooling; Heat Transfer

Title: A Nickel/Hydrogen Battery for PV Systems
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bush, D.M., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States
Abstract: The nickel/hydrogen battery was developed in the early nineteen-seventies as an energy storage subsystem for commercial communication satellites. The advantages offered by nickel/hydrogen batteries, including long life, low maintenance and high reliability, make it very attractive for terrestrial applications such as stand-alone photovoltaic systems. The major drawback to the wider use of the nickel/hydrogen battery is its high initial cost. Sandia National Laboratories has placed cost-shared contracts with Comsat Laboratories and Johnson Controls, Inc., to reduce the cost, and a battery consisting of prismatic cells in a common pressure vessel has evolved. A 7-kWh battery has been on test at Sandia since January 1988 using a flat-plate photovoltaic array for charging. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electrochemistry; Solar Power Plants; Nickel/Hydrogen Battery; Photovoltaic Systems; Remote Solar Plants; Electric Batteries

Title: Battery Configurations for Multi-Megawatt Pulse Power
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace, Seattle, WA 98124, United States
Authors with affiliations: Oman, H., Boeing Aerospace, Seattle, WA 98124, United States
Abstract: Some of the new high-energy pulse loads can be most economically powered with lead-acid batteries. For example, consider a 400 metric ton hypersonic passenger carrying airplane that could be accelerated to Mach 2.3 on a launch ramp. During the last second of a 3-g acceleration the plane’s kinetic energy increases by a 2.6 MWh increment. The 9300 MW of power required during this last second is not a desirable load for an electric-utility, but it could be supplied with lead acid batteries. A technique of analyzing batteries and controlling voltage for pulse loads is described. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Aircraft--Acceleration; Electric Batteries; Superconducting Magnets; Voltage Regulators; High-Energy Pulse Loads; Hypersonic Plane; Lead Acid Batteries; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage; Electromagnetic Launchers

Title: Bimode Uninterruptible Power Supply Compatibility in Renewable Hybrid Energy Systems
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Abacus Controls, Inc., Somerville, NJ 08876, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bower, W., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; O’Sullivan, G., Abacus Controls, Inc., Somerville, NJ 08876, United States
Abstract: Inverters installed in renewable hybrid energy systems are typically used in a stand-alone mode to supply ac power to loads from battery storage when the engine-generator is not being used. Similarities in topology and in the performance requirements of the standby uninterruptible power supply (UPS) system and the hybrid system suggest the UPS could be used in hybrid energy systems. Another alternative to inverters with add-on charging circuits or standby UPS hardware is the Bimode UPS. The bimode UPS uses common circuitry and power components for dc to ac inversion and battery charging. It also provides an automatic and nearly instantaneous ac power transfer function when the engine-generator is started or stopped. The measured operating and transfer characteristics of an Abacus Controls Inc., bimode UPS in a utility system and in a hybrid system are presented. The applicability of the bimode UPS to hybrid systems and its compatibility in a PV/engine-generator hybrid system are given. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Electric Inverters; Electric Waveforms; Solar Power Plants; Wind Power; Abacus Bimode UPS; Bimode UPS; Renewable Hybrid Energy Systems; Standby UPS; Uninterruptible Power Supply; Power Plants

Authors: Emons H.‐H., Jahn K., Naumann R.
Title: The behaviour of acetamide under ‘Galisol’ heat storage conditions
Affiliations: Mining Academy of Freiberg, Department of Chemistry, Freiberg, 9200, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Emons, H.‐H., Mining Academy of Freiberg, Department of Chemistry, Freiberg, 9200, Germany; Jahn, K., Mining Academy of Freiberg, Department of Chemistry, Freiberg, 9200, Germany; Naumann, R., Mining Academy of Freiberg, Department of Chemistry, Freiberg, 9200, Germany
Abstract: Acetamide, as a phase‐change material for energy storage, is preferable to other organic materials because of its noncorrosive behaviour and the high storage capacity (264 MJ/m3). In the paper a possibility is offered for a considerable decrease of the supercooling tendency and for the prevention of the disturbing sublimation effects, by modifying the dynamic working function principle ‘Galisol’. For this purpose we have used a heat‐transfer liquid with a partial solubility for acetamide. The study reviews solubility data, investigations of the thermal behaviour by the DTA method with large samples, cloud point investigations, equilibrium surface tensions and heat‐storage investigations of combinations of acetamide and heat‐transfer liquids. A phase diagram of the acetamide‐trichloroethylene system is presented. The heat‐storage behaviour of acetamide in its combination with trichloroethylene and a surface active material is very promising and offers a high heat‐transfer power comparable to that of inorganic salt hydrates under ‘Galisol’ conditions. Nevertheless, the fact that water‐free acetamide, which is very expensive, has to be used must be taken into consideration. Copyright © 1990 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd
Author Keywords: Acetamide; Latent heat storage; Phase diagram
Index Keywords: Materials--Phase Diagrams; Organic Compounds--Applications; Acetamide; Dynamic Working Function; Galisol; Heat Transfer Liquids; Phase Change Materials; Trichloroethylene; Heat Storage

Authors: Kanbara T., Takada K., Yamamura Y., Kondo S.
Title: Photo-rechargeable solid state battery
Affiliations: Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kanbara, T., Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., Japan; Takada, K., Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., Japan; Yamamura, Y., Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., Japan; Kondo, S., Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., Japan
Abstract: Photoelectrochemical reactions on a semiconductor electrode (P-I aSi/SiOx) with a silver ion conductive solid electrolyte (Ag6I4WO4) have been investigated and photo-sensitizing effect was observed. On the basis of this reaction, photo-battery was examined which had a capability of self-charging under the sun or fluorescence illuminations. The battery consists of two parts. One is a MIS-type photovoltaic part (ITO/P-I aSi/SiOx/Ag), and another is its energy storage part (AgxV2O5/Ag6WO4/ Agx-V2O5). Behaviors of photo reactions and the electrochemical characteristics in this system are discussed. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Photovoltaic Cells; Solar Cells; Photo-Rechargeable Battery; Photoelectrochemical System; Semiconductor Electrode; Solid State Battery; Electrolytes, Solid

Authors: Kandil M.S., Farghal S.A., Hasanin N.E.
Title: Optimum operating policy for energy storage for an interconnected power system
Source title: IEE Proceedings C: Generation Transmission and Distribution
Affiliations: Mansoura Univ, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Kandil, M.S., Mansoura Univ, Egypt; Farghal, S.A., Mansoura Univ, Egypt; Hasanin, N.E., Mansoura Univ, Egypt
Abstract: Economical operation of integrated power systems with energy storage has been attempted as a dynamic programming formulation (DPF). The dimensionality of the problem may be unacceptable especially when a large number of storage devices and interconnected power plants are used. This paper suggests another method, based on the generalised network programming formulation (GNP), to solve the problem with minimum computational requirements. The proposed method can be used to find the optimum energy interchange between multiple area systems over a period of 24 h. This method can represent the power losses between the generating units and the storage system, losses of the transmission network and the nonlinear production cost functions. The power system security is also incorporated in this method. For the sake of comparison, the problem is also solved by the DPF, and the results show that the proposed method is computationally efficient and is suitable for practical applications.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Mathematical programming, Dynamic; Cost Functions; Energy Interchange; Generalised Network Programming; Integrated Power Systems; Multiple Area Systems; Electric power systems

Title: Parametric Analysis of the Configuration of Autonomous Underwater Vehicles
Affiliations: Mechanical Technologies Section, Tecnomare SPA, 2091 San Marco, 30124 Venice, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Brighenti, A., Mechanical Technologies Section, Tecnomare SPA, 2091 San Marco, 30124 Venice, Italy
Abstract: The design of an Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) is a complex trade-off among various design variables and mission requirements. Particularly important issues are the selection of a suitable energy source and the sensitivity of vehicle dimensional characteristics to mission requirements. This paper suggests a method of comparison based on an approximate but comprehensive approach, which refers to specific parameters derivable from known designs or literature. Specific energy and energy density of candidate systems are derived with due consideration to depth resistant vessels. The impact of the energy system choice is then highlighted, going beyond the simplistic comparison of the former parameters. A design model has been developed which allows quick sensitivity analyses and mass/volume breakdowns of alternative configurations under varying mission requirements; these are exemplified in the paper with reference to a design case. The procedure allows the correct specification of power, energy, surface-handling system for more detailed comparative analyses, given a common project goal and a basis for realistic cost comparison. The results show the wide difference in energy capacity of AUV’s complying with the same mission data, but equipped with different energy systems. Another conclusion is that rechargeable electric batteries, even of high energy density, imply unacceptably heavy vehicles for ranges around 1000 km unless very low drag characteristics are achieved. Closed-cycle diesel and fuel cell systems would instead allow the AUV mass to be kept below 10t. © 1990 IEEE
Author Keywords: AUV; configuration analysis; energy systems; pressure vessels
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Electric Power Supplies to Apparatus; Mathematical Techniques--Sensitivity Analysis; Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUV); Configuration Analysis; Depth Resistant Vessels; Energy Storage Unit; Submersibles

Title: Transient Charge Decay in Lined Vessels and Silos
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jones, T.B., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States
Abstract: The hazard due to electrostatic discharges in powder or liquid storage vessels abates as charge decays to grounded conducting walls. This charge relaxation is governed by three characteristic times: τ (the relaxation time of the charged powder or liquid that governs decay of the initial volume charge within the material), τck1 (an extrinsic time constant dependent upon the vessel geometry that controls the redistribution and decay of surface charge at discontinuities), and τδ (the relaxation time associated with leakage of charge through the liner). The relative ordering of τ, τCK1, and τδ determines the time course of the charge redistribution and ultimate decay. In the case of thin insulative liners, the residence time for charge is dramatically increased, and the redistribution is seen to increase the fraction of electrostatic energy available for a discharge, leading to the possibility of greatly increased risk of ESD-induced dust or vapor ignition. In the present work, a simple model for the transient charge decay dynamics in lined vessels is presented. A simple canonical form is revealed for the extrinsic circuit time constant which may be used to estimate the time required for the decay of the charge accumulated on the liner. In addition, methods of calculating the time-dependent potential drop and capacitive energy per unit area of a vessel liner are presented. Such calculations provide the means to estimate time-dependent ignition hazard probabilities associated with energetic Lichtenberg and propagating brush discharges. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electrostatics; Relaxation Processes; Silos; Bulk Storage Operations; Electrostatic Discharge Hazards; Ignition Hazard Probabilities; Lined Vessels; Surface Charge Accumulation; Transient Charge Decay; Materials Handling

Authors: Nomura H., Fujiwara K., Kawakami H.
Title: A Power Factor Compensator Using a Force-Commutated Cycloconverter
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Kochi National College of Technology, 200-1 Monobe, Nangoku 783, Japan; Power Generation and Transformation Department, Shikoku Electric Power Company, Inc., 4-1-11 Honmachi, Kochi 780, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nomura, H., Department of Electrical Engineering, Kochi National College of Technology, 200-1 Monobe, Nangoku 783, Japan; Fujiwara, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Kochi National College of Technology, 200-1 Monobe, Nangoku 783, Japan; Kawakami, H., Power Generation and Transformation Department, Shikoku Electric Power Company, Inc., 4-1-11 Honmachi, Kochi 780, Japan
Abstract: This paper proposes a unique power factor compensator using a force-commutated cycloconverter (FCC), which constantly keeps the displacement factor of the ac system at unity regardless of the load power factor. No energy storage elements and no feedback controls are required basically in this system. An FCC with half of the load capacity can achieve a fast and complete compensation of the reactive power in the load. The extension of the basic idea leads to the development of a power factor compensator with output-voltage control, finding additional application areas of this compensator. A complete analytical description with experimental verification is presented. © 1990 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electric Converters, Static; Electric Loads; Electric Waveforms; Pulse Width Modulation; Force-Commutated Cycloconverter; Power Factor Compensator; PWM Switching Functions; Electric Power Factor

Authors: Kandil M.S., Farghal S.A., Hasanin N.E.
Title: Economic assessment of energy storage options in generation expansion planning
Source title: IEE Proceedings C: Generation Transmission and Distribution
Affiliations: Mansoura Univ, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Kandil, M.S., Mansoura Univ, Egypt; Farghal, S.A., Mansoura Univ, Egypt; Hasanin, N.E., Mansoura Univ, Egypt
Abstract: An efficient method to assess the economic feasibility of introducing a storage capacity alongside a conventional generation system is presented. The operational cost saving of the optimally operated storage capacity with the conventional system is determined using a production simulation model. This is optimised so that a generation schedule for a power system with a storage facility will accurately reflect the time dependency of storage operation policies through the charging and discharging processes. The optimum capacity of a storage facility is chosen to minimise the total revenue requirements and to satisfy the system reliability constraint for each year in the plan.
Index Keywords: Electric generators; Energy Policy--Economics; Generation Expansion Planning; Storage Capacity; Electric power systems

Authors: Narumi A., Kashiwagi T., Sakatoku Y.
Title: Cooling and Freezing Processes of Water with a supercooled Region in the Double Horizontal Concentric Cylinders
Source title: Nihon Kikai Gakkai Ronbunshu, B Hen/Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers, Part B
Authors with affiliations: Narumi, A.; Kashiwagi, T.; Sakatoku, Y.
Abstract: In this study, the cooling and freezing processes of pooled water to the point of release of supercooling have been investigated both experimentally and numerically. Pure water in double horizontal concentric cylinders is cooled, varying the cooling rate. In the experiment, the time-dependent sequential flow and temperature fields are visualized and measured using a real-time holographic interferometry technique coupled with a speckle photography one. The nurerical calculation is made under the condition of the same cooling rates as obtained in the experiment in order to verify the validity of the experimental results. It is clarified that a cooling rate influences the supercooling characteristics and its relation to the ice formation appeared just after the release of supercooling. © 1990, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.

Authors: Okada M., Gotoh K., Murakami M.
Title: Solidification of an Aqueous Solution in a Rectangular Cell with Hot and Cold Vertical Walls
Source title: Nihon Kikai Gakkai Ronbunshu, B Hen/Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers, Part B
Authors with affiliations: Okada, M.; Gotoh, K.; Murakami, M.
Abstract: The solidification process of aqueous sodium chloride solutions in a rectangular cell was studied experimentally and analytically. The solution, which was initially at 1°C and of 3, 5, or 10 wt % concentration, was solidified from one of the vertical walls of the cell. The other vertical wall was maintained at the initial temperature and the horizontal walls were thermally insulated. The temperature and concentration distributions, the shape of the mush-liquid interface, and the heat fluxes at the vertical walls were measured. In the analysis, the natural convection caused by the gradients of both the temperature and the concentration was calculated. The solid phase was assumed to be pure and the mushy region was not considered. It was clarified from the results of the experiments and the analyses that the growth of the high-concentration layer suppressed the natural convection in the liquid phase. The cold energy storage by the latent heat at the steady state was obtained as a function of two nondimensional variables. © 1990, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Aqueous Solution; Double Diffusive Convection; Phase Change; Rectangular Cell; Solidification
